item.title: List of reported UFO sightings
item.description:
List of Reported UFO Sightings 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a compilation of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), including claims of close encounters and alien abduction. It clarifies that UFOs encompass any aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified, noting that most are eventually explained as known objects or atmospheric phenomena. The article also mentions the use of the term “Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena” (UAP) to avoid associations with UFO conspiracy theories.

Antiquity 🔗

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts and records.

  • c. 1450 BC: The Tulli Papyrus describes a “star” that came down and set fire to enemies of Thutmose III during a battle in Ancient Egypt.
  • 218 BC: Mentions “ships in the sky” reported over Italia in the Roman Republic.
  • 76 BC: Describes a “spark from a star” that grew to the size of the Moon over Asia in the Roman Republic.
  • 73 BC: Plutarch’s account of a “flame-like body” resembling a wine-jar falling between Roman and Pontic armies in Phrygia.
  • AD 65: Flavius Josephus’s report of chariots “hurtling through the clouds” over Judaea before the First Jewish-Roman War.
  • AD 196: Cassius Dio’s description of a “fine rain resembling silver” falling on the Forum of Augustus in Rome.

8th century 🔗

This section includes a single entry:

  • AD c. 740: The “Air ship of Clonmacnoise” describes “ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Ireland.

16th–17th centuries 🔗

This section covers reports from the Renaissance and early modern periods.

  • 1561: The 1561 celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg describes an aerial battle with spheres, cylinders, and other objects.
  • 1566: The 1566 celestial phenomenon over Basel depicts spherical objects appearing out of the sun.
  • 1609: Mentions UFO turmoil during the Gwanghaegun period in Joseon (Korea), with multiple witnesses describing a divided “halo” or “washbowl” in the sky.

19th century 🔗

This section lists sightings from the 1800s.

  • 1883: The Bonilla observation involves astronomer José Bonilla photographing hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: The Mystery airships wave across the United States, with reports of strange airships and lights.
  • 1897: The Aurora, Texas, UFO incident, where a local correspondent reported the crash of an airship piloted by an alien.

20th century 🔗

This section is divided into two sub-sections: 1900-1949 and 1950-1974.

1900–1949 🔗

  • 1904: USS Supply sighting of three red objects in geometrical formation flight pattern in the North Pacific.
  • 1907: Mihal Grameno UFO sighting in Albania, where a shiny object was seen hovering in the air.
  • 1909: New Zealand airship sightings, with reports of moving lights and whirring sounds.
  • 1917: The Miracle of the Sun in Fátima, Portugal, interpreted by some as a mass UFO sighting.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich UFO sighting in Tibet, describing an oval object in the sky.
  • 1933: Frank Smythe UFO sighting on Mount Everest, witnessing two spots hovering in the sky.
  • 1940s: Foo fighters reported by Allied fighter pilots during World War II.
  • 1941: Cape Girardeau UFO legend, involving a crashed flying saucer and dying crew.
  • 1942: The Battle of Los Angeles, where U.S. radar stations picked up an unidentified aerial object.
  • 1942: Army Air Corps Flying School near Columbus, Missouri, control tower operator observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group returning from a bombing mission at an altitude of 14000 feet, speed “about 210 mph”: 500 yards (about 457 meters) from the starboard an object appeared which the pilot estimated at the distance viewed was “probably 5-6 feet in diameter” (1.5-1.8 meters) - “intense red or orange” color - throbbed or vibrated constantly.
  • 1945: Trinity UFO Case, involving a crashed avocado-shaped craft piloted by insectoid aliens at the site of the first atomic bomb detonation.
  • 1946: The Ghost Rockets sightings over Europe.
  • 1946: Ängelholm UFO memorial in Sweden, commemorating a 1946 UFO encounter.
  • 1947: Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting near Mount Rainier, sparking the term “flying saucers.”
  • 1947: The 1947 flying disc craze, with over 800 similar sightings reported.
  • 1947: Flight 105 UFO sighting, where a United Airlines crew witnessed nine unidentified objects.
  • 1947: Rhodes UFO photographs taken in Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 1947: The Roswell Incident, involving the “capture” of a “flying saucer.”
  • 1947: Maury Island hoax, involving claims of flying doughnut-shaped objects and threats from Men in Black.
  • 1948: The Green Fireballs sightings across the Southwestern United States.
  • 1948: Mantell UFO incident, where Captain Thomas F. Mantell died in a plane crash while pursuing a UFO.
  • 1948: Aztec, New Mexico UFO hoax, involving conmen selling “magnetic oil-detecting machines” based on a crashed spaceship story.
  • 1948: Chiles-Whitted UFO encounter, where commercial pilots reported a near-collision with a UFO near Montgomery, Alabama.
  • 1948: Gorman dogfight, where a US Air Force pilot pursued a UFO over Fargo, North Dakota.

1950–1974 🔗

  • 1950: McMinnville UFO photographs taken in Oregon.
  • 1950: Mariana UFO incident, where the manager of a baseball team filmed two UFOs over Great Falls, Montana.
  • 1951: Sioux City mystery plane incident, involving pilots and a military officer being buzzed by an unidentified plane.
  • 1951: Lubbock Lights, with lights in V-shaped formations spotted over Lubbock, Texas.
  • 1952: Wonsan-Sunchon UFO incident, where American military personnel reported seeing an orange globe-shaped light over Korea.
  • 1952: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, with sightings and radar contacts in the Washington area.
  • 1952: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting, where pilots reported eight large, round, glowing red objects over Norfolk, Virginia.
  • 1952: The Flatwoods Monster sighting in West Virginia.
  • 1954: Marius Dewilde sighting in France, where a metalworker claimed to have become a contactee.
  • 1954: Fiorentina Stadium mass sighting in Florence, Italy, where a football game was interrupted by a group of UFOs.
  • 1955: Kelly–Hopkinsville encounter, where eleven people witnessed creatures at a farmhouse in Kentucky.
  • 1956: Lakenheath-Bentwaters incident, involving radar operators detecting objects over Suffolk, England.
  • 1956: Elizabeth Klarer claimed detailed adventures with an alien race including having had an alien lover, Akon, who would have fathered her son Ayling in South Africa.
  • 1957: Gordon Cooper UFO Sightings, where one of the original Project Mercury astronauts witnessed a metallic craft without wings flying over Germany.
  • 1957: Milton Torres 1957 UFO Encounter, where a U.S. Air Force fighter pilot reports that he was ordered to intercept and fire on a UFO over East Anglia.
  • 1957: Antônio Vilas-Boas Abduction in Brazil, where a law student described being abducted by humanoid aliens.
  • 1957: Levelland UFO case, where drivers observed cigar-shaped lights above the highway in Texas.
  • 1957: Kirtland AFB UFO sighting, where tower operators reported seeing an egg shape emitting a white light in New Mexico.

item.title: List of reported UFO sightings
item.description:
List of Reported UFO Sightings 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a compilation of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), including claims of close encounters and alien abduction. It clarifies that UFOs encompass any aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified, noting that most are eventually explained as known objects or atmospheric phenomena. The article also mentions the use of the term “Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena” (UAP) to avoid associations with UFO conspiracy theories.

Antiquity 🔗

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts.

  • c. 1450 BC: The Tulli Papyrus describes an event during Thutmose III’s reign in Ancient Egypt, where a “star came down” and set fire to his adversaries.
  • 218 BC: Reports from the Roman Republic in Italia mention “phantom navy” seen shining in the sky.
  • 76 BC: An account from Asia (Roman Republic) describes a “spark” falling from a star, growing to the size of the Moon, and then transforming into a torch.
  • 73 BC: Plutarch recounts a “flame-like body” resembling a wine-jar (pithos) falling between Roman and Pontic armies in Phrygia.
  • AD 65: Flavius Josephus reports chariots “hurtling through the clouds” in Judaea before the First Jewish–Roman War.
  • AD 196: Cassius Dio describes a “fine rain resembling silver” falling from a clear sky in Rome.

8th Century 🔗

This section contains a single entry:

  • c. AD 740: The “Air ship of Clonmacnoise” is recorded in Irish annals, describing “ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Teltown and Clonmacnoise in Ireland.

16th–17th Centuries 🔗

This section lists reports from the Renaissance and early modern periods.

  • 1561: A celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg, Bavaria, is described as an aerial battle with spheres, cylinders, and other odd-shaped objects.
  • 1566: A broadsheet depicts spherical objects appearing out of the sun over Basel, Switzerland.
  • 1609: Multiple witnesses in Joseon (Korea) describe a Halo or washbowl that was divided in two in the sky.

19th Century 🔗

This section covers sightings from the 1800s.

  • 1883: Astronomer José Bonilla photographed hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun at the Zacatecas Observatory in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: Reports of “mystery airships” with bright lights and cigar-shaped bodies appear in newspapers across California and the Midwest United States.
  • 1897: S.E. Hayden reports the crash of an airship piloted by an alien in Aurora, Texas.

20th Century 🔗

This section is divided into two sub-sections: 1900-1949 and 1950-1974.

1900–1949 🔗

This section covers the early to mid-20th century.

  • 1904: Crew members aboard the USS Supply report seeing three “bright red” objects in geometrical formation flight pattern in the North Pacific.
  • 1907: Fighters of Çerçiz Topulli in Albania report seeing a shiny object suspended in the air.
  • 1909: Moving lights are reported in the sky around Otago, New Zealand, followed by more sightings across the country.
  • 1917: Thousands gather in Fátima, Portugal, and claim to see bizarre solar activity, later interpreted as a mass UFO sighting.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich reports an oval object in the sky above his caravan in Tibet.
  • 1933: Frank Smythe witnesses two spots hovering and pulsating in the sky near Mount Everest.
  • 1940s: Allied fighter pilots report colorful balls of light following their aircraft during World War II (Foo fighters).
  • 1941: A local legend emerges in Cape Girardeau, Missouri, about a crashed flying saucer and its dying crew.
  • 1942: Anti-aircraft artillery fires thousands of rounds at an unidentified aerial object over Los Angeles, California (Battle of Los Angeles).
  • 1942: Control tower operator near Flying School, Columbus, Missouri observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group reports an intense red or orange object that throbbed or vibrated constantly.
  • 1945: Conflicting accounts emerge regarding an avocado-shaped craft piloted by insectoid aliens crashing at the Trinity nuclear test site in New Mexico.
  • 1946: Thousands of UFO sightings are reported over Europe (Ghost Rockets), prompting investigations by the Swedish and Greek governments.
  • 1946: Swedish entrepreneur Gösta Carlsson commemorates a 1946 UFO encounter with a concrete monument in Ängelholm, Sweden.
  • 1947: Private pilot Kenneth Arnold reports seeing a group of reflective craft moving at high speeds near Mount Rainier, Washington, coining the term “flying saucers.”
  • 1947: Over 800 similar sightings are reported throughout 1947 after the Kenneth Arnold sighting.
  • 1947: A United Airlines crew witnesses nine unidentified objects en route from Boise, Idaho, to Pendleton, Oregon.
  • 1947: William Albert Rhodes takes photographs of a silent grey object in Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 1947: Walter Haut issues a press release announcing the “capture” of a “flying saucer” near Roswell, New Mexico, later retracted as a weather balloon.
  • 1947: Fred Crisman mails an account of flying doughnut-shaped objects and threats from Men in Black to Raymond A. Palmer (Maury Island hoax).
  • 1948: Reports of green flares streaking across the sky are investigated by the US Air Force (The Green Fireballs).
  • 1948: Captain Thomas F. Mantell dies in the crash of his P-51 Mustang fighter plane near Franklin, Kentucky, after pursuing an unidentified flying object.
  • 1948: Conmen Silas Newton and Leo Gebauer sell “magnetic oil-detecting machines” based on a story about replicated technology from a crashed spaceship (Aztec, New Mexico UFO hoax).
  • 1948: Clarence Chiles and John Whitted report that their airplane nearly collided with a UFO near Montgomery, Alabama.
  • 1948: A US Air Force pilot sights and pursues a UFO for 27 minutes over Fargo, North Dakota (Gorman dogfight).

1950–1974 🔗

This section covers the mid to late 20th century.

  • 1950: A farmer takes pictures of a purported “flying saucer” near McMinnville, Oregon.
  • 1950: The manager of Great Falls’ pro baseball team took color film of two UFOs flying over Great Falls, Montana.
  • 1951: Two pilots and a military officer passenger aboard a commercial DC-3 reported being buzzed by an unidentified straight-winged plane over Sioux City, Iowa.
  • 1951: Several lights in V-shaped formations were repeatedly spotted flying over the city of Lubbock, Texas.
  • 1952: Four American military personnel aboard two different B-29 bombers reported seeing an orange globe-shaped light over two different cities in northern Korea.
  • 1952: A series of sightings accompanied radar contacts in the Washington, D.C. area.
  • 1952: William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, pilots of a DC-4 airliner of Pan American Airways, radioed the Norfolk civil aviation authority to report eight large, round, glowing red objects.
  • 1952: Three local boys followed a bright object into the forest to what they believed was a UFO landing in Flatwoods, West Virginia.
  • 1954: French metalworker Marius Dewilde claimed to have become a contactee in Quarouble, France.
  • 1954: A football game between Fiorentina and Pistoiese was under way at the Stadio Artemio Franchi in Florence when a group of UFOs traveling at high speed abruptly stopped over the stadium.
  • 1955: Eleven people witnessed creatures in the night at a rural farmhouse near Hopkinsville, Kentucky.
  • 1956: United States Air Force (USAF) and Royal Air Force (RAF) radar operators detected up to 15 objects over Suffolk, England.
  • 1956: Elizabeth Klarer claimed detailed adventures with an alien race including having had an alien lover, Akon, who would have fathered her son Ayling in Drakens

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UFO_sightings

item.title: UFO (British TV series)
item.description:
UFO (British TV series) 🔗

A British science fiction television series that aired from 1970 to 1971, focusing on Earth’s defense against an alien invasion in the then-future of 1980.

Premise 🔗

In 1980, Earth is under threat from aliens from a dying planet who are abducting humans for their organs. SHADO (Supreme Headquarters Alien Defence Organisation), a secret international military agency operating under the guise of a movie studio, is formed to defend Earth. SHADO utilizes advanced technology, including a space intruder detection satellite (SID), lunar interceptors, a submarine/aircraft called Skydiver, and ground-based SHADO Mobiles. The aliens are humanoid, requiring a green oxygenated liquid and special contact lenses. Their UFOs can travel faster than light but have limited time in Earth’s atmosphere.

Cast and characters 🔗

The series features a large ensemble cast with frequent changes. Ed Bishop as Commander Ed Straker is the only actor to appear in every episode.

Main characters 🔗

  • Commander Edward Straker (Ed Bishop): The head of SHADO, posing as the head of Harlington-Straker Film Studios.
  • Colonel Paul Foster (Michael Billington): A former test pilot recruited into SHADO.
  • Lieutenant Gay Ellis (Gabrielle Drake): Moonbase commander.
  • Colonel Alec Freeman (George Sewell): SHADO’s second-in-command.
  • General James Henderson (Grant Taylor): Straker’s superior and president of the International Astrophysical Commission.
  • Colonel Virginia Lake (Wanda Ventham): A SHADO operative who later becomes first officer.
  • Captain Peter Carlin (Peter Gordeno): First commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Nina Barry (Dolores Mantez): Moonbase operative.
  • Captain Lew Waterman (Gary Myers): Second commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Keith Ford (Keith Alexander): Communications officer.
  • Lieutenant Ayshea Johnson (Ayshea Brough): SHADO headquarters officer.
  • Doctor Douglas Jackson (Vladek Sheybal): SHADO psychiatrist and science officer.
  • Lieutenant Joan Harrington (Antonia Ellis): Moonbase operative.
  • Miss Ealand (Norma Ronald): Straker’s secretary.
  • Lieutenant Mark Bradley (Harry Baird): Interceptor pilot.

Minor characters 🔗

Shakira Baksh (later Michael Caine’s wife) played Joanna, a Moonbase operative. Steven Berkoff played Interceptor pilot Steve Minto, and Georgina Moon played Lieutenant Sylvia Howell.

Episodes 🔗

The 26 episodes were broadcast in a non-chronological order by ITV. The list provides the original ATV (Midlands) broadcast order, along with director, writer, original air date, and production code. Episode titles include “Identified,” “Exposed,” “The Cat with Ten Lives,” “Conflict,” “A Question of Priorities,” and “The Long Sleep.”

Alternative viewing orders 🔗

Different viewing orders exist, including production order, ATV broadcast order, and recommended orders by UFO Series, Fanderson, and ITC. A table compares these different orders.

Production 🔗

Lew Grade approached Gerry Anderson to create a live-action TV series, resulting in UFO. The series was influenced by UFO sightings and Christiaan Barnard’s transplant operations. Sylvia Anderson designed the costumes, including the purple wigs for female Moonbase staff. The Harlington-Straker Studio was the actual studio where the series was filmed.

Filming 🔗

Filming began in April 1969 at MGM-British Studios, then moved to Pinewood Studios in June 1970. George Sewell and Gabrielle Drake left after the studio change. Harry Baird and Peter Gordeno also left the series.

Costumes 🔗

Female Moonbase personnel wore purple wigs, silver catsuits, and heavy eye makeup for a futuristic look. Ed Bishop initially bleached his hair, then wore a white wig. Other male characters also wore wigs. Only two alien suits were made.

Special effects 🔗

Derek Meddings supervised the special effects, using techniques like double-walled visors and underwater effects.

Vehicle design 🔗

Derek Meddings and Mike Trim designed the vehicles. The gull-winged cars were originally built for Doppelgänger. The blue SHADO Jeeps were built on Mini Moke chassis. Few original props and miniatures have survived.

Broadcast 🔗

Broadcasters were unsure if UFO was for adults or children. In the UK, episodes were shown in the late afternoon and Saturday mornings.

Reception 🔗

Reviews of UFO are mixed. Some praise the visuals, music, and costumes, while others criticize the writing and pacing. Some reviews note the series’ mix of adult themes and science fiction elements.

Aborted second series 🔗

ITC commissioned a second series, UFO 2, set entirely on the Moon. However, when ratings dropped, ITC cancelled the plans. Gerry Anderson then created Space: 1999 from the pre-production work.

Merchandise 🔗

The series generated a range of toys, including Dinky die-cast vehicles.

Compilation films 🔗

Several episodes were compiled into films, including Invasion: UFO. Italian producers also created compilation films with mixed reviews.

Home media 🔗

Channel 5 and ITC released VHS collections. The complete series was released on DVD in 2002.

Proposed feature film 🔗

In 2009, a feature film adaptation was announced, but it did not enter production.

In other media 🔗

Stories set in the UFO universe have appeared in novels, comics, and video games. Julian Gollop cited UFO as an influence for UFO: Enemy Unknown. Yoshiyuki Sadamoto drew inspiration from UFO for character designs in Neon Genesis Evangelion.

Translations 🔗

The series has been translated into French, German, Japanese, Italian, Spanish, and Brazilian Portuguese.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(British_TV_series)

item.title: Fictional Creatures in a Fictional Universe
item.description:
Fictional Creatures in a Fictional Universe 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a comprehensive list of fictional creatures and aliens from the Doctor Who universe, a long-running BBC science fiction television series. It notes the show’s initial run from 1963 to 1989, its revival in 2005, and the central character, the Doctor, an extraterrestrial who travels through time and space in the TARDIS. The list excludes specific characters and focuses on alien races and fictional creatures, including those appearing in spin-off series like The Sarah Jane Adventures, Torchwood, and Class, but excludes antagonists original to those series.

A 🔗

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “A.”

Abzorbaloff 🔗

The Abzorbaloff is an alien creature from the planet Clom, known for absorbing living beings into its body through touch. It appeared in the episode “Love & Monsters” (2006). In this episode, an Abzorbalovian disguised as “Victor Kennedy” infiltrated a group called L.I.N.D.A. to gain knowledge from the Doctor. The Abzorbaloff was ultimately defeated when Elton Pope broke its cane, causing the Earth to absorb it. The creature was created by William Grantham, a nine-year-old who won a Blue Peter contest. Comedian Peter Kay portrayed the Abzorbaloff on-screen. A short sequel, “The Genuine Article,” features the Abzorbaloff’s father seeking revenge, directed and animated by Grantham.

Adipose 🔗

The Adipose are aliens composed of living fat, featured in the episode “Partners in Crime” (2008). Originating from the lost breeding world Adipose 3, they rely on a drug formulated by “Miss Foster” to convert human fat into Adipose children through parthenogenesis. This process, if accelerated, can be fatal to the host. The Adipose abandoned Foster to hide their illegal activities. In an alternate timeline in “Turn Left” (2008), the Adipose incident in America resulted in over 60 million deaths. The Adipose were inspired by a plush toy owned by writer Russell T Davies.

Aggedor 🔗

Aggedor is the Sacred Royal Beast of the planet Peladon, first appearing in The Curse of Peladon (1972). The creature is a large, hairy beast with a single horn, hunted to near extinction. In the story, Peladon’s High Priest, Hepesh, used a captured Aggedor to generate superstition and prevent Peladon from joining the Galactic Federation. Actor Nick Hobbs portrayed Aggedor in both The Curse of Peladon and The Monster of Peladon (1974). The audio story The Bride of Peladon reveals Aggedor had a child, which later gave birth to many baby Aggedors.

Axons 🔗

The Axons are golden-skinned humanoids who attempt to take over Earth by distributing Axonite, pieces of the single creature Axos, in The Claws of Axos (1971). They pose as a friendly family but can shapeshift into monstrous forms. The Axons are later trapped in a time loop alongside Axos. Actors Bernard Holley, Patricia Gordino, John Hicks, and Debbie Lee London portrayed the Axons. The Axons reappeared in the 2010 comic strip “The Golden Ones,” where they attempted to free Axos and rampage across Tokyo until defeated by the Eleventh Doctor.

B 🔗

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “B.”

Bandril 🔗

The Bandrils are a reptilian species encountered in the serial Timelash (1985). A villain known as the Borad seeks to start a war between them and the people of Karfel. The Sixth Doctor is able to thwart the plot. Actor Martin Gower portrayed the Bandril Ambassador.

Boneless 🔗

The Boneless are creatures from a two-dimensional universe, seen in “Flatline” (2014). They harness energy from the TARDIS to infiltrate the Doctor’s universe. Clara Oswald and Rigsy trick the Boneless into restoring the TARDIS, allowing the Doctor to send them back to their home dimension. The Boneless later appeared in the comic story The Fourth Wall, where they use comic books to trap readers until the Twelfth Doctor defeats them.

C 🔗

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “C.”

Carrionite 🔗

The Carrionites are creatures from “The Dark Times,” who fought against the Time Lords. They appear in “The Shakespeare Code” (2007). Three Carrionites, Bloodtide, Doomfinger, and Lilith, attempt to release their species from a prison using the power of words and witchcraft, manipulating William Shakespeare. The Tenth Doctor and Shakespeare reverse the process, trapping the Carrionites back into their prison. They reappeared in the audio drama The Carrionite Curse, facing the Sixth Doctor.

Catkind 🔗

The Catkind are felines evolved into humanoids, first seen in “New Earth” (2006). They have hair-covered bodies, feline facial features, and retractable claws. In “New Earth,” the Sisters of Plenitude, a group of Catkind, run a hospital where they test on human subjects. The Tenth Doctor develops a cure, and the Sisters are arrested. In “Gridlock” (2007), a Cat Person, Thomas Kincade Brannigan, has a human wife and kittens. Novice Hame, a surviving Sister of Plentitude, aids the Tenth Doctor. Actress Anna Hope portrayed Hame. A short scene, “The Secret of Novice Hame,” depicts Hame on her deathbed.

Chameleons 🔗

Chameleons are aliens with no features who can take on the appearance of individual humans, seen in The Faceless Ones (1967). They lost their identities in an explosion and kidnap humans to adopt their identities. The Second Doctor convinces them to seek another solution. The Chameleons later re-appeared in the spin-off book Short Trips and Side Steps, where they infiltrate the planet Krennos until the Sixth Doctor stops them.

Cheetah People 🔗

Cheetah People are feline humanoids resembling cheetahs who enjoy hunting humans, encountered in Survival (1989). They were once humanoids who mutated after bonding with cat-like creatures known as Kitlings. The Master, stranded on their planet, attempts to use them to escape. The Seventh Doctor stops the Master, leaving him stranded. Writer Rona Munro was disappointed with the final version of the Cheetah People.

Chronovores 🔗

Chronovores are glowing white creatures that live outside time, one of whom, Kronos, is encountered in The Time Monster (1972). The Master attempts to use Kronos, but the Third Doctor thwarts his plans. The Chronovores re-appeared in the book The Quantum Archangel, where Kronos sought revenge against the Master and sacrificed itself to stop the Chronovores from feeding on Earth.

Chuldur 🔗

The Chuldur are a race of shape shifting bird-like aliens who appeared in the Fifteenth Doctor story “Rogue” (2024). The Chuldur appeared in 1813, where they infiltrated a ball in order to “cosplay” as those from the nineteenth century. The Fifteenth Doctor is able to trap the Chuldur within a sealing device, which banished them to another dimension, but at the sacrifice of Rogue, a bounty hunter the Doctor had fallen in love with.

Cryons 🔗

Cryons are an all-female species of alien first seen in Attack of the Cybermen (1985). They cannot exist at temperatures above zero degrees. The Cryons lived on Telos until the Cybermen took control, and allied with the mercenary Lytton to defeat them. The Cryons were later destroyed by an attack by the Cybermen. Director Matthew Robinson elected to make the Cryons an all-female race.

Cyberman 🔗

The Cybermen are humanoids originating on Earth’s twin planet Mondas, first seen in The Tenth Planet (1966). They replace organic body parts with artificial ones, becoming coldly logical. The Cyberman concept was created by Dr. Kit Pedler and Gerry Davis in 1966. The Cybermen were portrayed by tall actors. In the two-part story “Rise of the Cybermen” and “The Age of Steel” (2006), the Cybermen originate on a parallel-universe version of Earth, created by John Lumic. The Cybermen have several variants, such as the Cybermat and the Cybershades.

D 🔗

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “D.”

Dæmon 🔗

A race of humanoids from the planet Dæmos, seen in The Dæmons (1971). They resemble demons and have great power. The Master attempts to obtain the power of a Dæmon named Azal, but Jo Grant sacrifices herself, confusing Azal and reversing his powers, killing him. Another Dæmon later appeared in the unofficial 2004 BBV film Dæmos Rising, and the spin-off novel Child of Time.

UFO Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This Wikipedia article discusses various conspiracy theories surrounding Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), particularly the idea that governments, especially the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology. It also explores the evolution of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview 🔗

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: governments concealing evidence of extraterrestrial involvement. It traces the origins of these theories back to pulp science fiction and the “lost continent” myths. The section highlights Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting as a catalyst for widespread UFO reports and the subsequent speculation about secret technologies. Donald Keyhoe is identified as a key figure in popularizing the idea of a government cover-up. The emergence of the “Men in Black” concept is also mentioned. The section further explains how UFO conspiracy theories became more prevalent after the Kennedy assassination, linking his death to aliens. The term “Cosmic Watergate” is introduced to describe the alleged cover-up. The section also mentions the influence of films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind and the introduction of the Roswell incident to a mass audience. The shift from benevolent “space brothers” to malevolent aliens in the 1980s is discussed, along with the connection of UFO cover-ups to alien abductions, cattle mutilations, and the JFK assassination. The section concludes by noting the resurgence of interest in UFO conspiracy theories in the 1990s and 2017 with Leslie Kean’s stories of a Pentagon UFO program.

Mainstream Views 🔗

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It mentions government investigations like Project Blue Book and Project Condign, as well as studies by organizations and individuals. The section emphasizes that these investigations have not confirmed claims of extraterrestrial intelligence or other unconventional explanations for UFOs. It highlights that scientists and skeptical organizations offer prosaic explanations, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes. The section also notes that beliefs surrounding UFOs have inspired new religions and that social scientists view the ongoing interest in UFOs as a form of modern folklore and mythology. Benjamin Radford’s argument against the feasibility of a long-term, international UFO cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents 🔗

This section identifies key individuals who have promoted UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent figures from the 1950s to the 1970s. The section also notes that some proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, had mental health issues, while others, like Gray Barker, Carl Allen, Richard Doty, Bill Moore, and Ray Santelli, confessed to hoaxes or lies. The violent ends of Morris Jessup, James E. McDonald, and Bill Cooper are also mentioned. The section lists individuals who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed, including Barry Goldwater, Lord Hill-Norton, Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, Gordon Cooper, and Edgar Mitchell. 21st-century proponents such as Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction 🔗

This section explores the presence of UFO conspiracy theories in popular culture. It mentions films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned as featuring government efforts to conceal information about extraterrestrial beings. John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, where he confesses to a UFO cover-up, is also noted. The Sidney Sheldon novel The Doomsday Conspiracy and the American Horror Story: Double Feature series are also mentioned.

In Religion 🔗

This section examines the connection between UFO conspiracy theories and new religious movements. It identifies the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate as examples of religious groups that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology’s view of inhabited planets is also mentioned. Theosophists and occultists, such as Meade Layne, George Adamski, George Hunt Williamson, and Guy Warren Ballard, are discussed as early proponents of extraterrestrial contact. The Nation of Islam’s concept of The Mother Plane is also explored. The section also mentions UFO religions such as Unarius, the Aetherius Society, Raëlism, and the Order of the Solar Temple. The Heaven’s Gate mass suicide, linked to the Hale-Bopp comet, is also discussed.

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine 🔗

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his hiring of Kenneth Arnold to investigate the Maury Island incident and the magazine’s claims of a cover-up.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” 🔗

This subsection discusses Richard Shaver’s stories of a secret underground race and their spaceships, published in Amazing Stories. It mentions Palmer’s argument that governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze 🔗

This subsection covers Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent “flying disc craze.” It mentions the Roswell incident and Palmer’s investigation of the Maury Island report.

Aftermath 🔗

This subsection discusses the aftermath of the 1947 flying disc craze, including Palmer’s linking of the sightings to Shaver’s claims and Shaver’s prediction that the truth about the discs would remain secret. It also mentions Palmer’s later linking of UFOs to the JFK assassination and Watergate.

National Coverage in the 1950s 🔗

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax 🔗

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s claims of recovered alien bodies from crashed flying saucers and the subsequent exposure of the hoax by True magazine.

Air Force Accounts 🔗

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings, including General John Samford’s press conference and the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education. It also mentions Al Chop’s role as a press officer for Project Bluebook and the film Unidentified Flying Objects: The True Story of Flying Saucers.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax 🔗

This subsection discusses the Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, involving Carl Meredith Allen’s letters and annotations.

‘Men in Black’ Legends 🔗

This subsection explores the origin of the “Men in Black” concept in Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers.

This section discusses the increasing government skepticism during the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Perspectives on the Alien Abduction Phenomenon 🔗

This explores various explanations for claims of alien abduction and examination by otherworldly beings. Perspectives range from complete disbelief to the acceptance of these claims as objective reality. Some researchers, like Harvard psychiatrist John E. Mack, acknowledge an “authentic mystery” surrounding the phenomenon, urging consideration of all associated aspects, including missing time, UFO sightings, and occurrences in children. The mainstream scientific view leans towards a psychosocial explanation rooted in human psychology, neurology, and culture, while others, including conspiracy theorists and ufologists, believe in literal extraterrestrial abductions. Authors like Jacques Vallée and John E. Mack suggest the need to re-evaluate our understanding of reality to comprehend the phenomenon fully.

Extraterrestrial Hypothesis 🔗

This section presents the idea that alien abduction is a real phenomenon where extraterrestrial beings abduct humans for study or experimentation. The elusiveness of these beings is attributed to their advanced technology. The hypothesis lacks widespread support among mainstream scientists due to the absence of physical evidence and the contradictory nature of abduction accounts.

Literary Perspectives 🔗

This section explores the appeal of alien abduction accounts from a literary standpoint. Terry Matheson suggests that these tales are captivating due to their depiction of human powerlessness. The section contrasts the temporary fear experienced from ghost stories with the inescapable nature of alien abductions, which the abduction myth suggests cannot be avoided.

Skeptical Perspectives 🔗

This section outlines skeptical explanations for alien abduction reports, focusing on psychological processes rather than extraterrestrial beings. Skeptics critically examine claims for evidence of hoaxes or influence from popular culture. Brian Dunning notes psychological explanations such as hallucination, temporary schizophrenia, epileptic seizures, and parasomnia (including hypnagogic states, night terrors, and sleep paralysis). Sleep paralysis, often accompanied by hallucinations, is presented as a potential explanation, although individuals experiencing it do not typically interpret it as alien encounters.

Hoax 🔗

This section addresses the possibility of alien abduction claims being hoaxes, motivated by financial gain or attention. While some skeptics believe abductees are lying, it is acknowledged that most abductees genuinely believe in their experiences, making simple fabrication an insufficient explanation for the majority of claims.

Psychopathology 🔗

This section discusses the view, once common but now largely unsupported by scientists, that those claiming alien abduction are mentally ill. Studies have found that alleged abductees are generally no more likely to suffer from psychopathologies than the general population. However, abductees often score higher in tests measuring hypnotic suggestibility, absorption, magical ideation, and dissociative experiences.

False Memory Hypothesis 🔗

This section presents the false memory hypothesis, a widely accepted theory in the scientific community, which explains how psychologically healthy individuals may develop and maintain a belief in alien abduction through psychological processes.

Sleep Paralysis 🔗

This section details how sleep paralysis, often accompanied by feelings of chest pressure and hypnopompic hallucinations (such as flying, lights, presences, and figures), can contribute to abduction experiences. Cultural beliefs strongly influence the content of these hallucinations. Carl Sagan’s comparison of alien abduction experiences to historical tales of demon abduction is highlighted.

Lucid Dreams 🔗

This section explores the connection between lucid dreams and alien abduction experiences. Research from the Phase Research Center suggests that experiences of close encounters with UFOs and extraterrestrials can be products of the human mind during lucid dreaming. A 2021 study found that a significant percentage of volunteers could emulate alien encounters via lucid dreams, with some experiencing sleep paralysis and fear similar to “real” abduction stories.

Hypnosis 🔗

This section discusses the use of hypnosis in recovering memories of “missing time” in abduction cases, starting with the Betty and Barney Hill abduction. It notes that individuals interested in UFOs may seek therapists with similar beliefs, potentially leading to the creation of false memories under hypnosis due to increased suggestibility. Thomas Bullard notes that hypnotized subjects are more likely to confabulate or be open to memory implantation. Budd Hopkins’ counterargument, citing the Hill case, is also presented. Skeptics Robert Sheaffer and Phillip J. Klass suggest that individual abduction researchers influence the characteristics of narratives retrieved during hypnotic recall.

Cultural Impact 🔗

This section examines the influence of cultural factors on abduction claims. Skeptics argue that variations in abduction details across cultures support a psycho-social hypothesis. The section notes that abduction accounts may be influenced by science fiction, citing the resemblance between the Betty and Barney Hill case and media they had recently consumed. It also mentions how abduction claims have changed over time to align with scientific discoveries about the solar system. Robert Sheaffer highlights differences in the types of aliens reported in different countries and similarities between aliens in early science fiction films and abduction reports.

Maintenance of Abduction Memories 🔗

This section discusses how abductees maintain their beliefs, even when faced with disbelief. Many seek support groups where they find validation from others with similar experiences, reinforcing the accuracy of their abduction memories.

Drug-Induced Hallucinations 🔗

This section explores the possibility that some alleged abductions are drug-induced hallucinations. It mentions Terence McKenna’s experiences with “Machine Elves” while using DMT and Rick Strassman’s research at the University of New Mexico, which found that a significant percentage of volunteers injected with high doses of DMT had experiences similar to purported alien abductions.

Parallels with Other Phenomena 🔗

This section draws parallels between the abduction phenomenon and other unusual events, such as witchcraft claims. Robert Sheaffer notes similarities in imagery, uncovered memories, and sex, suggesting a common underlying psychopathology.

This section also notes Gwen Dean’s presentation of 44 parallels between alien abduction and satanic ritual abuse (SRA) at a 1992 MIT conference. Both phenomena emerged in the late 1970s and early 1980s, often use hypnosis, and feature similar elements such as familial involvement, generational occurrences, examination tables/altars, focus on genitals/sexuality/breeding, altered states of consciousness, and “missing time.”

Abductors as Demonic Manifestations 🔗

This section presents the view that abduction experiences share similarities with pre-20th century accounts of demonic manifestations. Writers have noted numerous similarities. Fr. Seraphim Rose, an Orthodox monk, dedicates a chapter in his book Orthodoxy and the Religion of the Future to UFOs and abductions, concluding that they are manifestations of the demonic.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspectives_on_the_abduction_phenomenon

item.title: UFO sightings in Africa
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Africa 🔗

This is a compilation of reported Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) sightings across various countries in Africa.

Algeria 🔗

This section details alleged UFO sightings during the Algerian War (1954–1962) around conflict zones. A specific incident from March 1958 is highlighted, where a soldier reported witnessing a large, elliptical craft with green lights and a beam of light. In March 1975, multiple UFOs were reportedly observed by several people across the country.

Benin 🔗

This section simply states that reports were received from Benin, but does not provide any specific details.

Botswana 🔗

This section lists two specific UFO sightings in Botswana: one in the Okavango Delta on June 25, 2016, and another in Gaberone on May 14, 2008.

Morocco 🔗

This section describes three UFO sightings in July 1952. The first involved two elongated flying saucers spotted by policemen above Had Kourt. The second involved inhabitants of Fedala spotting a blue-green, ball-shaped object. The third involved a couple observing another flying saucer.

Senegal 🔗

This section details a UFO sighting above Dakar on July 3, 1952. The object was described as a flat, tapered saucer surrounded by flames, moving at high speed.

South Africa 🔗

This section refers to a main article dedicated to UFO sightings in South Africa.

Sudan 🔗

This section describes a UFO sighting in January 2018 over Khartoum. The Sudanese military identified it as a potential satellite, possibly the failed US satellite Zuma, but admitted they could not clearly identify the object.

Tunisia 🔗

This section recounts a UFO sighting in July 1969, where many observers, including US embassy officials, reported a large, two-part green-blue object in the sky of Tunis. The object reportedly exploded, forming a greenish circular cloud.

Zimbabwe 🔗

This section focuses on the Ruwa UFO incident on September 14, 1994, where 62 children from a school in Ruwa witnessed the landing of a large spaceship and smaller ones. The children described the aliens as having large heads, slits for mouths, and dark suits. American psychiatrist John E. Mack interviewed the children and concluded that the incident was likely not mass hysteria, as the children gave consistent accounts.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists two books related to UFOs in Africa:

  • UFOs Over Africa by Cynthia Hind
  • The ufo issue in Central Africa (Gabon, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo) by Jann Halexander

References 🔗

This section provides a list of citations used as sources for the information presented in the article.

External links 🔗

This section contains a link to a YouTube video titled “UFO Sightings in Algeria 22/01/2008” showing a UFO sighting in Taguercift village, Algeria.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Africa

item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) 🔗

This is a comprehensive description of the Wikipedia article for the American television series Resident Alien.

Overview 🔗

This section provides a brief introduction to the television series Resident Alien. It establishes the show’s genre as a science fiction mystery comedy-drama and identifies Chris Sheridan as the creator. It also mentions that the show is based on the comic book series of the same name by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse. The premiere date of the first season on Syfy is noted, along with the star, Alan Tudyk. The renewals for subsequent seasons, including the move to USA Network for the fourth season, are also mentioned.

Premise 🔗

This section outlines the central plot of the series. An alien arrives on Earth with the mission to wipe out humanity. After crashing in Colorado, the alien assumes the identity of a doctor named Harry Vanderspeigle. As he lives among humans, he begins to question his mission. A young boy, Max Hawthorne, can see through his disguise. The alien grapples with his mission and ultimately defends humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and characters 🔗

This section details the main and recurring cast members and their respective characters.

Main 🔗

  • Alan Tudyk plays the alien, who takes on the identity of Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle. He is sent to Earth to destroy humanity but develops compassion. Tudyk also portrays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle.
  • Sara Tomko plays Asta Twelvetrees, the assistant to the town doctor and a member of the Ute tribe. She is the first person after Max to discover Harry’s true identity.
  • Corey Reynolds plays Sheriff Mike Thompson, the town’s sheriff, who is dealing with past trauma.
  • Alice Wetterlund plays D’arcy Bloom, the owner of the town pub and Asta’s best friend. She discovers Harry’s true identity after learning that the real Harry killed Sam Hodges.
  • Levi Fiehler plays Ben Hawthorne, the town’s mayor, who has a history of alien abductions.
  • Judah Prehn plays Max Hawthorne, Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen plays Deputy Liv Baker, the town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrials.

Recurring 🔗

This section lists actors and the recurring characters they portray, including:

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest 🔗

This section lists actors and the guest characters they portray, including:

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes 🔗

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, broken down by season.

Series overview 🔗

This subsection presents a table summarizing the number of episodes per season, the original release dates, and the network on which each season aired.

Season 1 (2021) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 10 episodes of the first season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Season 2 (2022) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 16 episodes of the second season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot. The season is split into two parts, each with eight episodes.

Season 3 (2024) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 8 episodes of the third season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Production 🔗

This section details the development, casting, and filming aspects of the series.

Development 🔗

This subsection explains the origins of the series, stating that Chris Sheridan was inspired by the novels and comic book series of the same name. It also mentions Sheridan’s personal experience with a UFO sighting as inspiration. The initial pilot order by Syfy, along with the involvement of Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television, is mentioned. The series order, production location in Vancouver, and David Dobkin’s role as director and executive producer are also noted.

Casting 🔗

This subsection lists the initial casting announcements, including Alan Tudyk as the lead, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. It also mentions the casting of Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, Alex Barima, and Elizabeth Bowen in recurring roles.

Filming 🔗

This subsection provides information on the filming locations and timelines for each season. Principal photography for the first season took place in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. Filming details for the second and third seasons are also included.

Release 🔗

This section details the release dates of the series. Syfy initially announced a summer 2020 premiere, which was later moved to January 2021. International premiere dates in Canada and the United Kingdom are also mentioned.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical response 🔗

This subsection presents the review scores from Rotten Tomatoes and Metacritic for the first and second seasons, highlighting the positive critical reception.

Ratings 🔗

This subsection provides a table with viewership and ratings per episode for the first season.

Accolades 🔗

This section lists the awards and nominations received by the series, including those from the Saturn Awards, Critics Choice Super Awards, Dragon Awards, and Hollywood Critics Association Television Awards.

Notes 🔗

This section provides clarifying information and context for certain details within the article, such as character name spellings, guest star credits, and rating metrics.

References 🔗

This section contains a list of citations used throughout the article, providing sources for the information presented.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to the official website and the IMDb page for the series.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Futurama
item.description:
Futurama 🔗

A 1999 American animated science fiction sitcom created by Matt Groening.

Genre 🔗

Animated sitcom, science fiction, and satire.

Created by 🔗

Matt Groening.

Developed by 🔗

Matt Groening and David X. Cohen.

Voices of 🔗

Billy West, Katey Sagal, John DiMaggio, Tress MacNeille, Maurice LaMarche, Phil LaMarr, Lauren Tom, and David Herman.

Opening theme 🔗

“Theme from Futurama” composed by Christopher Tyng.

Country of origin 🔗

United States.

Original language 🔗

English.

Number of seasons 🔗

9

Number of episodes 🔗

160

Executive producers 🔗

Matt Groening, David X. Cohen, Ken Keeler, and Claudia Katz.

Producers 🔗

Lew Morton, J. Stewart Burns, Patric M. Verrone, Bill Odenkirk, Eric Kaplan, Michael Rowe, Brian J. Cowan, Jason Grode, Jane O’Brien, and Lee Supercinski.

Editors 🔗

Paul D. Calder, Danik Thomas, and Chris Vallance.

Production companies 🔗

The Curiosity Company, 20th Century Fox Television (seasons 1–7), and 20th Television Animation (season 8–present).

Original release 🔗

  • Fox: March 28, 1999 – August 10, 2003
  • Comedy Central: March 23, 2008 – September 4, 2013
  • Hulu: July 24, 2023 – present

Premise 🔗

The series follows Philip J. Fry, a pizza delivery boy who is cryogenically preserved for 1,000 years and revived on December 31, 2999. Fry finds work at the interplanetary delivery company Planet Express, working alongside the one-eyed mutant Leela and the robot Bender. Groening envisioned the series in the mid-1990s while working on The Simpsons, and brought David X. Cohen aboard to develop storylines and characters.

Characters 🔗

The plot revolves around the Planet Express interplanetary delivery company and its employees. Episodes usually feature the central trio of Fry, Leela, and Bender, though occasional storylines center on the other main characters.

  • Philip J. Fry: Voiced by Billy West, Fry is an immature, slovenly, yet good-hearted pizza delivery boy who is cryogenically frozen for 1,000 years.
  • Turanga Leela: Voiced by Katey Sagal, Leela is the competent, one-eyed captain of the Planet Express Ship.
  • Bender Bending Rodriguez: Voiced by John DiMaggio, Bender is a foul-mouthed, heavy-drinking, cigar-smoking, kleptomaniacal, misanthropic, egocentric, ill-tempered robot.
  • Professor Hubert J. Farnsworth: Voiced by Billy West, Professor Farnsworth is Fry’s distant nephew and the founder of Planet Express Inc.
  • Hermes Conrad: Voiced by Phil LaMarr, Hermes is the Jamaican accountant of Planet Express.
  • Dr. John A. Zoidberg: Voiced by Billy West, Zoidberg is a Decapodian and the neurotic staff physician of Planet Express.
  • Amy Wong: Voiced by Lauren Tom, Amy is an incredibly rich, blunt, ditzy, and accident-prone intern at Planet Express.

Setting 🔗

Futurama is set in New New York at the turn of the 31st century. The city of New New York has been built over the ruins of present-day New York City, which has become a catacomb-like space that acts as New New York’s sewer, referred to as “Old New York”. Parts of the sewers are inhabited by mutants. Various devices and architecture are similar to the Populuxe style. Global warming, inflexible bureaucracy, and substance abuse are a few of the subjects given a 31st-century exaggeration.

Episodes 🔗

The list of episodes follows the season box sets, which feature the episodes in the original production season order, ignoring the order of broadcast. The Hulu revival has alternatively been titled the eighth and ninth seasons (production), and the eleventh and twelfth seasons (broadcast). The tenth and eleventh production seasons will also be considered as Futurama’s thirteenth and fourteenth broadcast seasons.

Season Episodes Originally released Network
1 13 March 28, 1999 – November 14, 1999 Fox
2 19 November 21, 1999 – December 3, 2000 Fox
3 22 January 21, 2001 – December 8, 2002 Fox
4 18 February 10, 2002 – August 10, 2003 Fox
5 16 March 23, 2008 – August 30, 2009 Comedy Central
6 26 June 24, 2010 – September 8, 2011 Comedy Central
7 26 June 20, 2012 – September 4, 2013 Comedy Central
8 10 July 24, 2023 – September 25, 2023 Hulu
9 10 July 29, 2024 – September 30, 2024 Hulu

Production 🔗

Development 🔗

Fox expressed a strong desire in the mid-1990s for Matt Groening to create a new series after the success of The Simpsons. In 1995, he enlisted David X. Cohen to assist in developing the show. When they pitched the series to Fox in April 1998, Groening and Cohen had composed many characters and story lines. Fox ordered thirteen episodes. Fox feared the themes of the show were not suitable for the network and Groening and Fox executives argued over whether the network would have any creative input into the show. The episode “I, Roommate” was produced to address Fox’s concerns. The name Futurama comes from a pavilion at the 1939 New York World’s Fair.

Writing 🔗

The planning for each episode began with a table meeting of writers, who discussed the plot ideas as a group. A single staff writer wrote an outline and then produced a script. Once the first draft of a script was finished, the writers and executive producers called in the actors for a table read. After this script reading, the writers collaborated to rewrite the script as a group before sending it to the animation team. The writing staff held three Ph.D.s, seven master’s degrees, and cumulatively had more than 50 years at Harvard University.

Voice actors 🔗

Futurama had eight main cast members. Billy West performed the voices of Philip J. Fry, Professor Farnsworth, Doctor Zoidberg, Zapp Brannigan, and many other incidental characters. Katey Sagal voiced Leela, and is the only member of the main cast to voice only one character. John DiMaggio performed the voice of the robot Bender Bending Rodríguez and other, more minor, characters. Phil LaMarr voices Hermes Conrad, his son Dwight, Ethan Bubblegum Tate, and Reverend Preacherbot. Lauren Tom voices Amy Wong, and Tress MacNeille voices Mom and various other characters. Maurice LaMarche voices Kif Kroker and several supporting characters. David Herman voiced Scruffy and various supporting characters.

Animation 🔗

Futurama is produced by The Curiosity Company and 20th Television Animation with the animation being done by Rough Draft Studios. In addition to traditional cartoon drawing, Rough Draft Studios often used CGI for fast or complex shots. The series began high-definition production in season 6, with Bender’s Big Score. For the final episode of season 6, Futurama was completely reanimated in three different styles: Fleischer- and Walter Lantz-style animation, a low-resolution video game, and Japanese anime.

Hallmarks 🔗

Opening sequence 🔗

The Planet Express Ship flies across the screen with the title of the show being spelled out in its wake. Underneath the title is a joke caption. After flying through downtown New New York and past various recurring characters, the Planet Express ship crashes through a large screen showing a short clip from a classic cartoon. The Futurama theme was created by Christopher Tyng.

Languages 🔗

There are three alternative alphabets that appear often in the background of episodes. The first alphabet consists of abstract characters and is referred to as Alienese, a simple substitution cipher from the Latin alphabet. The second alphabet uses a more complex modular addition code. The third language sometimes used is Hebrew. The show predicts that several English expressions will have evolved by the year 3000

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alienese

item.title: Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise
item.description:
Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise 🔗

This article provides a comprehensive list of alien races featured in the Star Trek franchise, spanning from the original series to the latest installments. It emphasizes the significance of these alien encounters as a core element of the Star Trek narrative.

Key 🔗

This section provides a key to the abbreviations used throughout the list to indicate the specific Star Trek media (TV series, films) in which each alien race appears. It includes the title, date, and medium for each abbreviation.

A 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

  • Aenar: A sub-species of Andorians from the planet Andoria, characterized by their light blue/white skin, near-blindness, and telepathic abilities. They are generally pacifistic. Key figures include Hemmer from Strange New Worlds and Talla, Shran’s daughter.
  • Andorian: A blue-skinned, antenna-bearing humanoid species from Andoria. They are depicted as a warrior race and were founding members of the United Federation of Planets.
  • Angosian: A species known for genetically and chemically engineering soldiers for the Tarsian Wars. These “super soldiers” were later confined to a penal settlement.
  • Antedean: An ichthyohumanoid species from Antede III that resembles fish and has a strong aversion to space travel.
  • Arcadian: A member of the United Federation of Planets with a representative on the Federation Council. They have large, round heads and distinctive hairstyles.
  • Arcturian: A species known for their clones, which have a melted skin appearance. They hail from the densely populated world Arcturus.
  • Axanar: The first extraterrestrial race befriended by Earth people aboard the NX-01 Enterprise. Captain Garth of Izar achieved a great victory on behalf of the Federation at the Battle of Axanar.

B 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

  • Bajoran: A humanoid species from the planet Bajor, characterized by nose ridges and deep spirituality. They worship The Prophets and were occupied by the Cardassians. Key locations include Bajor.
  • Ba’ku: A technologically advanced humanoid civilization that chose to abandon technology and live a simple life on an isolated planet with metaphasic radiation. Their aging process is significantly slowed. Key locations include The Briar Patch.
  • Benzite: A humanoid race from the planet Benzar, a member of the United Federation of Planets. They are known for their resistance to poisons and ability to digest almost any organic compound.
  • Betazoid: A telepathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed, a member of the United Federation of Planets. Deanna Troi is a prominent half-Betazoid character.
  • Bolian: Humanoids with blue skin and a ridge running from the back of their heads to their noses. They are active members of the Federation and known for crystal steel and the Bank of Bolius.
  • Borg: A pseudo-species of cybernetically enhanced individuals forming a collective consciousness. They assimilate other species to achieve perfection.
  • Breen: A mysterious race who joined the Dominion during the Dominion War.
  • Brikar: A large, rock-like species. Rok-Tahk from Star Trek: Prodigy is a notable example.

C 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

  • Cardassian: A species with ridges along their foreheads and necks, known for their military dictatorship and conflict with the United Federation of Planets. Key figures include Garak and Gul Dukat. Their homeworld is Cardassia Prime.
  • Chameloid: A race of shapeshifters. Martia is a notable example encountered by Kirk and McCoy.
  • Changeling: A race of fluid shapeshifters who founded the Dominion. Odo is a prominent Changeling character.

D 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “D.”

  • Douwd: Immortal energy beings with vast powers. Only one is known to exist, who committed xenocide against the Husnock.
  • Deltan: A humanoid species from the planet Delta IV, known for their strong sexual attraction. They take a vow of chastity upon joining Starfleet. Ilia and Melle are notable Deltans.

E 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “E.”

  • Edosian: A race of sentient tripedal beings. Lieutenant Arex was introduced in Star Trek: The Animated Series.
  • El-Aurian: A humanoid race known as “Listeners,” with long lifespans and a patient, wise demeanor. Their homeworld, El-Auria, was destroyed by the Borg. Guinan is a notable El-Aurian.

F 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “F.”

  • Ferengi: A species known for their focus on profit and the Rules of Acquisition. Quark is a notable Ferengi character. Their homeworld is Ferenginar.

G 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “G.”

  • Gorn: A violent, lizard-like species known for kidnapping people to serve as incubators for their eggs.

H 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “H.”

  • Hirogen: A violent Delta Quadrant species whose culture is based on hunting other sentient species.
  • Horta: Silicon-based life forms that eat rock on the planet Janus VI.

I 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “I.”

  • Illyrian: A species that practices genetic augmentation to adapt to various environments.

J 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “J.”

  • Jem’Hadar: Genetically engineered shock troops of the Dominion, bred for strength and loyalty to the Founders.

K 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “K.”

  • Kazon: A species introduced in Star Trek: Voyager. They are a nomadic species.
  • Kelpien: A species from the planet Kaminar, suppressed by the Ba’ul for generations. Commander Saru is a notable Kelpien.
  • Klingon: A warrior race with a strict honor code and ridged foreheads. Their homeworld is Kronos.
  • Kzinti: Feline warriors who had four wars with humanity.

L 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “L.”

  • Lanthanite: A long-lived species that has been secretly present on Earth since the 22nd century. Chief Engineer Pelia is a notable Lanthanite.

O 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “O.”

  • Ocampa: A humanoid species from the Delta Quadrant with a history of great mental feats.
  • Organian: Incorporeal energy creatures who render weapons inoperable to prevent conflict.
  • Orion: A green-skinned, humanoid species.

P 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “P.”

  • Pakled: A species that obtains technology from other races, often through trickery.

Q 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “Q.”

  • Q: Immortal, omnipotent beings who belong to the Q Continuum. One Q is particularly interested in humanity.

R 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “R.”

  • Romulan: A violent, treacherous offshoot of the Vulcans who rule the Romulan Empire. Their homeworld is Romulus.
  • Reman: A humanoid caste related to the Romulans, forced to live as enslaved under the Romulans and work in the dilithium mines on Remus.

S 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “S.”

  • Son’a: Former members of the Ba’ku who were exiled for embracing technology.
  • Species 8472: A powerful species from fluidic space that surpasses the Borg in combat prowess.

item.description:
Alien Abduction 🔗

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of people reporting what they believe to be the real experience of being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. Those who claim to have been abducted are called “abductees” or “experiencers.” Most scientists and mental health professionals attribute these experiences to suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology.

Overview 🔗

Mainstream scientists generally reject claims that alien abduction literally occurs as reported. Some, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that most abductees are sane and common people, with psychopathology associated only with some cases. Mack noted the detailed nature of some abduction reports and the existence of a subculture with support groups and a mythos explaining the roles, origins, and motivations of various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics, etc.). Some abductees explain the lack of wider awareness as a result of extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History 🔗

Paleo-abductions 🔗

Before the term “alien abduction” gained widespread attention, some older stories were speculated to be possible cases, dubbed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark.

  • In 1896, Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them in Stockton, California.
  • In 1953, an article in Man to Man Magazine questioned whether humans were being captured by flying saucers for zoological specimens or vivisection.
  • In 1955, Harold T. Wilkins’s Flying Saucers Uncensored reported the mysterious disappearance of Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who claimed alien contact, with speculation that they were victims of abduction by flying saucers.

Two Landmark Cases 🔗

The Antônio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil in the mid-1950s was an early claim, but the Betty and Barney Hill abduction case of 1961 generated widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident was the first in which the claimants described beings that later became widely known as the Greys and in which the beings were said to explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin.

Later Developments 🔗

R. Leo Sprinkle, a psychologist at the University of Wyoming, became interested in the abduction phenomenon in the 1960s and suggested a link between abductions and cattle mutilation. Budd Hopkins became interested in abduction reports in the 1970s and used hypnosis to extract more details.

The 1980s brought mainstream attention to the subject through works by Hopkins, novelist Whitley Strieber, historian David M. Jacobs, and psychiatrist John E. Mack. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard published a comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees. Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was far more common than earlier suspected and that aliens were attempting to create human-alien hybrids.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Skeptic Michael Shermer noted that the ubiquity of camera phones increases the burden of evidence for such claims.

John E. Mack 🔗

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce writing in The Lancet called him “a well-meaning man uncritically elaborating on tales of alien abduction, and potentially both cementing and constructing false memories”. Mack’s work in hypnotic regression of claimants helped spread the Grey aliens meme into the culture.

Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject. Due to Mack’s belief and subsequent promotion of the claims of those he interviewed, his professional reputation suffered, prompting Harvard to review his position in 1994. He retained tenure, but “was not taken seriously by his colleagues anymore”.

Abductees 🔗

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. One of the earliest studies of abductions found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys argued that 5–6 percent of the general population allege to have been abducted.

Demographics 🔗

Although abduction reports are usually made by adults, sometimes young children report similar experiences. These child-reports often feature very specific details in common with reports of abduction made by adults, including the circumstances, narrative, entities and aftermaths of the alleged occurrences. Often, these young abductees have family members who have reported having abduction experiences. Family involvement in the military, or a residence near a military base is also common among child abduction claimants.

Mental Health 🔗

Some studies show that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that “as a group, abduction experients are not different from the general population in term of psychopathology prevalence”. Elizabeth Slater conducted a blind study of nine abduction claimants and found them to be prone to “mildly paranoid thinking”, nightmares and having a weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally of Harvard Medical School concluded in a similar study of 10 abductees that “none of them was suffering from any sort of psychiatric illness.”

Political Conspiracy Theories 🔗

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlighted links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, government and world takeover. He observed the rise of a form of eclectic and apocalyptic millenarism which he termed “improvisional millenarism”. UFO and abduction stories can often be part of stigmatized or suppressed knowledge narratives. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

According to Barkun, in popular culture, TV shows like The X-Files included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies, with militias and black helicopters but also featured demonization of FEMA. Political scientist Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities of victims and may resort to questionable regression therapy, similarly to other self-reported victims of child sexual abuse or satanic ritual abuse. Some espouse conspiracy theories of sophisticated technological mind control, including the use of implants, to force them to serve an alleged New World Order, or for the purposes of the antichrist, considering it important to warn the world of such imminent danger.

Abduction Narrative 🔗

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. According to CUFOS’s definition of abductee, the person must have been taken against their will by apparent non-human beings, taken to a special place perceived as extraterrestrial or to be a spaceship. They then must experience being subjected to an examination or to engage in some form of communication with the beings (or both). Communication may be perceived as telepathic rather than verbal. The memory of the experience may be conscious or “recovered” through means like hypnosis.

Although different cases vary in detail, some UFO researchers, such as folklorist Thomas E. Bullard argue that there is a broad, fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind”.

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  1. Capture. The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures. Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and on occasion simulated behavioral situations, training & testing, or sexual liaisons.
  3. Conference. The abductors communicate with the abductee or direct them to interact with specific individuals for some purpose.
  4. Tour. The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time. Abductees often rapidly forget the majority of their experience.
  6. Return. The abductees are returned to earth, occasionally in a different location from where they were allegedly taken or with new injuries or disheveled clothing.
  7. Theophany. Coinciding with their immediate return, abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high” similar to those induced by certain drugs, or a “mystical experience”, accompanied by a feeling of oneness with God, the universe, or their abductors.
  8. Aftermath. The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs says: “The entire abduction event is precisely orchestrated. All the procedures are predetermined. There is no standing around and deciding what to do next. The beings are task-oriented and there is no indication whatsoever that we have been able to find of any aspect of their lives outside of performing the abduction procedures.”

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience. These feelings manifest as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place at a certain time or as expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will soon occur. Abductees also report feeling severe, undirected anxiety at this point even though nothing unusual has actually occurred yet.

Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. British abduction researchers have called this change in consciousness “the Oz Factor”. External sounds cease to have any significance to the experiencer and fall out of perception. They report feeling introspective and unusually calm. As consciousness shifts one or more lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist.
