Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, often focusing on reproductive systems, warnings against environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or interspecies breeding. Mack have argued that many abductees are sane individuals reporting genuine experiences. Skeptic Peter Rogerson notes that these cases established a template for later abductions.

Bullard also published a comparative analysis of alleged abductees.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was more common than suspected, estimating tens of thousands of North Americans had been taken. Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities and may resort to questionable regression therapy. Some espouse conspiracy theories of technological mind control, including implants, to force them to serve a New World Order or for the purposes of the antichrist.

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. CUFOS defines an abductee as someone taken against their will by non-human beings to an extraterrestrial place or spaceship, subjected to examination or communication, with memory of the experience either conscious or recovered through hypnosis.

Though cases vary, folklorist Thomas E. Bullard argues there is a fairly consistent sequence of events in a typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.”

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and sometimes simulated behavioral situations, training, testing, or sexual liaisons.

  4. Tour: The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.

  6. Return: The abductees are returned to earth, sometimes in a different location or with new injuries.
  7. Theophany: Abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high,” or a “mystical experience.”
  8. Aftermath: The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the experience, such as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place or expectations of something “familiar yet unknown.” They also report severe anxiety. This period of foreboding can last for days or be absent.

Eventually, the experiencer undergoes an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness, called “the Oz Factor” by British researchers. External sounds cease to have significance, and the experiencer feels introspective and calm. This marks a transition to “limited self-willed mobility.” Lights appear, sometimes accompanied by a strange mist. The source and nature of the lights differ by report.

As the abduction proceeds, claimants say they walk or are levitated into an alien craft, sometimes through solid objects. Alternatively, they may experience rising through a tunnel or along a beam of light into the craft.

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024
item.description:
National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 🔗

The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 (NDAA 2024) is a United States federal law that outlines the budget, expenditures, and policies of the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) for fiscal year 2024.

Background 🔗

The National Defense Authorization Act is an annual bill proposed in the United States Congress that redefines the United States military budget for the following fiscal year. Each chamber of Congress introduced a version of the NDAA: H.R. 2670 in the House and S. 2226 in the Senate.

History 🔗

The House passed their version on July 14, 2023 by a vote of 219–210. Led by Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds, the Senate passed theirs on July 27, 2023 by a vote of 86–11. The Senate then replaced H.R. 2670 with the text of S. 2226 and passed it by unanimous consent, and indefinitely postponed S. 2226. The House disagreed to the Senate amendment and asked to hold conference on September 19, with the Senate insisting on its amendment and agreeing to conference on November 15. The subsequent conference report was filed on December 6 (H. Rept. 118-301). The bill was approved by the Senate and House and sent to President Joe Biden on December 14. Biden signed it into law on December 22. In his signing statement, Biden expressed reservations about provisions that restrict the executive branch’s discretion in Guantanamo detainee transfers and raised constitutional concerns regarding congressional oversight and foreign policy authority.

Provisions 🔗

This section requires updating to reflect recent events or newly available information.

Unidentified flying objects (UFOs) 🔗

Sections 1841 et seq. outline the creation and management of a comprehensive collection of government records on UFOs or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) at the National Archives (NARA), detailing the processes for assembling, preserving, and providing public access to these records, along with specific protocols for their review, disclosure, and secure handling. NARA subsequently provided guidance to federal agencies to identify, organize, and disclose UAP records for the new collection.

Sections 1687 and 7343 disallow use of funds or independent research and development (IRAD) indirect expenses for UFOs or UAP unless such material and information is made available the appropriate congressional committees and congressional leadership.

Language on the topic of UFO/UAP was also included in the previous 2023 NDAA, the 2022 NDAA, the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, as well as an accompanying Senate Select Committee on Intelligence report for the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021.

Foreign Extortion Prevention Act 🔗

The Foreign Extortion Prevention Act (FEPA) enables US authorities to prosecute foreign officials who demand or accept bribes from a US citizen, US company, or within a US jurisdiction. FEPA addresses a longstanding gap in US anti-bribery legislation by tackling the “demand” side of bribery. At the same time, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) focuses on the “supply” side of bribery.

Counter-extremist working group defunded 🔗

Republicans opposed the anti-extremism working group created by Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin. That working group had been created by Austin after it became apparent that some service members and veterans had participated in the attack on the US Capitol January 6, 2021. That working group released recommendations at the end of 2021. Implementation, however, appeared to stall as Republicans increasingly opposed diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in the military, which Republicans derided as “wokeness”.

Meanwhile, a recent inspector general report found dozens of troops, who appeared to be advocating violent overthrow of the US government.

The seriousness of this issue seems apparent from the fact that military and veterans have participated in other violent extremist events. For example, the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, had served with distinction in Operation Desert Storm but had earned a reputation as a sergeant for assigning undesirable work to black servicemen and using derogatory language.

NATO withdrawal 🔗

Section 1250A prevents the President from withdrawing the United States from NATO without the approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

Original proposals 🔗

The original House bill contained provisions to:

  • Space Force Personnel Management Act: Disestablish the regular Space Force in order to integrate both active duty and reserve personnel into one Space Force entity. This is to allow for better flexibility for the Space Force by replacing “active duty” with “sustained duty” or “full-time” status, and replacing “reserve” with “part-time” status. This change would only pertain to the Space Force and not to the other armed services.
  • Elevate the position of vice chief of the National Guard Bureau to hold a statutory rank of general.
  • Permanently establish the titles of commissioned officer ranks of the Space Force to be the same as the Army, Marine Corps, and Air Force.
  • Authorize a $886 billion spending budget for national defense programs including:
    • A 5.2% pay increase for service members of the armed forces.
    • Procurement of up to 13 Virginia-class submarines.
  • Authorize the sale and transfer of defense articles and services relating to the implementation of the AUKUS partnership, including:
    • Up to three Virginia-class submarines, one year after this act is passed, however the Navy doesn’t intend implement this until 2032.

The Senate amendment contained:

  • UAP Disclosure Act: The Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Disclosure Act of 2023 would direct the National Archives and Records Administration to collect and disclose records on unidentified flying objects (UFOs) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) no later than 25 years after enactment with a presumption of immediate disclosure. The U.S. president can certify that continued postponement can be made necessary by an identifiable harm to military defense, intelligence operations, law enforcement or conduct of foreign relations. The federal government would have eminent domain over recovered technologies of unknown origin (TUO) and biological evidence of non-human intelligence (NHI) that may be controlled by private persons or entities, such as aerospace companies. Legislation was necessary in part because UAP records had not been subject to mandatory declassification review due to exemptions under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 as well as an over-broad interpretation of “transclassified foreign nuclear information”.
  • The Intelligence Authorization Act (IAA) requires people currently or formerly under contract with the federal government to make all UFO/UAP material and information and a comprehensive list of all extraterrestrial or exotic UAP material available to the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).
  • A provision that prevents the President of the United States from withdrawing the U.S. from NATO without approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology 🔗

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science have investigated UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology 🔗

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background 🔗

Ufology’s roots trace back to various historical phenomena, including the mystery airships of the late 1890s, foo fighters reported during World War II, ghost fliers of the 1930s, ghost rockets of 1946 in Scandinavia, and the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting popularized the concept of flying saucers. Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with Cold War tensions and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government involvement in ufology in the United States ended after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. France maintains the GEIPAN program for UFO studies. In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the first Director of U.A.P. to study such occurrences scientifically.

As a field 🔗

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field by academia and is generally considered pseudoscience.

Status as a pseudoscience 🔗

Ufology is often listed as a pseudoscience due to its lack of adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, and falsifiability. Social factors contribute to this status, including mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis hinders public understanding and discourages academic inquiry.

Current interest 🔗

Astronomer Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project in 2021 to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrial technology. The University of Würzburg is developing sensors for detecting and analyzing aerial objects. A 2021 Gallup poll indicated increased belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft. In 2022, NASA announced a study to investigate UAP. In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing public reports of UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022.

Methodological issues 🔗

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of UFO phenomena, their lack of reproducibility, and tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable. J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallée developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings.

Phenomena linked to ufology 🔗

Ufologists are interested in phenomena related to UFO sightings, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants. Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, such as the Roswell Incident and the Majestic 12 documents. Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” and James E. McDonald identified “cultism” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism 🔗

During the Cold War, ufology was combined with the ideas of the Trotskyist Posadism movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to collaborate in suppressing poverty and creating a socialist system on Earth.

Governmental and private ufology studies 🔗

Since the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups have sponsored UFO investigations, studies, and conferences. These include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings on UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force.

UFO organizations and events 🔗

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study and discussion of ufology. Skeptic organizations emphasize the pseudoscientific nature of ufology. During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufologist

item.description:
Ufology 🔗

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science have investigated UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology 🔗

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical Background 🔗

Ufology’s roots can be traced to several historical phenomena:

  • Mystery Airships (late 1890s): Unexplained aerial objects reported during this period.
  • Foo Fighters (World War II): Reports from Allied airmen of unusual objects during flight.
  • Ghost Fliers (1930s): Sightings in Europe and North America.
  • Ghost Rockets (1946): Sightings in Scandinavia, particularly Sweden.
  • Kenneth Arnold Sighting (1947): Arnold’s report of “flying saucers” popularized the concept.

Increased media attention to UFOs after World War II coincided with the Cold War and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government involvement in ufology in the United States ended in the late 1960s after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. Other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden, also ended government-sponsored UFO activities. France is an exception, maintaining the GEIPAN program. In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the Director of U.A.P. to study such occurrences scientifically and transparently.

As a Field 🔗

Status as a Pseudoscience 🔗

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field by academia and is generally considered a pseudoscience. Pseudoscience lacks adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, or falsifiability. Social factors contribute to this status, including mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government investigative bodies. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis also hinders public understanding and academic inquiry.

Current Interest 🔗

Interest in ufology persists. In 2021, Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrial technology. The University of Würzburg in Germany is developing sensors to detect and analyze aerial objects. A 2021 Gallup poll indicated increased belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft. In 2022, NASA announced a study to investigate UAP. In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing 101,151 public reports of UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022.

Methodological Issues 🔗

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of the phenomena, lack of reproducibility, and absence of tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable. J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallée developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings.

Phenomena Linked to Ufology 🔗

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists:

  • Crop circles
  • Cattle mutilations
  • Anomalous materials
  • Alien abductions and implants

Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, such as the Roswell Incident and Majestic 12 documents. Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” while James E. McDonald identified “cultism” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism 🔗

During the Cold War, ufology was synthesized with the ideas of Posadism, a Trotskyist movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to intervene and collaborate in suppressing poverty and creating a socialist system on Earth.

Governmental and Private Ufology Studies 🔗

Starting in the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups sponsored investigations, studies, and conferences related to ufology. These studies include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge of the University of Missouri, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings concerning UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force.

UFO Organizations and Events 🔗

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study and discussion of ufology. Skeptic organizations also exist, emphasizing the pseudoscientific nature of ufology. During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology.

J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallée developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings and organizing ufology investigations.

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants.

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study, discussion, and publicity of ufology. Skeptic organizations emphasize the pseudoscientific nature of ufology.

During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology, including group gatherings to search for and observe UFOs.

item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation 🔗

Alien Nation is an American science fiction media franchise created by Rockne S. O’Bannon, known for Farscape. The franchise, owned by 20th Century Studios, encompasses film, television, novels, and comics centered around alien refugees living on Earth. It blends science fiction with elements of drama, police procedural, and buddy cop genres.

Setting 🔗

The franchise is set in the near future in the United States, specifically starting in 1991. A flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert, revealing the Tenctonese, an extraterrestrial race referred to as “Newcomers.” These aliens are escaping slavery from a cruel Overseer race. The Tenctonese resemble humans but possess anatomical differences and enhanced physical and intellectual capabilities due to selective breeding. The core concept revolves around the Newcomers’ integration into American society, exploring themes of multiculturalism and acceptance.

Film 🔗

The franchise began with the 1988 film Alien Nation, released by 20th Century Fox. The film depicts the integration of the Tenctonese refugees, or Newcomers, into human society in Los Angeles. It combines science fiction and police drama elements. The film stars Mandy Patinkin as Sam “George” Francisco, a Newcomer detective in the Los Angeles Police Department, and James Caan as Matthew Sykes, his initially reluctant human partner.

Television 🔗

In 1989, Fox adapted the film into a television series, also called Alien Nation. The series follows the same premise as the film, focusing on the Newcomers’ integration after their ship crashes on Earth. Eric Pierpoint stars as George Francisco, and Gary Graham as Matthew Sikes. The series explores themes of racism and the treatment of minority ethnic groups. The series ran for one season of 21 episodes and a pilot episode, ending in 1990. Fox abruptly cancelled the series after the season. Beginning in 1994, the network continued the story in five TV movies, which brought back the entire cast. The installments include Dark Horizon (1994), Body and Soul (1995), Millennium (1996), The Enemy Within (1996), and The Udara Legacy (1997).

Novels 🔗

Pocket Books, a division of Simon & Schuster, published a novel series connected to the franchise starting in 1993. Judith and Garfield Reeves-Stevens, known for their work in Star Trek, wrote a novel entitled Day of Descent. Some novels served as prequels to the movie sequels, such as K.W. Jeter’s Cross of Blood, a tie-in to the Dark Horizon film, and Peter David’s Body and Soul, which became one of the sequels of the same name. The novels regularly addressed racism and discrimination with extraterrestrial themes. K. W. Jeter and Barry B. Longyear were regular contributors to the series with novels like, The Change and Slag Like Me.

Comics 🔗

From 1990 to 1992, Malibu Comics published several comics adapting the Alien Nation storyline. Among the first released titles were The Spartans, created with the help of author Bill Spangler and illustrator James Tucker, and A Breed Apart, authored by Steve Jones. Other titles included Public Enemy, authored by Sandy Carruthers and illustrated by Lowell Cunningham, and a crossover series with the Planet of the Apes franchise titled Ape Nation. The Ape Nation series included four different adventures called Plans, Pasts, Pawns and Pains along with a collector’s edition. Other contributors to the series included illustrators Terry Pallott and Leonard Kirk to titles like, The Skin Trade.

Remake 🔗

On March 25, 2015, Fox announced a remake with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing. On September 9, 2016, Deadline reported that Jeff Nichols would write and direct the film. On January 25, 2021, it was announced that Jeff Nichols would remake the film as a ten-part television series. On June 21, 2024, it was reported Nichols was developing an original sci-fi feature film for Paramount instead of an Alien Nation project.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Nation

item.title: Spacecraft
item.description:
Spacecraft 🔗

A spacecraft is a vehicle or machine designed to fly and operate in outer space. It serves various purposes, including communications, Earth observation, meteorology, navigation, space colonization, planetary exploration, and transporting humans and cargo. Spacecraft typically require a launch vehicle to reach space, except for single-stage-to-orbit vehicles.

History 🔗

The history of spacecraft begins with the German V-2 rocket, which reached an altitude of 189 km in June 1944 in Peenemünde, Germany. Sputnik 1, launched by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957, was the first artificial satellite, marking the start of the Space Age. Sputnik 1’s launch initiated new political, military, technological, and scientific developments. It also helped identify the density of the upper atmospheric layer and provided data on radio-signal distribution in the ionosphere. While Sputnik 1 was the first spacecraft to orbit the Earth, other human-made objects had previously reached an altitude of 100 km, the Kármán line, which is the height required by the international organization Fédération Aéronautique Internationale to count as a spaceflight.

Crewed and Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

Spacecraft are categorized into crewed and uncrewed vehicles.

Crewed Spacecraft 🔗

As of 2016, only Russia, the United States, and China have flown crewed spacecraft. Vostok 1, carrying Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin in 1961, was the first crewed spacecraft to complete a full Earth orbit. The second crewed spacecraft was Freedom 7, which performed a sub-orbital spaceflight in 1961 carrying American astronaut Alan Shepard. Other crewed spacecraft include the Soviet Voskhod and Soyuz, the American Gemini and Apollo spacecraft, the Skylab space station, the Space Shuttle, and the Chinese Shenzhou. The International Space Station (ISS), crewed since November 2000, is a joint venture between Russia, the United States, Canada, and other countries.

Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

Uncrewed spacecraft operate autonomously or telerobotically, often preferred for cost-effectiveness and lower risk. They are used for missions unsuitable for humans, such as exploring Venus or the outer planets. Robotic spacecraft used for scientific research are space probes, while those orbiting a planetary body are artificial satellites. Examples include the Hubble Space Telescope and cargo spacecraft like the Jules Verne Automated Transfer Vehicle (ATV).

Other 🔗

Some spacecraft, like the Buran spaceplane and SpaceX Dragon 2, can operate as both crewed and uncrewed vehicles.

Types of Spacecraft 🔗

Spacecraft are designed for various specific purposes.

Communications Satellite 🔗

Communications satellites relay and amplify radio telecommunication signals between a source transmitter and a receiver on Earth. They are used for television, telephone, radio, internet, and military applications. Many are in geostationary orbit, while others form satellite constellations in low Earth orbit.

Cargo Spacecraft 🔗

Cargo spacecraft are robotic vehicles designed to carry cargo, such as food, propellant, and other supplies, to support space station operations. Automated cargo spacecraft have serviced Salyut 6, Salyut 7, Mir, the International Space Station, and Tiangong space station.

Space Probes 🔗

Space probes are robotic spacecraft sent to explore deep space or astronomical bodies other than Earth. They have visited every planet in the Solar System and Pluto. The Voyager probes, launched in 1977, took advantage of a rare alignment of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune to visit all four planets in one mission.

Voyager Program 🔗

The Voyager probes, launched in 1977, took advantage of a rare planetary alignment to visit Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 are now escaping the Solar System, providing valuable data from interstellar space.

Space Telescopes 🔗

Space telescopes are telescopes in outer space used to observe astronomical objects, avoiding the filtering and distortion of electromagnetic radiation and light pollution. Examples include the Hubble Space Telescope and the James Webb Space Telescope.

Landers 🔗

Landers are spacecraft that make a soft landing on the surface of an astronomical body other than Earth. They use various techniques, including fuel supply and aerobraking, to achieve a safe landing.

Space Capsules 🔗

Space capsules are spacecraft that can return from space at least once. They have a blunt shape and do not possess wings. The Vostok capsule, built by the Soviet Union, carried the first person in space, Yuri Gagarin.

Spaceplanes 🔗

Spaceplanes are spacecraft built in the shape of airplanes. The North American X-15 was an early example, while the Space Shuttle orbiter was the first reusable orbital spaceplane. The Buran-class shuttle, launched by the USSR, was the first autonomous reusable spaceplane.

Space Shuttle 🔗

The Space Shuttle was a reusable Low Earth Orbital launch system consisting of two reusable Solid Rocket Boosters, a Space Shuttle Orbiter, and a throwaway Space Shuttle external tank. It flew 135 times from 1981 to 2011, supporting Mir, the Hubble Space Telescope, and the International Space Station.

Other 🔗

Some spacecraft do not fit neatly into the general categories.

SpaceX Starship 🔗

Starship is a spacecraft and second stage under development by SpaceX, designed to transport crew and cargo to Earth orbit, the Moon, Mars, and beyond. It will also be capable of point-to-point transport on Earth and refueling other Starship vehicles.

Mission Extension Vehicle 🔗

The Mission Extension Vehicle is a robotic spacecraft designed to prolong the life of another spacecraft by docking to it and correcting its orientation or orbit.

Subsystems 🔗

A spacecraft’s astrionics system comprises various subsystems, including attitude determination and control, guidance, navigation and control, communications, command and data handling, power, thermal control, propulsion, and structures. Spacecraft intended for human spaceflight must also include a life support system.

Spacecraft Records 🔗

Spacecraft records include achievements such as speed and distance from the Sun.

Fastest Spacecraft 🔗

  • Parker Solar Probe (estimated 700,000 km/h at final perihelion)
  • Helios I and II Solar Probes (252,792 km/h)

Furthest Spacecraft from the Sun 🔗

  • Voyager 1 (156.13 AU as of April 2022)
  • Pioneer 10 (122.48 AU as of December 2018)
  • Voyager 2 (122.82 AU as of January 2020)
  • Pioneer 11 (101.17 AU as of December 2018)

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacecraft

item.title: Alien Apocalypse (2005 film)
item.description:
Alien Apocalypse (2005 film) 🔗

This entry describes the 2005 American science fiction TV film Alien Apocalypse.

Overview 🔗

This section presents the film’s promotional poster and basic information in a table format. Key details include:

  • Writer and Director: Josh Becker
  • Starring: Bruce Campbell, Renee O’Connor, Remington Franklin, Michael Cory Davis, and Peter Jason
  • Theme Music Composer: Joseph LoDuca
  • Country of Origin: United States
  • Language: English
  • Production: Jeff Franklin and Bob Perkis
  • Cinematography: David Worth
  • Editor: Shawn Paper
  • Production Company: Syfy
  • Original Release: March 26, 2005
  • Network: Sci Fi Channel

It establishes the film as a Sci Fi Channel original movie.

Plot 🔗

The plot summary details the events of the film:

  • Astronaut Dr. Ivan Hood (Bruce Campbell) and his companion Kelly return to Earth after a 40-year space mission.
  • They discover Earth has been conquered by giant termite-like aliens who used EMP bombs to disable the planet 20 years prior.
  • Humans are enslaved and forced to work in camps.
  • Dr. Hood and Kelly are captured near the ruins of Portland, Oregon.
  • They plan an escape after learning of a surviving President.
  • Kelly is recaptured, and Dr. Hood seeks out the President, eventually finding him a broken man.
  • Dr. Hood rallies escaped slaves to attack the alien camp and rescue Kelly.
  • The attack is successful with the help of the President’s forces.
  • Dr. Hood becomes known as “The Great Exterminator” and continues to fight the aliens.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the film:

  • Bruce Campbell as Dr. Ivan Hood
  • Renee O’Connor as Lieutenant Kelly Lanaman
  • Remington Franklin as Alex
  • Michael Cory Davis as Captain Chuck Burkes
  • Peter Jason as President Demsky
  • Vladimir Kolev as Bob “Fisherman Bob”
  • Valentin Giasbeily as Tyler
  • Velizar Binev as Manager
  • Dimiter Kuzov as Bounty Hunter 1
  • Krum Iapulov as Bounty Hunter 2
  • Jonas Talkington as Bounty Hunter 3
  • Zlatko Zlatkov as Bounty Hunter 4
  • Chavdar Simeonov as Alien Leader
  • Anton Trendafilov as Jeff
  • Rosi Chernogova as Bizzy
  • Todor Nikolov as Bill “Mountain Man Bill”
  • Asen Blatechki as Crazy Man

Production 🔗

This section provides information about the film’s production:

  • The film was shot in Bulgaria.
  • Many of the actors were Bulgarian and spoke little English, requiring extensive dubbing in post-production.

It includes an image of Josh Becker directing the film.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes the critical reception of the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse received mixed reviews from critics and audiences.
  • David Nusair of Reel Film Reviews noted that the film doesn’t take itself seriously, especially by the end.

See also 🔗

This section lists other films with similar themes:

  • Planet of the Apes (1968)
  • Battlefield Earth
  • Android Apocalypse

References 🔗

This section provides links to external sources used in the article:

  1. DVD Talk review
  2. Reel Film Reviews article

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to the film:

  • Alien Apocalypse at IMDb
  • “The Making of Alien Apocalypse” by Josh Becker
  • The shooting script for Alien Apocalypse

A navigation template for films directed by Josh Becker is also included.

item.title: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film)
item.description:
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film) 🔗

A comprehensive overview of the 1982 American science fiction film produced and directed by Steven Spielberg and written by Melissa Mathison. The film tells the story of a boy, Elliott, who befriends an extraterrestrial stranded on Earth.

Plot 🔗

A race of alien botanists visits Earth, but one of them gets separated from the group and is left behind. The alien takes shelter in a shed belonging to the family of ten-year-old Elliott Taylor. Elliott lures the alien back to his home with Reese’s Pieces, and he hides the creature in his room. Elliott introduces E.T. to his older brother, Michael, and five-year-old sister Gertie, who agree to keep E.T. hidden from their mother, Mary. Elliott and the creature begin to bond, they start to share thoughts and emotions. E.T. displays telekinetic abilities and revives a dead chrysanthemum.

At school, Elliott becomes intoxicated because E.T. is drinking beer and watching television at home. Inspired by a Buck Rogers comic strip, E.T. builds a makeshift device to “phone home”, using various parts around the Taylor home. On Halloween, the children disguise E.T. as a ghost and Elliott sneaks E.T. into the forest, where they set up the device to call E.T.’s people. Elliott begs E.T. to stay on Earth with him, before falling asleep and waking alone in the forest the next day. He returns home to his worried family, while Michael searches for E.T., finding him pale and weakened in a culvert. He takes E.T. home, where Elliott is also growing weaker, and reveal the creature to Mary just before government agents invade and quarantine the house. The lead agent, Keys, asks for Elliott’s help to save E.T., stating that meeting aliens was his childhood dream and he considers E.T’s arrival a genuine miracle. However, E.T. dies while Elliott rapidly recovers. Left alone to say goodbye, Elliott tells E.T. that he loves him, but E.T.’s heart begins to glow and he is revived and restored to health. E.T. tells Elliott that his people are returning for him.

Elliott and Michael flee with E.T. on their bikes, flanked by Michael’s friends who help them evade the pursuing authorities. Heading towards a roadblock, E.T. levitates the boys to safety and lands them in the forest. E.T.’s ship arrives, and he says goodbye to Michael and Gertie, who gifts him the chrysanthemum he previously revived. Elliott tearfully asks E.T. to stay, but E.T. places his glowing finger on Elliott’s head and tells him that he will always be there. The children, Mary, and Keys observe as the ship blasts off into space, leaving a rainbow in the sky.

Cast 🔗

The main cast includes:

  • Dee Wallace as Mary Taylor, the single mother.
  • Henry Thomas as Elliott Taylor, the boy who befriends E.T.
  • Peter Coyote as Keys, the government agent.
  • Robert MacNaughton as Michael Taylor, Elliott’s older brother.
  • Drew Barrymore as Gertie Taylor, Elliott’s younger sister.

Other cast members include K.C. Martel, Sean Frye, C. Thomas Howell, Erika Eleniak, David O’Dell, Richard Swingler, Frank Toth, Robert Barton, Michael Darrell, and Pat Welsh as the voice of E.T.

Production 🔗

Details the development, pre-production, casting, filming, and music of the movie.

Development 🔗

The film’s concept originated from an imaginary friend Steven Spielberg created after his parents’ divorce. He initially planned a darker project called Night Skies but developed a subplot into what became E.T. Melissa Mathison wrote the first draft, titled E.T. and Me.

Pre-production 🔗

Carlo Rambaldi designed the animatronics for E.T., inspired by his painting Women of Delta and the faces of Carl Sandburg, Albert Einstein, and Ernest Hemingway. Kathleen Kennedy visited the Jules Stein Eye Institute to study eyes for E.T. Four heads were created for filming, one as the main animatronic and the others for facial expressions, as well as a costume. Tamara De Treaux, Pat Bilon, and Matthew DeMeritt took turns wearing the costume. Mars, Incorporated refused to allow M&M’s to be used in the film, so The Hershey Company was asked if Reese’s Pieces could be used, and it agreed. Henry Feinberg created E.T.’s communicator device.

Casting 🔗

Spielberg cast Henry Thomas as Elliott after an impressive improvised audition scene. Robert MacNaughton played Michael, and Drew Barrymore was cast as Gertie. Pat Welsh provided the major voice work for E.T., with additional sounds from Debra Winger, Spielberg, and various animals. A scene featuring Harrison Ford as the school principal was cut.

Filming 🔗

Principal photography began on September 8, 1981, in Los Angeles County and the San Fernando Valley, under the cover name A Boy’s Life. Filming locations included Culver City High School, Northridge, Tujunga, Laird International Studios in Culver City, and a redwood forest near Crescent City in Northern California. The exterior Halloween scene and the “flying bicycle” chase scenes were filmed in Porter Ranch. The film was shot in roughly chronological order to achieve convincing emotional performances from the young cast. Sean Frye revealed how the visual effect close-up shots for the climax of the “flying bicycle” chase scene were filmed. BMX riders Robert Cardoza, Greg Maes, and David Lee served as stunt doubles for the scene.

Music 🔗

John Williams composed the score, taking a modernist approach with polytonality and the Lydian mode. Spielberg edited the final chase sequence to suit Williams’ music.

Themes 🔗

The film explores themes of divorce, alienation, growing up, and communication. Critics have noted parallels between E.T. and Elliott, as well as religious parallels between E.T. and Jesus. Some see the movie as a modern fairy tale, drawing comparisons to Peter Pan and The Wizard of Oz. Kathleen Kennedy highlighted tolerance as an important theme.

Reception 🔗

Details the film’s release, sales, critical response, and accolades.

Release and sales 🔗

E.T. premiered at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival and was released in the United States on June 11, 1982. It opened at number one at the US box office and stayed at the top for six weeks. In 1983, E.T. surpassed Star Wars to become the highest-grossing film of all time. The film was also a merchandising success, with dolls selling 15 million units by September 1982 and becoming the best-selling toy that Christmas season. The film was re-released in 1985 and 2002, earning another $60 million and $68 million respectively. It was re-released in IMAX on August 12, 2022, to commemorate the film’s 40th anniversary.

Home media 🔗

E.T. was released on VHS and LaserDisc on October 27, 1988. The videos were priced with a recommended retail price of $24.95, the lowest initial price at the time for a major movie compared to the normal price of $89.95. The film doubled the record pre-orders of Cinderella released the same month and went on to sell over 15 million VHS units in the United States, and grossed over $250 million in video sales revenue.

Critical response 🔗

The film received near-universal acclaim. Roger Ebert gave it four out of four stars, and Michael Sragow of Rolling Stone called Spielberg “a space age Jean Renoir.” George Will was one of few to pan the film. The film holds a 99% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Accolades 🔗

The film was nominated for nine Oscars at the 55th Academy Awards, winning four: Best Original Score, Best Sound, Best Sound Effects Editing, and Best Visual Effects. It also won Golden Globe Awards for Best Picture (Drama) and Best Original Score.

Legacy 🔗

The film has been voted one of the greatest films of all time by the American Film Institute. The line “E.T. phone home” was ranked 15th on AFI’s 100 Years…100 Movie Quotes list. In 1994, it was selected for preservation in the U.S. National Film Registry. In 2023, actress Rita Moreno named E.T. as one of her top five favorite films. Many people in the world of entertainment have cited E.T. as among their favorite films, including filmmakers Stanley Kubrick, Sidney Lumet, Edgar Wright, J. A. Bayona, Dustin Lance Black, Spenser Cohen, Dustin Guy Defa, Gareth Edwards, Michael Giacchino, Sarah Greenwood, Chad Hartigan, Max Hechtman, Jordan Horowitz, Phil Joanou, Travis Knight, David Lowery, Rod Roddenberry, Céline Sciamma, Ed Solomon, Goran Stolevski, Clement Virgo and Molly Manning Walker, actors

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 🔗

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s generally believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The USAF and CIA acquired the site in 1955, primarily for flight testing the Lockheed U-2 aircraft. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a frequent subject of conspiracy theories and a central component of unidentified flying object (UFO) folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. It’s located in southern Nevada, approximately 83 miles (134 km) north-northwest of Las Vegas.

Geography 🔗

This section details the physical location and surrounding areas of Area 51. The original base was a 6 by 10 mile rectangle, part of the larger “Groom box,” a 23 by 25 mile area of restricted airspace. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and eventually connects to State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel, Nevada. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, where many US nuclear tests were conducted. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake. Groom Lake itself is a salt flat used for runways.

History 🔗

The origin of the name “Area 51” is uncertain. The CIA refers to the facility as Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. Other nicknames include “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace is Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and mining operations occurred until the early 1950s. The airfield began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program 🔗

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE, the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. sought a secure testing site. Lockheed’s Kelly Johnson found Groom Lake ideal due to the dry lake bed and surrounding mountain ranges. The CIA acquired the land from the AEC, designating it “Area 51.” Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch.” A survey team arrived in May 1955, laying out a runway and base support facility. The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. By July 1955, the base had a paved runway, three hangars, a control tower, and accommodations for personnel. The first U-2 delivery arrived on July 24, 1955. Regular flights were established between Area 51 and Lockheed’s Burbank offices.

OXCART program 🔗

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. Groom Lake’s facilities were initially inadequate. Construction of “Project 51” began in September 1960, including a new 8,500 ft runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) upgraded base facilities. A 10,000 ft runway (14/32) was built, and an Archimedean spiral was marked on the dry lake as an overrun. Three Navy hangars were erected, and the original U-2 hangars were converted to maintenance shops. Facilities included workshops, storage, administration buildings, a commissary, a control tower, a fire station, and housing. A permanent aircraft fuel tank farm was constructed for the JP-7 fuel required by the A-12. Security was enhanced, and the FAA expanded the restricted airspace. The CIA facility received USAF F-101 Voodoos, T-33 Shooting Star trainers, a C-130 Hercules, a U-3A, a helicopter, a Cessna 180, and an F-104 Starfighter. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived in February 1962 and made its first flight on April 26, 1962. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard 🔗

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2, discussions arose about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962, designated “Q-12,” later renamed the “D-21.” “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The D-21 was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21.” Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965. The first D-21 launch was made on March 5, 1966, with a successful flight. An accident on July 30, 1966, caused the D-21 to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft, resulting in one crew member drowning. Kelly Johnson cancelled the program. The Air Force proposed launching them from a B-52H bomber. The test missions were flown out of Groom Lake, with the actual launches over the Pacific. Several more tests were made, none of which met with success. The D-21B program was cancelled on July 15, 1971. The remaining drones were transferred to the Davis-Monthan AFB Military Storage and Disposition Center.

Foreign technology evaluation 🔗

During the Cold War, the United States tested and evaluated captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, Area 51 hosted Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate their performance and capabilities, pitting them against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT. Comparisons between the F-4 and the MiG-21 indicated that the skill of the pilot was what made the difference. On August 12, 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel with a pair of MiG-17Fs. These MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. The aircraft were given USAF designations and fake serial numbers. The data from the HAVE DOUGHNUT and HAVE DRILL tests were provided to the newly formed Top Gun school at NAS Miramar. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. The Air Force began funding improvements to Area 51 in 1977 under project SCORE EVENT. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program 🔗

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. In 1978, the Air Force awarded a full-scale development contract for the F-117 to Lockheed Corporation’s Advanced Development Projects. On January 17, 1981, the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype, designated YF-117A. On June 18, 1981, Lockheed Skunk Works test pilot Hal Farley lifted the nose of YF-117A off the runway of Area 51. Tactical Air Command (TAC) decided to set up a group-level organization to guide the F-117A to an initial operating capability, the 4450th Tactical Group, which officially activated on October 15, 1979, at Nellis AFB, Nevada, although the group was physically located at Area 51. The 4450th TG also operated the A-7D Corsair II as a surrogate trainer for the F-117A. On October 15, 1982, Major Alton C. Whitley Jr. became the

item.title: Psychological perspectives on UFO belief
item.description:
Psychological Perspectives on UFO Belief 🔗

Claims of sighting, visitation, and contact with unidentified flying objects (UFOs) have been the subject of medical and psychological research. Some research suggests psychopathological origins for these claims, while others propose that “experiencers” may simply have overactive imaginations. Treatment approaches include antipsychotic medication, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

UFO Belief as a Mental Health Disorder 🔗

This section examines the idea that belief in UFOs and extraterrestrial contact may be linked to underlying mental health conditions. It highlights research suggesting that individuals claiming face-to-face contact with extraterrestrials (ETs) may have distinct psychological profiles compared to those without such experiences.

Research 🔗

Several studies are presented that explore the potential link between UFO beliefs and mental health.

  • A 1983 study in the Canadian Journal of Psychiatry examined six individuals claiming extraterrestrial contact and concluded that five suffered from a paranoid delusional state akin to paraphrenia.

  • A 1997 study by researchers at the University of Essex found an association between UFO-related beliefs and schizotypy, a construct that may indicate a risk of developing schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders.

  • A 2008 study published in Cortex found that individuals alleging alien abduction showed higher levels of dissociativity and a tendency to hallucinate compared to a control group.

Individual Experiencers 🔗

This section presents case studies of individuals whose belief in alien encounters was linked to mental health issues.

  • A 2000 case study at Boston University Medical Center described a married couple with shared psychotic disorder involving a belief in alien abductions. The husband had a history of mental health issues and suicide attempts, and the couple’s shared delusion reinforced their beliefs.

  • A 2008 case at the University of Louisville involved a woman with sleep paralysis who believed she was being abducted by aliens. Her belief was attributed to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) resulting from the paralysis and cultural acclimation to the alien abduction phenomenon. Psychotherapy improved her condition.

  • A 2023 case study from Nova Southeastern University reported on a 17-year-old boy who felt “as if he is being chased by Martians.” He was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treated with risperidone, cognitive behavioral therapy, and counseling to stop using marijuana.

UFO Belief as a Personality Trait 🔗

This section explores the idea that belief in UFOs may be related to certain personality traits, particularly fantasy-prone personality.

Persons with a fantasy-prone personality spend a significant portion of their lives involved in fantasy and may confuse or mix their fantasies with their real life.

Medical sociologist Robert Bartholomew suggests that some individuals are prone to exceptionally vivid fantasies and have difficulty distinguishing between fantasy and reality. Science journalist Eric Smalley hypothesizes that “starseeds” may be experiencing the Barnum effect, with books providing a sense of authenticity to their beliefs.

Psychology professor Robert Baker proposed fantasy-prone personality as an explanation for UFO contacts, noting that individuals reporting such contacts are not necessarily psychotic or neurotic, just “a little different.” Armando Simon, a staff psychologist at the Texas Department of Corrections, argued that belief in UFOs is a cultural norm in North America and not necessarily a sign of mental illness.

A 1991 study of 152 individuals reporting alien abductions found that 132 exhibited characteristics consistent with fantasy-prone personality. A 2001 study in the European Journal of UFO and Abduction Studies found that persons who reported seeing UFOs tended “to have a richer fantasy life than those who do not report UFOs.”

UFO Belief as Faulty Perceptuality 🔗

This section examines how cognitive and perception psychology can explain UFO beliefs, focusing on how human perception, cognitive biases, and psychological tendencies shape beliefs about UAP stimuli. Joey Florez explored UAPs through comparative institutional psychology, focusing on the intuitive and conspiratorial mind.

Florez explains that understanding flawed perception entails considering anomalous phenomena from antiquity, given the over-reliance on superstition and illogical assumptions about the external world. Ancient Greeks interpreted bright flashes in the sky as Zeus firing lightning bolts, reinforcing divine authority and political legitimacy.

Two central modes of information processing, intuitive and conspiratorial, can be used to identify modern UAP beliefs from a cognitive and perceptual perspective. Primary experiences with UAP stimuli often involve intuitive processing, while secondary experiences often involve conspiratorial processing.

Pareidolia refers to anomalies in the brain’s initial perception of recognizable patterns in ambiguous visual stimuli, while apophenia is intentional and results in complex convictions of conspiratorial narratives. Research has suggested cognitive reflection and education may reduce narcissistic susceptibility to conspiratorial processing.

Other Studies and Hypotheses 🔗

This section presents additional research and perspectives on UFO belief.

A 1993 study in the Journal of Abnormal Psychology found no difference in psychopathology and fantasy proneness between persons alleging abduction by UFOs and those with more mundane UFO experiences, concluding that UFO belief did not have a psychopathological origin.

Research published in 2017 in Motivation and Emotion found that paranormal beliefs related to extraterrestrial life were partly motivated by the need for meaning in life, with persons experiencing a lack of life meaning demonstrating a higher propensity for such beliefs.

Harvard University psychiatrist John E. Mack suggested that some patients related actual encounters with non-humans or non-human controlled UFOs that were not explainable as mental illness. However, a Harvard review committee concluded that Mack was not using “rational and scholarly” research methods. Mack’s use of hypnosis to elicit purportedly repressed memories of abduction experiences has also been criticized. UCLA psychiatrist Fred Frankel and Michael D. Yapko criticized Mack’s use of hypnosis, explaining that fantasy and suggestion play a major role during hypnosis.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_perspectives_on_UFO_belief

item.title: UFO sightings in Australia
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the nation of Australia 🔗

This article lists alleged UFO sightings in Australia, spanning from the pre-1900s to recent times.

Pre 1900 🔗

This section details an 1868 sighting in Parramatta, New South Wales, where Alderman Frederick Birmingham reported seeing an ark-like object floating in the sky before landing in Parramatta Park.

1950s 🔗

This section mentions a 1954 sighting in Gawler, South Australia, where three people observed a white UFO flying overhead, followed by an RAAF jet.

1960s 🔗

This section includes two notable events:

  • A 1966 incident in Tully, Queensland, where a farmer reported a large saucer-shaped object and a “nest” of reeds in a swamp.
  • The 1966 Westall High School UFO incident in Clayton South, Victoria, where many students and staff claimed to have witnessed a UFO flying over the school and descending into a paddock.

1970s 🔗

This section focuses on the Valentich Disappearance in 1978. Frederick Valentich, a pilot, disappeared while flying a Cessna 182 over Bass Strait to King Island (Tasmania). He reported to Melbourne air traffic control that he was being accompanied by an unknown aircraft.

1980s 🔗

This section describes a 1988 sighting in South Australia’s Nullarbor Plain. A family reported seeing a “big glowing ball” that resembled “an egg in an egg cup.”

1990s 🔗

This section details two incidents:

  • In 1993, Eric Thomason photographed a craft hovering around Maslin Beach.
  • Also in 1993, Kelly Cahill from Melbourne claimed to have seen a large craft over the road in the Dandenong Ranges near Belgrave, Victoria, and further claimed to have been abducted by aliens.

2012 🔗

This section describes an alleged encounter in Frankston South, Victoria. A resident, K.T., reported being hit by a blinding light and later encountering a tall, white humanoid being identifying as a “Paladeian” from the “Star Cluster Pladieas.” K.T. claimed to have communicated telepathically with the being, experiencing paralysis and lost time during the encounter.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related topics, including the Bass Strait Triangle and a general list of reported UFO sightings.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles and websites.

item.title: Alien Autopsy Fact or Fiction (1995 film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction (1995 film) 🔗

This entry discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The footage, released by British entrepreneur Ray Santilli, was broadcast on television networks worldwide, including Fox television, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, and Channel 4 in the UK. Despite its popularity, the program was thoroughly debunked, with the footage revealed to have been shot on a set in London using plaster casts filled with offal and other materials.

Production 🔗

This section details the production of the hoaxed footage. In 2006, Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the 1995 footage in a documentary presented by Eamonn Holmes. They simulated an autopsy on a fabricated alien, constructed by artist and sculptor John Humphreys in a London flat. Humphreys created two dummy alien bodies filled with raspberry jam, sheep brains, and chicken entrails. Alien artifacts were also fabricated. Santilli and Shoefield also admitted to hiring a homeless man in Los Angeles to play the role of the original cameraman.

In popular culture 🔗

This section outlines how Alien Autopsy was received and referenced in media. The X-Files satirized the footage, and Fox later aired a special debunking it. A fictionalized version of the creation of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading 🔗

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including articles from Skeptical Inquirer and books about the Roswell incident and alien autopsy film.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources, including Ray Santilli’s “My Story” on VJ Enterprises, his IMDb page, and a YouTube link to Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction?

item.title: List of UFO religions
item.description:
UFO Religions 🔗

UFO religions are groups that incorporate beliefs about communication with extraterrestrial beings into their religious doctrines. These groups often interpret major religions as being based on supernatural beings from heaven. Communication methods include telepathy and astral projection. A common belief is that humanity can be saved through education provided by aliens, leading to societal improvement. Alien abduction experiences can also contribute to the formation of these religions.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for understanding UFO religions. It highlights that these religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings, often through physical contact, telepathy, or astral projection. These groups typically believe that aliens will save humanity by teaching them a better way to live, sometimes by taking believers to a more positive location. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity.

J. Gordon Melton is identified as considering the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion. However, Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion rather than a UFO religion. Partridge emphasizes the belief within UFO religions that supreme beings originate from other planets or planes, not from Earth.

The Roswell incident of 1947 is identified as a key event in the history of UFO spirituality, marking the emergence of UFOs into public consciousness. UFO religion is placed within the context of theosophical esotericism and New Age thought, with many groups believing that extraterrestrial beings are heralds of a new era.

The Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, is described as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults. Heaven’s Gate and the Order of the Solar Temple are mentioned as controversial groups combining UFO beliefs with contactee assertions. Scientology is also discussed as a UFO religion due to its Xenu cosmogony and space opera elements.

List 🔗

This section provides a table listing various UFO religions, their founders, and the year they were founded. The list includes:

  • Aetherius Society: Founded by George King in 1955.
  • Ashtar Galactic Command: Founded by Thelma B. Terrill (“Tuella”) in 1977.
  • CEIRUS: Founded by Jean Miguères in 1987.
  • Chen Tao: Founded by Hon-ming Chen in 1993.
  • Christ Brotherhood: Founded by Wallace C. Halsey in 1956.
  • Cosmic Circle of Fellowship: Founded by William R. Ferguson in 1955.
  • Fiat Lux: Founded by Uriella in 1980.
  • Freie Interessengemeinschaft für Grenz- und Geisteswissenschaften und Ufologiestudien: Founded by Billy Meier in the 1970s.
  • Ground Crew Project: Founded by Sheldon Nidle in the 1980s.
  • Heaven’s Gate: Founded by Marshall Applewhite and Bonnie Nettles in the 1970s.
  • “I AM” Activity: Founded by Guy Ballard in the 1930s.
  • Industrial Church of the New World Comforter: Founded by Allen Michael in 1973.
  • Mark-Age: Founded by Charles Boyd Gentzel and Pauline Sharpe in 1962.
  • Nation of Islam: Founded by Wallace Fard Muhammad in 1930.
  • Néo-Phare: Founded by Arnaud Mussy in 2001.
  • Nuwaubian Nation: Founded by Dwight York in the 1970s.
  • Order of the Solar Temple: Founded by Joseph Di Mambro and Luc Jouret in 1984.
  • Raëlism: Founded by Raël in 1974.
  • Rational Culture: Founded by Manoel Jacintho Coelho in the 1930s.
  • Sanctuary of Thought: Founded by Truman Bethurum in the 1950s.
  • The Seekers: Founded by Charles Laughead (aka “Dr. Armstrong”) or Dorothy Martin (aka “Marian Keech”) in 1953.
  • Siderella: Founded by Jean-Paul Appel-Guéry.
  • Scientology: Founded by L. Ron Hubbard in 1952.
  • Unarius: Founded by Ernest Norman and Ruth Norman in 1954.
  • Universe People: Founded by Ivo A. Benda in 1997.
  • Urantia movement: Authorship of The Urantia Book is unknown and disputed. The book alleges it was written by celestial beings. Founded between 1924 and 1955.
  • Vale do Amanhecer: Founded by Neiva Chaves Zelaya in the 1960s.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and links for further exploration, including:

  • Religion portal
  • Outer space portal
  • Doomsday cult
  • List of new religious movements
  • List of ufologists
  • List of UFO organizations

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation 🔗

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon is often linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. Mutilations typically involve the removal of specific body parts such as ears, eyeballs, jaw flesh, tongues, lymph nodes, genitals, and rectums. Two independent federal investigations in the United States have been conducted into these incidents.

Early History 🔗

Documented reports of unexplained livestock deaths date back to 1606 in England, with sheep being slaughtered and only tallow and inward parts removed. Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 🔗

The case of “Snippy,” a horse found mutilated in Alamosa, Colorado, in 1967, brought widespread attention to unexplained livestock deaths. The horse’s head and neck were skinned and defleshed, with precise cuts and no blood at the scene. Agnes King and her son Harry discovered the body. The incident fueled speculation about extraterrestrial involvement. Wadsworth Ayer’s investigation for the Condon Committee found no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips initially suggested a lightning strike. Later, two students confessed to shooting the horse weeks after the publicity.

Cattle Mutilations 1973–1980 🔗

This period saw waves of cattle mutilations reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico. In April 1973, sheriffs in Western Iowa reported unidentified helicopters involved in cattle and pig rustling. Similar rustling was reported in Missouri in August.

1973 Kansas Wave 🔗

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about a caller posing as a USDA official. A series of butchered cows were found on farms near Munden, Kansas, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” Butcher. By December, law enforcement reported 40 mutilations across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, a conclusion disputed by Modlin.

1974 Nebraska Wave 🔗

Reports resumed in April 1974 with a mutilated and blood-drained cow in Nebraska. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. In May, mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, with coyotes suggested as the cause. By June, mutilations were reported in Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. In August, an unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By late August, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. In September, authorities ordered helicopters to fly above 1000 feet after a commercial helicopter was shot at. A meeting of law enforcement officials from 24 counties estimated 27 out of 80 cow deaths were suspected mutilations. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande reported mutilations in his state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. In December 1974, mutilations were reported in Minnesota.

1975 Colorado 🔗

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico 🔗

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting 🔗

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. In May 1979, Valdez reported finding tranquilizers and anticoagulants in a mutilated bull. In June 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents 🔗

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002.

In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of São Paulo, Brazil, in 1988.

Characteristics 🔗

Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by the absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts are described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals are reported to have been drained of blood with no sign of blood in the immediate area. Howard Burgess stated that nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found. In the “Snippy” case, there was an absence of tracks and several small holes were found seemingly “punched” in the ground. In Rio Arriba County, New Mexico, a “trail of suction cup-like impressions” was found leading from a mutilated cow.

Laboratory Reports 🔗

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals in tissue samples, and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In a case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI involving a bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, the animal displayed “classic” mutilation signs. The animal’s heart, bone, and muscle samples were sent to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, while liver samples were sent to private laboratories. The liver was found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain 4 times the normal level of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were reported to be “light pink in color” and “Did not clot after several days.”

Helicopter Sightings 🔗

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters were reported to have opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported that residents had seen unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilation.

Official Investigations 🔗

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover to investigate. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms 🔗

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger, tasked with investigating possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents and circumstantial evidence but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation 🔗

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under the leadership of Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University but no conclusive results emerged. The US Bureau of Land Management was forced to ground all helicopters in Eastern Colorado. By December, the CBI had investigated 203 reports of cattle mutilations.

New Mexico State Police 🔗

On June 13, 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation headed by Officer Gabe Valdez with the assistance of Cattle Inspector Jim Dyad and Officer Howard Johnston of the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. On the night of July 5, Burgess and Valdez screened the Gomez herd; five animals were found to have been marked with a chemical that fluoresced under ultraviolet light. On June 14, 1981, intact radar chaff was found near a mutilated cow on the Gomez ranch. This investigation reported finding evidence that some mutilated animals had been tranquilized and treated with an anti-coagulant prior to their mutilation.

Rommel Investigation 🔗

Beginning in May 1979, an investigation was funded by a grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration and was headed by recently-retired FBI agent Kenneth Rommel. Rommel’s final report, released in June 1980, concluded that
