item.title: Planetary objects proposed in religion, astrology, ufology and pseudoscience
item.description:
Non-scientific hypothetical objects 🔗

This article discusses planetary objects proposed in religion, astrology, ufology, and pseudoscience that lack scientific evidence. It distinguishes these from scientifically accepted hypothetical astronomical objects and fictional planets in science fiction.

Kolob 🔗

Kolob is a star or planet described in the Book of Abraham, a sacred text in the Latter Day Saint movement. While the Book of Abraham refers to Kolob as a “star,” it also refers to planets as stars, leading Latter Day Saints to commonly view Kolob as a planet. It is described as the heavenly body closest to the throne of God and is said to have “signified” the first creation according to Joseph Smith.

Lilith 🔗

Lilith is a fictitious, invisible moon of Earth proposed in 1918 by astrologer Walter Gorn Old (Sepharial). Sepharial claimed Lilith was the same second moon that scientist Georg Waltemath claimed to have discovered twenty years earlier, but which was never confirmed. Sepharial claimed to be the first to observe Waltemath’s moon crossing the Sun. The scientific community had already discredited Waltemath’s proposed moon. While fringe groups believe in Lilith’s existence, astrologers now generally use the name for the position of the Moon’s apogee.

In modern astrology 🔗

In modern astrology, “Lilith” or “Black Moon Lilith” refers to a point on the horoscope representing the Moon’s apogee. This point is sometimes defined as the second focus of the ellipse described by the Moon’s orbit. It takes approximately 8 years and 10 months for this point to complete a circuit through the zodiac, tracking the apsidal precession.

Planets proposed by L. Ron Hubbard 🔗

L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of Scientology, proposed a Galactic Confederacy as part of his cosmology. This confederacy consisted of 26 stars and 76 planets, including Earth, then known as “Teegeeack.” Helatrobus is another planet mentioned in Scientology doctrine.

Ummo 🔗

Ummo is a hypothetical planet believed to be located in the Constellation Virgo. A series of claims describe aliens from Ummo communicating with people on Earth through detailed documents and letters. The Ummo affair gained attention in France and Spain during the 1960s. Ummoism refers to groups interested in studying the ideas presented in the Ummo letters. José Luis Jordán Peña has claimed responsibility for writing the letters and instigating Ummoism, leading many to believe Ummo is a hoax. Jacques Vallée compared the Ummo documents to Borges’ “Tlön, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius.” Mike Dash notes that Ummoism began on February 6, 1966, in Madrid, when Jordán Peña claimed to have seen a circular object with a symbol resembling the alchemical sign for Uranus. Fernando Sesma Manzano, a contactee, became involved after receiving documents purportedly from the Ummites. Jean-Pierre Petit claims to have detected signs of superior intelligence in the Ummite writings and that they have inspired his research in cosmology and magnetohydrodynamics. Antonio Ribera compiled 403 Ummo words in 1978, and Jean Pollion listed over a thousand words in 2002.

Two theories have been formulated by analysts of Ummite letters:

  • Jean Pollion considers each letter (sound or phoneme) in words transcribed in typewritten form to be signifying, calling these sounds “soncepts” and considering the language to be “ideophonemic.”
  • The second theory considers that differences in spelling are of little significance and are due to differences in the understanding of foreign sounds by the typist(s), or to difficulties in alphabetic transcription, considering that language is made up of word-objects and not of “soncepts.”

More than 1300 pages of letters have been registered, with references to 3850 pages in a 1988 letter.

Dash notes that the photographic evidence was suspect, and the letters, while sophisticated, could have originated on Earth. Jerome Clark notes that Jacques Vallée argued that the scientific content of the Ummo letters was knowledgeable but unremarkable, comparing the scientific references to a well-researched science fiction novel.

The controversy over an “error” in the distance from Wolf 424 arose from the first letter, referenced D21 (May 1966), which states that the distance used by terrestrial astronomers is different from the real distance in decadimensional space.

Planets proposed by Zecharia Sitchin 🔗

Zecharia Sitchin’s work has gained attention among ufologists, ancient astronaut theorists, and conspiracy theorists. He claimed to have found evidence in Sumerian texts that the human race was visited/created by extraterrestrials from a distant planet in the Solar System. He interpreted the Babylonian creation myth, the Enuma Elish, by replacing the names of gods with hypothetical planets. Academics consider his work pseudoscience and pseudohistory.

Sitchin’s theory proposes the planets Tiamat and Nibiru. Tiamat supposedly existed between Mars and Jupiter, and its orbit was disrupted by the arrival of Nibiru. The collision of Tiamat with one of Nibiru’s moons supposedly formed the asteroid belt and Earth.

Sitchin claimed the Babylonians associated Nibiru with the god Marduk. He hypothesized it as a planet in a highly elliptic orbit around the Sun, with a perihelion passage some 3,600 years ago and an orbital period of about 3,450 years. He also claimed it was the home of the Anunnaki, a technologically advanced alien race who visited Earth in search of gold and created humanity by genetically crossing themselves with primates.

Websites such as ZetaTalk have claimed that Nibiru or “Planet X” is a brown dwarf within our planetary system, soon to pass close to Earth. Sitchin disagreed that it is a star, with the timing and parameters of passage.

Sitchin also postulated that Pluto began life as Gaga, a satellite of Saturn, which was flung into orbit beyond Neptune due to Nibiru’s passing.

Serpo 🔗

Project Serpo is an alleged top-secret exchange program between the United States government and an alien planet called Serpo in the Zeta Reticuli star system. Details of the alleged exchange program have appeared in UFO conspiracy stories, including an incident in 1983 involving Richard C. Doty and Linda Moulton Howe, and emails sent to a UFO discussion group run by Victor Martinez in 2005. Some versions state that Serpo is the nickname of the extrasolar planet, while others claim it is a mispronunciation of Serponia or Seinu.

The first mention of Project Serpo was in a UFO email list maintained by Victor Martinez. According to the story, an alien survived a crash near Roswell in the late 1940s and was repatriated, leading to a relationship between the American government and the people of its home world in the Zeta Reticuli system.

The story claims that twelve American military personnel visited the planet between 1965 and 1978 and that all have since died from radiation levels from the two suns. Another version claims that eight team members returned, one died en route, one died on the planet, and two decided to remain on Serpo.

Criticism of Project Serpo stems from the lack of veracity of Richard Doty, who has been involved in other UFO-related activities and is considered a discredited source. There is no physical evidence supporting the project’s existence. Tim Swartz of Mysteries Magazine expressed that the details of Project Serpo have varied considerably with different accounts. It has been alleged that the entire series of posts were designed to be viral marketing for a new book by Doty.

Bill Ryan, a proponent of publicizing the Project Serpo claims, stepped down from his role as webmaster for the Serpo material but maintains his belief that an extraterrestrial exchange program did occur, although the Serpo releases contained disinformation.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_objects_proposed_in_religion,_astrology,_ufology_and_pseudoscience

item.title: David Grusch UFO whistleblower claims
item.description:
David Grusch: Former U.S. Military Intelligence Officer’s Claims About “Non-Human” Spacecraft Recovery 🔗

This article focuses on the claims made by David Grusch, a former U.S. Air Force officer and intelligence official, regarding the U.S. government’s alleged involvement in recovering and reverse-engineering “non-human” spacecraft. It also covers the responses to these claims from various experts and government entities.

Background 🔗

David Charles Grusch is introduced as an Afghanistan combat veteran and former intelligence officer who worked at the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). From 2019 to 2021, he served as the NRO representative to the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force. He assisted in drafting the National Defense Authorization Act of 2023, which included whistleblower protections for UFO reporting. The section notes that Congressional interest in UFOs increased prior to Grusch’s claims due to the downing of four objects by the Air Force in February 2023.

Grusch’s Claims 🔗

This section details Grusch’s allegations, which were initially reported by Leslie Kean and Ralph Blumenthal in The Debrief. Grusch claims the U.S. government possesses multiple spacecraft of “non-human” origin and the corpses of their pilots. He alleges a secret UFO retrieval program, “substantive evidence” of white-collar crime to conceal UFO programs, and that officials have stated people have been killed to conceal these programs.

In an interview with Le Parisien, Grusch elaborated, suggesting UFOs could be from extra dimensions, mentioning “football-field” sized crafts, the transfer of crashed UFOs to defense contractors, and “malevolent activity” by UFOs.

During a Congressional hearing in July 2023, Grusch testified about being informed of a multi-decade UAP crash retrieval and reverse-engineering program to which he was denied access. He stated his belief that the U.S. government possesses UAP based on interviews with 40 witnesses. He also claimed the U.S. has retrieved “non-human ‘biologics’” from the crafts. When asked about harm or injury related to cover-ups, Grusch said yes, but could only provide details in a SCIF.

Responses from Relevant Experts 🔗

This section presents the views of various experts on Grusch’s claims. It highlights that his assertions are based on alleged documents and conversations, rather than testable evidence. The scientific community generally considers claims of government conspiracy to conceal extraterrestrial visitation untrue.

Joshua Semeter of NASA’s UAP independent study team states that without data or material evidence, evaluating the claims is impossible. Adam Frank, an astrophysics professor, criticizes the claims as hearsay and lacking extraordinary evidence.

Stuart Clark’s opinion piece in The Guardian includes questions from scientists like Avi Loeb, Michael Garrett, and Sara Russell, who point out the lack of observed extraterrestrial activity and the ease of identifying extraterrestrial materials.

Greg Eghigian, a history professor and UFO expert, notes the historical pattern of individuals making “bombshell allegations” about UFOs and the lack of corroboration. Seth Shostak, senior astronomer at the SETI Institute, questions the absence of physical evidence and dismisses the claims as an “argument from authority.” Michael Shermer, publisher of Skeptic magazine, notes the lack of physical evidence and scientific community involvement.

Physicist Sean M. Carroll calls Grusch’s claims “laughable” and describes him as a “complete crackpot.” NASA’s JPL director, Laurie Leshin, denies having seen spacecraft from outside this world. Michio Kaku suggests the burden of proof has shifted to the Pentagon, a statement criticized by Ross Pomeroy.

Responses from the United States Government 🔗

This section outlines the responses from various U.S. government entities.

Department of Defense and NASA 🔗

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre referred questions to the Department of Defense (DoD). A Pentagon spokesperson stated that AARO has not discovered verifiable information to substantiate claims of programs regarding the possession or reverse-engineering of extraterrestrial materials. General Mark Milley stated he had never encountered evidence verifying Grusch’s claims. NASA stated it has not found credible evidence of extraterrestrial life and that there is no evidence that UAPs are extraterrestrial.

Congress 🔗

Representative Mike Turner stated there is no evidence of the U.S. possessing UFOs from outer space. Senator Lindsey Graham found the claims unreasonable. Senator Josh Hawley said the allegations sounded close to what they were “grudgingly admitted to us in the briefing”. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand intends to hold a hearing to assess whether “rogue SAP programs” existed. Senator Marco Rubio said people with “first-hand knowledge” have shared information with his committee.

In July 2023, Senators Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds proposed the UAP Disclosure Act 2023, an amendment to the 2024 National Defence Authorization Act, to provide wider access to UAP records. The enrolled bill directs the National Archives to collect government documents about UAP.

In January 2024, members of the House Oversight Committee received a classified briefing from the Intelligence Community Inspector General (IC IG) Thomas A. Monheim regarding UAP reporting transparency. Some members were frustrated by the lack of new information regarding Grusch’s allegations.

2023 House Committee Oversight and Accountability Hearing 🔗

Representatives Anna Paulina Luna and Tim Burchett organized a hearing on July 26, 2023, in response to Grusch’s claims. Grusch testified, repeating his earlier UFO claims. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez asked where to look for evidence, and Grusch offered to provide specifics in a closed environment. Officials later informed lawmakers that Grusch lacked security clearance to discuss the issues in a SCIF. Following the hearing, a bipartisan group of U.S. representatives called for the formation of a select committee on UAPs with subpoena power.

AARO’s director Sean Kirkpatrick wrote that Grusch “has refused to speak with AARO” and that the hearing was “insulting”.

Sean Kirkpatrick 🔗

After retiring from AARO, Kirkpatrick wrote an opinion piece for Scientific American stating that the US Government UFO coverup allegations “derive from inadvertent or unauthorized disclosures of legitimate U.S. programs or related R&D that have nothing to do with extraterrestrial issues or technology.” He described the allegations’ supporters as “a small group of interconnected believers and others with possibly less than honest intentions,” who promote a “whirlwind of tall tales, fabrication and secondhand or thirdhand retellings”.

In an interview with Peter Bergen, Kirkpatrick said that Grusch may have misinterpreted things or fallen under the influence of a core group of people. He characterized the situation as a “self licking ice cream cone,” where UFO true believers are carrying out a conspiracy to get the government involved in investigating aliens.

Media Reporting on Grusch’s Claims 🔗

This section examines how the media has covered Grusch’s claims.

Connections to Studies Funded by Robert Bigelow 🔗

Keith Kloor draws a connection between Grusch’s claims and studies funded by Robert Bigelow, noting specific references to “a football field–sized UFO” in both.

Reporting on Psychiatric Treatment Received by Grusch 🔗

Ken Klippenstein reported in The Intercept that Grusch was twice committed after incidents involving drunkenness and suicidal comments. Police records mentioned PTSD. Grusch was placed under an emergency custody order and transported to an emergency room. Grusch sued Loudoun County Sheriff Mike Chapman for releasing the information.

News Stories and Commentary 🔗

Nick Pope, who previously ran the British Ministry of Defense “UFO Desk”, expressed doubt about confirming Grusch’s claims. Marina Koren wrote that the case fits a pattern of unprovable claims. Matt Laslo described the sympathetic hearing of Grusch’s claims by some members of Congress as an indication that “once-fringe notions have built-in fan bases in today’s Capitol”. Tucker Carlson publicized the claims. Tom Rogan was skeptical but opined that they should be further investigated.

Andrew Prokop wrote that skeptics question whether Grusch is repeating tall tales. Sean Thomas expressed confusion that others have tried to convince officials and the public that UFOs are worthy of serious considerations. Ross Douthat noted that one interpretation is that parts of the U.S. government see benefit in promoting belief in UFOs. Matt Stieb described Grusch’s claims as “crazy”.

Ezra Klein interviewed Leslie Kean, noting that reactions to her story about Grusch have been either to embrace it as definitive truth or dismiss it out of hand. Steven Greenstreet criticized Grusch for previously attending UFO conventions and associating with Jeremy Corbell and George Knapp.

The story received attention from multiple foreign mainstream news outlets.

Disinformation Campaign Allegations 🔗

Grusch claimed that intentional disinformation was being promoted by the US government to cast doubt on the veracity of “non-human” UFO claims. Adam Gabbatt described Grusch’s position as “a common conspiracy trope in the UFO community”. Others have suggested that Grusch was given disinformation about aliens. Gareth Nicholson wrote that “the current UAP flap could be an attempt by the US military to engage in a disinformation campaign to disguise real aerospace breakthroughs or an attempt to flush out advanced technologies held by rivals such as Russia and China”.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Grusch_UFO_whistleblower_claims

item.title: Alien
item.description:
Alien 🔗

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979–present

Premise 🔗

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background 🔗

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, Mœbius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

Films 🔗

This section lists the Alien films, including the original series, Alien vs. Predator films, and Prometheus films. It includes the U.S. release date, director, screenwriter(s), story by, and producer(s) for each film.

Original series 🔗

  • Alien (1979): Directed by Ridley Scott, starring Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley. The crew of the Nostromo encounters a deadly alien creature.
  • Aliens (1986): Directed by James Cameron, Ripley returns to LV-426 with a squad of marines to investigate a lost colony.
  • Alien 3 (1992): Directed by David Fincher, Ripley crash-lands on a prison planet and faces a new alien threat.
  • Alien Resurrection (1997): Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Ripley is cloned 200 years after her death, and the military attempts to exploit the Aliens.

Crossover series 🔗

  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, a group of explorers discovers an ancient pyramid in Antarctica, where they become caught in a battle between Aliens and Predators.
  • Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem (2007): Directed by Greg & Colin Strause, the Predalien hybrid from the previous film causes a Predator ship to crash in Gunnison, Colorado, leading to a battle between Aliens and a Predator.

Prequel series 🔗

  • Prometheus (2012): Directed by Ridley Scott, scientists Elizabeth Shaw and Charlie Holloway discover a star map and travel to LV-223, where they encounter the Engineers.
  • Alien: Covenant (2017): Directed by Ridley Scott, the crew of the Covenant traces a transmission to an Engineer homeworld, where they encounter David 8 and a new breed of Alien.

Spin-off film 🔗

  • Alien: Romulus (2024): Directed by Fede Álvarez, set between Alien and Aliens.

Future 🔗

Discusses potential future installments in the Alien franchise, including a cancelled Alien 5 project by Neill Blomkamp and ongoing development of new films.

Short films 🔗

This section lists the Alien short films, including the U.S. release date, director(s), screenwriter(s), and producer(s) for each film.

Television and web series 🔗

This section lists the television and web series in the Alien franchise, including the season, episodes, originally released dates, network, showrunner(s), and status for each series.

  • Alien: Isolation – The Digital Series (2019): A seven-episode animated adaptation of the video game Alien: Isolation.
  • Alien: Earth (2025): A new TV series project based on the franchise, set on Earth in the near future.

Cast and crew 🔗

This section lists the principal cast and additional crew members involved in the Alien franchise.

Principal cast 🔗

Lists actors and the characters they portrayed in the films, web series, television series, and audio dramas. Key actors include Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley, Ian Holm as Ash, Lance Henriksen as Bishop II Michael Bishop Weyland, Carrie Henn as Rebecca “Newt” Jorden, Michael Biehn as Dwayne Hicks, Noomi Rapace as Elizabeth M. Shaw, and Michael Fassbender as David 8.

Additional crew 🔗

Lists the composers, cinematographers, editors, production companies, and distributors for each Alien film.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the box office performance, critical and public response, and accolades received by the Alien films.

Box office performance 🔗

Provides a table of the box office revenue for each Alien film, including North America, foreign, and worldwide totals, as well as the budget for each film.

Critical and public response 🔗

Provides a table of the critical and public response to each Alien film, including Rotten Tomatoes scores, Metacritic scores, and CinemaScore grades.

Accolades 🔗

Lists the Academy Award nominations for Alien films.

Alien Day 🔗

Discusses “Alien Day,” the fan celebration day for the Alien franchise on April 26.

Alien: The Play 🔗

Discusses the North Bergen High School’s adaptation of Alien entitled Alien: The Play, which was widely praised.

In academia 🔗

Discusses the Bishop character as a high-profile android character conforming to Isaac Asimov’s Three Laws of Robotics.

Music 🔗

Lists the soundtracks for Alien films, including the U.S. release date, length, composer(s), and label for each soundtrack.

Home media 🔗

Discusses the various home media releases of the Alien films, including VHS, Laserdisc, DVD, and Blu-ray.

Other media 🔗

This section discusses spin-offs in other media, including crossovers with the Predator franchise.

Print media 🔗

Discusses Alien print media, including novelizations of the films, original content that expand upon the fictional universe, comics, and companion books.

Novels 🔗

Lists several novelizations of each of the six films and some comic books as well as original canonical novels based on the franchise have been released.

Comic books 🔗

Discusses the numerous limited series set in the Alien universe, as well as non-canonical crossover appearances of the Alien.

Picture books 🔗

Discusses Jonesy: Nine Lives on the Nostromo, a 2018 picture book that retells the plot of Alien (1979) from the perspective of Jones, the ship’s cat from the film.

Video games 🔗

Discusses the numerous video games released over the years, spanning a variety of genres.

Merchandising 🔗

Discusses the merchandise manufactured and marketed to a wide range of age groups.

Theme park attractions 🔗

Discusses the Alien-themed attraction at the Genting SkyWorlds Theme Park in Malaysia and The Great Movie Ride at Disney’s Hollywood Studios.

Alien vs. Predator franchise 🔗

Discusses the Alien vs. Predator franchise, inspired by the Dark Horse Comics series.

The Predator (2018) 🔗

item.title: Pentagon UFO videos
item.description:
Pentagon UFO Videos 🔗

This article discusses the widely publicized cockpit instrumentation display videos from US Navy fighter jets, often characterized as UFOs.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the videos, referencing historical UFO photographs and events. It details the initial incident on November 14, 2004, involving Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigating radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. The USS Princeton had been tracking unusual aircraft for two weeks prior to the incident. Fravor’s account of encountering a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance is highlighted, as well as the observations of other pilots. It also mentions Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, who recorded the “FLIR” video and coined the term “Tic Tac” to describe the object. The section also mentions the 2014-2015 incidents involving fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group operating off the East Coast of the United States, during which the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos were recorded.

Release of Videos 🔗

This section focuses on the public release of the videos. The New York Times reported on the incidents and published the “FLIR” and “GIMBAL” videos in December 2017, while the Washington Post published the “GOFAST” video. Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, provided the videos to the press. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy. In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed the videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 Release 🔗

This section details the release of additional footage in 2021. In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed the authenticity of a video taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019, showing a triangular object. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”. In May 2021, a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, was confirmed and is under review by the UAP Task Force. The video purportedly shows a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented on the video, suggesting it could simply be a plane.

2023 Release 🔗

This section covers the release of additional videos in 2023. In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia, initially believed to be anomalous but later identified as a commuter aircraft. On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft. On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon resembling a small “metallic orb”. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee on the video, but stated they are unable to fully identify anything from the video.

Potential Explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos. As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified”. Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational error, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are “encroaching on these real issues of UAPs”. Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Thomas Bania speculated that they could be some form of electronic warfare fielded by China or Russia. The US Navy updated its reporting guidelines for unexplained aerial observations. Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive. Jeff Wise suggests advancements in electronic warfare could deceive sensors. In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath regarding the USS Nimitz sighting, stating that the technology was far superior to anything the US had.

June 2021 UFO Report 🔗

This section discusses the preliminary report on UAPs released by the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) on June 25, 2021. The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. Some UAPs appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics, including high velocity and maneuverability. The report indicated that the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects and proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category. The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI Request by The Black Vault 🔗

This section details a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security. Gregory Cason stated that the release of this information would harm national security.

In Popular Culture 🔗

This section notes the videos’ appearance in the History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation and an interview with Fravor on The Joe Rogan Experience.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force, All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, Navy UFO patents, and the film The Phenomenon.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagon_UFO_videos

item.title: Pentagon UFO videos
item.description:
Pentagon UFO videos 🔗

The Pentagon UFO videos are visual recordings from United States Navy fighter jets, widely publicized as UFOs. These videos were recorded using forward-looking infrared (FLIR) targeting cameras from fighter jets based aboard the aircraft carriers USS Nimitz and USS Theodore Roosevelt in 2004, 2014, and 2015. Additional footage was taken by other Navy personnel in 2019. The videos, characterized as officially documenting UFOs, have received extensive media coverage since 2017. The Pentagon officially released the first three videos of unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) in 2020 and confirmed the provenance of the leaked 2019 videos in 2021. Footage of UAPs was also released in 2023, sourced from MQ-9 military drones.

Publicity surrounding the videos has prompted explanations including drones or unidentified terrestrial aircraft, anomalous instrument readings, physical observational phenomena, human observational and interpretive error, and speculations of alien spacecraft.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Pentagon UFO videos, referencing the broader history of UFO sightings and investigations. It mentions UFO photographs and links to other Wikipedia articles on the topic.

On November 14, 2004, Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigated radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. Fravor reported seeing a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance. A second wave of fighters, including Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, recorded the FLIR video, with Underwood coining the term “Tic Tac” to describe the infrared image.

During 2014–2015, fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group recorded the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos while operating off the East Coast of the United States.

Release of videos 🔗

This section details the public release of the videos and the reactions that followed.

On December 16, 2017, The New York Times reported on the incidents and published two videos, “FLIR” and “GIMBAL.” The Washington Post published a video titled “GOFAST.” The reports led to speculation by UFO investigators. Journalism professor Keith Kloor criticized the reporting as thinly-sourced and slanted.

The videos were initially provided to the press by Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy.

In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed that the released videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 release 🔗

This section covers the release of additional videos and images in 2021.

In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed that video footage of an unidentified triangular object taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019 was authentic. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”.

In May 2021, the Pentagon confirmed a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, showing a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented that the object was likely a plane.

2023 release 🔗

This section describes the release of additional footage in 2023, including analysis of the objects.

In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia. Initially believed to be anomalous, the object was later identified as a commuter aircraft.

On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which the AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft.

On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that it resembled a small “metallic orb” but said they are unable to fully identify anything from this video. Some skeptics suggested it might be a balloon.

Potential explanations 🔗

This section discusses potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos.

As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified.” Widespread media attention has led to various theories, including pseudoscientific explanations such as ufology.

Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational illusion, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are encroaching on real issues and that the recorded UFOs might be commercial airplanes or balloons distorted by infrared glare.

Astrophysicist Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Astronomer Thomas Bania speculated that they could be electronic warfare technology.

The US Navy updated its guidelines for reporting unexplained aerial observations. A spokesman suggested that the increase in reported intrusions could be due to the rise in availability of unmanned aerial systems.

Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Retired Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive.

Adam Dodd and security expert Jack Weinstein say that neither China nor Russia presently have the capability to produce aircraft with such extraordinary capabilities.

Jeff Wise suggested that advancements in electronic warfare techniques could deceive sensors, resulting in false velocity and position information.

In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath that the technology they faced was far superior to anything they had.

June 2021 UFO report 🔗

This section summarizes the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) preliminary report on UAPs released on June 25, 2021.

The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. In a limited number of incidents, UAP appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics. Some of the UAPs appeared to move with no discernible means of propulsion.

The report indicated that, in most cases, the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects. The report proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category.

The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI request by The Black Vault 🔗

This section discusses a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage.

In April 2020, The Black Vault made a Freedom of Information request to the US Navy. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security.

In popular culture 🔗

This section notes the appearance of the videos in popular media.

The videos were featured in the 2019 History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation. Episode 1361 of The Joe Rogan Experience featured the videos and interviewed Fravor.

item.title: Barney and Betty Hill incident
item.description:
Barney and Betty Hill Incident 🔗

This Wikipedia article details the alleged alien abduction of Barney and Betty Hill in 1961, a case that gained significant notoriety and influenced the alien abduction narrative. The article covers the background of the Hills, the details of their reported encounter, the aftermath, analysis of the star map Betty Hill claimed to have seen, and the cultural impact of their story.

Background 🔗

Barney and Betty Hill were an interracial couple living in Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Barney was a postal worker and Betty was a social worker. They were active in civil rights and community affairs. The article also mentions that they are the grandparents of UFC fighter Angela Hill.

UFO Encounter 🔗

On September 19-20, 1961, the Hills claimed to have encountered a UFO while driving back from a vacation in Canada. Near Lancaster, New Hampshire, Betty noticed a bright light in the sky. They stopped near Twin Mountain to observe the object, which Betty viewed through binoculars. Barney initially thought it was a commercial airliner, but it rapidly descended towards them. They continued driving, observing the object near Cannon Mountain and the Old Man of the Mountain. South of Indian Head, the object descended rapidly, causing Barney to stop the car. He observed humanoid figures through binoculars. Fearing capture, Barney ran back to the car, and as they drove away, they heard beeping sounds and experienced a daze. They reported the incident to NICAP investigator Walter Webb.

Immediate Aftermath 🔗

Upon arriving home, the Hills noted odd sensations and unexplained occurrences. Betty insisted on keeping their luggage near the back door. Their watches stopped working. Barney found the binocular strap torn and his shoes scraped. They both took showers to remove possible contamination and drew pictures of what they had seen. Betty’s dress was torn and had a pinkish powder on it. Shiny, concentric circles appeared on their car’s trunk, which affected a compass.

Initial Report to the U.S. Air Force and NICAP 🔗

Walter N. Webb, a Boston astronomer and NICAP member, interviewed the Hills. Barney mentioned a “mental block” and suspected he was suppressing parts of the event. Webb concluded that they were truthful, and the incident likely occurred as reported.

Betty’s Dreams 🔗

Ten days after the encounter, Betty began experiencing vivid dreams for five consecutive nights. In her dreams, they encountered a roadblock and were forced into a forest by small men in blue uniforms. The men appeared nearly human with greyish skin. They were eventually returned to their car and watched the craft depart.

Medical Help and More Interviews 🔗

The Hills sought medical help to understand their experience.

Missing Time 🔗

During a follow-up interview with NICAP members C.D. Jackson and Robert E. Hohmann, the Hills realized they had “missing time” – a period of about seven hours they couldn’t account for. They recalled almost nothing of a 35-mile stretch of road and an image of a fiery orb.

Private Disclosure 🔗

In 1962, the Hills privately disclosed their encounter to Captain Ben H. Swett of the United States Air Force, who was interested in the “missing time” aspect.

Simon’s Hypnosis Sessions 🔗

The Hills underwent hypnosis with Dr. Benjamin Simon to recover their memories.

Barney’s Sessions 🔗

Under hypnosis, Barney recalled the binocular strap breaking as he ran from the UFO. He remembered being compelled to drive into the woods and seeing six men. He described the beings’ terrifying eyes and their communication through “thought transference.”

Betty’s Sessions 🔗

Betty’s account under hypnosis was similar to her dreams, with some differences. The technology on the craft was different, the short men differed significantly in physical appearance and the sequential order of the abduction differed. Barney’s and Betty’s memories in hypnotic regression were consistent with one another.

Simon’s Conclusions 🔗

Dr. Simon concluded that the case was a psychological aberration.

Post-Hypnosis Publicity and Barney’s and Betty’s Death 🔗

The Hills initially kept a low profile. However, in 1965, a front-page story in the Boston Traveller revealed their story, leading to international attention. John G. Fuller wrote the book The Interrupted Journey about the case in 1966. Barney died in 1969, and Betty became a figure in the UFO community. Betty died in 2004.

Analyzing the Star Map 🔗

In 1968, Marjorie Fish, an amateur astronomer, attempted to decipher the star map Betty Hill had drawn. Fish constructed a three-dimensional model of nearby Sun-like stars and concluded that the map’s perspective matched the Zeta Reticuli star system. The analysis was debated, with Carl Sagan arguing it was a random alignment of points. Later, more accurate data from the Hipparcos mission led Fish to reject her hypothesis.

Interrupted Journey 🔗

The 1966 book Interrupted Journey by John G. Fuller detailed the Hills’ claims. Betty Hill’s niece, Kathleen Marden, further explored these themes in Captured! The Betty and Barney Hill UFO Experience.

Rebutting the Hills 🔗

Jim Macdonald argued that the Hills’ experience was caused by misinterpreting an aircraft warning beacon on Cannon Mountain, combined with stress, sleep deprivation, and false memories. Robert Sheaffer criticized Betty Hill’s credibility, citing her UFO photos and later delusional stories.

Influence from The Outer Limits 🔗

Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by “The Bellero Shield,” an episode of The Outer Limits. Jason Colavito pointed out other episodes of The Outer Limits that aired before Barney’s hypnosis sessions that were even more reminiscent of the Hill’s story.

In Popular Media 🔗

The Hills’ story has been depicted in various forms of media.

Nonfictional Accounts 🔗

Barney Hill appeared on To Tell the Truth in 1966. Kathleen Marden and Stanton Friedman authored Captured in 2004.

In Fiction 🔗

The 1975 film The UFO Incident dramatized the Hills’ abduction. The story has also been referenced in comic books, films like Prometheus, virtual reality exhibits, and television series like Project Blue Book.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_and_Barney_Hill_abduction

item.title: Uncrewed spacecraft
item.description:
Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides an overview of spacecraft that operate without human presence on board, often referred to as uncrewed or robotic spacecraft. It covers their purpose, history, design considerations, control mechanisms, and various types, including space probes and cargo spacecraft.

Spacecraft without people on board 🔗

This introductory section defines uncrewed spacecraft as those without humans on board, highlighting their varying levels of autonomy, from remote control to pre-programmed operations. It distinguishes between space probes/observatories (for scientific measurements) and other types of uncrewed spacecraft. The section emphasizes the advantages of using uncrewed spacecraft for certain missions due to lower costs, reduced risks, and the ability to explore hostile environments unsuitable for humans. It also mentions the importance of sterilization for missions exploring regions vulnerable to contamination by Earth microorganisms. The launch of Sputnik on October 4, 1957, is noted as the first uncrewed space mission.

History 🔗

This section traces the historical development of uncrewed spacecraft, starting with the Soviet Union’s suborbital flight in 1951 carrying two dogs, Dezik and Tsygan. It details the launch of Sputnik 1 in 1957, the first artificial satellite, followed by Sputnik 2, which carried the first animal, Laika, into orbit. The United States’ response with Explorer 1 in 1958, which confirmed the existence of the Van Allen belts, is also covered. The section mentions early lunar probes like Luna 1 and highlights key milestones in planetary exploration, such as Mariner 2’s study of Venus, Venera 4’s atmospheric probe of Venus, and Mariner 4’s images of Mars. Voyager 1, launched in 1977, is identified as the first interstellar probe, entering interstellar space in 2012, followed by Voyager 2 in 2018. It also lists the other countries that have successfully launched satellites using their own launch vehicles.

Design 🔗

This section delves into the design considerations for uncrewed spacecraft. It references the United States Air Force’s approach, which divides a spacecraft into the mission payload and the bus (or platform), which provides essential support systems. JPL’s division of a spacecraft’s “flight system” into subsystems is also mentioned. The subsystems include:

Structure 🔗

The physical structure provides mechanical integrity and support for spacecraft components, ensuring they can withstand launch loads.

Data handling 🔗

The command and data subsystem stores command sequences, maintains the spacecraft clock, and collects/reports telemetry and mission data.

Attitude determination and control 🔗

This system maintains the spacecraft’s orientation in space, compensating for external disturbances and repositioning movable parts.

Entry, descent, and landing 🔗

This section discusses the integrated sensing technology used for safe landing on planetary surfaces, including real-time hazard detection and avoidance.

Landing on hazardous terrain 🔗

This section details the key processes involved in landing on the surface of a planet to ensure a safe and successful landing.

Telecommunications 🔗

This subsystem includes radio antennas, transmitters, and receivers for communication with Earth or other spacecraft.

Electrical power 🔗

Electric power is supplied by photovoltaic cells or radioisotope thermoelectric generators, with batteries for storage and distribution circuitry.

Temperature control and protection from the environment 🔗

Insulation, mirrors, and sunshades are used to protect spacecraft from temperature fluctuations, micrometeoroids, and orbital debris.

Propulsion 🔗

This section describes the methods used to propel spacecraft through space, including monopropellant, bipropellant, and ion propulsion systems.

Monopropellant 🔗

This propulsion system uses a fuel with a chemically bonded oxidizer, requiring a catalyst for combustion.

Bipropellant 🔗

This propulsion system uses a liquid propellant, where the oxidizer and fuel spontaneously combust upon contact.

Ion 🔗

This propulsion system generates thrust by accelerating ions, providing efficient velocity maintenance for deep-space travel.

Mechanical devices 🔗

Pyrotechnic devices are often used to control one-time movements for deployment or landing.

Robotic vs. uncrewed spacecraft 🔗

This section clarifies the distinction between robotic and uncrewed spacecraft, noting that robotic spacecraft are designed for specific hostile environments, while uncrewed spacecraft are operated automatically or remotely.

Control 🔗

This section explains how robotic spacecraft use telemetry to transmit data and status information back to Earth. It notes the evolution from early spacecraft without control signals to modern probes with increased autonomy, such as Cassini–Huygens and the Mars Exploration Rovers, which can operate independently for extended periods.

Space probes and observatories 🔗

This section defines space probes as robotic spacecraft that explore outer space beyond Earth’s orbit. It describes their scientific instruments and various mission types, including flybys, orbits, landings, and sample returns. The section also mentions trajectory techniques like Hohmann transfer orbits and gravitational slingshots. Space telescopes or observatories are defined as telescopes in outer space used to observe astronomical objects, avoiding atmospheric interference and light pollution.

Cargo spacecraft 🔗

This section focuses on cargo or resupply spacecraft, which transport supplies to space stations. It mentions the history of automated cargo spacecraft servicing stations like Salyut 6, Mir, and the ISS. The section lists the currently active cargo spacecraft, including Progress, Cargo Dragon 2, Cygnus, and Tianzhou, as well as those under development, such as Dream Chaser and HTV-X. The European Automated Transfer Vehicle (ATV) is mentioned as a previously used cargo spacecraft.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_probe

item.title: Uncrewed spacecraft
item.description:
Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

This Wikipedia article discusses spacecraft that operate without human presence, often referred to as robotic spacecraft. These vehicles can be remotely controlled, guided, or pre-programmed for autonomous operation. They are essential for space exploration due to lower costs, reduced risks, and the ability to explore environments too hostile for humans.

History 🔗

This section details the historical development of uncrewed spacecraft, beginning with the launch of Sputnik by the Soviet Union in 1957. Key events include:

  • 1951: The Soviet Union launches the first robotic spacecraft on a suborbital flight with two dogs, Dezik and Tsygan.
  • 1957: Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite, is launched by the USSR. Sputnik 2 follows, carrying the dog Laika, the first animal in orbit.
  • 1958: The United States launches its first satellite, Explorer 1, which confirms the existence of the Van Allen belts. Vanguard 1 is also launched.
  • 1959: Luna 1 becomes the first lunar probe to orbit the Moon and then the Sun.
  • 1962: Mariner 2 studies Venus, revealing its high temperature.
  • 1965: Mariner 4 captures the first images of Mars’ cratered surface. Luna 9 sends images from the Moon’s surface.
  • 1967: Surveyor 3 gathers crucial data about the Moon’s surface for the Apollo 11 mission.
  • 1977: Voyager 1 is launched, entering interstellar space in 2012, followed by Voyager 2 in 2018.

The section also mentions other countries that have successfully launched satellites using their own launch vehicles, including France, Japan, China, the United Kingdom, India, Israel, Iran, North Korea, and South Korea.

Design 🔗

This section outlines the design considerations for uncrewed spacecraft, dividing the vehicle into the mission payload and the bus (or platform). The bus provides essential functions such as physical structure, thermal control, electrical power, attitude control, and telemetry. JPL’s division of the “flight system” into subsystems is also mentioned.

Structure 🔗

The physical structure provides mechanical integrity and supports spacecraft components, ensuring they withstand launch loads.

Data Handling 🔗

The command and data subsystem stores command sequences, maintains the spacecraft clock, and collects and reports telemetry and mission data.

Attitude Determination and Control 🔗

This system maintains the spacecraft’s orientation in space, compensating for external disturbances and repositioning movable parts.

Entry, Descent, and Landing 🔗

Integrated sensing uses image transformation algorithms to interpret land data, detect and avoid terrain hazards, and increase landing accuracy.

Landing on Hazardous Terrain 🔗

Key processes for safe landing on a planet’s surface include entry into the gravity field and atmosphere, descent through the atmosphere, and a safe landing. The spacecraft must estimate its position, assess hazards, and adjust its trajectory in real time.

Telecommunications 🔗

The telecommunications subsystem includes radio antennas, transmitters, and receivers for communicating with ground stations or other spacecraft.

Electrical Power 🔗

Electric power is supplied by photovoltaic (solar) cells or radioisotope thermoelectric generators, with batteries for storage and distribution circuitry.

Temperature Control and Protection from the Environment 🔗

Spacecraft are protected from temperature fluctuations with insulation, mirrors, and sunshades. Shielding is also used to protect against micrometeoroids and orbital debris.

Propulsion 🔗

Spacecraft propulsion generates thrust for space travel, with various systems including monopropellant, bipropellant, and ion propulsion. Rocket engines are commonly used.

Monopropellant 🔗

Monopropellant propulsion uses a fuel with a chemically bonded oxidizer, requiring only a fuel line and a catalyst for combustion.

Bipropellant 🔗

Bipropellant propulsion uses liquid propellants that spontaneously combust upon contact, offering high density and space efficacy.

Ion 🔗

Ion propulsion generates thrust by electron bombardment or ion acceleration, providing efficient velocity maintenance for deep-space travel.

Mechanical Devices 🔗

Mechanical components are moved for deployment or landing, often controlled by pyrotechnic devices.

Robotic vs. Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

Robotic spacecraft are designed for specific hostile environments, while uncrewed spacecraft operate without personnel via automatic or remote control.

Control 🔗

This section discusses how robotic spacecraft use telemetry to transmit data and status information back to Earth. Early spacecraft lacked remote control, but command systems were later developed. Increased autonomy is crucial for distant probes due to light travel time delays. Probes like Cassini–Huygens and the Mars Exploration Rovers operate autonomously for extended periods.

Space Probes and Observatories 🔗

A space probe is a robotic spacecraft that explores outer space without orbiting Earth. These probes carry scientific instruments and can fly by, orbit, or land on planetary bodies, or even enter interstellar space. Space telescopes or observatories are telescopes in space that avoid atmospheric distortion and light pollution.

Cargo Spacecraft 🔗

Cargo or resupply spacecraft transport supplies to space stations. Automated cargo spacecraft have supported missions to Salyut 6, Salyut 7, Mir, the International Space Station (ISS), and the Tiangong space station. Currently, the ISS relies on Progress, Cargo Dragon 2, and Cygnus spacecraft, while Tiangong is supplied by Tianzhou. The Dream Chaser and HTV-X are under development for future use.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cargo_spacecraft

item.title: Uncrewed spacecraft
item.description:
Uncrewed Spacecraft 🔗

This article discusses spacecraft designed to operate without a human crew on board. These robotic spacecraft can be remotely controlled, guided, or fully autonomous, executing pre-programmed operations. They are often used for scientific measurements, in which case they are called space probes or space observatories.

Key Points:

  • Uncrewed spacecraft offer advantages over crewed missions due to lower costs and reduced risks.
  • They can explore environments too hostile for humans, such as Venus or Jupiter’s vicinity.
  • They allow for the exploration of regions vulnerable to contamination by Earth microorganisms.

History 🔗

This section details the historical development of uncrewed spacecraft, beginning with the first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, launched by the Soviet Union in 1957. It highlights the early competition between the USSR and the United States in space exploration, including the launch of Explorer 1 by the US in 1958. The section also mentions early lunar probes like Luna 1 and planetary probes like Mariner 2 (Venus) and Mariner 4 (Mars). The Voyager 1 probe, launched in 1977, is noted as the first interstellar probe. It also lists the countries that have successfully launched satellites using their own launch vehicles.

Key Events and Missions:

  • 1951: First robotic spacecraft launched by the Soviet Union with dogs Dezik and Tsygan.
  • 1957: Launch of Sputnik 1 (USSR), the first artificial satellite.
  • 1958: Launch of Explorer 1 (US), confirming the existence of the Van Allen belts.
  • 1959: Luna 1 (USSR) orbits the Moon and then the Sun.
  • 1962: Mariner 2 (US) studies Venus.
  • 1965: Mariner 4 (US) flies by Mars and sends back images.
  • 1977: Launch of Voyager 1 (US), the first interstellar probe.
  • 2012: Voyager 1 enters interstellar space.
  • 2018: Voyager 2 enters interstellar space.

Countries Mentioned:

  • Soviet Union (USSR)
  • United States
  • France
  • Japan
  • China
  • United Kingdom
  • India
  • Israel
  • Iran
  • North Korea
  • South Korea

Design 🔗

This section outlines the various subsystems and components that make up an uncrewed spacecraft. It references the United States Air Force’s definition of a spacecraft consisting of a mission payload and a bus (or platform). It also references JPL’s division of a spacecraft’s “flight system” into subsystems.

Subsystems Described:

  • Structure: Provides mechanical integrity and support for components.
  • Data Handling: Manages command sequences, spacecraft clock, telemetry, and mission data.
  • Attitude Determination and Control: Maintains correct orientation in space.
  • Entry, Descent, and Landing: Discusses integrated sensing for safe landing on planetary surfaces, including hazard assessment and avoidance.
  • Telecommunications: Includes radio antennas, transmitters, and receivers for communication.
  • Electrical Power: Describes power sources like solar cells and radioisotope thermoelectric generators.
  • Temperature Control and Protection from the Environment: Discusses insulation, mirrors, sunshades, and shielding from micrometeoroids and orbital debris.
  • Propulsion: Describes methods for spacecraft to travel through space, including monopropellant, bipropellant, and ion propulsion systems.
  • Mechanical Devices: Discusses the use of motors and pyrotechnic devices for deployment and landing.

Key Concepts:

  • Payload
  • Bus (or platform)
  • Telemetry
  • Attitude control
  • Hazard assessment and avoidance
  • Propulsion systems (monopropellant, bipropellant, ion)

Control 🔗

This section explains how robotic spacecraft are controlled, emphasizing the use of telemetry to transmit data and status information back to Earth. It notes that early spacecraft did not receive control signals from Earth, but command systems were later developed. The importance of increased autonomy for distant probes is highlighted, with examples like Cassini–Huygens and the Mars Exploration Rovers.

Key Points:

  • Telemetry is used to transmit data and status information.
  • Early spacecraft lacked remote control capabilities.
  • Increased autonomy is crucial for distant probes due to light travel time delays.

Missions Mentioned:

  • Sputnik 1
  • Explorer 1
  • Cassini–Huygens
  • Mars Exploration Rovers

Space Probes and Observatories 🔗

This section defines space probes as robotic spacecraft that explore outer space beyond Earth orbit. It describes their function of collecting and transmitting data back to Earth, and their various forms, including orbiters, landers, and rovers. It also mentions sample-return missions. The section also defines space telescopes or space observatories as telescopes in outer space used to observe astronomical objects.

Key Points:

  • Space probes explore beyond Earth orbit and transmit data.
  • Space telescopes avoid atmospheric distortion and light pollution.
  • Trajectory planning involves Hohmann transfer orbits and gravitational slingshots.

Cargo Spacecraft 🔗

This section focuses on cargo or resupply spacecraft, which are robotic vehicles designed to transport supplies to space stations. It distinguishes them from space probes, which are primarily for scientific exploration. The section lists several cargo spacecraft that have serviced space stations since 1978, including Progress, Cargo Dragon 2, Cygnus, and Tianzhou.

Key Points:

  • Cargo spacecraft transport supplies to space stations.
  • They are distinct from space probes, which focus on scientific exploration.

Spacecraft Mentioned:

  • Progress (Russia)
  • Cargo Dragon 2 (US)
  • Cygnus (US)
  • Tianzhou (China)
  • Dream Chaser (US - in development)
  • HTV-X (Japan - in development)
  • Automated Transfer Vehicle (Europe - retired)

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” which are names given in ufology to humanoid races purportedly from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones. George Adamski is noted as one of the first to report contact with these beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding them often includes telepathy, benevolence, and physical beauty.

History 🔗

This section discusses the historical context and cultural influences related to the Nordic alien phenomenon. David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” associating Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection. These aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal and youthful. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters became less common as the grey alien archetype rose to prominence.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites). The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends.”

Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” a type of humanoid extraterrestrial beings often discussed in ufology. These beings are said to originate from the Pleiades star cluster and are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans. They are typically depicted as taller than average humans (6-7 ft), with blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention skin tones of pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

George Adamski, a Polish-American ufologist, is noted as one of the first to publicly claim contact with Nordic beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding these beings often includes themes of telepathy, benevolence, beauty, and grace. Telepathy is often described as the primary form of communication.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical context and cultural influences surrounding the Nordic alien narrative.

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories of Nordic-type aliens. The film features an extraterrestrial arriving on Earth to warn humanity about the dangers of atomic weapons.

Bates College professor Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that Nordic aliens are often associated with spiritual growth, love, and protection among believers.

Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

Claims of encounters with Nordic aliens were common in Europe during the 1950s but became less frequent in later decades, as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.
