item.title: 2007 Alderney UFO sighting
item.description:
2007 Alderney UFO sighting 🔗

This article details the reported UFO sighting that occurred on April 23, 2007, over Alderney in the Channel Islands.

Accounts of the sighting 🔗

This section introduces the event, mentioning that a pilot, Ray Bowyer, reported seeing unidentified flying objects. An air traffic controller confirmed that another pilot had reported a similar sighting. Passengers on Bowyer’s aircraft also reported seeing unusual lights. Possible explanations for the sighting, such as earthquake lights and sun dogs, are also mentioned.

Bowyer’s accounts 🔗

This section focuses on the account of Ray Bowyer, the pilot who initially reported the sighting. It details his description of the object as a “cigar-shaped brilliant white light,” initially thought to be reflections from greenhouses. Bowyer’s estimates of the object’s size and distance evolved, eventually describing it as being the size of a Boeing 737, then later as large as five or six battleships or a reasonably large town. The section includes details from a recorded conversation between Bowyer and an air traffic controller, who reported only a faint radar contact. Bowyer’s actions, such as using binoculars to observe the light, and his report to the Civil Aviation Authority are also covered. The Ministry of Defence’s initial reluctance to investigate and subsequent release of information, including a statement from a second pilot, are mentioned.

Other witness accounts 🔗

This section presents accounts from other witnesses to the event. Passengers on Bowyer’s aircraft reported seeing the light, with one describing it as “sunlight-colored” and another as “an orange light … like an elongated oval.” Patrick Patterson, a pilot from Blue Islands, also reported seeing a similar object in the same general location. The section also mentions an interpretation that the sighting was an atmospheric phenomenon.

Proposed explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the UFO sighting. Bowyer rejected the idea that he saw an alien vessel, but considered the possibility of earthquake lights related to the earthquake in south-eastern England that occurred shortly after the sighting. A local astronomer, Michael Maunder, suggested that the sighting could be attributed to sun dogs, an optical phenomenon caused by the refraction of light through ice crystals. He noted that the weather conditions were favorable for sun dogs and that the reported lights were approximately 22 degrees from the sun, consistent with the appearance of sun dogs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Alderney_UFO_sighting

item.title: UFO reports and atomic sites
item.description:
Correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites 🔗

This article explores the historical and statistical connections between reports of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) and locations associated with atomic technology, primarily in the United States. It examines how early speculation linked UFO sightings to atomic sites, the influence of the Cold War, and various incidents and studies that have fueled this correlation.

Background 🔗

This section establishes the context for the link between UFO reports and atomic sites. It highlights the increased scrutiny of US airspace due to national security concerns in 1947, coinciding with increased media coverage of UFO reports. It notes that the development of atomic weapons and long-range vehicles meant that even a small number of adversarial overflights could have significant national security implications.

1940s weapons development 🔗

This section details the development of atomic weapons by the US during World War II as part of the Manhattan Project. Key locations mentioned are Oak Ridge, Tennessee (uranium enrichment), Hanford, Washington (plutonium production), and Los Alamos, New Mexico (bomb design and construction). It also discusses the increased lethality and range of air power during the war and Japan’s deployment of intercontinental balloon bombs, one of which interfered with plutonium production at Hanford. The US’s Project Mogul, inspired by the Japanese balloons, aimed to detect Soviet atomic tests. The section also mentions German advancements in rockets, jet fighters, and bomber designs, which both the US and Soviet governments learned about and utilized after the war.

Increased scrutiny of US airspace 🔗

This section explains how the possibility of a Soviet atomic attack led to increased surveillance of US airspace, particularly around atomic facilities. It mentions the development of the first intercontinental bomber, the Convair B-36 Peacemaker, which could reach the Soviet Union from American soil. Atomic sites were among the first locations in the US to operate radar, supported by visual spotters and fighter squadrons. The start of the Cold War in 1947 influenced media coverage of UFO reports, treating them as potential national security threats rather than folklore or tall tales.

Chronology 🔗

This section presents a timeline of notable UFO incidents and their connection to atomic sites, starting in 1947.

Supposed flying discs allegedly break sound barrier 🔗

This section focuses on the Kenneth Arnold sighting in June 1947, where he reported seeing nine objects flying at supersonic speeds near Mount Rainier and Mount Adams in Washington state. The proximity of this sighting to the Hanford plutonium plant led to media speculation about a connection. The section also notes that the sound barrier was not officially broken until October 1947 by Chuck Yeager, and the Air Force initially denied the achievement.

Roswell and atomic weapons 🔗

This section discusses the Roswell incident in July 1947, where debris was found on a ranch near Corona, New Mexico. The 509th at Roswell was the Army’s atomic bomb group. The initial explanation of a weather balloon was later questioned, and the Air Force eventually concluded the debris came from a Project Mogul balloon designed to detect Soviet atomic tests.

Public claims of link to atomic sites 🔗

This section covers the public’s perception of a link between flying discs and atomic weaponry in 1947. It mentions headlines claiming a connection between “discs” and “atom products,” citing an unnamed scientist from the Manhattan Project who suggested experiments in atomic energy transmutation were responsible for the sightings. The Hanford works were also mentioned as a location with numerous UFO reports. Atomic scientists Harold Urey and David E. Lilienthal dismissed these claims as “gibberish.”

Mantell crash near Oak Ridge 🔗

This section details the Mantell incident in January 1948, where Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a pilot from Fort Knox, Kentucky, crashed while pursuing a UFO near Oak Ridge, Tennessee. The Air Force later attributed the UFO to a Skyhook balloon, a classified project.

Green Fireballs near Hanford 🔗

This section discusses reports of green fireballs near Hanford, Washington, starting in December 1948. It mentions Lincoln LaPaz’s investigation of these reports and the issuance of orders to fire on potentially hostile aircraft over Hanford and Oak Ridge. The section also notes UFO reports over Hanford and Oak Ridge during the early days of the Korean War and a 1952 Life Magazine article reporting unusual radar returns near an atomic installation.

Contactees and nuclear war 🔗

This section discusses the theme of nuclear war in UFO culture. The 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still featured a benevolent spaceman warning about atomic weapons. George Adamski began claiming contact with “space brothers” concerned about atomic weapons.

Big Sur missile test 🔗

This section describes a reported UFO incident during a 1964 Air Force missile test near Big Sur, California. Robert Jacobs, who oversaw the team, claimed a UFO interfered with the test. Kingston George, the project engineer, argued the team had actually recorded the release of decoy warheads and chaff.

Malmstrom missile malfunction 🔗

This section discusses UFO reports over a missile complex in March 1967 during a routine malfunction. Retired Air Force personnel later claimed the weapons failure was caused by a UFO.

Hynek suggests atomic link 🔗

This section notes that astronomer J. Allen Hynek, initially hired by the Air Force to debunk UFO reports, began speculating in 1968 that UFOs might be related to an unknown phenomenon connected to nuclear energy.

Rendelsham 🔗

This section describes the Rendlesham Forest incident in December 1980, a series of reported sightings of unexplained lights near RAF Woodbridge in England, which was used by the United States Air Force (USAF). USAF personnel, including Lieutenant Colonel Charles I. Halt, claimed to see things they described as a UFO.

21st century 🔗

This section covers more recent developments, including a legend that the 1945 Trinity atomic bomb test brought down an alien spacecraft. It mentions Robert Hastings’ book UFOs & Nukes: Extraordinary Encounters at Nuclear Weapons Sites and claims by former AATIP director Luis Elizondo and former U.S. Air Force personnel that UAPs have interfered with nuclear capabilities. It also notes reports of UFOs interfering with other major powers’ nuclear weapons systems. The section mentions the U.S. National Defense Authorization Act requesting more information on UAP incidents associated with military nuclear assets and claims by Robert L. Salas and Robert Hastings of alien abduction. Finally, it mentions that the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission will raise the issue of UAP with its United States counterpart.

Statistical studies 🔗

This section examines the statistical evidence for a correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites, considering the possibility of observational bias.

It introduces the concept of the “streetlight effect,” where observations are more likely to be reported where observations are most likely to occur. Mainstream experts argue that increased scrutiny of airspace around strategically important facilities explains the correlation.

The section mentions a rudimentary spatial analysis conducted by Air Force officers in the 1950s, which found that UFOs were seen more frequently around areas vital to US defense, such as Los Alamos-Albuquerque, Oak Ridge, and White Sands Proving Ground.

A 2015 study of UFO reports in France concluded that there was a statistically significant link between nuclear activities and unexplained UFO reports.

A 2021 document from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence suggested that clustering of UFO reports around US training and testing grounds might be due to “collection bias as a result of focused attention.”

A 2023 study examined a National UFO Reporting Center dataset and found that UFO reports are more frequent in areas with darker nighttime skies and “wide-open spaces.” Additionally, analysis suggested that proximity to airports and military installations was linked to increased UFO reports.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_reports_and_atomic_sites

item.title: European mission to study Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko (2004–2016)
item.description:
European mission to study Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko (2004–2016) 🔗

This section introduces the Rosetta mission, a European Space Agency (ESA) project launched in 2004 to study Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko. It highlights that Rosetta, along with its lander module Philae, conducted a detailed study of the comet. The mission involved flybys of Earth, Mars, and asteroids 21 Lutetia and 2867 Šteins. It was the third cornerstone mission of ESA’s Horizon 2000 program.

Mission overview 🔗

This section provides a summary of the Rosetta mission’s timeline and objectives. Key points include:

  • Launch on March 2, 2004, from the Guiana Space Centre in Kourou, French Guiana, aboard an Ariane 5 rocket.
  • Arrival at Comet Churyumov–Gerasimenko on May 7, 2014, and entering orbit on August 6, 2014, becoming the first spacecraft to orbit a comet.
  • Philae lander’s successful landing on the comet nucleus on November 12, 2014.
  • Loss of communication with Philae due to battery power depletion, with brief restoration in June and July 2015.
  • End of mission on September 30, 2016, with Rosetta hard-landing on the comet.
  • Mention of the European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) in Darmstadt, Germany, as the control center and the European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC) near Madrid, Spain, for scientific payload planning and data management.
  • Estimated involvement of 2,000 people in the mission over a decade.

History 🔗

This section details the background and naming of the Rosetta mission. Key points include:

  • The mission evolved from earlier cooperative efforts between ESA and NASA, including the Comet Rendezvous Asteroid Flyby (CRAF) and Comet Nucleus Sample Return (CNSR) missions.
  • NASA’s cancellation of CRAF led ESA to develop a similar project independently.
  • The mission was redesigned due to budgetary constraints, resembling the cancelled CRAF mission.
  • Gerhard Schwehm was the mission manager until his retirement in March 2014.
  • The mission included generational team management for continuity and knowledge transfer.
  • The probe was named after the Rosetta Stone, and the lander after the Philae obelisk, symbolizing the deciphering of cometary composition.
  • The spacecraft carried a micro-etched nickel prototype of the Rosetta disc with language translations.

Mission firsts 🔗

This section highlights the groundbreaking achievements of the Rosetta mission. Key points include:

  • First European close encounter with asteroids in the asteroid belt.
  • First spacecraft to fly close to Jupiter’s orbit using solar cells as its main power source.
  • First spacecraft to orbit a comet nucleus.
  • First spacecraft to fly alongside a comet as it headed towards the inner Solar System.
  • First controlled touchdown on a comet nucleus by the Philae lander.
  • First images from a comet’s surface and in situ analysis of its composition.

Design and construction 🔗

This section describes the technical aspects of the Rosetta spacecraft. Key points include:

  • The spacecraft’s dimensions, mass, and construction materials.
  • Details about the solar arrays, power generation, and batteries.
  • Information on the propulsion system, including thrusters and propellant.
  • Mention of the clean room construction and COSPAR rules.
  • Total mission cost of about €1.3 billion (US$1.8 billion).

Launch 🔗

This section covers the launch details and trajectory of the Rosetta spacecraft. Key points include:

  • Initial launch plan for January 12, 2003, targeting comet 46P/Wirtanen, which was abandoned due to an Ariane 5 ECA failure.
  • Revised plan to target comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko, with a launch date of February 26, 2004.
  • Successful launch on March 2, 2004, from the Guiana Space Centre using an Ariane 5 G+ rocket.
  • Presence of Klim Churyumov and Svetlana Gerasimenko, the co-discoverers of the comet, at the launch.

Deep space manoeuvres 🔗

This section details the gravity assist maneuvers used by Rosetta to reach its target. Key points include:

  • Use of gravity assist maneuvers to accelerate throughout the inner Solar System.
  • First Earth flyby on March 4, 2005.
  • Low-altitude flyby of Mars on February 25, 2007, which involved a risky period in the planet’s shadow.
  • Second Earth flyby on November 13, 2007, during which Rosetta was briefly mistaken for a near-Earth asteroid.
  • Flyby of asteroid 2867 Šteins on September 5, 2008.
  • Third and final Earth flyby on November 12, 2009.
  • Flyby of asteroid 21 Lutetia on July 10, 2010.
  • Series of eight burns in May 2014 to reduce the relative velocity between the spacecraft and 67P.

Reaction control system problems 🔗

This section describes technical issues encountered during the mission. Key points include:

  • A leak in the reaction control system (RCS) in 2006, causing lower operating pressure.
  • Increased levels of “bearing friction noise” in two of the spacecraft’s four reaction wheels.
  • Efforts to relubricate the reaction wheels and manage their operating temperatures and speed ranges.
  • Development of new on-board software to allow Rosetta to operate with only two active reaction wheels if necessary.

Orbit around 67P 🔗

This section details Rosetta’s orbital maneuvers around comet 67P. Key points include:

  • Rendezvous with comet 67P in August 2014.
  • Series of maneuvers to establish triangular paths around the nucleus.
  • Entry into orbit about the comet on September 10, 2014.
  • Mapping of the comet’s surface to determine a landing site for Philae.
  • Selection of Site J, named Agilkia, as the lander’s destination.

Philae lander 🔗

This section focuses on the Philae lander’s mission. Key points include:

  • Philae’s detachment from Rosetta on November 12, 2014, and approach to 67P.
  • Initial landing at 15:33 UTC, followed by two bounces and final settling at 17:33 UTC.
  • Failure of harpoons to fire upon landing.
  • Philae’s science mission objectives, including characterization of the nucleus and determination of chemical compounds.
  • Philae settling in the shadow of a cliff, leading to inadequate solar power collection and loss of contact after three days.
  • Brief reestablishment of contact several months later, followed by permanent loss of communication.
  • Discovery of the lander’s precise location in September 2016 through high-resolution images.

Notable results 🔗

This section highlights some of the significant scientific findings from the mission. Key points include:

  • Discovery that the magnetic field of 67P oscillated at 40–50 millihertz.
  • Determination that the comet’s nucleus has no magnetic field, with the detected field likely caused by the solar wind.
  • Isotopic signature of water vapor from comet 67P being substantially different from that found on Earth.
  • Increase in the rate at which water vapor was released by the comet between June and August 2014.
  • Determination that electrons, not direct photons, are responsible for the degradation of water and carbon dioxide molecules in the comet’s coma.

End of mission 🔗

This section describes the conclusion of the Rosetta mission. Key points include:

  • Decision to guide Rosetta down to the comet’s surface due to decreasing sunlight reaching the solar panels.
  • Announcement that the end of mission would occur at the end of September 2016.
  • Descent maneuver initiated on September 29, 2016, targeting a site in the Ma’at region.
  • Impact on the comet’s surface on September 30, 2016, with the final data packet transmitted at 10:39:28.895 UTC.
  • Estimated speed at the time

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosetta_(spacecraft)

item.title: Contact (1985 novel)
item.description:
Contact (1985 novel) 🔗

This article provides information about Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel, Contact. It distinguishes the novel from other works with the same title.

Plot 🔗

The plot centers around Eleanor “Ellie” Arroway, a scientist with a strong aptitude for science and mathematics. Her father’s death deeply affects her, and she finds herself at odds with her stepfather. Ellie pursues a career in radio astronomy, eventually directing Project Argus, a SETI initiative in New Mexico.

The project detects a signal from Vega, which is analyzed and found to contain a retransmission of Hitler’s 1936 Olympic speech. Later, a third message reveals plans for an advanced machine. Ellie works with Ken der Heer and Vaygay Lunacharsky to decipher the message. Religious leaders Billy Jo Rankin and Palmer Joss also become involved. The final piece of the message is discovered with the help of S.R. Hadden, revealing the primer needed to build the machine.

A race to build the machine ensues between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. An extremist bombing delays the project. Ellie learns Hadden has secretly built a third machine in Hokkaido, Japan. Ellie, Vaygay, Devi Sukhavati, Abonnema Eda, and Xi Qiaomu travel through wormholes to a station near the Milky Way’s center. There, they meet extraterrestrials who explain their motives and a project to alter the universe’s properties.

Upon returning to Earth, the travelers find their journey seemingly took no time at all. Their video recordings are erased, and officials suspect a hoax. Ellie finds evidence of her journey in the digits of pi, confirming the reality of her experience.

Publication history 🔗

As a child, Sagan was inspired by science fiction and fantasy. He preferred realistic stories that helped readers understand real science and history. In 1978, Sagan predicted that science fiction would make young people interested in extraterrestrial contact. Simon & Schuster gave Sagan a $2 million advance on the novel in 1981. Kip Thorne provided Sagan with ideas on wormholes. Eleanor Arroway was named after Eleanor Roosevelt and Voltaire. The character is based on Jill Tarter. The novel won the Locus Award for Best First Novel in 1986.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related topics, including communication with extraterrestrial intelligence, the Fermi paradox, and His Master’s Voice.

Notes 🔗

This section clarifies two points related to the plot. The first note explains why a sequence of prime numbers is a predicted first message from alien intelligence. The second note updates the distance to Vega based on measurements from the Hipparcos satellite.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books and articles by Carl Sagan, Keay Davidson, and Jennifer Spence. It also includes links to online resources, such as Warner Bros.’ website and Space.com.

Sources 🔗

This section provides a list of sources used in the creation of the article, including books by Keay Davidson and Carl Sagan, as well as an archived webpage by Jennifer Spence.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to Larry Klaes’ in-depth analysis of the film and novel.

Carl Sagan Template 🔗

This template provides links to various aspects of Carl Sagan’s life and work, including his scientific career, books, media appearances, family, prizes, and related topics.

Locus Award Template 🔗

This template provides links to the winners of the Locus Award for Best First Novel from 1980 to 2024, as well as links to other Locus Awards categories.

Authority control databases 🔗

This section lists links to various authority control databases, including VIAF, United States Library of Congress, Israel National Library, and MusicBrainz.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_(novel)

item.title: First contact (science fiction)
item.description:
First Contact (Science Fiction) 🔗

First contact is a recurring theme in science fiction, exploring the initial meeting between humans and extraterrestrial life or any sentient species from different planets or natural satellites. It draws parallels with the anthropological concept of first contact.

History 🔗

The concept dates back to the 2nd century AD with Lucian of Samosata’s A True Story. Voltaire’s Le Micromégas (1752) features an alien from Sirius visiting Earth and engaging in philosophical discussions with humans. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds is traditionally credited with popularizing the trope of conflict between humans and alien intelligent species, although earlier examples exist, such as Les Xipéhuz.

The 1950s saw a surge in first contact stories in the United States, often reflecting Cold War anxieties about nuclear holocaust or communist invasion. Films like The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) began to portray first contact as potentially beneficial, while Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) reflected fears of communist infiltration.

Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End depicts both positive and negative consequences of first contact, while Stanisław Lem’s Solaris explores the futility of communication with extraterrestrial intelligence.

The Star Trek franchise introduced the Prime Directive, a non-interference regulation, which has since become a common trope in science fiction.

Later works include Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Carl Sagan’s Contact (1985), and novels like The Sparrow (1996) and The Three-Body Problem (2006). Films like Arrival (2016) focus on the linguistic challenges of first contact. Project Hail Mary (2021) depicts an unintended first contact scenario.

Types and Themes 🔗

First contact stories vary widely in their methods of contact and the nature of the subsequent interaction. These variations include positive vs. negative outcomes, physical meetings vs. message interception, and more.

Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion is a common early trope, popularized by The War of the Worlds. During the Cold War, these stories often reflected American anxieties about the Soviet Union, with infiltration narratives being a variation on the theme.

Alien Artifacts 🔗

Bracewell probes, hypothesized by Ronald N. Bracewell, are extraterrestrial artifacts that allow real-time communication. Big Dumb Objects, such as megastructures like ringworlds, are a common variation. 2001: A Space Odyssey features mysterious black Monoliths that enhance technological progress. Stories also involve finding alien spacecraft, such as in Rendezvous with Rama.

Communication with Alien Intelligence 🔗

Many stories deal with the challenges of communication. Stanisław Lem’s works often portray mutual understanding between humans and aliens as impossible, criticizing the idea of cognitive universality.

Message from Space 🔗

First contact may occur through the detection of an extraterrestrial signal or technosignature. The search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) began with the advent of radio.

Alien Languages 🔗

Languages are a common form of communication with aliens, and many stories explore language issues. While space operas often use universal translators, hard science fiction typically depicts the difficulties of communicating with aliens, which can lead to misunderstandings and even war.

Ethics of First Contact 🔗

Many writers have considered how humans should treat aliens upon first contact. The Prime Directive of Star Trek is a notable example of non-interference. In Soviet science fiction, “progressors” worked clandestinely to improve less advanced civilizations.

Notable Examples 🔗

The Day the Earth Stood Still 🔗

Based on the short story “Farewell to the Master,” The Day the Earth Stood Still depicts the arrival of Klaatu and Gort in Washington, D.C. Humanity’s hostile response to first contact is used as an allegory for the Second Red Scare.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind 🔗

This 1977 film by Steven Spielberg tells the story of Roy Neary, whose life changes after an encounter with a UFO. The film was deemed “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant” by the Library of Congress.

Contact 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel, later adapted into a film, depicts the reception of a radio signal from Vega and the construction of a Machine based on the message’s specifications.

Star Trek 🔗

First contact is central to Starfleet operations in the Star Trek franchise. The Prime Directive is a foundational regulation, though it is frequently violated.

Star Trek: The Original Series 🔗

The original pilot episode features the Talosians. The Prime Directive was introduced in “The Return of the Archons” to prevent negative consequences from contact with technologically inferior societies.

Star Trek: The Next Generation 🔗

The pilot episode, “Encounter at Farpoint,” depicts first contact with the Q Continuum. Episodes like “Who Watches the Watchers” and “First Contact” center on the Prime Directive.

Star Trek: First Contact 🔗

This 1996 film portrays first contact between humans and Vulcans, leading to the formation of the United Federation of Planets.

The War of the Worlds 🔗

H.G. Wells’ novel details a conflict between humankind and Martians. It has been adapted into numerous films, radio dramas, and other media. The 1938 radio drama, directed by Orson Welles, reportedly caused panic among listeners.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(science_fiction)

item.title: Potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact
item.description:
Cultural Impact of Extraterrestrial Contact 🔗

This article explores the potential changes to human society, science, technology, religion, politics, and ecosystems that could result from contact with an extraterrestrial civilization. It emphasizes that the nature and magnitude of these changes would depend on factors such as the extraterrestrial civilization’s technological advancement, intentions (benevolent or malevolent), and the level of mutual understanding between the two species. The article also draws parallels to historical encounters between vastly different human cultures on Earth, such as the Columbian Exchange, and encounters between native and invasive species.

Background 🔗

This section sets the stage by introducing the concept of the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) and its relationship to analyzing the implications of contact. It highlights that SETI focuses on locating intelligent life, while this article focuses on the potential consequences of such contact. It acknowledges that tragic consequences are largely speculative due to the absence of verified public contact to date.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence 🔗

This section details the efforts to detect extraterrestrial civilizations using radio telescopes. It mentions the challenge of identifying artificial signals against the background of natural radio waves. Key locations and projects mentioned include the Allen Telescope Array in Hat Creek, California, the Five hundred meter Aperture Spherical Telescope (FAST) in China, the now-demolished Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico, Project Cyclops commissioned by NASA, and Messaging to Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence (METI). The section also discusses the discovery of numerous extrasolar planets, including potentially habitable ones like Kepler-22b, and the renewed government interest in funding SETI programs, such as the European Space Agency’s COROT and NASA’s Kepler space observatory. Projects like A Message From Earth (AMFE) and SETILive are also mentioned, along with alternative search methods like SEVENDIP at the University of California, Berkeley. The section concludes by acknowledging that while several signals, such as the Wow! signal, have been detected, none have been confirmed as being of intelligent origin.

Impact Assessment 🔗

This section discusses methods for assessing the potential impact of extraterrestrial contact. It introduces the Rio scale, which provides a quantitative picture of the results of extraterrestrial contact based on factors such as the method of discovery, the information content of messages, and the nature of the extraterrestrial beings. The section also mentions a study by astronomer Steven J. Dick at the United States Naval Observatory, which analyzes events of similar significance in the history of science to predict the cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact. The study argues that the impact would be most strongly influenced by the information content of the message received and distinguishes between short-term and long-term impacts. The section also discusses the importance of physical distance between civilizations, with closer contact likely to be more disruptive. It also mentions a poll of United States and Chinese university students in 2000, which provides factor analysis of responses to questions about the participants’ belief that extraterrestrial life exists in the Universe, that such life may be intelligent, and that humans will eventually make contact with it. The section concludes by mentioning a survey by psychologists Douglas Vakoch and Yuh-shiow Lee to assess people’s reactions to receiving a message from extraterrestrials, including their judgments about likelihood that extraterrestrials would be malevolent.

Post-Detection Protocols 🔗

This section outlines the protocols that have been developed to guide scientists and governments in the event of extraterrestrial contact. It emphasizes that these protocols are not legally binding and are likely to be ignored if contact occurs. The section mentions the “Declaration of Principles for Activities Following the Detection of Extraterrestrial Intelligence,” created by the SETI Permanent Committee of the International Academy of Astronautics (IAA) and endorsed by various international scientific unions. The Declaration of Principles contains broad provisions, including verification of the signal’s intelligent origin, communication with other signatories of the Declaration, informing national authorities, informing the astronomical community, making news of the discovery public, publishing all data, minimizing terrestrial use of the electromagnetic frequency bands, and not responding to the signal without international agreement. The section also mentions a separate “Proposed Agreement on the Sending of Communications to Extraterrestrial Intelligence,” which proposes an international commission to decide whether to send a message and determine its contents. The section concludes by noting that Paul Davies, a member of the SETI Post-Detection Taskgroup, believes that post-detection protocols are unlikely to be followed by astronomers.

Contact Scenarios and Considerations 🔗

This section explores various models of interaction between extraterrestrial and human civilizations, ranging from beneficial collaborations to hostile subjugation. It highlights the importance of the extraterrestrial civilization’s level of aggressiveness, ethics, and biological compatibility with humans. The section also considers whether contact is via signals or physical probes, and the impact of mutual comprehension.

Friendly Civilizations 🔗

This section discusses potential interactions with benevolent extraterrestrial civilizations. It mentions Albert Harrison, a professor emeritus of psychology at the University of California, Davis, who suggests that advanced civilizations might share knowledge such as a physical theory of everything, zero-point energy, or faster-than-light travel. The section also mentions Seth D. Baum, of the Global Catastrophic Risk Institute, who suggests that cooperative civilizations are more likely to aid humanity. In contrast, Paolo Musso, a member of the SETI Permanent Study Group of the International Academy of Astronautics (IAA) and the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, takes the view that extraterrestrial civilizations possess, like humans, a morality driven not entirely by altruism but for individual benefit as well, thus leaving open the possibility that at least some extraterrestrial civilizations are hostile. The section also discusses Allen Tough’s suggestions for how a friendly civilization might help humanity, including intervention to avert catastrophe, advice and action with consent, and forcible corrective action. The section concludes by noting that even with friendly contact, humans could suffer from a loss of identity and confidence, and that a friendly civilization may avoid contact altogether to allow natural development, known as the zoo hypothesis.

Hostile Civilizations 🔗

This section explores the potential dangers of contact with aggressive extraterrestrial civilizations. It notes that while science fiction often depicts humans successfully repelling alien invasions, scientists generally believe that a technologically advanced civilization could easily destroy human civilization. The section mentions operations that are enormous on a human scale, such as destroying all major population centers on a planet, bombarding a planet with deadly neutron radiation, or even traveling to another planetary system in order to lay waste to it, may be important tools for a hostile civilization. The section also discusses the views of Carl Sagan, who believed that a civilization capable of interstellar travel would have transcended war, and Seth Shostak, who argues that limited resources would cultivate aggression. Ragbir Bhathal claims that an extremely advanced extraterrestrial civilization may have the motivation to colonize humanity in a similar manner to the European colonization of much of the rest of the world. The section also mentions David Brin, who states that while an extraterrestrial civilization may have an imperative to act for no benefit to itself, it would be naïve to suggest that such a trait would be prevalent throughout the galaxy. The section concludes by noting that humans may be an unsuitable food source for extraterrestrials due to biochemical differences, and that transmitting intentional signals may not increase the risk of invasion, as any civilization capable of interstellar travel could already detect Earth’s accidental radio leakage.

Equally Advanced and More Advanced Civilizations 🔗

This section examines the implications of contact with civilizations of similar or greater technological advancement. It mentions Robert Freitas’ speculation that the technological advancement and energy usage of a civilization, measured by its rating on the Kardashev scale, may play an important role in the result of extraterrestrial contact. The section also discusses Ben Finney’s comparison of the situation to the cargo cults of New Guinea, where indigenous people misunderstood European technology. The section concludes by noting that John Billingham suggests that a civilization which is far more technologically advanced than humanity is also likely to be culturally and ethically advanced, and would therefore be unlikely to conduct astroengineering projects that would harm human civilization.

Interstellar Groups of Civilizations 🔗

This section explores the possibility of “galactic clubs,” groupings of civilizations from across the galaxy. It mentions Albert Harrison’s surmise that such clubs might exist, beginning as loose confederations and eventually developing into powerful unions. The section also discusses Sebastian von Hoerner’s suggestion that entry into a galactic club may be a way for humanity to handle the culture shock arising from contact with an advanced extraterrestrial civilization. The section concludes by noting that Michael A. G. Michaud suggests that an interstellar grouping of civilizations might take the form of an empire, which need not necessarily be a force for evil, but may provide for peace and security throughout its jurisdiction.

Extraterrestrial Artifacts 🔗

This section discusses the possibility of extraterrestrial civilizations communicating through artifacts or probes rather than radio. It notes that probes can hold sustained dialogues and perform surveillance, and that Allen Tough speculates that the enormous amount of energy required to achieve such speeds under currently proposed mechanisms means that robotic probes traveling at conventional speeds will still have an advantage for various applications. The section also mentions Robert Freitas’ reasons why interstellar probes may be a preferred method of communication, including the ability to survey non-intelligent populations, store information for long timescales, and emit strong, unambiguous signals. The section concludes by noting that given the age of the Milky Way galaxy, an ancient extraterrestrial civilization may have existed and sent probes to the Solar System millions or even billions of years before the evolution of Homo sapiens.

Further Implications of Contact 🔗

This section explores the potential theological, political, legal, scientific, technological, ethical, ecological, and biological-warfare impacts of extraterrestrial contact.

Theological 🔗

This section discusses the
