item.title: Nazi UFOs
item.description:
Conspiracy theories alleging connections between UFOs and Nazi Germany 🔗

This article explores the conspiracy theories linking UFOs to Nazi Germany, asserting that the Nazis attempted to develop advanced aircraft and spacecraft before and during World War II. It further claims that these craft survived in secret underground bases in Antarctica, South America, or the United States, along with their creators.

Early UFOs as possible Nazi technology 🔗

This section discusses how unusual aerial sightings during and after World War II were initially attributed to novel Nazi technology. During the Cold War, speculation arose that the Soviets might be deploying captured or reverse-engineered Nazi technology.

Foo fighters 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis personnel witnessed unusual aerial phenomena called “foo fighters.” While some reports were dismissed as misperceptions, others were taken seriously, leading scientists like Luis Alvarez to investigate. Allied intelligence suspected some foo fighters were advanced German aircraft or weapons, given Germany’s technological innovations like V-1 and V-2 missiles and the Me 262 jet fighter.

Ghost rockets 🔗

In 1946, rocket- or missile-shaped UFOs, known as “ghost rockets,” were sighted primarily in Sweden and nearby countries. Finnish observers made the first reports in February 1946. Investigations suggested some sightings were meteors, but others displayed characteristics inconsistent with meteors, such as maneuverability. It was initially believed that the ghost rockets originated from the former German rocket facility at Peenemünde and were Soviet tests of captured German missiles.

Flying discs 🔗

Following Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting of crescent-shaped objects, speculation about German technology resurfaced. Project Sign personnel noted similarities between the Horten brothers’ flying wing designs and some UFO reports. Edward J. Ruppelt, the first head of Project Blue Book, noted that the Germans had several radical aircraft and guided missiles under development at the end of WWII.

The earliest media assertion of German flying saucers appeared in the Italian newspaper Il Giornale d’Italia in 1950. Professor Giuseppe Belluzzo claimed that flying discs were designed and studied in Germany and Italy as early as 1942.

In the same month, German technician Rudolf Schriever claimed to Der Spiegel that he designed a craft powered by rotating turbine blades while working at BMW’s Prague works until April 1945. He said his designs were stolen, and he believed Czech agents built his craft for a foreign power.

In 1953, German engineer Georg Klein claimed that designs similar to Avro Canada’s Avrocar had been developed during the Nazi era. Klein identified two types of supposed German flying disks: one developed by Richard Miethe in Breslau and another developed by Rudolf Schriever and Klaus Habermohl in Prague.

Aeronautical engineer Roy Fedden stated in 1945 that the only craft that could approach the capabilities attributed to flying saucers were those being designed by the Germans towards the end of the war.

Nazi UFO conspiracy theories 🔗

By the 1960s, fringe authors began circulating tales of Nazi UFOs tied to the occult or aliens. These theories reference various potential code-names or sub-classifications of Nazi UFO craft.

German UFO literature often aligns with documented history regarding Nazi Germany’s claim to New Swabia in Antarctica and its research into advanced propulsion technology.

The Morning of the Magicians 🔗

Le Matin des Magiciens, a 1960 book by Louis Pauwels and Jacques Bergier, made claims about the Vril Society of Berlin. Later writers, including Jan van Helsing, Norbert-Jürgen Ratthofer, and Vladimir Terziski, connected the Vril Society with UFOs, claiming the society contacted an alien race and developed spacecraft to reach them. They allege that the Vril Society, in partnership with the Thule Society and the Nazi Party, developed flying disc prototypes and retreated to a base in Antarctica after the Nazi defeat.

The works of Ernst Zündel 🔗

Ernst Zündel’s Samisdat Publishers claimed that flying saucers were Nazi secret weapons launched from an underground base in Antarctica, aiming to conquer Earth and other planets. Zündel also sold seats on an exploration team to locate the polar entrance to the hollow earth.

Miguel Serrano’s book 🔗

In 1978, Miguel Serrano published El Cordón Dorado: Hitlerismo Esotérico, claiming that Adolf Hitler was an Avatar of Vishnu communing with Hyperborean gods in an underground Antarctic base in New Swabia. Serrano predicted that Hitler would lead a fleet of UFOs from the base to establish the Fourth Reich.

Die Glocke 🔗

Die Glocke (“The Bell”) was a purported top-secret Nazi scientific technological device or Wunderwaffe. First described by Igor Witkowski in Prawda o Wunderwaffe (2000) and popularized by Nick Cook, it was associated with Nazi occultism, antigravity, and free energy suppression research. Claims about Die Glocke have been criticized as fictional and a hoax.

In popular culture 🔗

This section lists examples of Nazi UFOs appearing in popular culture, including:

  • Robert A. Heinlein’s Rocket Ship Galileo (1947) featuring a Nazi Moon base.
  • The video game Medal of Honor: Frontline (2002) featuring a Nazi UFO.
  • The movie Iron Sky (2012) featuring a Nazi base on the moon launching an assault on Earth with flying saucers.
  • Revell releasing a scale model kit of a Nazi flying saucer called “Haunebu II” (2018), which was later removed from production due to historical inaccuracies.
  • The video game Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus (2017) featuring “Haunebu-V” craft manufactured in Nazi-controlled Roswell, New Mexico.
  • The Commando Comic Flight of Fancy (2017) featuring the Schriever Flugkreisel.
  • The second season finale of 30 Coins (2023) mentioning Haunebu UFOs as copies of Nazca UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_UFOs

item.title: List of alien races in Marvel Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in Marvel Comics 🔗

This document provides a comprehensive list of alien races that appear in Marvel Comics. It is organized alphabetically and includes both major and secondary races, along with their key characteristics and appearances.

Contents 🔗

This section simply lists the letters of the alphabet, serving as a quick index to find alien races by their starting letter.

Overview 🔗

This section establishes that the Marvel Comics universe contains a vast number of extraterrestrial races, most of which are humanoid.

Galactic Council 🔗

This section introduces the Galactic Council, an assembly of leaders from various alien empires. It was created to address universal matters.

Current members 🔗

This lists the current members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from the Kree/Skrull Alliance (Kl’rt/Paibok), Shi’ar Empire (Oracle-2/Izzy Kane), Utopian Kree (Noh-Varr), Earth/Nova Corps (Richard Rider), Spartax (Empress Victoria/Peter Quill), Rigellians (Mentacle), Kymellians (Nymbis Sternhoof), Wakanda (Riitho), Galactic Rim Collective (Zoralis Gupa/Orbis Stellaris), Badoon Sisterhood (Lani Ko Ako), Chitauri Empire (Peacebringer), and Zn’rx Empire (Empress Kuga).

Former members 🔗

This lists former members of the Galactic Council, including representatives from Asgard (Freyja), Brotherhood of the Badoon (Y-Gaaar), Kree Empire (Supreme Intelligence/Ronan the Accuser), Negative Zone (Annihilus), Axi-Tun (Alberik), Shi’ar Empire (Majestor/Lilandra), Badoon (Manat), Brood (Brood Queen), Inhuman Royal Family (Gorgon/Medusa/Crystal/Karnak), Ruul/Kree Empire (Kronaster Sintariis), Kree/Skrull Alliance (Captain Val-Lorr), Krylorians (Bartos), Kymellians (Fayrelyte Strongheart), Negative Zone (Blastaar), Planet X (Groot), Rigellians (Nelet Pa), Skrull Empire (Kreddik), Sneepers (Dibdeb), Stonians (Basaltar), Wobbow (Wibbow), Spartax (J’son), Zn’rx (Emperor Stote), and Chitauri (Peacemaker).

In other media 🔗

This section notes the Galactic Council’s appearance in the Guardians of the Galaxy animated series, with members including J’son, Thor, Irani Rael, the Rigellian Grand Commissioner, and the Supreme Intelligence.

Major races 🔗

This section introduces alien races that have had significant presence in Marvel Comics publications, including major crossovers and storylines.

Badoon 🔗

The Badoon are reptilian aliens known for strict gender segregation, resulting in the Brotherhood of Badoon (ruled by a “Brother Royal”) and the Sisterhood of Badoon (ruled by a Queen). They first appeared in Silver Surfer #2.

Beyonders 🔗

The Beyonders are enigmatic, virtually omnipotent entities powerful enough to collect planets. They cannot leave their dimension and operate through agents. The Beyonder is the most notable member. They were first mentioned in Marvel Two-in-One #63.

Brood 🔗

The Brood are a race of insectoid, parasitic, extraterrestrial beings. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #155.

Celestials 🔗

The Celestials have existed since near the birth of the universe. They first appeared in The Eternals #1.

Chitauri 🔗

The Chitauri are aliens similar to the Skrulls in the Ultimate Marvel universe. They have since been established in the main Marvel Universe. They first appeared in The Ultimates #8.

Cotati 🔗

The Cotati are a race of highly intelligent, telepathic plants originating on Hala, the same planet as the Kree. They first appeared in The Avengers #133.

Dire Wraiths 🔗

The Dire Wraiths are an evolutionary offshoot of the Skrulls from the Andromeda Galaxy. Like the Skrulls, they are shapeshifters. They first appeared in Rom the Spaceknight #1.

Kree 🔗

The Kree are a scientifically and technologically advanced militaristic alien race native to the planet Hala. They were the rivals of the Skrulls. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #65.

Phalanx 🔗

The Phalanx are a cybernetic species that form a hive-mind. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men #305.

Shi’ar 🔗

The Shi’ar are alien humanoids of avian descent residing in the Shi’ar Empire. Their empire is a vast collection of alien species, cultures, and worlds. They first appeared in X-Men #97.

Skrulls 🔗

The Skrulls are a race of shapeshifting aliens originating from the planet Skrullos. They were the rivals of the Kree. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #2.

Symbiotes 🔗

The Symbiotes are amorphous extraterrestrial parasites that envelop their hosts like costumes, creating a symbiotic bond. They are also known as the Klyntar. They first appeared in Secret Wars #8.

Watchers 🔗

The Watchers are the first humanoid race created in the Marvel Universe. They observe and compile knowledge on all aspects of the universe but have vowed not to interfere. Uatu is the most known Watcher. They first appeared in Fantastic Four #13.

Secondary races 🔗

This section lists a multitude of other extraterrestrial races that have appeared in Marvel Comics, though not as prominently as the major races.

A 🔗

This section lists alien races starting with the letter “A”.

A’askvarii 🔗

The A’askvarii are a green-skinned humanoid race with octopus traits from the oceanic planet O’erlanii. They first appeared in Black Goliath.

A-Chiltarians 🔗

The A-Chiltarians are a purple-grey furred humanoid race with many eyes from the marshy planet A-Chiltar III. Kraglin is an A-Chiltarian. They first appeared in Tales to Astonish.

Aakon 🔗

The Aakon are a yellow-skinned, dark-haired humanoid race and enemies of the Kree. They are allied with the Shadow Consortium. They first appeared in Captain Marvel.

Acanti 🔗

The Acanti are a race of space creatures that resemble whales. They first appeared in The Uncanny X-Men.

Achernonians 🔗

The Achernonians are a purple-skinned humanoid race from the rocky planet Achernon. They are depicted as superstitious and have a dictatorial government. Some can become immaterial. They first appeared in Thor.

Aedians 🔗

The Aedians are thin humanoid bipeds with elongated craniums and no noses. They possess telepathic and empathic powers and can project their astral selves. They first appeared in Silver Surfer.

Agullo 🔗

The Agullo are an alien race that was diminished from over 60,000,000 to a few thousands after Thanos came to their planet Ahl-Agullo.

Alpha Centaurians 🔗

The Alpha Centaurians are a humanoid race with grey scales adapted for underwater living from the planet Arima. They have a feudal government and are capable of near-lightspeed travel. They first appeared in Sub-Mariner.

Amebids 🔗

The Amebids are a race of jellyfish-like aliens that come from the planet Sakaar.

Annunaki 🔗

The Annunaki are an alien race that helped Silver Surfer gather and protect some of Earth’s most extraordinary gifted children.

Archeopians 🔗

The Archeopians are from the planet Archeopia. Most of the race was killed when the incubator cube of Galactus was opened and he consumed Archeopia.

Arcturans 🔗

The Arcturans are a pink-white skinned humanoid race from Arcturus IV. A significant portion of their population are mutants. Starhawk and Aleta are Arcturans. They first appeared in Fear.

Aris 🔗

The Aris are an alien race that comes from the planet Ariston.

Arthrosians 🔗

The Arthrosians are a race of insectoids that come from the planet Anthros in the Negative Zone. Annihilus is an Arthrosian.

Aspirants 🔗

The Aspirants are a race of celestial beings that were the result of the First Firmament’s loneliness.

Astrans 🔗

The Astrans are a yellow-skinned humanoid race with flat feet from the planet Astra. They can control metal and are mostly priests or artists. They first appeared in The Incredible Hulk.

Astrans in other media 🔗

The Astrans appear in Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Ataraxians 🔗

The Ataraxians are a race of aliens from the planet Ataraxia in the Negative Zone.

Autocrons 🔗

The Autocrons are a blue-black skinned humanoid race with iron-based bodies from the planet Cron. They possess superhuman strength and durability and have an imperialistic, militaristic culture ruled by a world-computer

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_alien_races_in_Marvel_Comics

item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology 🔗

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology posits that psychological and social factors best explain some UFO reports. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH). This perspective is favored by UFO researchers in the UK, including David Clarke and Hilary Evans, and in France, following Michel Monnerie’s 1977 book. PSH researchers distinguish themselves from debunkers by maintaining a serious, albeit skeptical, interest in UFOs. The hypothesis suggests that mundane explanations combined with emotional climates distort perceptions, and that claims of contact with extraterrestrials from uninhabitable planets point to psychological processes like dreams and hallucinations.

Origin 🔗

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, with Jacques Scornaux and Peter Rogerson’s article in Magonia. Scornaux’s use of the term originated from French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift from paranormal explanations to normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers for Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, noting the failure of the ETH to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to believe that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos 🔗

Bertrand Méheust’s discovery of parallels between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature led to a study of the science fiction aspects of UFO mythology. Méheust found numerous parallels, including wondrous effects and humanoid motives. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis into a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural back-stories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids. Other studies explore science fictional saucer esoterica along psychosocial and historical lines.

The Saucer Rumor 🔗

The mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports was addressed by Martin Kottmeyer, who discovered that Kenneth Arnold’s initial sighting in 1947 was misinterpreted. Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion, rather than their shape, led to the “flying saucer” label. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences. Kottmeyer’s findings, first reported in 1988, suggest a cultural origin for the flying saucer phenomenon. The principal counterargument is that flying saucers were seen before Kenneth Arnold’s story, but Kottmeyer argues that the dominance of the saucer shape after 1947 is the key issue.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms 🔗

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Roger Sandell’s work on a 1905 Welsh UFO outbreak revealed odd facets and high strangeness material. Nigel Watson reported on a 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were catalogued from various locations, involving cigar-shaped craft and rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung 🔗

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work for the PSH. Jung’s use of synchronicity has also led some to see him as a proponent of paranormal explanations. While Jung acknowledged the possibility of some UFOs being physical objects, he clarified that he was uncommitted on the issue of their reality. He expressed concern that news affirming the existence of UFOs was more welcome than skepticism.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_hypothesis

item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology 🔗

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology suggests that some UFO reports are best explained by psychological or social factors rather than extraterrestrial origins. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH) and is favored by UFO researchers in the UK and France. Proponents view UFOs as an interesting subject for study, even with skepticism.

Origin 🔗

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, influenced by French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Magonia magazine played a key role in popularizing the term. Peter Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift away from paranormal explanations towards normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers associated with Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, driven by the belief that it failed to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to conclude that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos 🔗

Bertrand Méheust’s study of science fiction parallels to UFO mythology revealed numerous similarities between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature. These parallels include wondrous effects like invisible force-fields, teleportation, and engine-stopping rays, as well as humanoid motives for visiting Earth. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis with a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural backstories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids.

The Saucer Rumor 🔗

The psychosocial approach helped solve the mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports. Martin Kottmeyer discovered that the “flying saucer” label originated from a misinterpretation of Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting. Arnold described the objects’ motion as erratic, “like a saucer if you skip it across the water,” but the reporter misinterpreted this as describing the objects’ shape. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms 🔗

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Nigel Watson researched a March–May 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were cataloged in various locations, often accompanied by rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of rapid social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung 🔗

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work of the PSH. While some argue that Jung also considered the ETH, Jung himself refuted claims that he believed UFOs were physically real. He emphasized the psychological significance of the UFO phenomenon, regardless of its objective reality.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they are portrayed in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It includes a link to a separate article listing alleged extraterrestrial beings. A banner at the top indicates that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and needs more citations.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from antiquity and progressing through modern times.

Antiquity 🔗

This subsection covers early depictions of extraterrestrials, beginning with Lucian’s 2nd-century satire True History, where the protagonist visits the Moon and finds it inhabited by warring factions. It emphasizes how early concepts of extraterrestrials were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed aliens as human-like, as exemplified by Voltaire’s Micromégas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac.

Early 20th Century 🔗

This section discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species on alien depictions, leading to the creation of non-humanoid aliens in fiction. Camille Flammarion’s works are mentioned as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also highlights H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon as influential works that explored the implications of evolution and alien civilizations. The rise of pulp magazines and their role in popularizing science fiction with various alien tropes are also discussed, including the common use of Martians, Venusians, and other Solar System inhabitants. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is noted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times 🔗

This section covers the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. It mentions The Eternaut by Héctor Germán Oesterheld, an Argentine work that critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that popularized the “grey alien” archetype. The influence of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, is highlighted, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budgetary constraints. The section concludes by mentioning the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses differences in intelligence levels, biological forms (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or bizarre), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions that some extraterrestrials in fiction originate from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

  • Parasites in fiction
  • List of fictional extraterrestrials
  • List of films featuring extraterrestrials
  • List of humanoid aliens
  • Mars in fiction

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography 🔗

Further Reading 🔗

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins 🔗

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations 🔗

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration 🔗

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion 🔗

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans 🔗

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility 🔗

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_invasion

item.title: The Flying Saucer (song)
item.description:
The Flying Saucer (song) 🔗

This entry focuses on the 1956 novelty record “The Flying Saucer” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It details the song’s genre, release information, structure, reception, legacy, and chart performance.

Single Information 🔗

This section identifies “The Flying Saucer” as a single by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, released in July 1956 on the Luniverse label. It classifies the song’s genre as mashup, novelty, break-in, and sound collage. The song’s length is 4:17 (both parts). It also provides a chronology of Buchanan and Goodman’s singles, placing “The Flying Saucer” between their previous and subsequent releases.

Overview 🔗

“The Flying Saucer” is a novelty record and the first in a series of break-in records by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It’s considered an early example of a mashup, using segments of popular songs intertwined with spoken “news” commentary to tell a story about a UFO visit. Bill Buchanan plays the radio announcer, and Dickie Goodman plays reporter John Cameron-Cameron.

Structure 🔗

This section explains the song’s construction using a reel-to-reel tape recorder. It’s described as a two-part sound collage and an audio adaptation of Orson Welles’ “The War of the Worlds,” but comedic. The song intersperses popular song lyrics into a broadcast to describe Martians landing on Earth. Buchanan’s radio disc jockey character is based on Alan Freed.

The song uses clips from 17 different songs, all top 20 hits from 1955 or 1956. The section lists these songs in order of appearance, divided by side one and side two of the record. Artists include Nappy Brown, The Platters, The Teenagers featuring Frankie Lymon, Little Richard, Fats Domino, Elvis Presley, The Penguins, Smiley Lewis, Don Cherry, Carl Perkins, Chuck Berry, and Bill Haley & His Comets.

The section also highlights the song’s technological significance, comparing it to the work of musique concrète composers like Pierre Schaeffer, Pierre Boulez, and Karlheinz Stockhausen, who also used tape manipulation in the early 1950s. It’s also described as an early, less avant-garde example of a sample collage, compared to James Tenney’s Collage #1.

Release and Reception 🔗

The extensive sampling in “The Flying Saucer” led to copyright lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman in July 1956. The duo faced criticism, but they responded with a follow-up song, “Buchanan and Goodman on Trial.” In November 1956, a judge ruled the song artful and clever, refusing to issue an injunction against sales. This ruling was significant because it essentially considered the record a new work, paving the way for legal sampling.

Following the single and the trial record, Buchanan and Goodman created more “Flying Saucer” records, forming a “UFO comedy series.” Other artists, including Dewey, George and Jack and the Belltones, Alan Freed, Steve Allen, Al “Jazzbo” Collins and the Modernaires, and Sid Noel, released their own versions of “The Flying Saucer.” The success of “The Flying Saucer” increased sales of songs excerpted in the pastiche, such as The Penguins’ “Earth Angel” and Little Richard’s “Long Tall Sally.”

Legacy 🔗

“The Flying Saucer” is recognized as the first song to sample the work of other artists. It’s considered an early instance of sampling and industry litigation. The lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman made them trailblazers in sampling and related litigation. The song is considered a musical concept that is now a part of popular music. It is also considered the first acknowledged example of a mashup.

The song paved the way for artists like Public Enemy, Freelance Hellraiser, Negativland, and Danger Mouse, who also faced litigation for sample-based copyright infringement. Steinski cited “The Flying Saucer” as a formative influence. The record’s influence stretches to pop music built on samplings and comedy routines that take answers out of context.

Charts 🔗

This section provides the chart performance of “The Flying Saucer,” noting that it reached a peak position of 3 on the US Best Sellers in Stores chart in Billboard in 1956.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Flying_Saucer_(song)

item.title: UFO Abduction (film)
item.description:
UFO Abduction (film) 🔗

This article provides information about the 1989 American found-footage science fiction horror film UFO Abduction, also known as The McPherson Tape. It details the film’s production, plot, cast, release, reception, and legacy, as well as its remake.

Title Misconception 🔗

This section clarifies that the film, originally conceived as UFO Abduction, is now more commonly known as The McPherson Tape.

Plot 🔗

This section outlines the film’s storyline, which centers on the Van Heese family in Connecticut during a birthday celebration on October 8, 1983. The family encounters extraterrestrials, leading to a night of terror and a supposed alien abduction. Key events include the initial sighting of a spacecraft, attempts by the aliens to enter the house, the shooting of an alien, and the family’s eventual disappearance. The film is presented as found footage, with the implication that the Van Heeses’ whereabouts remain unknown.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the actors who portrayed the Van Heese family members and the aliens. Key actors include Tommy Giavocchini, Patrick Kelley, Shirly McCalla, Stacey Shulman, Christine Staples, Laura Tomas, and Dean Alioto.

Production 🔗

This section details the film’s production, noting that it was written, directed, filmed, and produced by Dean Alioto through IndieSyndicate Productions. It highlights the film’s low budget of $6,500 and its presentation as found footage.

Release, Reception and Legacy 🔗

This section discusses the film’s limited release through Axiom Films and its intended appearance as a genuine 1983 home video recording. It mentions the destruction of the film’s materials in a warehouse fire, hindering its wide release. It also notes criticisms of the original film’s sound quality, visual effects, and aesthetics. The section further mentions the film’s official DVD and Digital download release in 2018 and its Blu-ray re-release in 2020 by AGFA, including a new transfer and director’s commentary.

Remake 🔗

This section mentions the 1998 remake of UFO Abduction by Dean Alioto and Paul Chitlik, which had a larger budget and professional actors. The remake was originally titled The McPherson Tape but was later changed to Alien Abduction: Incident in Lake County.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related topics, including the Kelly–Hopkinsville encounter and UFO conspiracy theories.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_Abduction_(film)

item.title: Malmstrom UFO incident
item.description:
Malmstrom UFO Incident 🔗

This article discusses the alleged Malmstrom UFO incident, focusing on claims that a UFO sighting was connected to a weapons failure at a nuclear missile complex in Montana in 1967. It presents claims made by retired Air Force personnel, skeptical counterarguments, and the incident’s coverage in media.

1967 Missile Complex Malfunction 🔗

This section details the 1967 incident at the Echo Flight missile complex, located between Hilger and Winifred, Montana, and operated by personnel from Malmstrom Air Force Base. On March 16, 1967, all sites in Echo Flight experienced a shutdown with “No-Go” indications, causing all launch facilities to lose strategic alert nearly simultaneously. An Air Force report mentioned rumors of UFOs around the area but stated they were disproven. A Mobile Strike Team reported no unusual activity or sightings. The malfunction, termed the “Echo Flight Incident,” was resolved within a day by maintenance crews.

Public Claims by Robert Salas 🔗

This section focuses on the claims made by Robert Salas, a 26-year-old Air Force Lieutenant at the time of the 1967 malfunction. In a 1996 Great Falls Tribune article, Salas recounted how a security guard reported flying objects performing strange maneuvers and a glowing red object hovering above the front gate. Shortly after, the complex’s ten Minuteman nuclear missiles went offline. Salas emphasized he was not a “UFO junkie” and sought answers to the mystery.

Promotion in Media 🔗

This section outlines the media coverage of the Malmstrom UFO incident. It notes coverage in regional papers starting in 2000, including the Missoula Independent in 2001 and 2002. Air Force documents related to the incident were released under the Freedom of Information Act. Robert Salas authored Faded Giant in 2005, speculating about a government cover-up to exploit extraterrestrial technology. In 2008, UFO author Robert Hastings discussed the incident in his book UFOs and Nukes, which Salas defended. Salas appeared at the National Press Club in 2010 with other UFO speakers and authored Unidentified: The UFO Phenomenon in 2014 and UAPs and the Nuclear Puzzle in 2023. The Great Falls Tribune marked the event’s 50th anniversary in 2017.

Skeptical Views 🔗

This section presents skeptical perspectives on the Malmstrom UFO incident. Science writer Mick West argues that the military investigated the incident and found no connection to UFO sightings, attributing the story’s persistence to Salas’s promotional efforts. Brian Dunning points out discrepancies between Salas’s memories and records from the 341st Strategic Missile Wing, suggesting the missile restart was due to a commonplace power failure and unrelated to later UFO reports. Michael Shermer, appearing with Salas on CNN, suggested that people can be unreliable observers and that extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. Robert Sheaffer suggests the UFO sighting was likely Mars and unrelated to the missile malfunction.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malmstrom_UFO_incident

item.title: UFO (1956 film)
item.description:
UFO (1956 film) 🔗

A 1956 American semi-documentary film that explores the development of the UFO phenomenon in the United States. It is noted for its use of documentary clips that have been featured in other UFO-related media.

Origins and plot 🔗

In 1952, Hollywood producer Clarence Greene, after witnessing an unusual aerial object, contacted US Air Force public information officer Albert M. Chop. Intrigued, Greene decided to create a documentary about UFOs, using film footage provided by Chop. The film begins in 1947, covering early UFO sightings like the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Mantell UFO incident, and the Gorman Dogfight. It follows the evolution of UFOs as a cultural fad and a concern for the US Air Force, including the history of Project Sign. The film then focuses on Albert M. Chop, who is assigned as the public information officer at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. Chop initially debunks UFOs but gradually changes his views, believing they are unknown aircraft, possibly extraterrestrial. By 1952, Chop is in Washington, D.C., as the press spokesman for Project Blue Book. The documentary analyzes the Mariana UFO Incident of 1950 and the 1952 UFO film taken near the Great Salt Lake in Utah by Delbert Newhouse. The film concludes with the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, where Chop played a central role, ultimately stating his belief that UFOs are a real, physical phenomenon of unknown origin.

Cast 🔗

The cast includes Willis Sperry, Nicholas Mariana, Delbert Newhouse, Wendell Swanson, and U.S. Air Force General John A. Samford as themselves. Tom Towers plays Albert M. (Al) Chop, Floyd Burton plays Major Dewey Fournet, Gene Coughlan plays an editor from the Dayton Daily News, Bert Freed plays a Colonel, Stan Gordon plays a reporter, Marie Kenna plays Mrs. Albert Chop, Harry Morgan provides voices, Robert Phillips plays Captain Edward Ruppelt, William Solomon plays a German scientist, and Olan Soule is a narrator.

Trivia 🔗

Actor Harry Morgan, known for his roles in M*A*S*H and Dragnet 1967, voices the pilot of “Air Force 216” and “Red Dog One” during key scenes, including the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident. Morgan’s Dragnet 1967 co-star Jack Webb produced and narrated the 1978 television series Project U.F.O., which recreated Project Bluebook.

See also 🔗

Lists similar media, including the book The Report On Unidentified Flying Objects (1956), the film UFOs: Past, Present, and Future (1976), and the TV broadcast UFO Cover Up? Live (1988).

References 🔗

Lists the references used in the article, including articles from the Los Angeles Times, Turner Classic Movies, Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Post and Times-Herald, and New York Times.

External links 🔗

Provides links to the film’s IMDb page, TCM Movie Database page, and a full film available at the Internet Archive.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(1956_film)

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network 🔗

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters in over 43 countries and all 50 US states. MUFON aims to investigate UFO sightings and provide information to the public.

History 🔗

MUFON was originally established as the Midwest UFO Network on May 31, 1969, in Quincy, Illinois, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., John F. Schuessler, and others. It was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973 due to its expansion. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation 🔗

Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, MUFON has chapters throughout the U.S. and internationally. It hosts an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution for training UFO investigators. The organization has over 500 field investigators who investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft.

Criticism 🔗

Pseudoscience 🔗

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience, including topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, and human-ET hybrids. Critics argue that MUFON’s investigations lack scientific rigor and that its researchers are often not scientists.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints 🔗

In 2018, Newsweek reported on anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and John Ventre. This led to resignations from members like Chris Cogswell and James Clarkson. In 2020, Vice reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist content on Facebook.

Popular culture 🔗

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows and news articles, including:

Television 🔗

  • UFOs Over Earth (2008)
  • UFO Hunters (2008)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star (Season 3, Episode 6 “The ATX-Files”)

News 🔗

  • The New York Times article “People Are Seeing U.F.O.s Everywhere, and This Book Proves It”
  • Forbes article “MUFON, America’s UFO Experts, Discuss Roswell And Possible Cover-Ups”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUFON

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network 🔗

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters and representatives in numerous countries and all 50 US states.

History 🔗

Originally established as the Midwest UFO Network in Quincy, Illinois, on May 31, 1969, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., and John F. Schuessler, among others. Many early members were associated with the SKYLOOK newsletter and the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO). The organization expanded and was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation 🔗

MUFON is headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, and has chapters in every U.S. state. It holds an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution that trains members to investigate UFO sightings. The network claims over 500 field investigators and specialized teams to investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft. Volunteers are trained to interview witnesses, conduct research, and analyze evidence, requiring them to pass an exam and a background check. MUFON’s website features a newsroom and case management system.

Criticism 🔗

Pseudoscience 🔗

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience. Critics argue that the organization’s conferences and publications delve into topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, human-ET hybrids, hypnotic regression, and repressed memories, which are considered unscientific. The qualifications of the amateur volunteers who examine UFO reports have also been questioned.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints 🔗

In April 2018, Newsweek reported evidence of anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and former MUFON State Director for Pennsylvania John Ventre. These individuals have publicly expressed racist and/or anti-Semitic views. This led to resignations from MUFON, including former Director of Research Chris Cogswell and former board member and Washington State Director James Clarkson. Erica Lukes, former MUFON State Director for Utah, described MUFON as unwilling to adequately address sexual harassment. In 2020, Vice magazine reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist memes and comments on Facebook.

Popular culture 🔗

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows, including:

  • UFOs Over Earth (Discovery Channel)
  • UFO Hunters (History Channel)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens (History Channel)
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star

It has also been mentioned in news articles in The New York Times and Forbes.

item.title: Roswell That Ends Well
item.description:
Roswell That Ends Well 🔗

“Roswell That Ends Well” is the 19th episode of the third season of the animated television series Futurama. It originally aired on December 9, 2001.

Plot 🔗

The Planet Express crew, while observing a supernova, accidentally time travel to 1947 after Fry microwaves a metal pan of popcorn. They crash-land in Roswell, New Mexico, becoming part of the Roswell Incident. Bender is shattered upon impact. The crew searches for a way back to the 31st century. Zoidberg is captured by the U.S. military and experimented on at Roswell Air Base. The military reconstructs Bender’s body into a flying saucer.

The crew needs a microwave oven to return to their time. Professor Farnsworth warns Fry against interacting with his grandfather, Enos, to avoid a grandfather paradox. Fry tries to protect Enos, but Enos dies in a nuclear weapon test. Fry sleeps with Mildred, Enos’s fiancée, and realizes she is his grandmother, making him his own grandfather.

The crew storms Roswell Air Base to steal a microwave dish. Fry and Leela rescue Zoidberg from an alien autopsy. Farnsworth retrieves Bender’s body. While time jumping, Bender’s head is left behind. Back in the 31st century, the crew returns to Roswell, finds Bender’s head, and reattaches it to his body.

Production 🔗

The writing team developed the episode from ideas initially considered for “Anthology of Interest II.” The writers initially avoided time travel in Futurama, but changed their minds. They made the time travel unintentional, triggered by a supernova, to avoid regular time travel. The episode was directed by Rich Moore, who used screen position and character movement to represent time travel. Actions to the left represented the past, while actions to the right indicated progress.

Cultural references 🔗

The episode references time travel stories like Back to the Future and Terminator. It also shares similarities with the Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode “Little Green Men.” Bender’s head buried in the sand is similar to Data’s head in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Enos’s character is based on Gomer Pyle.

Broadcast and reception 🔗

“Roswell That Ends Well” won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (Programming Less Than One Hour) in 2002. Rich Moore won an Annie Award for directing. IGN ranked it as one of the best Futurama episodes. David X. Cohen considered it one of his favorite episodes. Sci Fi Weekly gave it an “A” grade. Despite critical acclaim, the episode had low ratings during its original airing.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_That_Ends_Well

item.title: Alien Trespass (2009 Film)
item.description:
Alien Trespass (2009 Film) 🔗

This is a description of the 2009 film Alien Trespass, directed by R.W. Goodwin. The film is a science-fiction comedy that pays homage to the B movies of the 1950s.

Plot 🔗

The story is set in 1957 in California’s Mojave Desert. Astronomer Ted Lewis and his wife Lana are observing a meteor shower when something crashes nearby. Ted investigates and discovers an alien spaceship. His body is then taken over by Urp, a well-meaning alien who is searching for Ghota, a one-eyed monster that escaped from the ship. Ghota consumes people to grow and multiply, threatening Earth. Urp enlists the help of Tammy, a local waitress, to stop Ghota. The local police, Chief Dawson and Officer Vern, are skeptical. Urp and Tammy hunt down Ghota, and they eventually fall in love. At the end, Urp returns to his home planet, leaving Tammy to pursue her dreams.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Eric McCormack as Ted Lewis/Urp, Jenni Baird as Tammy, Robert Patrick as Vernon, Jody Thompson as Lana Lewis, and Dan Lauria as Chief Dawson. Other cast members include Sarah Smyth, Aaron Brooks, Andrew Dunbar, Dayna Reid, Chelah Horsdal, Sage Brocklebank, Jonathon Young, and Tom McBeath.

Analysis 🔗

The film replicates the look and feel of 1950s science fiction films, with the exception of being in color. The film uses the trope of monsters terrorizing small desert towns, which was common in 1950s B movies due to lower production costs. The character of Lana Lewis is depicted as a “sexpot,” a common archetype in 1950s science fiction films. The Ghota is similar to B.O.B. from Monsters vs. Aliens. The romance between Urp and Tammy is reminiscent of The Day the Earth Stood Still. Director Goodwin states that the film takes elements from The Day the Earth Stood Still, It Came from Outer Space, and The War of the Worlds.

Reception 🔗

The film received mixed reviews. Rotten Tomatoes gives it a 38% approval rating, with the consensus being that it loses its charm due to tedious dialogue and cheesy special effects. Roger Ebert gave the film two out of four stars, stating that it was a labor of love but questioning whether there was a demand for cheesy 1950s sci-fi movies. Jeannette Catsoulis of The New York Times described the film as a charming but pointless homage. Betsy Sharkey of the Los Angeles Times felt that the film stayed too true to the era and genre, forgetting to entertain. IGN praised the film’s recreation of the 1950s aesthetic but found that it couldn’t decide whether to emulate or satirize the genre. Ty Burr of The Boston Globe felt that the film was superior to Monsters vs. Aliens. Entertainment Weekly gave the film a “B+” rating, praising its warm tone and anti-CGI look. Gary Westfahl considers the film an overlooked gem that captures the charm of 1950s science fiction films.

See also 🔗

The article lists other films related to the genre, including Earth vs. the Flying Saucers, Forbidden Planet, Invaders from Mars, Mars Attacks!, and The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra.

Sources 🔗

The article cites several sources, including reviews by Roger Ebert, Gary Westfahl, and articles from AMC.com.

References 🔗

The article includes a list of references to support the information presented.

External links 🔗

The article provides links to the film’s official website, IMDb page, Rotten Tomatoes page, TCM Movie Database page, and articles from The New York Times, AMCtv.com, and Starlog magazine.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Trespass

item.title: Phoenix (NASA Mars Lander)
item.description:
Phoenix (NASA Mars Lander) 🔗

The Phoenix was a NASA uncrewed space probe that landed on Mars on May 25, 2008, and operated until November 2, 2008. It was designed to assess the local habitability and research the history of water on Mars. The mission was part of the Mars Scout Program and cost $420 million.

Mission Overview 🔗

The mission had two primary goals: to study the geological history of water on Mars and to evaluate past or potential planetary habitability in the ice-soil boundary. Phoenix was the first mission to return data from either of the Martian poles and contributed to NASA’s “Follow the water” strategy for Mars exploration. The primary mission was planned to last 90 sols (Martian days), but it exceeded this by two months. It was a fixed lander rather than a rover to reduce costs and allow for more scientific instruments. The mission also aimed to determine the biological potential or habitability of the Martian arctic’s soils, considering the presence of methane gas on Mars.

History 🔗

The Mars Odyssey orbiter detected hydrogen, suggesting water ice below the surface, which led to the funding of the Phoenix mission. In August 2003, NASA selected the University of Arizona’s “Phoenix” mission for launch in 2007. Peter H. Smith of the University of Arizona Lunar and Planetary Laboratory led the mission. The spacecraft used modified components from the canceled Mars Surveyor 2001 Lander and the Mars Polar Lander. Lockheed Martin kept the lander in a clean room from 2001 until the mission was funded. The mission was a partnership of universities, NASA centers, and the aerospace industry. The Canadian Space Agency provided a meteorological station. NASA approved the mission to proceed as planned on June 2, 2005, following a critical review.

Specifications 🔗

The Phoenix had a launch mass of 670 kg, including the lander, aeroshell, parachutes, and cruise stage. The lander itself weighed 350 kg and was about 5.5 meters long with deployed solar panels. It used X-band and UHF communications. Power was generated by solar panels and a NiH2 battery. The lander systems included a RAD6000-based computer system.

Scientific Payload 🔗

Phoenix carried improved versions of cameras and volatiles-analysis instruments from the Mars Polar Lander, as well as experiments from the canceled Mars Surveyor 2001 Lander. This included a robotic arm, wet chemistry laboratories, and optical and atomic force microscopes. The science payload also included a descent imager and meteorological instruments. During entry, descent, and landing (EDL), the Atmospheric Structure Experiment used accelerometer and gyroscope data to create a vertical profile of the atmosphere.

Robotic Arm and Camera 🔗

The robotic arm could extend 2.35 meters and dig down to 0.5 meters below the surface to collect samples. It was designed and built for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory by Alliance Spacesystems, LLC. A rotating rasp-tool was used to cut into the permafrost. The Robotic Arm Camera (RAC) took full-color pictures of the area and verified the samples. The camera was made by the University of Arizona and Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research, Germany.

Surface Stereo Imager 🔗

The Surface Stereo Imager (SSI) was the primary camera on the lander. It is a stereo camera that took stereo images of the Martian Arctic and measured atmospheric distortion. The camera was provided by the University of Arizona in collaboration with the Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research.

Thermal and Evolved Gas Analyzer 🔗

The Thermal and Evolved Gas Analyzer (TEGA) combined a high-temperature furnace with a mass spectrometer. It baked samples of Martian dust to determine the composition of the resulting vapors. It had eight ovens to analyze separate samples. TEGA measured water vapor, carbon dioxide, water ice, minerals, and organic volatiles. TEGA was built by the University of Arizona and University of Texas at Dallas.

Mars Descent Imager 🔗

The Mars Descent Imager (MARDI) was intended to take pictures of the landing site during the last three minutes of descent. However, a potential data corruption problem was discovered, and it was decided not to use MARDI during the mission. It was built by Malin Space Science Systems.

Microscopy, Electrochemistry, and Conductivity Analyzer 🔗

The Microscopy, Electrochemistry, and Conductivity Analyzer (MECA) was an instrument package originally designed for the canceled Mars Surveyor 2001 Lander mission. It consisted of a wet chemistry lab (WCL), optical and atomic force microscopes, and a thermal and electrical conductivity probe. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory built MECA. A Swiss consortium led by the University of Neuchatel contributed the atomic force microscope.

Sample Wheel and Translation Stage 🔗

This instrument presents 6 of 69 sample holders to an opening in the MECA instrument to which the robotic arm delivers the samples and then brings the samples to the optical microscope and the atomic force microscope. Imperial College London provided the microscope sample substrates.

Optical Microscope 🔗

The optical microscope, designed by the University of Arizona, is capable of making images of the Martian regolith with a resolution of 256 pixels/mm or 16 micrometers/pixel. The field of view of the microscope is a 2 mm × 2 mm sample holder to which the robotic arm delivers the sample.

Atomic Force Microscope 🔗

The atomic force microscope has access to a small area of the sample delivered to the optical microscope. The instrument scans over the sample with one of 8 silicon crystal tips and measures the repulsion of the tip from the sample. The maximum resolution is 0.1 micrometers. A Swiss consortium led by the University of Neuchatel contributed the atomic force microscope.

Wet Chemistry Laboratory (WCL) 🔗

The wet chemistry lab (WCL) sensor assembly and leaching solution were designed and built by Thermo Fisher Scientific. Tufts University developed the reagent pellets, barium ISE, and ASV electrodes, and performed the preflight characterization of the sensor array. The robotic arm scooped up some soil and put it in one of four wet chemistry lab cells, where water was added, and, while stirring, an array of electrochemical sensors measured a dozen dissolved ions.

Thermal and Electrical Conductivity Probe (TECP) 🔗

The MECA contains a Thermal and Electrical Conductivity Probe (TECP). The TECP, designed by Decagon Devices, has four probes that made the following measurements: Martian soil temperature, relative humidity, thermal conductivity, electrical conductivity, dielectric permittivity, wind speed, and atmospheric temperature.

Meteorological Station 🔗

The Meteorological Station (MET) recorded the daily weather of Mars during the course of the Phoenix mission. It is equipped with a wind indicator and pressure and temperature sensors. The MET also contains a lidar (light detection and ranging) device for sampling the number of dust particles in the air. It was designed in Canada by Optech and MDA, supported by the Canadian Space Agency. A team initially led by York University’s Professor Diane Michelangeli, then by Professor James Whiteway, oversaw the science operations of the station.

Mission Highlights 🔗

Launch 🔗

Phoenix was launched on August 4, 2007, from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on a Delta II 7925 launch vehicle. The launch was nominal with no significant anomalies. The Phoenix lander was placed on a trajectory of such precision that its first trajectory course correction burn was only 18 m/s.

Cruise 🔗

(This section is empty in the original article.)

Entry, Descent, and Landing 🔗

The Jet Propulsion Laboratory made adjustments to the orbits of its two active satellites around Mars, Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter and Mars Odyssey, and the European Space Agency similarly adjusted the orbit of its Mars Express spacecraft to observe Phoenix as it entered the atmosphere and landed. Phoenix entered the Martian atmosphere at nearly 21,000 km/h and decreased its speed to 8 km/h before touching down. Confirmation of atmospheric entry was received at 4:46 p.m. PDT. Radio signals confirmed that Phoenix had survived its descent and landed 15 minutes earlier. Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter’s High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE) camera photographed Phoenix suspended from its parachute. Phoenix landed in the Green Valley of Vastitas Borealis on May 25, 2008.

Surface Mission 🔗

Communications from the Surface 🔗

The robotic arm’s first movement was delayed by one day when commands from Earth were not relayed to the Phoenix lander on Mars. The robotic arm was a critical part of the Phoenix Mars mission. On May 28, scientists sent commands to unstow its robotic arm and take more images of its landing site. The lander’s robotic arm touched soil on Mars for the first time on May 31, 2008.

Presence of Shallow Subsurface Water Ice 🔗

The polygonal cracking at the landing zone had previously been observed from orbit and is similar to patterns seen in permafrost areas on Earth. Phoenix’s robotic arm camera took an image underneath the lander that shows patches of a smooth bright surface uncovered when thruster exhaust blew off overlying loose soil. On June 19, 2008, NASA announced that dice-sized clumps of bright material in the “Dodo-Goldilocks” trench had vaporized over four days, implying

item.title: Aurora, Texas, UFO incident
item.description:
Aurora, Texas, UFO Incident 🔗

This article details the alleged UFO crash that reportedly occurred on April 17, 1897, near Aurora, Texas. Locals claimed a UFO crashed on a farm, resulting in the death of its pilot, an alien being. The pilot was purportedly buried in the Aurora Cemetery.

The Incident as Reported 🔗

This section recounts the details of the incident as reported in the Dallas Morning News article written by S.E. Haydon. The article describes how a UFO crashed into a windmill on Judge J.S. Proctor’s property. The pilot, described as “not of this world,” was speculated to be from Mars by an Army Signal Service officer named T.J. Weems. The pilot was buried with Christian rites in the Aurora Cemetery, which now has a Texas Historical Commission marker mentioning the incident. The wreckage was reportedly dumped into a well on the property. Mr. Brawley Oates, who later purchased the property, sealed the well after developing severe arthritis, which he attributed to contamination from the wreckage.

Hoax Theory 🔗

This section presents the theory that the Aurora incident was a hoax. It cites a 1980 Time magazine interview with Etta Pegues, an Aurora resident, who claimed that S.E. Haydon fabricated the story to revive the town’s economy after the railroad bypassed it. Pegues also claimed that Judge Proctor never had a windmill on his property, a statement that was later challenged. Paranormal researcher Jerry Drake challenged the finding that the well was designed for use with a windmill.

Investigations 🔗

This section outlines the various investigations into the Aurora incident, including reports by KDFW, UFO Files, and UFO Hunters.

KDFW Report 🔗

In 1998, KDFW aired a report featuring interviews with Jim Marrs and other locals who believed something crashed in Aurora. The report found no conclusive evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology.

UFO Files Investigation 🔗

The UFO Files episode, “Texas’ Roswell,” featured a 1973 investigation led by Bill Case of the Dallas Times Herald and MUFON. The investigation uncovered two new eyewitnesses: Mary Evans, who spoke of her parents’ visit to the crash site and the discovery of the alien body, and Charlie Stephens, who saw the airship trailing smoke. MUFON investigated the Aurora Cemetery and found a grave marker that appeared to depict a flying saucer. They requested permission to exhume the site but were denied. The marker later disappeared, and metal readings from the grave vanished. The report concluded that the evidence was inconclusive.

UFO Hunters Investigation 🔗

The UFO Hunters episode, “First Contact,” featured Tim Oates, grandson of Brawley Oates, allowing investigators to unseal the well on his property. Water samples showed high levels of aluminum, but the well contained no significant debris. The remains of a windmill base were found near the well site. Ground-penetrating radar revealed an unmarked grave in the cemetery near other 1890s graves. The condition of the grave was badly deteriorated, and the radar could not conclusively prove what type of remains existed. The landowner provided pieces of metal containing mostly aluminum and an unknown element.

In Popular Culture 🔗

This section notes the dramatization of the incident in the 1986 film The Aurora Encounter and its discussion in Ancient Aliens. It also mentions an independent short movie titled Aurora by Thomas Negovan and Aaron Shaps, which combines the incident with the Nazi conspiracy theory of Die Glocke. The Firesign Theatre’s comedy LP Everything You Know Is Wrong satirizes the incident.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including “List of reported UFO sightings” and “Mystery airship.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aurora,_Texas,_UFO_incident

item.title: Kepler space telescope
item.description:
Kepler 🔗

The Kepler space telescope, a NASA mission from 2009 to 2018, was designed to discover Earth-sized exoplanets. Named after astronomer Johannes Kepler, it operated in a heliocentric orbit. The mission ended when its reaction control system fuel was depleted.

Mission type 🔗

The Kepler mission was a space telescope mission.

Operator 🔗

NASA and the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP) operated the Kepler mission.

COSPAR ID 🔗

The COSPAR ID for Kepler is 2009-011A.

SATCAT no. 🔗

The SATCAT number for Kepler is 34380.

Website 🔗

The official website for the Kepler mission is www.nasa.gov/kepler.

Mission duration 🔗

The Kepler mission was initially planned for 3.5 years but ultimately lasted 9 years, 7 months, and 23 days.

Spacecraft properties 🔗

Manufacturer 🔗

Ball Aerospace & Technologies manufactured the Kepler spacecraft.

Launch mass 🔗

The launch mass of the Kepler spacecraft was 1,052.4 kg (2,320 lb).

Dry mass 🔗

The dry mass of the Kepler spacecraft was 1,040.7 kg (2,294 lb).

Payload mass 🔗

The payload mass of the Kepler spacecraft was 478 kg (1,054 lb).

Dimensions 🔗

The Kepler spacecraft’s dimensions were 4.7 m × 2.7 m (15.4 ft × 8.9 ft).

Power 🔗

The Kepler spacecraft had a power of 1100 watts.

Start of mission 🔗

Launch date 🔗

Kepler was launched on March 7, 2009, at 03:49:57 UTC.

Rocket 🔗

A Delta II (7925-10L) rocket was used to launch Kepler.

Launch site 🔗

The launch site was Cape Canaveral Air Force Station SLC-17B.

Contractor 🔗

United Launch Alliance was the contractor for the launch.

Entered service 🔗

Kepler entered service on May 12, 2009, at 09:01 UTC.

End of mission 🔗

Deactivated 🔗

Kepler was deactivated on November 15, 2018.

Orbital parameters 🔗

Reference system 🔗

The reference system for Kepler’s orbit is heliocentric.

Regime 🔗

Kepler’s orbital regime was Earth-trailing.

Semi-major axis 🔗

The semi-major axis of Kepler’s orbit was 1.0133 AU.

Eccentricity 🔗

The eccentricity of Kepler’s orbit was 0.036116.

Perihelion altitude 🔗

The perihelion altitude of Kepler’s orbit was 0.97671 AU.

Aphelion altitude 🔗

The aphelion altitude of Kepler’s orbit was 1.0499 AU.

Inclination 🔗

The inclination of Kepler’s orbit was 0.4474 degrees.

Period 🔗

The orbital period of Kepler was 372.57 days.

Argument of perihelion 🔗

The argument of perihelion of Kepler’s orbit was 294.04 degrees.

Mean anomaly 🔗

The mean anomaly of Kepler’s orbit was 311.67 degrees.

Mean motion 🔗

The mean motion of Kepler’s orbit was 0.96626 deg/day.

Epoch 🔗

The epoch for Kepler’s orbital parameters was January 1, 2018 (J2000: 2458119.5).

Main telescope 🔗

Type 🔗

The Kepler telescope was a Schmidt camera.

Diameter 🔗

The diameter of the Kepler telescope was 0.95 m (3.1 ft).

Collecting area 🔗

The collecting area of the Kepler telescope was 0.708 m2 (7.62 sq ft).

Wavelengths 🔗

The Kepler telescope operated at wavelengths of 430–890 nm.

Transponders 🔗

Bandwidth 🔗

Kepler’s bandwidth was:

  • X band up: 7.8 bit/s – 2 kbit/s
  • X band down: 10 bit/s – 16 kbit/s
  • Ka band down: Up to 4.3 Mbit/s

Discovery program 🔗

Kepler is part of the Discovery Program.

History 🔗

Pre-launch development 🔗

The Kepler space telescope was part of NASA’s Discovery Program. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory managed construction and initial operation, while Ball Aerospace developed the flight system. Budget cuts and consolidation at NASA delayed the launch. The high-gain antenna design was changed to reduce cost and complexity.

Post launch 🔗

The Ames Research Center managed ground system development, mission operations, and data analysis. The initial mission lifetime was 3.5 years, but noise in the data required more time. Reaction wheel failures in 2012 and 2013 threatened the mission. NASA sought alternative mission plans, leading to the K2 “Second Light” proposal. By 2015, Kepler had found over 1,000 confirmed exoplanets and thousands of candidates. Astronomers estimated billions of rocky, Earth-sized exoplanets in habitable zones. NASA announced the 1,000th confirmed exoplanet in 2015. In 2016, 1,284 new exoplanets were verified. Kepler data also helped study supernovae. The mission ended on October 30, 2018, after running out of fuel.

Spacecraft design 🔗

The Kepler telescope had a mass of 1,039 kg and used a Schmidt camera with a 0.95-meter corrector plate and a 1.4-meter primary mirror. It had a 115 deg2 field of view.

Camera 🔗

The camera’s focal plane consisted of forty-two 50 × 25 mm CCDs with a total resolution of 94.6 megapixels. The CCDs were read out every 6.5 seconds and co-added on board. Data from selected pixels was requantized, compressed, and stored in a 16 gigabyte solid-state recorder.

Primary mirror 🔗

The primary mirror was 1.4 meters in diameter, made by Corning using ultra-low expansion (ULE) glass. It had a nine-layer silver coating to enhance reflection.

Photometric performance 🔗

Kepler’s photometric performance was good but fell short of design goals. The objective was 20 ppm CDPP for a magnitude 12 star for a 6.5-hour integration. The median obtained accuracy was 29 ppm.

Orbit and orientation 🔗

Kepler orbits the Sun in an Earth-trailing orbit with a period of 372.5 days. The photometer pointed to a field in the constellations Cygnus, Lyra, and Draco. Orientation was three-axis stabilized using fine-guidance sensors and reaction wheels.

Operations 🔗

The Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP) operated Kepler from Boulder, Colorado. The spacecraft’s solar array was rotated at solstices and equinoxes.

Communications 🔗

NASA contacted Kepler using the X band communication link. Scientific data was downloaded monthly using the Ka band link.

Data management 🔗

Science data was processed by the Kepler Data Management Center (DMC) at the Space Telescope Science Institute and the Science Operations Center (SOC) at NASA Ames Research Center. Calibrated data products and scientific results were archived and distributed to astronomers.

Reaction wheel failures 🔗

Reaction wheel failures in 2012 and 2013 were traced to pitting caused by arcing between steel ball bearings, triggered by coronal mass ejections (CMEs).

Operational timeline 🔗

The Kepler observatory launched on March 7, 2009, aboard a Delta II rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The telescope cover was jettisoned on April 7, 2009. The focus was optimized in April 2009. Kepler began its search for planets on May 13, 2009. The first science data was sent to Earth on June 19, 2009. Safe mode events occurred in June and July 2009 due to a processor reset. A low voltage power supply was identified as the cause. In January 2010, a problem occurred with focal plane MOD-3 module.

Field of view 🔗

Kepler had a fixed field of view (FOV) in the constellations Cygnus, Lyra, and Draco, covering 115 square degrees.

Objectives and methods 🔗

Kepler’s objective was to explore the structure and diversity of planetary systems. It aimed to determine the number of Earth-size planets in or near habitable zones, the range of orbit sizes and shapes, the number of planets in multiple-star systems, and the properties of stars with planetary systems. The transit method was used to detect planets.

Planet finding process 🔗

Finding planet candidates 🔗
