item.title: Rod (optical phenomenon)
item.description:
Rods (Optical Phenomenon) 🔗

Rods, also known as skyfish, air rods, or solar entities, are elongated visual artifacts that appear in photographic images and video recordings. While cryptozoologists and ufologists consider them paranormal, most optical analyses conclude they are insects moving across the frame during capture.

Optical Analysis 🔗

This section details the scientific explanations for the “rod” phenomenon. Robert Todd Carroll, consulting with entomologist Doug Yanega, identified rods as images of flying insects captured over several wing-beating cycles on video. This creates the illusion of a single, elongated body. A report by “The Straight Dope” also attributes rods to tricks of light and motion blur due to long exposure times when recording flying insects. The section emphasizes that claims of extraordinary or alien origins are often attributed to imagination or hoaxes. China Central Television (CCTV) aired a documentary debunking rods, revealing them to be ordinary insects captured by surveillance cameras. Scientists at Tonghua Zhenguo Pharmaceutical Company in Tonghua City, Jilin Province, captured “rods” in nets, finding them to be moths and other insects. UFO investigator Robert Sheaffer, after attending a lecture by Jose Escamilla, concluded that some “rods” were insects moving rapidly, while others were blurred bird wings.

Paranormal Claims 🔗

This section focuses on the paranormal interpretations of rods, particularly those promoted by Jose Escamilla. Escamilla claimed to have filmed the first rods on March 19, 1994, in Roswell, New Mexico, while attempting to film a UFO. He subsequently created videos and gave lectures promoting his claims of rods being alien life forms.

Explanatory Notes 🔗

This section contains a footnote clarifying that claims of rods being extraordinary creatures are often exploited by unscrupulous individuals for profit, according to “Straight Dope” staff.

See Also 🔗

This section lists related topics, including optical phenomena and orbs (optics).

References 🔗

This section provides a list of references used in the article, including:

  • Robert Todd Carroll’s entry on “rods” in The Skeptic’s Dictionary.
  • Doug Yanega’s explanation of rods in “The Straight Dope.”
  • A report from SINA Technology News about CCTV’s documentary debunking rods.
  • Robert Sheaffer’s article “ET, You’ve Got Mail” in Skeptical Inquirer.

External Links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources, including:

  • Jose Escamilla’s “Rods” Video Sequences.
  • Brian Dunning’s Skeptoid podcast episode on rods.
  • A video of “rods” at the Cave of the Swallows.
  • A detailed video analysis of rods.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_(ufology)

item.title: Ancient astronauts in popular culture
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts in Popular Culture 🔗

This article explores the presence of the ancient astronaut theory in various forms of fiction, including literature, comics, television, film, documentaries, music, and video games. The theory posits that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in the distant past and influenced the development of human civilization.

Literature 🔗

This section details numerous literary works that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Les Xipehuz (1887) by J.-H. Rosny aîné: Features geometric aliens encountered by primitive humans.
  • Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) by Garrett P. Serviss: Martians enslaved inhabitants of the Fertile Crescent and used them to build monuments in Egypt.
  • The Call of Cthulhu (1926) and At the Mountains of Madness (1931) by H.P. Lovecraft: Deals with ancient aliens.
  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) by Arthur C. Clarke: Based on his short story “Encounter in the Dawn,” explores the idea of extraterrestrial influence on human evolution.
  • The Sirens of Titan (1959) by Kurt Vonnegut: Human development is manipulated by aliens to relay messages.
  • Known Space (1964–present) by Larry Niven: Humanity is descended from aliens called the Pak.
  • Heechee Saga (1972–2004) by Frederik Pohl: The Heechee are an ancient alien race that left behind futuristic technology.
  • Uplift Universe (1980-…) by David Brin: Explores the idea that all species were brought to sapience through the intervention of a galactic “patron.”
  • VALIS trilogy (1981) by Philip K. Dick: An ancient astronaut race placed an information-streaming satellite in orbit around Earth.
  • Encounter With Tiber (1996) by Buzz Aldrin and John Barnes: Deals with the discovery of ancient alien encounters on Earth and Mars.
  • Outlanders novel series (1997-…) by Mark Ellis: The Anunnaki are revealed to have been behind a nuclear war and the Root Race of the Gray aliens.

Comics 🔗

This section highlights comic books and series that feature ancient astronauts or related concepts. Some notable examples include:

  • Uncle Scrooge #34 (1961): A Carl Barks story where Scrooge McDuck’s family discovers a planetoid inhabited by beings who were the basis for Roman and Norse gods.
  • Tales of Suspense #50 (1964): Introduces the Mandarin’s rings, created by the alien Makluans.
  • The Adventures of Tintin: Flight 714 to Sydney (1968) by Hergé: Features a temple built to honor ancient astronauts.
  • The Eternals: Deals with advanced aliens (the Celestials) who experimented on early hominids, creating the Eternals and Deviants.
  • Thorgal series by Grzegorz Rosiński and Van Hamme: The main protagonist is the son of ancient astronauts.
  • Karmatrón y los Transformables by Oscar González Loyo: Relies heavily on the ancient astronaut theory.

Television 🔗

This section details television shows that have explored the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Quatermass and the Pit (1958–1959): A miniseries that used a version of the ancient astronaut idea.
  • Star Trek: The franchise has numerous examples of extraterrestrials visiting Earth in past centuries, influencing pre-modern humans.
  • Doctor Who: Pyramids of Mars (1975): Features a conflict between aliens of a race named the Osirans forming the basis of Egyptian mythology.
  • Space: 1999 (1975–1977): Many alien species have controlled or visited Earth in the past.
  • Battlestar Galactica: Depicts humans as having originated on the planet Kobol and later settled thirteen colony planets, Earth being the last and most distant.
  • Babylon 5 (1993–1998): Many of the First Ones, particularly the Vorlons and Shadows, visited Earth at various times in history.
  • The X-Files (1993–2002, 2016–2018): Has borrowed the ancient astronaut theory.
  • Earth: Final Conflict (1997–2002): The Atavus species traveled to Earth in the distant past and ruled over it.
  • The Super Dimension Fortress Macross (1982): Features an ancient alien civilization called The Protoculture, who created the human race on Earth.
  • Neon Genesis Evangelion: Lilith and Adam were two extraterrestrial beings that landed on Earth and gave birth to humanity.

Film 🔗

This section lists films that incorporate the ancient astronaut theory. Some notable examples include:

  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968): The first act of the movie features paleocontact.
  • Horror Express (1972): An extraterrestrial is found frozen for millions of years.
  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): The Predator race traveled to Earth at a prehistoric time and had a human culture serve them as Gods.
  • Prometheus (2012): Themed around a group of scientists who set out to discover the origins of human life, which was seeded on Earth and influenced by an ancient race of aliens.
  • Hangar 18 (1980): Involves a UFO whose symbols are found to match those used in ancient cultures.
  • Stargate (1994): Features Ra, a member of the alien species Goa’uld that came to Earth around 8000 BC, enslaved the ancient Egyptians, adopting their culture and religion and posing as their God.
  • Mission to Mars (2000): Another movie with an “alien seeding” theme.
  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008): Links the existence of crystal skulls to beings that were perceived as gods by the Maya civilization.

Documentaries 🔗

This section lists documentaries that explore the ancient astronaut theory.

  • Chariots of the Gods (1970)
  • In Search of Ancient Astronauts (1973)
  • In Search of Ancient Mysteries (1974)
  • The Outer Space Connection (1975)

Music 🔗

This section highlights musical works that deal with the ancient astronaut concept.

  • A Spaceman Came Travelling by Chris de Burgh: Deals with the concept of an ancient astronaut, in this case pertaining to the Christ story.
  • Inca Roads by Frank Zappa: Deals with Ancient Astronaut Theory.
  • Several songs by The Lost Children of Babylon: Explicitly state that “Jesus Christ was really an ancient astronaut.”
  • God Is an Astronaut: A post-rock musical group from Ireland with a name exploiting the theory.
  • Ayreon albums: About ancient astronauts, that go by the name Forever, who traveled from the Andromeda Galaxy to earth long ago and influenced the development of science and technology.

Video Games 🔗

This section lists video games that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme.

  • Spore (2008): Has many elements of ancient astronauts, even giving player the ability to manipulate other less developed species as a space travelling species.
  • Final Fantasy VII: Features an ancient astronaut, Jenova, as the main antagonist.
  • Halo series: Ancient humanity was a spacefaring society technologically superior to modern humanity.
  • Dark Void: Features a race of humanoid shape-shifters called Watchers, who ruled over ancient humans as gods.
  • Mass Effect: Humanity discovers a cache of alien technology built by an alien species known as the Protheans.
  • Assassin’s Creed franchise: Humanity was originally created as a slave race by the “First Civilization.”
  • Rise of Nations: Rise of Legends: The Cuotl is a nation of Mesoamerica-inspired tribes subjugated by four extraterrestrial beings who install themselves as deities.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts_in_popular_culture

item.title: Extra Terrestrial Visitors
item.description:
Extra Terrestrial Visitors 🔗

This entry details the 1983 French-Spanish science fiction film Extra Terrestrial Visitors (also known as Los nuevos extraterrestres and Pod People). It covers the film’s production, plot, cast, release, and reception, including its later cult status due to being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot 🔗

The story unfolds in the woods of New England, where egg poachers stumble upon a cave containing alien eggs. After one poacher destroys the eggs, a vengeful alien begins targeting the poachers and a rock band camping nearby. Meanwhile, a young boy named Tommy discovers the remaining egg, which hatches into a creature he names Trumpy. Tommy and Trumpy become friends, and Trumpy develops telekinetic powers. The alien mother searches for her offspring, leading to encounters with the rock band and Tommy’s family. The film culminates in a confrontation between the humans and the alien mother, with tragic consequences for some characters. Tommy and Trumpy say goodbye before Tommy returns to his family.

Cast 🔗

The cast includes Ian Serra as Rick, Nina Ferrer as Sharon, Susana Bequer as Lara Stapleton, Sara Palmer as Kathy, Óscar Martín as Tommy Stevens, Maria Albert as Tracy, Emilio Linder as Brian, Concha Cuetos as Molly Stevens, Manuel Pereiro as Bill Stevens, and Frank Braña as Burt.

Production 🔗

Extra Terrestrial Visitors was a co-production between France and Spain, filmed in Madrid. The cast consisted largely of Spanish actors, and the film was shot in both Spanish and French, later dubbed in post-production. Juan Piquer Simón directed the film. Faruk Alatan, Dick Randall, and Edward L. Montoro produced the film.

Release 🔗

The film was initially released in France. In the United States, it was sometimes shown on television under the title The Unearthling. Film Ventures International later acquired the film and re-titled it Pod People for U.S. television distribution.

Reception and legacy 🔗

The film received negative reviews, with some finding it unintentionally funny. Its legacy is largely tied to its appearance on Mystery Science Theater 3000 (MST3K), which lampooned the Pod People version of the film.

Mystery Science Theater 3000 🔗

The film gained popularity after being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000 in 1991. The MST3K episode used a print of the film re-titled Pod People by Film Ventures International. The opening and ending credits of Pod People are superimposed over footage from The Galaxy Invader. The fictional pop band’s song “Hear the Engines Roll” became a recurring joke on the show.

Home media 🔗

The film has been released on VHS under various titles, including The Unearthling and E. T.: The Second Coming. The MST3K version of the film has been released on DVD and Blu-ray.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra_Terrestrial_Visitors

item.title: Nobody Told Me
item.description:
Nobody Told Me 🔗

“Nobody Told Me” is a posthumously released single by John Lennon, appearing on the album Milk and Honey.

Writing 🔗

This section discusses the lyrical content and inspiration behind the song. It mentions references to J. Milton Hayes’ poem The Green Eye of the Yellow God, specifically the line “There’s a one-eyed yellow idol to the north of Kathmandu.” Lennon’s documented UFO sighting in New York on August 23, 1974, which he noted in the liner notes of his Walls and Bridges album, is also referenced in the lyrics “There’s UFOs over New York and I ain’t too surprised.” May Pang, Lennon’s girlfriend at the time, corroborated this event in her book Loving John. The lyrics “Nobody told me there’d be days like these / Strange days indeed / Most peculiar, mama” are contrasted with the adage “My mother told me there’d be days like this.” Yoko Ono described the song as “kind of a fun song” and related it to Lennon’s feeling that the world had lost its direction.

Recording 🔗

This section details the recording history of the song. It explains that the song was recorded but left incomplete before Lennon’s death in 1980 and was later completed by Yoko Ono in 1983. It was released as the first single from Milk and Honey in 1984. A re-release occurred in the UK in 1990 with “I’m Stepping Out” as the B-side. The song was originally intended for Ringo Starr’s 1981 album, Stop and Smell the Roses, but Starr decided not to record it after Lennon’s death. A promo video was created in 2003 for the Lennon Legend DVD, using archival footage from the early 1970s, including outtakes from the film Imagine. The video features appearances by Phil Spector, George Harrison, Dick Cavett, Fred Astaire, Andy Warhol, and Miles Davis.

Reception 🔗

This section presents a review of the song from Cash Box magazine, which described it as a melodic blend of “Just Like Starting Over” and “Instant Karma!,” praising its inspiring and memorable qualities.

Personnel 🔗

This section lists the musicians who played on the song:

  • John Lennon – vocals, rhythm guitar
  • Earl Slick, Hugh McCracken – lead guitar
  • Tony Levin – bass
  • George Small – keyboards
  • Andy Newmark – drums
  • Arthur Jenkins – percussion

Chart Performance 🔗

This section details the song’s performance on various music charts. It reached number 6 in the UK in January 1984 and number 5 on the Billboard Hot 100 in the US. It also reached number 6 on the Cashbox Top 100. Chart positions are provided for Australia, Canada, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Ireland, the UK, and the US (Billboard Hot 100, Adult Contemporary, and Cash Box Top 100). Year-end chart rankings for Australia, Canada, and the US are also included.

Cover Versions 🔗

This section lists notable cover versions of the song. The Flaming Lips recorded a version for the 1995 tribute album Working Class Hero: A Tribute to John Lennon. Big & Rich covered the song for the 2007 benefit album Instant Karma: The Amnesty International Campaign to Save Darfur.

Notes 🔗

This section contains a note referencing The Goon Show, a radio program that Lennon enjoyed. The note points out that the show had an episode where characters joked about the phrase “There’s a little yellow idol to the north of Kathmandu,” using the adjective “little” as in the song lyrics.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Lennon_UFO_incident

item.title: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident
item.description:
Washington, D.C. UFO Incident (1952) 🔗

This article details a series of unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings that occurred in Washington, D.C., during July 1952. These sightings, known as the “Washington flap,” the “Washington National Airport Sightings,” or the “Invasion of Washington,” garnered significant media attention and became one of the most well-known UFO incidents.

1952 UFO flap 🔗

This section describes the broader context of the 1952 UFO flap, a period of heightened media and public interest in UFO sightings. It notes the surge in reported sightings during the summer of 1952, with the US Air Force receiving over 717 new reports, compared to 615 in the previous four years. It mentions the role of media coverage, including a Life magazine article titled “Have We Visitors From Space?” which is believed to have contributed to the increased sightings. The section also highlights other notable sightings and reports leading up to the Washington D.C. events, including a UFO report filed by Hughes Aircraft Company in Los Angeles and an interception of a UFO over Boston by F-94s. The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting over Chesapeake Bay is also mentioned. Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, is a key figure mentioned in this section.

Sightings over Washington, D.C. 🔗

This section focuses on the specific UFO sightings that occurred over Washington, D.C., on two consecutive Saturday nights in July 1952.

Night of July 19 🔗

This subsection details the events of the first night of sightings, beginning with air traffic controller Edward Nugent spotting seven objects on radar at Washington National Airport. Senior air-traffic controller Harry Barnes also witnessed the objects and noted their unusual movements. Controllers at the airport’s control tower, Howard Cocklin and Joe Zacko, also reported seeing unidentified blips on radar and a “bright light” in the sky. Airman William Brady at Andrews Air Force Base reported seeing an “orange ball of fire.” S.C. Pierman, a Capital Airlines pilot, observed six “white, tailless, fast-moving lights” near his plane. Staff Sgt. Charles Davenport at Andrews Air Force Base observed an orange-red light exhibiting unusual movements. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters were dispatched from New Castle Air Force Base in Delaware, but the objects vanished from radar upon their arrival, only to reappear after the jets left.

Publicity and Air Force reaction 🔗

This subsection discusses the widespread media coverage of the July 19-20 sightings, which made front-page headlines across the nation. It mentions the involvement of USAF Captain Edward J. Ruppelt, the supervisor of Project Blue Book, who was in Washington at the time but faced difficulties in investigating the sightings. The section also notes that an Air Force radar specialist, Captain Roy James, suggested that unusual weather conditions could have caused the radar targets.

Night of July 26 🔗

This subsection describes the events of the second night of sightings, beginning with a pilot and stewardess on a National Airlines flight reporting lights above their plane. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews AFB tracked more unknown objects. USAF master sergeant Charles E. Cummings visually observed the objects at Andrews. Albert M. Chop, the press spokesman for Project Blue Book, arrived at National Airport. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters from New Castle Air Force Base were scrambled. Captain John McHugo, the flight leader, saw nothing, but his wingman, Lieutenant William Patterson, saw four white “glows” and chased them. USAF Major Dewey Fournet, Project Blue Book’s liaison at the Pentagon, and Lt. John Holcomb, a United States Navy radar specialist, arrived at the radar center at National Airport. Civilian aircraft also reported glowing objects that corresponded to radar blips.

Aftermath 🔗

This section briefly mentions a report from West Palm Beach scoutmaster Sonny DesVergers, who claimed to have been burned by a flying disc on August 19.

Air Force explanation 🔗

This section details the Air Force’s official explanation for the sightings. Major Generals John Samford, USAF Director of Intelligence, and Roger M. Ramey, USAF Director of Operations, held a press conference at the Pentagon on July 29, 1952. Samford stated that the visual sightings could be explained as misidentified aerial phenomena, such as stars or meteors, and the unknown radar targets could be attributed to temperature inversion. The crew of a B-25 bomber and Air Force Captain Harold May are mentioned as witnesses who supported the Air Force’s explanation. The CAA’s Technical Development and Evaluation Center also conducted an analysis that supported the temperature inversion theory. Donald Menzel and Philip Klass are mentioned as prominent UFO skeptics who also supported the temperature inversion/mirage hypothesis.

Criticisms 🔗

This subsection presents criticisms of the Air Force’s explanation. Edward J. Ruppelt, in his book, noted that radar and control tower personnel, as well as some Air Force officers, disagreed with the Air Force’s explanation. Michael Wertheimer, a researcher for the Condon Report, stated that radar witnesses still disputed the Air Force explanation in 1966. Former radar controller Howard Cocklin maintained his belief that he saw an object over Washington National Airport.

White House concern and CIA interest 🔗

This section discusses the concern that the sightings caused within the White House and the CIA. President Harry Truman requested an explanation of the sightings and radar returns. CIA historian Gerald Haines noted that the Truman administration was alarmed by the sightings. The CIA formed a special study group to review the situation and recommended continued monitoring of the problem. This concern led to the creation of the Robertson Panel in January 1953.

The Robertson Panel 🔗

This section describes the creation and findings of the Robertson Panel, formed in January 1953 due to the high number of UFO reports. The panel, chaired by physicist Howard P. Robertson, consisted of prominent scientists who examined UFO cases collected by Project Blue Book. The panel dismissed most cases as not representing anything unusual or threatening and recommended that the Air Force and Project Blue Book focus on debunking UFO reports.

In popular culture 🔗

This section notes the appearances of the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident in popular culture, specifically in the History Channel television series Project Blue Book and the Netflix series Top Secret UFO Projects Declassified.

References 🔗

This section lists the notes and sources used in the article.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources related to the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, including articles from the CIA, Fold3, Saturday Night Uforia, and Ghosts of DC.

It highlights the unprecedented media attention and the large number of UFO reports received by the US Air Force. Key figures mentioned include Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, who noted the extensive media coverage. item.title: 1976 Tehran UFO incident
item.description:
1976 Tehran UFO Incident 🔗

The 1976 Tehran UFO incident involved radar and visual sightings of an unidentified flying object (UFO) over Tehran, Iran, in the early morning hours of September 19, 1976. Two Imperial Iranian Air Force (IIAF) F-4 Phantom II jet interceptors were dispatched to investigate. Pilots reported instrumentation and communication failures as they approached the object, which were restored upon withdrawal. One aircraft also experienced a temporary weapons systems failure while preparing to fire. An initial report was relayed to the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff on the day of the incident.

Incident 🔗

On September 19, 1976, at least four civilians reported a shining object in the sky above Tehran. Lieutenant Yaddi Nazeri and a weapons officer were sent to investigate in an F-4 Phantom II. Nazeri reported losing all instruments and communications upon reaching Tehran, prompting a return to base where the instruments returned to normal.

Major Parviz Jafari, a squadron commander, and First Lieutenant Jalal Damirian were dispatched in a second F-4 Phantom II. Jafari acquired radar lock on an object 27 nautical miles away, estimating its size to be comparable to a Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker. As he approached, Jafari described the object as flashing intense red, green, orange, and blue lights. His plane’s communications system shut off. When he attempted to fire an AIM-9 Sidewinder missile, his equipment failed and only returned to normal after moving away.

Jafari reported a round object emerging from the primary object and moving towards him at high speed. His weapons control panel failed, and he lost all instruments and radio communication. Instructed to return to base, Jafari saw the primary, diamond-shaped object and another bright object descending towards the ground, emitting a bright light. The next day, Jafari and Damirian searched the area by helicopter but found nothing. Residents reported hearing a loud noise and seeing a bright flash of light.

Analysis 🔗

Martin Bridgstock of Griffith University summarized the incident as Iranian air force jets investigating lights in the sky, with at least one jet experiencing electrical failures and an attempt to fire a missile. A nearby airliner also suffered radio failure.

Philip J. Klass suggested the pilots initially mistook Jupiter for a UFO. He attributed equipment failures to pilot incompetence and equipment malfunction. Klass noted that only the first F-4 reported equipment failure and had a history of electrical outages. A McDonnell Douglas repair supervisor suggested the radar might have been in “manual track” mode, leading to misinterpretation.

Bridgstock criticized UFOlogists’ reports and highlighted Klass’s findings that only one aircraft had electrical malfunctions and that the aircrews were tired and could have mistaken stars or meteors for UFOs.

Brian Dunning noted that the incident occurred during the peak of the Gamma Piscids and Southern Piscids meteorite showers, making observations of falling objects common. A beeping transponder from a C-141 aircraft was found at the supposed crash site. Dunning concluded that the Tehran 1976 UFO case was unusual only because planes chased celestial objects and experienced equipment failures.

Reference to incident in the media 🔗

The Sightings television program covered the incident in 1994, interviewing participants. The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian listed it among their top 10 UFO sightings.

Gallery 🔗

The gallery includes an editorial from the United States Air Force Security Services quarterly MIJI newsletter, which Dunning describes as a dramatized retelling of the incident offered as an editorial on jamming and interference.

See also 🔗

Links to related articles including UFO sightings in Iran and a list of UFO sightings.

References 🔗

A list of references is provided, including reports from the National Security Agency, articles from The Times, Columbia Journalism Review, The New Yorker, Herald-Tribune, Skeptoid.com, books by Leslie Kean and Philip J. Klass, and articles from The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian.

External links 🔗

Links to external resources such as the original report, DIA reports, and articles from Skeptoid.com and NICAP.org.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_Tehran_UFO_incident

item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in DC Comics 🔗

This is a comprehensive list of extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics, including comic books and other media. It provides brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Overview 🔗

The DC Comics universe contains a vast number of alien races, most of which are humanoid.

United Planets 🔗

The United Planets is a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. Members include planets of the Solar System, Htrae, artificial planet-sized satellites, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. In the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros.

0-9 🔗

5th Dimensional Imps 🔗

Zrfff is the homeworld of 5th Dimensional Imps, including Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Brpxz, Mister Genie (Genro), Quisp, Bat-Mite, Kcid Nosyarg (Larry), Zook, Gazook, and Mopee. In other media, 5th Dimensional Imps appear in Supergirl, consisting of Mxyzptlk and Gsptlsnz / Nyxlygsptlnz. The Music Meister is revealed to be an imp in a Supergirl crossover with The Flash.

A 🔗

Adaptoids 🔗

The Adaptoids are blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus that attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans 🔗

The Aellans are yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello (Stormswift), Demonia, Harpis, and Doc of Aello were all members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders 🔗

The Alien Invaders are the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci 🔗

The Almeraci are a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the House of the Blood Royale, a matriarchy of superpowered monarchs. They choose mates through ceremonial gladiatorial competitions. Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and her onetime betrothed Ultraa represent this species.

Aloi 🔗

The Aloi are blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device known as the “Grayl”. Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans 🔗

The Alstairans of Alstair are plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, one of four technologically advanced spacefaring races native to the Antares system. Their ruler is the alien plant elemental Hyathis.

Anasazi 🔗

The Anasazi are metahumans resettled to planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Andromedans 🔗

The Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy are a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites, with red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak was exiled to Earth and later cured by Superman and Vartox.

Angtuans 🔗

The Angtuans are inhabitants of the planet Angtu, a world with a thick, noxious atmosphere. Angtu was destroyed in the 30th century by the mutated native Mano.

Anunnake 🔗

The Anunnake are reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs; they are also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann 🔗

The Anndrann are green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, later banished to Bellatrix, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a deleterious effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians 🔗

The Appellaxians of Appellax are technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies for their minds. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. The Justice League first came together because of them. In Young Justice, Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem using a Mother Box, before it is destroyed by Black Beetle.

Aipitons 🔗

The Aipitons are the presumed name of a species of small flying insects of the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids 🔗

The Aquoids are natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes 🔗

The Aranes of Arane II are light blue-skinned, white-haired humanoids with tiny blue protruding horns on their foreheads. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans 🔗

The Ardenans are the presumed name of a sentient race of humanoids with orange scaly skin from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians 🔗

The Astonians are a minor alien race under a once dying star saved by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker upon facing extinction. Saint Walker is of this race.

Azarathians 🔗

The Azarathians are people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B 🔗

Barrions 🔗

The Barrions of Barrio III are silicon-based lifeforms, represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers 🔗

The Bellatrix Bombers are alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians 🔗

The Bgztlians are humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Blight 🔗

The Blight are a cybernetic race whose bodies are composed of rotting flesh and villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos.

Bloodline Parasites 🔗

The eight Bloodline Parasites were extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of accidentally activating the human metagene during the act of feeding on human spinal fluid.

Braalians 🔗

The Braalians are humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes are their representatives.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X 🔗

The Brain-Parasites of Planet X hail from Planet X and use powerful Knowledge-Extractors to steal knowledge from other races.

Branx 🔗

The Branx of Emana Branx are a gray-skinned race of dull-witted, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians.

Brylyx 🔗

The Brylyx are white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians 🔗

The Bolovax Vikians are highly communal and technologically advanced. Bolovax Vikians of Bolovax Vik are a dead race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member of this species. A holographic Bolovax Vikian appears in the My Adventures with Superman episode “The Machine Who Would Be Empire”.

Bugs of New Genesis 🔗

The Bugs of New Genesis are an insectoid race who were spread on New Genesis during their war with Apokolips. Forager and Mantis are the most prominent members of the race.

C 🔗

Cairnians 🔗

The Cairnians are members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians 🔗

The Calatonians are an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by the Doomsday creature.

Canopians 🔗

The Canopians are a member of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites 🔗

The Carggites are humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Catherix 🔗

The Cathexis are a race of alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality endangering technology.

Changralynians 🔗

The Changralynians of Changralyn are a race of silicon-based pacifists, they are represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Children of Tanjent 🔗

The Children of Tanjent are a psionic race.

Circadians 🔗

The peaceful insectoid Circadians of Circadia established a joint human/Circadian settlement in the 30th Century known as Pax Colony. Circadia Senius is a Chronarch Research Fellow at the Metropolis Time Institute and a friend of Brainiac 5.

Citadelians 🔗

The Citadelians of the Citadel are a race of sadistic imperialistic clones, whose intellect and genetic viability degrades with each newly cloned generation.

Clementians 🔗

The Clementians of Clementia are also known as “Black Mercies”. The Green Lantern Mother Mercy is the caretaker and ruler of the Clementian race.

Coluans 🔗

The Coluans (sometimes known as Yod-Colu) of Colu are a hyper-intelligent species, one of the most technologically advanced in the known universe. They are most notably represented by the various men and women who hold the title of Brainiac along with Pulsar Stargrave. The planet Colu was destroyed by the Omega Titans in Justice League: No Justice. The Coluans appear in *

The Alien 🔗

This article details the history of The Alien, an unproduced science fiction film conceived by Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray in the late 1960s. The film was a joint venture between India and the United States, with Columbia Pictures slated to produce it. Despite the involvement of notable actors like Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando, the film was ultimately shelved.

Plot 🔗

The story centers around an alien spaceship that lands in a rural village in Bengal, India. The villagers, awestruck by the craft, begin to worship it. The alien, named “Mr. Ang,” communicates with a young boy named Haba through dreams and engages in playful pranks within the village. The narrative also includes an Indian businessman, a journalist from Calcutta (now Kolkata), and an American engineer. A specific scene is highlighted, describing the alien’s interaction with plant life, showcasing its gentle and curious nature.

Production 🔗

Columbia Pictures was the producer for this planned US–India co-production, and Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando were slated to play lead roles. However, Ray discovered that his script had been copyrighted by Michael Wilson, his representative in Hollywood, who claimed co-writer credit without contributing to the writing. Marlon Brando later left the project, and although James Coburn was considered as a replacement, Ray became discouraged and returned to Calcutta. Columbia Pictures expressed interest in reviving the project in the 1970s and 1980s, but it never materialized.

Legacy 🔗

The article discusses the similarities between The Alien and Steven Spielberg’s E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, released in 1982. Satyajit Ray pointed out the parallels between his script and Spielberg’s film, suggesting that E.T. would not have been possible without his script being available in Hollywood. Spielberg denied these claims. The article also mentions the Hindi film Koi… Mil Gaya, directed by Rakesh Roshan, as another film that appears to be based on The Alien, particularly in its focus on an intellectually disabled person interacting with a friendly alien. In 2003, Satyajit Ray’s son, Sandip Ray, began adapting Ray’s original 1962 story Bankubabur Bandhu into a Bengali television movie of the same name, which was eventually broadcast in India in 2006.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Alien_(unproduced_film)

item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation 🔗

A science fiction police procedural television series that aired on Fox from 1989 to 1990. It’s based on the 1988 film Alien Nation.

Plot 🔗

The series is set in the near future, beginning in 1990, after a flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert. The ship contains the Tenctonese, a race of extraterrestrials escaping slavery. They are accepted as immigrants to the US, and the series explores their integration into American society. Storylines often address themes of racism and bigotry, using the Newcomers as a stand-in for discriminated minorities. The series uses social commentary to illustrate what it means to be human and the often bizarre rituals we observe.

Cast 🔗

  • Detective Matthew “Matt” Sikes: Played by Gary Graham, a human detective partnered with George Francisco.
  • Detective George Francisco: Played by Eric Pierpoint, a Newcomer detective partnered with Matthew Sikes.
  • Susan Francisco: Played by Michele Scarabelli, George’s wife, a Newcomer advertising businesswoman.
  • Emily Francisco: Played by Lauren Woodland, George and Susan’s young daughter.
  • Buck Francisco: Played by Sean Six, George and Susan’s initially delinquent teenage son.
  • Cathy Frankel: Played by Terri Treas, Matt’s Newcomer neighbor and on-off girlfriend, a bio-chemist.
  • Albert Einstein: Played by Jeff Marcus, a timid Newcomer janitor working at the police department.
  • Cpt. Bryon Grazer: Played by Ron Fassler, Matt and George’s human superior officer.
  • Beatrice Zepeda: Played by Jenny Gago, a human detective in Matt and George’s squad.
  • Burns: Played by Jeff Doucette, a human photographer.
  • Sergeant Dobbs: Played by Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, a human police officer.
  • Jill: Played by Molly Morgan, a human girl and Emily’s friend.
  • Uncle Moodri: Played by James Greene, an eccentric but wise Newcomer and member of the Francisco family.

Production 🔗

Kenneth Johnson, responsible for other science-fiction television series, was approached for the television adaptation of the 1988 film Alien Nation. He initially had no interest in the project but was later inspired to create a series focusing on social commentary about the integration of a new minority group.

Changes from the film 🔗

Several changes were made from the original film. The human detective Matthew Sykes was played by James Caan in the film, but Gary Graham in the TV series. Detective George Francisco was played by Mandy Patinkin in the film, but Eric Pierpoint in the TV series. The TV series explores Newcomer culture more deeply than the film. Francisco’s family also differs, with a daughter, Emily, added to the TV series.

Cancellation 🔗

The series ran for one season on Fox. Despite building a strong fan base, the show was cancelled due to the network’s financial difficulties. The season ended on a cliffhanger, and popular demand led to the unproduced second season premiere being adapted as a novel and comic book. Years later, Fox produced five television films to continue the story.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of 22 episodes, each dealing with the integration of the Newcomers into human society and the challenges they face. The episodes often involve police procedural elements, with Sikes and Francisco investigating crimes involving both humans and Newcomers.

Television films 🔗

Five television films continued the story after the series’ cancellation:

  • Alien Nation: Dark Horizon (1994)
  • Alien Nation: Body and Soul (1995)
  • Alien Nation: Millennium (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Enemy Within (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Udara Legacy (1997)

Home media 🔗

The complete series was released on DVD by 20th Century Fox in 2006. The five television films were later released as a collection.

Revival 🔗

In 2009, Syfy announced a new take on the series with Tim Minear writing. However, the series was later cancelled. In 2015, a remake was reported to be in the works with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing the script.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Nation_(TV_series)

item.title: Storm Area 51
item.description:
Storm Area 51 🔗

Storm Area 51 was a Facebook event and internet meme that gained widespread attention in 2019. It centered around the idea of raiding Area 51, a highly classified United States Air Force facility, in search of extraterrestrial life.

Background 🔗

Area 51 is a United States Air Force facility within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It opened in 1955 and functioned as an aircraft testing and development facility during the Cold War. Due to its intense secrecy, Area 51 has become the subject of conspiracy theories regarding the presence of aliens. These theories began in the 1950s, with some individuals reporting UFO sightings at the base. Conspiracy theorists believe aliens, UFOs, or related information are stored at Area 51.

Facebook event and Internet meme 🔗

Matty Roberts, a Bakersfield resident and moderator of the Facebook page Shitposting cause I’m in shambles, created the Storm Area 51 event. He devised the idea after watching Area 51 conspiracy theorist Bob Lazar and filmmaker Jeremy Corbell on The Joe Rogan Experience podcast. The event was planned to take place in Amargosa Valley on September 20, 2019. The Facebook event page included the phrase “If we Naruto run, we can move faster than their bullets. Lets see them aliens.” The event quickly went viral, spreading to other social media platforms. The event received 2 million “going” and 1.5 million “interested” signatures. Rapper Lil Nas X released a music video for the remix of “Old Town Road” about the planned raid. Copycat events were also created, such as plans to storm a genealogical vault of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Loch Ness, the Bermuda Triangle, the US Capitol Building, and the Vatican City’s archives.

Response 🔗

National government 🔗

Air Force spokeswoman Laura McAndrews stated that officials were aware of the event and issued a warning against attempting to enter the area. The FBI also stated that they would be monitoring the situation. The FAA posted temporary flight restrictions, closing the airspace above two places nearby Area 51. The DVIDS made a Twitter post depicting military personnel and a B-2 stealth bomber with a controversial caption, which was later deleted, and an apology was issued.

Local government 🔗

Lincoln County officials drafted an emergency declaration and a plan to pool resources with neighboring counties, anticipating a large crowd. Concerns were raised about the limited number of hotel rooms, cellphone network capacity, and overcrowding at campsites, gas stations, and medical facilities. The town of Rachel posted a caution on its website, advising attendees to be experienced in desert survival and warning that the town would likely be unable to provide sufficient resources.

Businesses 🔗

Business owners in and around Rachel, Nevada, made preparations for visitors. Connie West, co-owner of the Little A’Le’Inn, booked all rooms and planned to open up camping space. Las Vegas businessman George Harris planned to hire bands for a festival called “The Swarm.” Other businesses around the U.S. based products and services on the event. Bud Light planned to release a promotional alien-themed beer label. Arby’s had planned to deliver food with a special menu to the event.

Gathering and music festivals 🔗

While the event was intended as comedic, some took it seriously and traveled to areas surrounding the facility. The Lincoln County Sheriff estimated that about 1,500 people showed up at the festivals, while about 150 people made the journey to the back gate of Area 51. One person attempted to enter the facility and received a warning, while six others were arrested for various offenses. Two people were injured in a rollover crash near Rachel.

Two music festivals were announced: Alienstock in Rachel, Nevada, and Storm Area 51 Basecamp in Hiko, Nevada. Event creator Roberts pulled out of Alienstock 10 days before the festival, citing poor planning, and joined an alien-themed party in Las Vegas. Roberts’s lawyers sent a cease and desist regarding use of the name to Little A’Le’Inn owner Connie West, who continued with the name Alienstock in Rachel, Nevada. After the raid, the Area 51 Basecamp event was deemed a failure, while Alienstock was considered a success. The event’s aftermath saw several pending lawsuits surrounding the festival and Roberts’s call to breach the government facility.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm_Area_51

item.title: Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family
item.description:
Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family 🔗

Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family is an Indian animated science fiction comedy series that premiered on Nickelodeon India on April 24, 2023. The show is directed by Abhijit Daripkar and Santosh Pednekar and produced by Hi-Tech Animation. The title track’s lyrics are by Gulzar, with music by Simaab Sen. The series revolves around a 12-year-old boy named Abhimanyu who can transform into an alien, focusing on his efforts to fit into human society, make friends, hide his identity, and overcome challenges.

Synopsis 🔗

The series tells the story of Abhimanyu, a 12-year-old who can transform into an alien. The narrative focuses on his journey to integrate with humans, form friendships, conceal his true identity, and tackle various challenges. It also highlights his family’s adaptation struggles. Characters are shown in both human and alien forms.

Cast 🔗

The voice cast includes:

  • Jasleen Singh as Abhimanyu
  • Merlin James as Arya
  • Mohit Sinha as Naveen
  • Roop Thakkar as Kookie
  • Sanchit Wartak as Supremo of Planet Zonga and Mr. Ghotala
  • Asavari Ajinkya as Mrs. Ghotala
  • Pratik Verma as Ronnie

Characters 🔗

  • Abhimanyu: The protagonist, a smart and strong alien who can assimilate powers from objects. He must conceal his abilities to maintain his human disguise.
  • Arya: Abhimanyu’s sister and the first-in-command on the Earth mission, serving as Supremo’s eyes and ears. Her elastic tongue helps her solve problems.
  • Naveen: Abhimanyu’s father, who can turn people into statues with a touch. He is timid and clumsy, struggling with physical contact.
  • Kookie: Abhimanyu’s mother, who can move massive objects and manipulate wind. She is fascinated by Earth fashion and enjoys shopping.
  • Supremo of Planet Zonga: The commander of the aliens’ Earth mission, instructing them to maintain human forms.
  • Mr. Ghotala: The Kumar family’s neighbor, an alien research scientist who suspects aliens are nearby. His catchphrase is “Aiga!”.
  • Mrs. Ghotala: The neighbor and friend of the Kumar family. Her catchphrase is “Sahi samay par sahi jagah tapakne ki toh meri aadat hai!”.
  • Ronnie: The Ghotalas’ son, a bully who uses his height and fashion sense to cause trouble. He is Abhimanyu’s enemy.

Production 🔗

Viacom18’s Kids TV Network produces the series, and Nickelodeon distributes it. Hi-Tech Animation conceptualized and produced the show using 3D animation techniques with 2D rendering.

Episodes 🔗

Season 1 🔗

Season 1 consists of 70 episodes, with titles including “Being Human,” “Ghotala Dinner,” “Alien Sunglasses,” “Beware Of Dog,” “Charge Ho Jao,” and many others.

Reception 🔗

Garima Das of Outlook India included Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family in a list of sci-fi shows to watch, highlighting the show’s premise and the challenges faced by the alien characters as they navigate human life.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abhimanyu_Ki_Alien_Family

item.title: Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film)
item.description:
Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film) 🔗

This article provides a detailed overview of the 2011 American science fiction Western film Cowboys & Aliens, directed by Jon Favreau. It covers various aspects of the film, including its plot, cast, production, themes, marketing, release, reception, and home media.

Plot 🔗

The plot unfolds in 1873 New Mexico Territory, where an amnesiac outlaw named Jake Lonergan, portrayed by Daniel Craig, awakens with a mysterious metal bracelet attached to his wrist. He finds himself in the town of Absolution, which is soon attacked by aliens. The aliens abduct several townspeople, including Sheriff Taggart and Percy Dolarhyde. Lonergan’s bracelet activates, transforming into a weapon that he uses to shoot down an alien ship. A posse, including Colonel Woodrow Dolarhyde (Harrison Ford) and a mysterious woman named Ella Swenson (Olivia Wilde), forms to track the aliens. Lonergan’s memories gradually return, revealing his past abduction and the death of his lover, Alice. Ella reveals herself to be an alien from another race, who came to Earth to help resist the invaders. The group plans an attack on the aliens’ mothership, resulting in a final confrontation where Ella sacrifices herself to destroy the ship and save Earth.

Cast 🔗

The film features a prominent cast:

  • Daniel Craig as Jake Lonergan, an amnesiac outlaw.
  • Harrison Ford as Woodrow Dolarhyde, a powerful cattleman.
  • Olivia Wilde as Ella Swenson, an alien traveler.
  • Sam Rockwell as Doc, a doctor and saloon owner.
  • Adam Beach as Nat Colorado, Dolarhyde’s Apache right-hand man.
  • Paul Dano as Percy Dolarhyde, Woodrow’s son.
  • Noah Ringer as Emmett Taggart, Taggart’s grandson.
  • Keith Carradine as Sheriff John Taggart.
  • Clancy Brown as Meacham, Absolution’s preacher.

Production 🔗

The production section details the film’s development, casting, writing, filming, design, and visual effects. The project began in 1997, with Universal Pictures and DreamWorks Pictures acquiring film rights to a concept by Scott Mitchell Rosenberg. Jon Favreau joined as director in 2009, and Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford were cast in the lead roles. Filming took place in New Mexico and California in 2010. The film was shot in the anamorphic format on 35mm film to achieve a classic movie feel. Industrial Light & Magic (ILM) created the visual effects, with Legacy Effects producing practical puppet aliens.

Themes 🔗

The film explores themes of redemption, unity against a common enemy, and the clash between low-tech and high-tech cultures. Jon Favreau aimed for a plausible approach to how 19th-century humans could confront technologically superior extraterrestrial beings. The film also draws parallels between the alien invasion and the historical conflicts between European settlers and Native Americans.

Marketing 🔗

The marketing section discusses the challenges of promoting a film with an “inherently comic” title and premise. The studio aimed to convey the film’s serious tone and adventure elements through trailers and presentations at events like San Diego Comic-Con.

Release 🔗

Cowboys & Aliens premiered at San Diego Comic-Con in July 2011 and was released theatrically in the United States and Canada on July 29, 2011. Paramount Pictures released the film in IMAX theaters internationally, and Reliance Entertainment released it in India.

Reception 🔗

The reception section covers the film’s box office performance and critical response. Cowboys & Aliens underperformed at the box office, earning $174.8 million worldwide on a $163 million budget. Critics praised the acting and special effects but criticized the screenplay and tone.

Home Media 🔗

The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray Disc on December 6, 2011, including an extended version, behind-the-scenes featurettes, and commentary with Jon Favreau. In 2024, Kino Lorber released a 4K Blu-ray of the theatrical cut.

Infringement Lawsuit 🔗

Steven John Busti filed a lawsuit against Universal, DreamWorks, Platinum Studios, and Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, claiming copyright infringement. Busti claimed he wrote a preview for his story Cowboys and Aliens in 1994, which was published in the April 1995 issue of Bizarre Fantasy #1. The lawsuit was dismissed.

Historical Legend 🔗

The capsized steamboat that appears in the film is presumed to be the Iron Mountain which, according to legend, steamed out of Vicksburg towing two barges. Two hours later, another boat found the barges adrift. The ship was not found until later, having apparently been refloated by flood waters and carried through a break in a levee, and grounded in a cotton field at Omega Landing, near Tallulah, Louisiana.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cowboys_%26_Aliens

item.title: Big Sur UFO
item.description:
The Big Sur UFO 🔗

This article details a reported UFO incident that allegedly occurred during a 1964 Air Force mission near Big Sur, California. The Air Force team was stationed on a mountaintop to film Atlas missile tests from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

Air Force deployment to Anderson Peak 🔗

From August to November 1964, the U.S. Air Force deployed personnel to the Los Padres National Forest in California. They used a special telescope borrowed from Boston University to photograph missile launches from Vandenberg Air Force Base. Lt. Robert Jacobs was the commander for the Big Sur location, managed by the 1369th Photo Squadron. The team successfully filmed nine launches, including one of an Atlas missile called “Buzzing Bee,” capturing footage of a re-entry vehicle deploying decoy warheads. This technology was highly classified and designed to protect American nuclear weapons from Soviet interception.

Fringe claims of extra-terrestrials 🔗

In 1982, Robert Jacobs wrote about the incident in the tabloid National Enquirer, claiming he had been part of a cover-up and was now breaking his silence. He described film footage of an unidentified object next to a warhead and a senior official’s reaction. Jacobs claimed he was instructed to never discuss the film. Major Florenz Mansmann reportedly confirmed Jacobs’ account in a 1987 letter. Robert Hastings, a UFO author, further popularized the story in 2007. In 2021, Jacobs participated in a press conference to discuss his interpretation of the incident.

Decoy warheads explanation 🔗

Kingston A. George, the project engineer during the incident, disputed Jacob’s claims of extraterrestrial interference in the Skeptical Inquirer. George stated that he, too, had seen footage he wasn’t cleared to see and was instructed not to speak of it. However, George claims he knew the true purpose of the test: filming the deployment of decoy warheads and chaff to confuse enemy air defenses. He attributed the lights Jacobs reported to the explosive deployment of decoys and chaff, not a UFO energy beam.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from Military.com, Skeptical Inquirer, National Enquirer, and MUFON UFO Journal.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “Malmstrom UFO incident” Wikipedia page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Sur_UFO

item.title: First contact (anthropology)
item.description:
First Contact (Anthropology) 🔗

First contact, in anthropology, refers to the initial meeting between two communities that were previously unaware of each other. This phenomenon is often associated with significant cultural and societal impacts.

Consequences 🔗

When cultures with vastly different technological advancements meet, the more technologically advanced society often has a disruptive advantage. This can lead to dire consequences for the less advanced society. Disease transmission also plays a critical role, as isolated populations often lack immunity to illnesses carried by the more urbanized society. The relative sizes of the populations involved can also influence intercultural development. Outcomes of first contact can range from social integration and colonization to elimination (genocide).

History 🔗

Before contemporary instances of contact with uncontacted peoples, many communities and states were isolated from each other, possessing limited knowledge of one another. The limited formal contact between Europe and China via the Silk Road and later with the Mongol Empire is one such example. European powers, such as Prince Henry the Navigator of Portugal, sought to reach Greater India, leading to the mistaken identification of the Americas as the West Indies and the indigenous peoples of the Americas as “Indians.” This “discovery” has been criticized as one-sided and has parallels in contemporary narratives of first contact beyond Earth, such as the Pioneer plaque. Colonialism often used first contact as a means to control knowledge and representation of “the other,” objectifying contact and its place on the frontier.

Notable Examples 🔗

Numerous instances of first contact have occurred throughout history, including Alexander the Great’s invasions from Persia to India in 330 BC and the establishment of Romano-Chinese relations in the 2nd century AD. However, well-established trade routes meant that many cultures were aware of each other before they met.

Some specific examples include:

  • ~1000: Vikings, led by Leif Erikson, established a settlement at L’Anse Aux Meadows (present-day Canada) and encountered the Beothuk people (referred to as Skræling). The nature of this contact (peaceful or violent) is debated.
  • 12 October 1492: Christopher Columbus’s first voyage led to contact between the Spanish Empire and the Taíno, Galibi, and Ciboney peoples in the West Indies. This contact was violent and resulted in numerous deaths, enslavement, and subjugation of the indigenous inhabitants.
  • 17 June 1579: Francis Drake’s circumnavigation brought the English into contact with the Coast Miwok in Northern California. Relations remained peaceful during Drake’s month-long stay, during which he claimed the land for England as Nova Albion.
  • 21 July 1595: Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira led a Spanish expedition to the Marquesas Islands (French Polynesia), resulting in initial friendly contact with the Polynesians that quickly turned violent, leading to 200 local deaths in the first two weeks.
  • 19 December 1642: Abel Tasman’s first voyage led to contact between the Dutch and the Ngāti Tūmatakōkiri in New Zealand. The encounter resulted in the death of four Dutch and the wounding of one Māori, with no further communication.
  • 19 January 1788: James Cook’s third voyage brought the British into contact with the Native Hawaiians on Kauai, Hawaii. General friendly trade occurred, but one Indigenous Hawaiian was killed.
  • 21 January 1788: The First Fleet’s arrival in Sydney, Australia, led to contact between the British Empire and the Cadigal and Bidjigal peoples. The initial contact was friendly but reserved, with one aborigine likely beaten.
  • 29 November 1791: William R. Broughton led a British expedition to Chatham Island, New Zealand, resulting in contact with the Moriori people. Initial shows of aggression by the Moriori were followed by peaceful relations, but a fight led to the death of one Moriori.
  • 1930: Mick Leahy led an Australian expedition to the New Guinea Highlands, resulting in contact with the Papuan people. The contact was friendly, with some Highland people believing the Australians were their ancestors and attempting to rub off their white skins.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(anthropology)

item.title: UFO sightings in Spain
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Spain 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Spain, organized chronologically by year.

1976 🔗

This section details an incident at the Talavera la Real Air Base in Badajoz province on November 12, 1976. Two soldiers, José María Trejo and Juan Carrizosa Luján, reported encountering a being of unknown origin. They heard unusual noises and saw a bright light. They described the being as approximately 3 meters tall, human-shaped, with a small head, long arms, and no apparent hands or feet. The soldiers claimed to have fired 40 to 50 bullets at the being, which then disappeared. An investigation by the Air Force confirmed that the soldiers fired their weapons, but no bullet casings or holes were found. Spanish Army veteran Vicente Juan suggests the soldiers experienced a hallucination.

1979 🔗

This section refers to the Manises UFO Incident, which occurred on November 11, 1979. This event involved a commercial flight making an emergency landing at Manises airport in Valencia due to a reported UFO encounter.

1981 🔗

This section mentions an event on July 24, 1981, where Prudencio Muguruza reportedly saw a bright light crash near Ochate. He took a photo of the event.

1994 🔗

This section notes a Tunguska-like event that occurred on January 18 in Cando, Galicia, Spain.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including the “List of reported UFO sightings” and “UFO sightings in the Canary Islands.”

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from El Mundo and Mundo Misterioso. The references provide verification and further information on the events described.

External links 🔗

This section includes a link to MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) for recent UFO sightings and pictures.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Spain

item.title: UFO sightings in South Africa
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in South Africa 🔗

This article documents reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) in South Africa.

1914 Phantom Monoplanes 🔗

This section details a series of sightings from August to September 1914, where numerous South Africans reported seeing a nighttime monoplane. These sightings occurred during the lead-up to the South West Africa campaign of World War I, leading to speculation that it was a German spy plane. However, the origin of the plane remained unknown, leading some to consider mass hysteria as a possible explanation. Key locations include various parts of South Africa.

1970s Sighting 🔗

This section focuses on an incident from June 26, 1971, involving Bennie Smit, a farm owner near Fort Beaufort in the Eastern Cape. Smit and local police reportedly fired shots at a fireball-like object that changed color. Rumors circulated about an army investigation, though no records were found. The incident gained international attention, and local businesses capitalized on the event.

1990s Sightings 🔗

This section covers several UFO sightings during the 1990s:

  • April 7, 1991: A family in Baviaanspoort, Pretoria, reported a triangular craft with red and white lights. Similar sightings occurred in nearby Eersterust.
  • November 18, 1993: Residents of Sasolburg observed lights moving from Vereeniging, describing a craft that could change color and shape.
  • September–October 1994: A farmer in Warrenton claimed to see a ‘mothership’ with a distinctive engine sound.
  • March–April 1995: A UFO flap occurred across South Africa, with reports including a hovering object at De Brug, a spacecraft blocking a road near Coligny, and disruptions to vehicles and watches.
  • August 28, 1996: Police Sgt. Nico Stander in Pretoria videotaped lights in the sky, leading to a chase involving police and a helicopter near Cullinan.
  • July 1997: Andreas Mathios claimed to film a cylindrical light above Trichardt.
  • May 8, 2000: Police inspector Kriel reported observing an orange, oval-shaped light on the N3 freeway near Warden.

21st Century 🔗

This section details UFO sightings in the 2000s and beyond:

  • June 27, 2004: Roshnie Naidu in Durban reported observing and videotaping a bright, colorful light changing shape.
  • 2009: Multiple people witnessed orange-red objects traveling between Middelburg and Witbank.
  • July 21–22, 2010: Residents of Booysens, Pretoria, reported seeing a triangle of bright lights.
  • May–October 2011: Numerous reports of silent, orange lights over Tierpoort and Krugersdorp, with additional sightings near Harrismith.
  • November 2015: Residents in Pietermaritzburg and Clarendon reported seeing orange orbs, and a green light was reported over Long Street in Cape Town.
  • December 12, 2016: The captain and co-pilot of a Boeing 737 cargo aircraft reported seeing a glowing green object near Jeffreys Bay.

Crash Claims and Hoaxes 🔗

This section addresses claims of alien spacecraft being shot down by South African aircraft in 1989 and 1995, which were later determined to be hoaxes.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the main “List of reported UFO sightings” article on Wikipedia.

Notes 🔗

This section contains footnotes and references to support the information presented in the article, citing various news reports, books, and other sources.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to UFO research in South Africa, including scans of Cynthia Hind’s UFO Afrinews and the UfoRSA website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_South_Africa

item.title: Alien TV (2019 TV series)
item.description:
Alien TV (2019 TV series) 🔗

Alien TV is a live-action/CG animation television series that premiered on 9Go! in Australia on November 23, 2019, and on Netflix. The show was created by Ian Brown and developed by Doug Hadders and Adam Rotstein. The series follows a television news crew of extraterrestrials named Ixbee, Pixbee, and Squee, who are sent to Earth to learn about the planet.

Cast 🔗

The main voice cast includes Rob Tinkler as Ixbee, Julie Lemieux as Pixbee, John Cleland as Squee, Kyle Dooley as Squood, and Rupert Degas as the Translator.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of two seasons. Season 1 was released on August 21, 2020, and Season 2 was released on March 19, 2021. There are no plans for a season 3.

Series Overview 🔗

The series is divided into two seasons, with 13 episodes each. Season 1 was released in 2020, and Season 2 in 2021. Each episode contains three segments.

Season 1 (2020) 🔗

Season 1 consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. Each segment focuses on the aliens’ experiences with different aspects of Earth culture and activities, such as bicycles, gymnastics, camping, playgrounds, art, gum, gyms, birthdays, restaurants, BBQs, offices, Halloween, pizza, magic, cleaning, arcades, dumplings, presents, junkyards, spas, love, movies, kindergarten, sickness, babies, supermarkets, tea, weddings, Loch Ness, soccer, skateboards, mannequins, survival, toyshops, laundromats, yoga, Santa, trophies, and makeup. Each segment is directed by Ian Brown and written by various writers, including Doug Hadders, Adam Rotstein, Jeff Sager, Brian Hartigan, Shawn Kalb, Cleon Prineas, Laurie Elliott, Bruce Griffiths, Simon Dodd, Jennifer Daley, Thomas Duncan-Watt and Naomi Jardine.

Season 2 (2021) 🔗

Season 2 also consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. The segments continue to explore the aliens’ interactions with Earth, featuring topics such as trains, barbershops, gnomes, florists, fashion, teeth, pools, dinner parties, skiing, joke shops, the Outback, fire halls, baby showers, yard sales, aquariums, dance, international games, shopping, school, holidays, lucha libre, cars, sleep, golf, airplanes, water parks, mail, music, bowling, gardening, museums, Bollywood, castles, ballet, energy, leprechauns, glasses, trials, and scary things. Ian Brown directs all segments, and the writing credits include Naomi Jardine, Jerome Simpson, Bruce Griffiths, Jennifer Daley, Jeff Sager, Kyle Dooley, Simon Dodd, Cleon Prineas, Brian Hartigan, and Gina Roncoli Bruce Griffiths.

item.title: UFO sightings in Russia
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Russia 🔗

This article catalogs alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) within Russia. It presents a list of incidents, each with a brief description and, where available, links to further information.

Sightings 🔗

This section details specific alleged UFO sightings in Russia, spanning from the early 20th century to the early 21st century.

  • Tunguska Event (1908): While generally attributed to a meteor explosion, some propose that the Tunguska event in Siberia was caused by a UFO explosion.
  • Petrozavodsk Phenomenon (September 20, 1977): This event involved sightings of unusual aerial phenomena over Petrozavodsk and surrounding areas.
  • Usove, Soviet Ukraine (October 4, 1982): A UFO allegedly hovered over a nuclear missile launch facility, causing the activation of nuclear missiles.
  • Voronezh UFO Incident (1989): This incident involved reported sightings of a UFO and alleged encounters with extraterrestrial beings in Voronezh.
  • Sasovo Explosions (April 12, 1990, and July 8, 1992): Two mysterious explosions occurred in Sasovo, Ryazan Oblast, with force equivalent to 25 tons of TNT.
  • Otradnenskoye “UFO Fragment” (Early 2012): A titanium object, described as a “UFO fragment,” was found near Otradnenskoye in Novosibirsk Oblast after unusual sounds were reported. The object was U-shaped and not linked to space technology.

This section focuses on the Emilcin Abduction, where a farmer in Emilcin claimed to have been abducted and examined by short, green-faced humanoid beings. The encounter allegedly took place inside a white, hovering craft. A memorial now stands at the site of the alleged abduction.

19 January 2009, Jarnołtówek 🔗

item.title: UFO sightings in Norway
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Norway 🔗

This article documents reported UFO sightings in Norway, spanning from 1986 to 2009. Each sighting includes a brief description, location, and any explanations or analyses provided.

1986 🔗

This section details a sighting that occurred on July 13, 1986, near Torpo. Married couples Tova and Tonning observed two bright objects in the sky, and Mr. Tonning filmed the event. The film was analyzed by Ground Saucer Watch (GSW), which found no evidence of a hoax but couldn’t definitively identify the objects due to a lack of reference points. Other experts suggested the objects were Jupiter and Arcturus.

2006 🔗

This section recounts a widespread sighting on August 21, 2006, where a bright, green orb was seen across northern Norway, from Finnsnes in Troms to Bodø in Nordland. Witnesses described the object as moving at great speed and being larger than an aircraft. Initially considered a possible UFO, the phenomenon was later attributed to a bolide.

2009 🔗

This section focuses on the 2009 Norwegian spiral anomaly, which occurred on December 9, 2009. A bluish spiraling light was observed, filmed, and photographed over Norway. While the exact cause remains uncertain, Norwegian news sources attributed the event to a failed Russian missile launch. A link to the main article on the anomaly is provided.

item.title: UFO sightings in Mexico
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Mexico 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Mexico, spanning from the late 19th century to the early 21st century. It presents specific incidents, including details, locations, and explanations where available.

1883 🔗

This section focuses on the observations made by astronomer José Bonilla on August 12, 1883, at the Zacatecas Observatory. Bonilla reported seeing and photographing numerous dark objects crossing the sun. Initially considered a potential early UFO photograph, the objects were later identified as high-flying geese. Despite the explanation, the event is still sometimes cited in ufological contexts.

1974 🔗

This section details the alleged mid-air collision between a UFO and a small airplane near Coyame on August 25, 1974. It mentions reports from local residents and claims of a subsequent military investigation and cover-up. However, it also presents an alternative explanation suggesting the reports were related to the crash and military recovery of a Cessna aircraft involved in drug trafficking.

2004 🔗

This section describes an incident on March 5, 2004, where Mexican Air Force pilots, using infrared equipment, recorded 11 unidentified objects over southern Campeche. The Mexican Defense Department released a press release and videotape of the event. Ufologist Jaime Maussan interpreted the footage as evidence of alien visitation. Skeptic Michael Shermer criticized the varying witness accounts, and other experts suggested the lights were likely burn-off flares from offshore oil platforms in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: UFO sightings in Iran
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings within the nation of Iran 🔗

This article documents alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in Iran.

1976 🔗

This section focuses on the 1976 Tehran UFO incident. This event involved radar and visual sightings of a UFO over Tehran. Key aspects include electromagnetic interference affecting approaching F-4 jet interceptors, causing instrumentation and communication failures that were resolved upon retreat. One F-4 also experienced weapons system failure when preparing to engage the object. The incident is documented in a U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) report distributed to high-ranking officials and agencies. Iranian military officers involved publicly stated their belief that the object was extraterrestrial.

1982 🔗

This section mentions a mass sighting in Isfahan during the summer of 1982. Thousands of people reportedly witnessed a large reflection of an object in the sky. However, this event lacks a citation.

2003 🔗

This section details a sighting near the Caspian Sea in August 2003. Two tourists reported observing a couple of yellow-white colored UFOs.

2004 🔗

This section describes a mass UFO sighting event, known as the 2004 Iran UFO sighting, which occurred between April 12–21. Thousands of people witnessed the UFOs, and one was filmed by Iranian TV. The nature of the objects remains unclear, with possibilities including UFOs, surveillance aircraft, or the planet Venus. Photos surfaced, with some deemed unknown by UFO groups but others dismissed as hoaxes, conventional aircraft, or Venus.

2005 🔗

This section mentions a report from a tourist who claimed to have seen a UFO hovering near the Tomb of Cyrus the Great.

2007 🔗

This section discusses a reported UFO crash in the Barez Mounts of Kerman province. Eyewitnesses informed the Fars News Agency (FNA) about a radiant UFO crash. Abulghassem Nasrollahi, the Deputy General of Kerman province, confirmed that all aircraft in the area were accounted for but didn’t dismiss the possibility of a meteor. Another source told FNA that the object was on fire with thick smoke, suggesting it wasn’t a meteor. A similar incident was reported in Rafsanjan a few days prior.

This section provides links to related articles, including the “List of reported UFO sightings.”

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to UFOinfo.com and BBC News articles.
