item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques Vallée in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include Aimé Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA 🔗

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

Official White 🔗

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) 🔗

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 🔗

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited 🔗

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors 🔗

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents 🔗

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies 🔗

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath 🔗

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views 🔗

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: Finnish Air Force UFO sighting
item.description:
Finnish Air Force UFO Sighting 🔗

The Finnish Air Force UFO sighting, also known as “The seven balloons of Pori,” refers to a UFO observation that occurred on April 12, 1969, in Pori, Finland, during military training exercises. This event is notable as the only UFO observation acknowledged by the Finnish Air Force. The Air Force suggested the objects may have been foreign reconnaissance aircraft.

Sighting 🔗

During a Fouga Magister jet training mission at Pori Airport on April 12, 1969, a Finnish Defence Forces flight controller instructed pilot-in-training Tarmo Tukeva to investigate seven airborne objects. These objects were floating at an altitude of approximately 1500-3000 meters above the airport. Tukeva described the objects as ball or disc-shaped but could not accurately determine his distance from them. He reported that the objects accelerated away from him “at great speed.” Radar images, the nature of which remains undetermined, were also reported 200 kilometers away in Vaasa. Jouko Kuronen, another pilot-in-training, stated that he overheard the radio communications between the flight controller and Tukeva and also observed the objects. According to the Finnish Armed Forces magazine Ruotuväki, the reports from April 12 were similar to other cases occurring over bodies of water during ongoing military exercises, suggesting the possibility of “transnational spy planes or aircraft.”

References 🔗

The references section lists the sources used to support the information presented in the article. These include articles from Ilta-Sanomat and Yle Uutiset, both Finnish news outlets. These articles provide further details and context regarding the UFO sighting and the Finnish Air Force’s acknowledgment of the event.

UFOs 🔗

This section provides a comprehensive template of UFO-related topics, including ufology, claimed sightings, types of UFOs, alleged extraterrestrial beings, studies, hypotheses, conspiracy theories, alien involvement, culture, skepticism, government involvement, and related categories. It serves as a navigation tool to explore various aspects of the UFO phenomenon.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finnish_Air_Force_UFO_sighting

item.title: Aliens in the Family (1996 TV series)
item.description:
Aliens in the Family (1996 TV series) 🔗

Aliens in the Family is an American science fantasy sitcom that aired on ABC from March 15 to August 31, 1996. It was created by Andy and Susan Borowitz and was part of ABC’s TGIF lineup.

Premise 🔗

The show centers around Doug Brody, a single father, who is abducted by Cookie, a single alien mother. They fall in love, get married, and attempt to live a normal life on Earth as a blended family.

Cast 🔗

The main cast includes:

  • John Bedford Lloyd as Doug Brody
  • Margaret Trigg as Cookie Brody
  • Paige Tiffany as Heather Brody
  • Chris Marquette as Adam Brody
  • Julie Dretzin as Sally Hagen

The show also features several puppeteers who brought the alien characters to life:

  • Alice Dinnean as Snizzy (face and voice)
  • Michael Gilden as Snizzy (body)
  • John Kennedy as Bobut (face)
  • Bruce Lanoil as Spit (face)
  • Peter Linz as Varch, Elder of the Nertron Galactic Federation, Red Yukkle
  • Joey Mazzarino as Spit (voice), Green and Yellow Yukkles
  • David Rudman as Bobut (body and voice), Orange and Purple Yukkles
  • Michelan Sisti as Spit (body)

Production 🔗

Andy and Susan Borowitz created, wrote, and executive produced the series. Brian Henson, son of Jim Henson, served as co-executive producer. Todd Rundgren wrote and performed the theme song. The series was filmed entirely at Lifetime Studios in New York City.

Episodes 🔗

The show had one season consisting of eight episodes:

  1. “Meet the Brodys” (March 15, 1996)
  2. “Bobut Conquers All” (March 22, 1996)
  3. “Cookie Makes Some Dough” (July 27, 1996)
  4. “You Don’t Have a Pet to Be Popular” (August 3, 1996)
  5. “Too Good to Be True” (August 10, 1996)
  6. “Respect Your Elders” (August 17, 1996)
  7. “Dissected and Neglected” (August 24, 1996)
  8. “A Very Brody Tweeznax” (August 31, 1996)

Cancellation 🔗

ABC canceled the show from its TGIF lineup after only two weeks. The remaining episodes aired on Saturday mornings during the summer of 1996.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_in_the_Family

item.title: UFO Hunters
item.description:
UFO Hunters 🔗

UFO Hunters is an American television series that aired on the History Channel from 2008 to 2009, spanning three seasons. The show explores the realm of ufology, pseudoscience, and conspiracy theories, with each episode focusing on investigations into reported UFO sightings and related phenomena.

Format 🔗

The show follows investigations led by William J. Birnes and his team of experts. The team includes researchers, engineers, and biologists who investigate reports of unidentified aerial phenomena, interview witnesses, analyze evidence, and consult with other experts to determine the validity of UFO reports. The team investigates long-standing UFO cases, such as the Roswell incident, and other famous sightings.

Series overview 🔗

The series consists of three seasons, with a total of 39 episodes. Season 1 premiered on January 30, 2008, and concluded on May 7, 2008, with 13 episodes. Season 2 aired from October 29, 2008, to February 25, 2009, also with 13 episodes. Season 3 premiered on March 18, 2009, and concluded on October 29, 2009, with 13 episodes.

Episodes 🔗

Season 1 (2008) 🔗

Season 1 explores various UFO-related topics and incidents. Key episodes include “The UFO Before Roswell,” which examines the Maury Island incident in Washington, and “USOs,” which investigates unidentified submerged objects off the coast of Santa Catalina Island, California. “Abductions” revisits the Betty and Barney Hill case in New Hampshire, while “Crash and Retrieval” delves into UFO crash cases in Coyame and Xilitla, Mexico. Other episodes cover military encounters with UFOs, police reports involving UFO sightings, rumors of reverse engineering of alien technology, UFO hotspots like the Hudson Valley and Stonehenge, alien contact experiences, mass UFO sightings in Texas, UFO dogfights involving Iranian and Peruvian fighter pilots, military air traffic controllers tracking UFOs, and NASA’s potential knowledge of UFOs.

Season 2 (2008–09) 🔗

Season 2 continues the investigation into UFO phenomena with episodes such as “Invasion Illinois,” which examines a mass sighting event in Tinley Park, Illinois. “UFO Emergency” reopens police cold cases involving mass UFO sightings in Trumbull County, Ohio, Holland, Michigan, and Millstadt, Illinois. “Heartland Explosion” investigates a mysterious boom and fiery object sighting in Kokomo, Indiana. “Aurora First Contact” researches the 1897 UFO crash in Aurora, Texas. “The Real Roswell” explores rumors of a crash site in Aztec, New Mexico. “Arizona Lights” investigates a mass sighting of a triangular craft over the Nevada/Arizona border and connections to the Phoenix Lights incident. “Lost UFO Files” delves into the archives of UFO investigator James E. McDonald. “Alien Fallout” examines close encounters of the second kind, such as the Cash-Landrum incident. “UFO Storm” investigates a wave of UFO hysteria in the United Kingdom. “Giant UFOs” probes sightings of gigantic unidentified craft over England and the United States. “Aliens at the Airport” investigates encounters between commercial aircraft and UFOs at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago and Osaka, Japan. “Alien Crashes” examines the crash of an unknown object in Needles, California, and the Kecksburg, Pennsylvania, incident. “Area 51 Revealed” explores recent activity at Area 51.

Season 3 (2009) 🔗

Season 3 investigates various UFO-related topics. “Giant Triangles” examines black triangle reports in Sonora, California. “Underground Alien Bases” explores claims about the Dulce Base in New Mexico. “The Greys Conspiracy” investigates alien abduction cases involving Grey aliens. “Underwater Alien Bases” delves into reports from Gulf Breeze, Florida, and Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. “Nazi UFOs” investigates rumors of the Third Reich’s involvement with alien technology and the Die Glocke project. “Alien Harvest” examines cattle mutilations in Norwood, Missouri, and black helicopter sightings in Trinidad, Colorado. “UFO Relics” studies physical evidence from UFO sightings in Poland and Missouri. “Underwater Area 51” monitors activity at the Atlantic Undersea Test and Evaluation Center (AUTEC). “UFO Surveillance” analyzes videos and accounts suggesting a UFO presence at Brookhaven National Laboratory and Lawrence Livermore Laboratory. “Dark Presence” investigates orb phenomena in Arizona, Indiana, and Missouri. “First Response” explores military protocols for UFO incidents near Long Beach, California, and Needles, California. “The Silencers” delves into cases involving the Men in Black. “Area 52” investigates the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_Hunters

item.title: NASA Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Independent Study Team
item.description:
NASA Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Independent Study Team 🔗

The NASA Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Independent Study Team (UAPIST) was a group of experts assembled by NASA to create a plan for analyzing unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAPs).
David Spergel, chair of NASA’s independent study on UAPs, answers a question during a public meeting of the team on May 31, 2023.
Agency overview
Formed May 24, 2022 (2022-05-24)
Dissolved September 14, 2023 (2023-09-14)
Agency executives * David Spergel, chair * Daniel Evans, designated federal official
Parent agency NASA
Website Official website

Scope and objectives 🔗

The UAPIST was officially created by Karen St. Germain, the director of NASA’s Earth Science Division, as a subcommittee of the Earth Science Advisory Committee (ESAC) on May 24, 2022. NASA appointed astrophysicist David Spergel as the chair of the team, and Daniel Evans as the official responsible for the study. The team’s goal was to gather data from various sources (civilians, government, non-profits, companies) to analyze UAPs. NASA emphasized openness and transparency, stating that findings would be shared publicly. The study was separate from the Department of Defense’s UAP efforts, although NASA coordinated with the government. In July 2022, the Department of Defense replaced the Airborne Object Identification and Management Synchronization Group with the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO). Further terms of reference were signed on May 18, 2023, extending the UAPIST and renaming it by changing “Aerial” to “Anomalous”. Sean Kirkpatrick, director of the Defense Department’s AARO, spoke at the first public meeting on May 31, 2023, emphasizing the complementary nature of NASA and AARO’s efforts. NASA focused on unclassified data, while AARO included classified material.

UAP versus UFO terminology 🔗

The term UAP emerged in the late 1960s, while “unidentified flying object” (UFO) dates back to 1947. UAP avoids the cultural associations with extraterrestrial life linked to UFOs. UFO has become associated with aliens, conspiracy theories, and religious movements. NASA updated the name of its independent study team at the start of 2023 from “unidentified aerial phenomena” to “unidentified anomalous phenomena” to be consistent with the James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023.

Team members 🔗

NASA announced the UAP study team members on October 21, 2022. The team included:

  1. David Spergel
  2. Anamaria Berea (George Mason University)
  3. Federica Bianco (University of Delaware)
  4. Paula Bontempi
  5. Reggie Brothers (AE Industrial Partners)
  6. Jen Buss (Potomac Institute for Policy Studies)
  7. Nadia Drake
  8. Mike Gold (Redwire)
  9. David Grinspoon
  10. Scott Kelly
  11. Matt Mountain
  12. Warren Randolph (FAA)
  13. Walter Scott (Maxar Technologies)
  14. Joshua Semeter (Boston University)
  15. Karlin Toner (FAA)
  16. Shelley Wright (University of California, San Diego)

Greg Eghigian noted that the NASA study team represents a significant shift, with many academics now supporting scholarly research into UFOs. He highlighted that NASA’s involvement and the scientifically informed questions being asked are unprecedented.

Team member commentary 🔗

During the first public meeting on May 31, 2023, the NASA team addressed questions about UFOs. They emphasized collecting empirical data and improving UAP analysis. Spergel noted that many UAP events could be attributed to commercial aircraft, drones, balloons, weather, and ionospheric phenomena, but some events remain unexplained due to poor data quality. He cited fast radio bursts as an example of how anomalies can lead to novel physical phenomena. Regarding David Grusch’s claims of a government coverup, Joshua Semeter stated that the NASA team is collaborating with the Defense Department’s AARO to determine the origin and nature of UAPs.

Final report 🔗

The independent study team’s final report was published on September 14, 2023, along with the announcement of a director of UAP research at NASA. The report found no evidence of extraterrestrial life. The report stated that the lack of reproducible data makes it difficult to draw conclusions about some UAP origins. It recommended a rigorous, evidence-based approach to studying UAPs, including data collection methods using artificial intelligence and citizen observers. NASA was deemed well-positioned to lead this study. According to its 2023 terms of reference, the team was dissolved upon the completion and submission of its final report.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA%27s_UAP_independent_study_team

item.title: Trinity UFO Case
item.description:
Trinity UFO Case 🔗

This article discusses the alleged Trinity UFO case, a story about a crashed unidentified object near the Trinity test site in New Mexico in August 1945. The narrative centers around claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca, who, as young boys, reported witnessing the crash and its aftermath.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Trinity UFO case by referencing the broader history of UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting, the 1947 flying disc craze, the Roswell incident, and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax. It also introduces Jacques Vallée, a ufologist and author who publicized the Trinity case, noting his involvement in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

The Context 🔗

This section describes the setting of the alleged incident, focusing on the Padilla family’s ranch near the Trinity test site. It details the family’s lifestyle, including Faustino Padilla’s work and José’s responsibilities on the ranch. It also mentions the impact of the Trinity test on the local population, including Inez Padilla’s loss of eyesight. The section touches on the backgrounds of both the Padilla and Baca families, noting their Spanish and Apache heritage.

Claims by Padilla and Baca 🔗

This section outlines the specific claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca regarding their alleged encounter with a crashed UFO.

First day 🔗

This subsection details the initial sighting of the crashed object by Padilla and Baca on August 16, 1945. It describes their search for a lost cow, the loud bang they heard, and their discovery of a groove in the ground leading to an “avocado-shaped” object. They report seeing small, insect-like creatures near the object, which they compared to a praying mantis, Jerusalem cricket, and fire ant. The boys estimated the object’s size and described its metallic appearance, as well as the appearance of the creatures.

Third day 🔗

This subsection recounts the boys’ return to the crash site with José Padilla’s father, Faustino Padilla, and Eddie Apodaca, a state police officer. It states that the adults entered the object but were visibly disturbed afterward, warning the boys to remain silent. The boys later returned alone and witnessed soldiers collecting debris.

Fourth day 🔗

This subsection describes a visit to the Padilla family by Sergeant R. Avila, who requested permission to access the property to recover an “experimental weather balloon.” Avila emphasized the need for secrecy and the use of heavy equipment.

The fifth and the following days 🔗

This subsection details the alleged military operation to recover the crashed object. It describes the construction of a road and gate, the arrival of a lowboy trailer, and the use of a crane to lift the object. Padilla and Baca claim to have secretly observed the military’s activities. They also describe how they obtained a “souvenir” from inside the object, a metal piece they named “Tesoro.”

After the recovery 🔗

This section describes the aftermath of the alleged recovery operation. It mentions the removal of the object, the clearing of the crash site, and the hiding of the “Tesoro” by the boys. It also touches on the atmosphere of secrecy and fear in the area, with rumors of government intervention for those who spoke too much about the events. Vallée draws parallels between this case and the Roswell incident.

Publication 🔗

This section details the publication history of the Trinity UFO case. It mentions Ben Moffett’s initial reporting in 2003, the analysis of the “Tesoro” metal piece, Timothy Good’s mention of the incident in his book, and Paola Harris’s awareness of the case.

Criticisms and responses 🔗

This section presents criticisms of the Trinity UFO case, primarily from skeptical writer Brian Dunning, who characterizes the story as a hoax. Dunning cites inconsistencies in the story, such as the claim that Eddie Apodaca was a state trooper at the time of the incident, when he was actually serving in World War II. It also includes responses from Jacques Vallée, who defends the case and addresses the criticisms raised by Douglas Dean Johnson. Vallée acknowledges some inaccuracies in the original reporting but maintains that the core story is valid.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, specifically the Roswell incident and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists the books cited in the article, including Need to Know by Timothy Good and Trinity: The Best-Kept Secret by Jacques Vallée and Paola L. Harris.

References 🔗

This section provides a list of citations used in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_UFO_Case

item.title: Flight 105 UFO sighting
item.description:
Flight 105 UFO Sighting 🔗

This article details the UFO sighting reported by the crew of United Airlines Flight 105 on July 4, 1947, over the Pacific Northwest. It connects the event to the broader context of the 1947 flying disc craze and provides background information, a description of the sighting, its aftermath, and eventual explanation.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Flight 105 incident by referencing the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting and the broader 1947 flying disc craze. It explains how Arnold’s report of objects flying near Mount Rainier led to the terms “flying saucers” and “flying discs” and sparked a wave of similar reports. The section establishes the Flight 105 sighting as part of this larger phenomenon.

Sighting 🔗

This section describes the details of the Flight 105 UFO sighting. On July 4, 1947, United Airlines Flight 105, a Douglas DC-3, departed from Boise, Idaho, bound for Pendleton, Oregon. First Officer Ralph Stevens spotted unusual objects and alerted Captain E.J. Smith. Both men, along with stewardess Marty Morrow, observed four to five “flat and circular” objects. The objects were larger than aircraft and flew in formation for approximately 10 to 15 minutes (about 45 miles). The crew radioed the tower in Ontario, Oregon, and another United flight, but neither could confirm the sighting. The passengers did not see the objects. The objects eventually sped away or disintegrated.

Aftermath 🔗

This section discusses the immediate reactions and consequences of the Flight 105 sighting. News outlets widely reported the crew’s account. The report was considered credible due to the professional background of the witnesses. Captain Smith, Ralph Stevens, and Kenneth Arnold were photographed together “comparing notes.” Kenneth Arnold felt vindicated by the corroboration of his own sighting. Arnold and Smith were interviewed by the FBI and investigated the Maury Island hoax together. Another “disklike object” was sighted on Flight 105 later in July by a different pair of pilots.

Explanation and Legacy 🔗

This section explains the official explanation for the Flight 105 sighting and its lasting impact. Air Materiel Command concluded that the objects were likely “ordinary aircraft, balloons, birds, or pure illusion” due to the sighting occurring at sunset. The Air Force suggested the power of suggestion influenced observers during the craze. Despite the official explanation, the Flight 105 sighting has become part of UFO folklore and conspiracy theories.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_105_UFO_sighting

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the United States 🔗

This is a compilation of reported UFO sightings within the United States, presented in a table format. Each entry includes the date of the sighting, the city and state where it occurred, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Table of Sightings 🔗

The table lists alleged UFO sightings chronologically, starting from September 1865 and extending to February 2023. Each row provides details about a specific incident.

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported seeing a craft and its subsequent crash, noting sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.

  • 1896–1897, Multiple Locations, Multiple States: Sightings of airship-like vehicles were reported across the United States during this period, known as the Mystery airship wave.

  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the deceased alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery.

  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles” involved an alleged enemy attack and anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Initially thought to be a Japanese attack, it was later attributed to “war nerves” and a possible weather balloon. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called the incident a “false alarm.”

  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported seeing an “avocado-shaped” object crash, containing insect-like alien creatures, shortly after the first atomic bomb detonation.

  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: This incident predates the Kenneth Arnold sighting and involves a reported encounter with “men in black” suits.

  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation near Mount Rainier. His description of the objects’ erratic flight and tremendous speed gained widespread media attention.

  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident involves the recovery of materials near Roswell, becoming a subject of intense speculation. The military claims it was a crashed research balloon, while ufologists believe it was an alien craft.

  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident involved the death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while pursuing a UFO.

  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involves two commercial pilots reporting a near-collision with a torpedo-shaped object.

  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight involves a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.

  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: Paul and Evelyn Trent took the McMinnville UFO photographs on their farm.

  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers on an American Airlines DC-6 reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”

  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention during a period of high interest in UFOs and alien invasion.

  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.

  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and their pilots during his drives home from an aircraft plant.

  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved multiple reports of unidentified flying objects over the city.

  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported seeing a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature.

  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.

item.title: Ariel School UFO incident
item.description:
1994 Sighting in Zimbabwe 🔗

On September 16, 1994, a UFO sighting occurred outside Ruwa, Zimbabwe, witnessed by 62 pupils aged six to twelve at Ariel School. The children reported seeing silver crafts descend from the sky and land in a nearby field. Some claimed to have encountered creatures dressed in black who communicated a telepathic message with an environmental theme, causing fear and distress.

Fortean writer Jerome Clark called it the “most remarkable close encounter of the third kind of the 1990s.” Skeptics have suggested mass hysteria as a possible explanation. Some children maintain the truthfulness of their accounts.

Background 🔗

Ruwa is described as a small agricultural center 22 kilometers southeast of Harare. Ariel School was a private school, primarily attended by children from wealthy white families in Harare.

Two days before the Ariel School incident, numerous UFO sightings were reported throughout southern Africa, including reports of a bright fireball in the sky at night. This led to a wave of UFO mania in Zimbabwe. Brian Dunning suggests the fireball was the re-entry of the Zenit-2 rocket from the Cosmos 2290 satellite launch. Local UFO researcher Cynthia Hind recorded other alien sightings during this period.

Incident 🔗

The sightings at Ariel School occurred at 10 a.m. on September 16, 1994, during mid-morning break. The faculty was in a meeting at the time. The incident lasted about fifteen minutes. The children reported the event to their teachers, but were dismissed.

After telling their parents, many parents came to the school the next day to discuss the incident with the faculty. The sighting was reported on ZBC Radio, where Cynthia Hind learned about it.

BBC correspondent Tim Leach visited the school on September 19 to film interviews with pupils and staff. Hind visited the school on September 20, interviewing children and asking them to draw what they had seen. She reported that the children told her the same story.

In November, Harvard University professor of psychiatry John Mack visited the school to interview witnesses. Mack had investigated UFO sightings and the alien abduction phenomenon throughout the 1990s.

According to interviews by Hind, Leach, and Mack, 62 children reported seeing at least one UFO. Silver objects, usually described as discs, appeared in the sky and descended to a field near the school.

Between one and four creatures with big eyes and dressed in black exited a craft and approached the children. Some children ran, but others stayed and watched. Mack’s interviews suggest the creatures telepathically communicated an environmental message to the children before returning to the craft and flying away. Dunning notes that the telepathic message aspect was primarily in Mack’s reports, although Hind reported it later.

Children described being warned about impending events and the importance of avoiding pollution. One child said they were told the world would end because of a lack of care for the planet.

The children insisted they had not seen a plane. Hind noted that the children’s different cultural backgrounds led to varying interpretations, with some believing they had seen tikoloshes from Shona and Ndebele folklore rather than extraterrestrials.

Aftermath 🔗

The Ariel School UFO incident became a famous UFO case in Africa. A June 2021 episode of the BBC’s Witness History described it as “one of the most significant events in UFO history.” Ufologists continue to cite the case as evidence of extraterrestrial visits to Earth. Skeptics have suggested mass hysteria or a prank as explanations. Gideon Reid proposed a hypothesis involving confusion with touring puppet shows promoting AIDS awareness. Another argument suggests the children misidentified a dust devil.

Hind interviewed the children in groups, potentially leading to cross-contamination of their stories. Dunning says that Mack, interviewed the children two months after the alleged sighting and as a known environmentalist, “prompted and suggested” the telepathic communication angle, which was not present in Hind’s previous report.

Several witnesses maintain the truthfulness of their accounts. In 2014, a witness told the Mail & Guardian that she fears the creatures will return and that she can sense when they are back in the atmosphere. In 2016, witness Emily Trim exhibited paintings described as a “manifestation of the messages she received” from the beings. In June 2021, Barstool Sports writer Zah, a former Ariel School pupil, recounted seeing a bright light and aliens exiting it. Other witnesses were interviewed for the 2020 documentary The Phenomenon.

In the 2023 Netflix documentary “Encounters”, a former student named Dallyn claimed that he was behind this incident. He claimed that he purposefully told his classmates and other students that a “shiny rock” in the distance was a UFO. According to his own statement in the documentary, he never thought this would work, and was surprised about the mass hysteria. Dallyn’s claims in the documentary directly contradict claims made on camera 15 years prior to the documentary, describing the UFO as having a light that would “flash a different color in the sky.”

  • List of reported UFO sightings
  • Westall UFO, a similar UFO sighting by school students

item.title: Trident A Proposed Mission to Neptune and Triton
item.description:
Trident: A Proposed Mission to Neptune and Triton 🔗

This article details the Trident mission, a proposed NASA space probe designed to study Neptune and its moon Triton. It outlines the mission’s objectives, timeline, scientific payload, and its selection process within NASA’s Discovery Program.

Mission Overview 🔗

Trident was a proposed reconnaissance mission to the outer solar system, specifically targeting Neptune and its moon Triton. The mission aimed to capitalize on a rare 13-year alignment of Jupiter and Neptune to enable efficient gravity assists. The primary goal was to study Triton, building upon the limited data obtained during Voyager 2’s flyby in 1989. The mission was proposed to NASA’s Discovery Program in 2019.

History 🔗

This section recounts the context for the Trident mission, emphasizing the importance of Triton as a geologically active moon with cryovolcanoes and a thin atmosphere. It highlights that Voyager 2 only observed about 40% of Triton’s surface. The Trident mission concept emerged from NASA’s Ocean Worlds Exploration Program to address unanswered questions from the Voyager 2 flyby.

Overview 🔗

This section details the mission’s scientific objectives and planned trajectory. Trident aimed to take advantage of a favorable gravity assist alignment between Jupiter and Neptune, which occurs once every 13 years. This alignment would allow the spacecraft to reach Neptune and Triton in 2038. The mission would map Triton’s surface, analyze its plume activity, and assess the potential existence of an internal ocean. The principal investigator for the Trident mission was Louise Prockter, director of the Lunar and Planetary Institute in Houston, Texas. The proposed launch vehicle was the Atlas V 401, potentially replaced by the Vulcan rocket.

Payload 🔗

This section lists the scientific instruments that Trident would carry to study Neptune and Triton. The payload includes:

  • An infrared spectrometer for compositional mapping.
  • Narrow and wide-angle cameras for high-resolution imaging.
  • A triaxial magnetometer for ocean detection.
  • Radio science equipment for atmospheric and gravimetry observations.
  • A plasma spectrometer for analyzing atmospheric charged particles.

The instruments have heritage from previous missions like New Horizons, Cassini, Psyche, MESSENGER, Rosetta, and JUICE.

Objects that Trident would visit 🔗

This section lists the celestial bodies that Trident would fly by during its mission. These include:

  • Venus (for a gravity assist)
  • Earth (for multiple gravity assists)
  • Jupiter and its moon Io (for a gravity assist)
  • Neptune and its moon Triton (the primary targets)

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related space missions and concepts, including:

  • Argo, a 2009 Triton flyby mission concept.
  • Interstellar Express, a Chinese probe with a planned Neptune and Triton flyby.
  • New Horizons, which performed a Pluto flyby.
  • New Horizons 2, a mission proposal that might have included a Triton flyby.
  • Triton Hopper, a lander concept for Triton.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trident_(spacecraft)

This is a compilation of songs across various decades that explore lyrical themes related to close encounters with extraterrestrial aliens.

1940s 🔗

This section highlights the earliest example on the list, “(When You See) Those Flying Saucers” by The Buchanan Brothers, released in July 1947. Its release coincided with the beginning of the flying saucer era, shortly after the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting.

1950s 🔗

The 1950s saw a surge in songs about flying saucers and aliens. Notable entries include “The Flying Saucer Parts 1 & 2” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, “My Flying Saucer” with lyrics by Woodie Guthrie, “The Purple People Eater” by Sheb Wooley, “Two Little Men In A Flying Saucer” by Ella Fitzgerald, and “Flyin’ Saucers Rock & Roll” by Billy Lee Riley and Jerry Lee Lewis.

Key songs include “Let There Be More Light” and “Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun” by Pink Floyd, “Mr. Spaceman” by The Byrds, “Voices Green and Purple” by The Bees, “It Came Out of the Sky” by Creedence Clearwater Revival, “Have You Seen the Saucers” by Jefferson Airplane, and “U.F.O.” by Jim Sullivan.

item.title: Shag Harbour UFO incident
item.description:
Shag Harbour UFO Incident 🔗

The Shag Harbour UFO incident refers to the reported crash of a large, unidentified object into the waters near Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia, on October 4, 1967. The incident was investigated by Canadian civilian and military agencies, as well as the U.S. Condon Committee.

Pre-incident Aerial Phenomenon 🔗

This section details several aerial phenomena reported before the Shag Harbour incident.

Air Canada flight 305 🔗

Air Canada Flight 305, en route from Halifax to Toronto, experienced a sighting. First Officer Robert Ralph pointed out a strange object to Captain Pierre Charbonneau. The object was described as a brilliantly lit, rectangular shape with trailing lights, flying parallel to the aircraft. The pilots reported two silent explosions near the object.

Yellow object 🔗

Darrel Dorey, along with his sister Kaykay and mother, witnessed a large object maneuvering in the southwestern horizon from their porch in Mahone Bay. Dorey wrote to the RCAF Greenwood Base Commander to inquire about the object.

MV Nickerson of Sambro, Nova Scotia 🔗

Captain Leo Howard Mersey of the MV Nickerson observed four bright objects in a rectangular formation on his Decca radar and visually in the northeastern sky, approximately 28 kilometers from his vessel. The entire crew of nearly twenty fishermen witnessed the event. Mersey reported the sighting to the rescue coordination center and the harbor master in Halifax, and later filed a report with the Lunenburg RCMP.

Halifax Harbour sightings 🔗

The Chronicle-Herald and local radio stations reported numerous sightings of a glowing object around Halifax at approximately 10:00 pm.

Initial events 🔗

On October 4, 1967, at approximately 11:20 pm Atlantic Daylight Time, reports surfaced of an object crashing into the waters of Shag Harbour. At least eleven witnesses observed a low-flying, lit object heading towards the harbor, accompanied by whistling and whooshing sounds, followed by a loud bang. Laurie Wickens and four friends, driving on Highway 3, witnessed a large object descending into the water. They observed the object floating offshore and contacted the RCMP detachment in Barrington Passage, reporting a possible plane or airliner crash.

Search and rescue efforts 🔗

Following the initial report, two RCMP officers arrived at the scene. The RCMP contacted the Rescue Coordination Centre (RCC) in Halifax to report the incident and inquire about missing aircraft. The object, still displaying lights, began to sink and disappeared from view before any rescue attempt could be initiated.

A rescue mission was assembled, with local fishing boats and a Canadian Coast Guard cutter dispatched to the crash site. No survivors, bodies, or debris were recovered. The next morning, RCC Halifax confirmed that no aircraft were missing. Despite this, the search continued.

RCC Halifax sent a telex to the “Air Desk” at air force headquarters in Ottawa, classifying the incident as a “UFO Report.” The Air Desk then sent a telex to navy headquarters, recommending an underwater search. Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic was tasked with carrying out the search.

Two days after the incident, navy divers from Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic searched the seafloor off Shag Harbour for three days. The final report indicated that no trace of an object was found.

Documents 🔗

The Department of National Defence files at the national Library and Archives contain a summary of the event.

Press coverage 🔗

The Shag Harbour incident received extensive coverage in the Halifax Chronicle-Herald. A headline story on October 7, titled “Could Be Something Concrete in Shag Harbour UFO – RCAF,” detailed witness accounts, the air force’s search and rescue efforts, and the navy’s underwater search. Squadron Leader Bain, head of the air force’s “Air Desk,” expressed the air force’s strong interest in the matter.

Another article on October 9, titled “UFO Search Called Off,” reported the navy’s conclusion of the underwater search, stating that no trace of the object was found. The Canadian Press also carried the story of the search being called off.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shag_Harbour_UFO_incident

item.title: 1967 British flying saucer hoax
item.description:
1967 British Flying Saucer Hoax 🔗

The 1967 British flying saucer hoax involved the supposed landing of six ‘spaceships’ across Southern England on September 4, 1967. These ‘spacecraft’ prompted a significant response from the police and army. The objects were described as being 54 inches long, 30 inches wide, and 20 inches deep, weighing 100 pounds, and emitting an electronic noise. The six craft were located along the 51st line of latitude, stretching from the Thames Estuary to the Bristol Channel. Specific locations included Queenborough on the Isle of Sheppey, Bromley golf course in south London, Winkfield village near Ascot, Welford near Newbury, Chippenham in Wiltshire, and Dial Hill in Clevedon, Somerset.

Planning and Building the ‘Spacecraft’ 🔗

The hoax was conceived in January 1967 by aircraft engineering apprentices from the Royal Aircraft Establishment (RAE) at Farnborough as part of Rag Week. The apprentices constructed the flying saucers from fiberglass halves, covered them in metal, and equipped them with electronic devices to produce eerie sounds when flipped. Each saucer also contained a mixture of flour and water. Teams of two or three transported the saucers to the chosen locations at night, flipped them over to activate the sound, and then left the scene undetected.

Response from the Authorities 🔗

The discovery of the saucers triggered a large-scale response from authorities. Police cordoned off each site, and the British army’s southern command, multiple police forces, army bomb disposal units, and RAF helicopters were mobilized. The Ministry of Defence was notified. The army detonated the saucer found in Chippenham, while the one on the Isle of Sheppey was removed by helicopter. Other saucers were sent to the Atomic Weapons Establishment at Aldermaston and the British Aircraft Corporation’s guided weapons division. When one of the saucers was drilled into, the mixture inside exploded, covering police officers in foul-smelling slime.

Revealing the Hoax 🔗

Christopher Southall and Roger Palmer, both 21 years old, were identified as the pranksters behind the hoax. Their motive was to raise funds during Rag Week. The hoax generated extensive media coverage both in Britain and internationally. The apprentices revealed the hoax on the same day the saucers were found. No legal action was taken against them, and they successfully raised £2,000 for charity.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources used in the article, including BBC and The Guardian articles, and a GetSurrey news report.

item.title: Gulf Breeze UFO incident
item.description:
Gulf Breeze UFO Incident 🔗

The Gulf Breeze UFO incident refers to a series of claimed UFO sightings that occurred in Gulf Breeze, Florida, between November 1987 and May 1988. The events gained widespread attention after the Gulf Breeze Sentinel newspaper published photographs purportedly showing a UFO, provided by local contractor Ed Walters.

Events of November 11, 1987 – May 1, 1988 🔗

Ed Walters claimed to have been immobilized by a blue beam on November 11, 1987, after which he took photos of a UFO hovering near his home. He reported multiple subsequent encounters, taking more photos and even videotaping the object. Walters also claimed to have witnessed the craft landing and aliens exiting, communicating with him telepathically in English and Spanish, and even being lifted off the ground by a blue beam. He reported a total of nineteen sightings or encounters. On one occasion, he claimed the UFO leaked a liquid that continued to boil for weeks.

Investigation 🔗

Walters initially provided his photographs to the Gulf Breeze Sentinel anonymously. He later admitted to being the photographer and submitted to a polygraph test, which indicated he believed his photos were real. Walters also claimed to have experienced missing time on three prior occasions and under hypnosis, stated he had been abducted by aliens.

Several individuals investigated the claims. Ray Stanford initially questioned the weather data related to the photos but later conceded they were likely taken on the reported day. Phillip Klass dismissed the photos as inauthentic. Robert Nathan from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory suggested the images were double exposures or manipulated. Ed Gray, the mayor of Gulf Breeze, also concluded the photos were fake.

Budd Hopkins believed Walters’ claims were genuine, citing his polygraph test and refusal of a book deal. Bruce Maccabee found a good chance the photos were real. Willy Smith from UNICAT suggested a support under the UFO in the photos indicated it was a model.

Eglin Air Force Base, located near Gulf Breeze, reported no unusual activity or radar blips during the alleged sightings. Gulf Breeze’s police chief, Jerry Brown, attributed the sightings to hysteria and misidentification of activity at the base.

Eyewitness Reports 🔗

Following the publication of Walters’ photos, numerous other residents reported sightings in the Gulf Breeze area. These reports described orange glows, beams of light, and oval or oblong crafts. Fenner McConnell and his wife Shirley claimed to have seen a disc-shaped aircraft with no wings. Brenda Pollak, a Gulf Breeze councilwoman, reported seeing an orange light and witnessed Walters taking photos of a UFO at Shoreline Park. Santa Rosa County Commissioner John Broxson also claimed to have seen unusual lights. Other residents, like Art and Mary Hufford, and Jeff Thompson, reported seeing similar objects. A tollbooth operator, Jerry Thompson, reported seeing thirteen pink-lighted objects.

UFO Research Group Response 🔗

Supporters of Walters, particularly within MUFON, viewed the mass sightings as evidence of the phenomena’s authenticity. MUFON’s director, Walter Andrus, considered the Gulf Breeze incident their “best case ever.” Donald Ware, MUFON’s Florida director, believed the aliens wanted the photos to be seen.

CUFOS, founded by J. Allen Hynek, deemed Walters’ photos fake due to inconsistencies in the craft’s windows and waviness suggesting reflection off water. Friends of Walters reportedly described him as a prankster who had planned “the ultimate prank” and noted parallels between his story and Whitley Streiber’s book Communion.

Model Discovered 🔗

In 1990, a model resembling the UFO in Walters’ photos was found in the attic of his former home. The model was made of foam plates and drafting paper. Craig Myers of the Pensacola News Journal reported the discovery and was able to duplicate Walters’ photos using the model. Walters denied any knowledge of the model, claiming it was planted.

The discovery of the model caused division within the UFO community. Supporters claimed it was planted, while others expressed doubt in Walters’ claims. It was also revealed that Walters had received a $200,000 book advance and was offered $450,000 for miniseries rights. Additionally, he had a prior criminal record for forgery and auto theft, for which he received a pardon from Governor Bob Martinez.

Renewed Interest After 1990 🔗

UFO sightings continued at the Pensacola Bay Bridge into 1991. In 1993, a friend of the Walters family admitted to witnessing Ed faking the UFO pictures. Mark Curtis also reported that Walter and his wife had divorced in November 1992, splitting $2.5 million in assets believed to have come from the hoax.

MUFON held its first annual UFO symposium in Pensacola in 1990, which continued for the rest of the decade. The publicity attracted tourists and UFO sightseers, boosting the local economy.

In the Media 🔗

The Gulf Breeze UFO case was featured on Unsolved Mysteries and a TV special called “UFO Cover-UP…Live!”. Eyewitness Shirley McConnell discussed her experience on A Current Affair. Unsolved Mysteries, Inside Edition, and A Current Affair filmed more UFO shows in July 1990.

In a 1994 episode of The X-Files, Fox Mulder mentions the Gulf Breeze UFO photos, stating he knew they were fakes.

Gulf Breeze singer Ken Manning won an award for his song “Gulf Breeze UFO” in 1999.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_Breeze_UFO_incident

item.title: Ground Crew Project
item.description:
Ground Crew Project 🔗

The Ground Crew Project is a UFO religion originating in the United States, founded in the 1980s by Sheldan Nidle. It transitioned online in 1996 and later divided into the “Ground Crew” and “Planetary Activation Organisation.” The group anticipates a cosmic transformation of Earth, facilitated by a passage through a ‘photon belt’ and aided by the “Galactic Federation.” Members prepare for first contact, envisioning themselves as intermediaries between extraterrestrials and humanity. Despite failed predictions, the group maintains its belief in imminent contact and the need to elevate mankind’s consciousness.

Sheldan Nidle 🔗

Sheldan Nidle, born in 1946, claims to have had extraterrestrial encounters from a young age, including telepathic communication and learning aboard spacecraft with ETs from Sirius. He published You’re Becoming a Galactic Human in 1994, detailing a childhood encounter. He claims regular communication with ETs since 1955, which he ceased at age 14 to fulfill his ‘star seed’ mission. He later became involved with the Amateur Astronomers Club and a film about Nikola Tesla. Nidle holds advanced degrees from Ohio University and the University of Southern California. In the mid-1980s, he resumed contact with the “Galactic Federation” and became a lecturer representing them.

Galactic Federation 🔗

The Galactic Federation is described as an alliance of extraterrestrial civilizations within the Milky Way galaxy. This concept is popular in UFO religions and New Age movements.

Haim Eshed’s claims 🔗

In 2020, Haim Eshed, former head of Israel’s military space program, claimed that aliens have contacted representatives of the United States and Israel, but humanity is not ready for contact. He stated that aliens are present on Earth and have formed a “Galactic Federation” to avoid mass hysteria until humanity is ready. NASA responded by stating that no extraterrestrial life has been found, but the search continues.

Photon Belt 🔗

Beginning in 1996, Nidle channeled messages about an imminent apocalypse due to Earth’s planetary transformation. He claimed to lead a mission for the “Galactic Federation of Planets” to prepare the world for this transformation as the planet passes into a cosmic ‘photon belt’. This area of space supposedly has high energy properties that would transform Earth into a pristine state and restore superhuman abilities by altering human DNA to a 12-helix pattern. The pineal gland would be activated, and humans would regain cosmic abilities like rejuvenation, telepathy, and overcoming illness. The channeling claimed that human structures would be destroyed, and the only safe places would be underground or in spaceships.

Imminent Landing 🔗

The narrative stated that a mass landing of 15 million starships of the “Galactic Federation” would occur no later than December 17, 1996, to raise humanity’s consciousness using advanced technology, achieving a galactic and divine society by 2012. The landing would involve advanced races like Pleiadians, Sirians, Cassopeans, and Arcturians, who would meet and placate human populations. Earthly weapons would be neutralized, mechanical devices shut down, and world government taken over by the Spiritual Hierarchy. The Earth transformation would include telepathy, airborne transport, and photon energy generators. This is considered a “cargoistic” belief, where alien “cargo” brings about human ascension.

Ground Crew 🔗

The “Ground Crew” refers to the virtual congregation who join the mission. Members were told they would assist humanity and the extraterrestrials as councillors and ambassadors. They would be trained by space forces and receive implants. After failed predictions, the emphasis shifted to spiritual development, requiring the Ground Crew to help raise humanity spiritually and assist in ecological restoration. This involved gathering humanity through world meditation days to harmonize vibrations and creating a ’network of light’ with other new age groups.

Landings delayed 🔗

The December 1996 mass landing did not occur, but Nidle continued to spread messages that spaceships would appear soon. Further dates, including the Gregorian New Year and spring of 1997, also passed without a landing. Delays were attributed to a solar storm and planetary instability. Details about the comet Hale-Bopp were communicated, and the number of spaceships in the landing fleet was increased to 25 million.

Hale-Bopp 🔗

A new landing date was set to coincide with the arrival of the Hale-Bopp comet on May 5, 1997. The comet was described as a large spaceship with cloaking and holographic systems, containing a crew of over 200,000 beings and 10,000 ambassadors. This would coincide with the mass landing by the Federation. After the mass suicide of Heaven’s Gate members, the Ground Crew distanced themselves from such acts. Instead of a mass landing, a meeting between a shuttle from the comet and a shuttle from the “Galactic Federation Fleet” took place near Ayers Rock in Australia, where a ceremony was conducted, and papers were exchanged.

Further re-scheduling and shift in focus 🔗

Nidle and the Ground Crew blamed repeated failed prophecies on external factors, such as dark forces conspiring with ‘planetary elites’. Messages began to deny the relevance of specific arrival dates and talked about “the right divine time.” The focus shifted to humans assisting in the planet’s transformation before galactic intervention. Salvation became a two-way street, determined by human attitudes. A more spiritual content appeared, referring to beings like Ashtar Sheran, Aaron Alaje, Megha Alcorn, Merku Alcorn, Great White Brotherhood, Ascended Masters, and archangels.

Split 🔗

In December 1997, Nidle split with Valerie Donnell, his secretary and the Ground Crew’s chief administrator. Donnell retained the Ground Crew name and website, posting channeled messages with a UFO content focused on personal spiritual transformation from a new age perspective. Nidle founded the Planetary Activation Organisation, restructuring it as the only source for messages about the Galactic Federation. He established a hierarchical system and created a “Web of Light” to unite like-minded groups.

Evolution of the narrative 🔗

According to Nidle’s channeling, the Federation remained dedicated to first contact, but the spiritual transformation of humans became the main focus. Earth rulers were identified as a secret cabal, but would be removed by the Federation. ‘Star Gates’ were being placed in the upper atmosphere, and ‘Galactic and Medical Teams’ were assisting people during sleep. Earth was portrayed as a vitally important planet due to humanity’s exalted role, acting as a switch in the spiritual transformation of the Milky Way. By 2000, the movement continued to develop its membership base, claiming hundreds of Planetary Activation Groups in over 29 countries. The Planetary Activation Organisation is classified as a progressive millennialist group promising collective salvation and a terrestrial paradise.

Credibility 🔗

The Ground Crew employed strategies to avoid prophetic disconfirmation and cognitive dissonance, such as disclaimers and exploiting temporality. Nidle reconceptualized the movement through spiritualization, changing the focus from a UFO landing to the need for humans to raise their own spirituality. Due to the virtual nature of the group, it is impossible to accurately account for membership. The movement’s period of failed prophecy is no longer online. The online narrative functions like fiction, conveying a vivid imaginary world and apocalyptic expectancy.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Federation_(ufology)

item.title: Alien from L.A. (1988 Film)
item.description:
Alien from L.A. (1988 Film) 🔗

This is a description of the 1988 science fiction film Alien from L.A. directed by Albert Pyun, based on the provided Wikipedia article.

Overview 🔗

Alien from L.A. is a 1988 science fiction film directed by Albert Pyun, starring Kathy Ireland. The film centers on a young woman from Los Angeles who discovers an underground civilization in Atlantis. The film is loosely based on Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth. It was also featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot 🔗

Wanda Saknussemm, a social misfit from Los Angeles, learns of her archaeologist father’s death in North Africa. While sorting through his belongings, she discovers notes about Atlantis, an alien ship that crashed and sank into the Earth’s center. Wanda accidentally falls into a deep hole and awakens in the underground world of Atlantis. She encounters Gus, a miner, who helps her search for her father, whom she believes is still alive. The Atlanteans consider surface dwellers “aliens” and suspect Wanda and her father of planning an invasion. Wanda becomes a fugitive, pursued by “Government House” and the crime lord Mambino. She receives assistance from Charmin’, a rogue who falls in love with her. Eventually, Wanda is captured by General Rykov, who intends to kill her and her father. Gus helps them escape, and they return to the surface. The film concludes with Wanda rejecting her ex-boyfriend and reuniting with Charmin’ on a beach.

Cast 🔗

The film stars:

  • Kathy Ireland as Wanda Saknussemm
  • William R. Moses as Guten “Gus” Edway
  • Richard Haines as Professor Arnold Saknussemm
  • Don Michael Paul as Robbie
  • Thom Mathews as “Charmin'”
  • Janie Du Plessis as General Rykov / Shank / Claims Officer
  • Simon Poland as Consul Triton Crassus / The Mailman
  • Linda Kerridge as Roryis Freki / Auntie Pearl
  • Kristen Trucksess as Stacy
  • Lochner de Kock as Professor Ovid Galba / Paddy Mahoney
  • Deep Roy as Mambino, The Boss of Bosses

Production 🔗

Albert Pyun took on Alien from L.A. after being approached by producers Yoram Globus and Menahem Golan during the troubled production of Journey to the Center of the Earth. Pyun agreed to finish the film if he could also film Alien from L.A. for under $1 million. Kathy Ireland was cast by Pyun after seeing a photo of her. Filming locations included Los Angeles, Redondo Beach, South Africa, and Namibia. The gold mines and dumps around South Africa were used for the underground setpieces. The sets were inspired by “future noir” films like Alien and Blade Runner.

Release 🔗

Alien from L.A. was released on February 26, 1988. It was released on VHS in June 1995 and on DVD in June 2005. Vinegar Syndrome has released a Blu-ray edition with special features. A direct-to-video sequel, Journey to the Center of the Earth, also directed by Albert Pyun and starring Kathy Ireland, was released in 1989.

Reception 🔗

Joe Bob Briggs called it a “pretty decent film”, awarding it two stars. Rebecca Harris of the Abilene Reporter-News gave the film 2.5 stars out of 4. David Picking called it “a cheapo adventure movie without a single redeeming quality”. Rob Thomas of The Capital Times said “Completely awful – you can’t believe they’re serious.” Daniel M. Kimmel of the Worcester Telegram & Gazette gave the film one out of five stars.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_from_L.A.

item.title: The Alien Factor (1978 film)
item.description:
The Alien Factor (1978 film) 🔗

This is a description of the 1978 science fiction horror film The Alien Factor, directed, written, and produced by Don Dohler.

Plot 🔗

The plot centers around a spaceship crash in a sparsely populated area of Earth. Three grotesque aliens survive the crash and begin terrorizing the local residents. A character named Ben Zachary steps forward to fight back against the extraterrestrial threat.

Cast 🔗

The main cast includes:

  • Don Leifert as Ben Zachary
  • Tom Griffith as Sheriff Cinder
  • Richard Dyszel as Mayor Wicker
  • Mary Mertens as Edie Martin
  • Richard Geiwitz as Pete
  • George Stover as Steven
  • Eleanor Herman as Mary Jane Carter
  • Anne Frith as Dr. Ruth Sherman

Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino played the aliens Inferbyce and Zagatile, respectively.

Production 🔗

The Alien Factor marked Don Dohler’s directorial debut after he was laid off from his job as a payroll manager. The initial script was a comedy with 15 monsters, but it was changed to a straight horror film with only three monsters. Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino built the creature suits for the Inferbyce and Zagtile, respectively. Ernest D. Farino created the Leemoid through stop motion animation. Filming took place in and around Baltimore, Maryland, from October 1976 to April 1977.

Release 🔗

The film was released on DVD by Retromedia Entertainment on February 26, 2002. Image Entertainment released it on November 15, 2005, as part of the Don Dohler Collection. Mill Creek Entertainment released it on July 19, 2011.

Reception 🔗

The film received generally negative reviews. TV Guide gave it two out of five stars, calling it “silly.” Dave Sindelar criticized the acting and direction. Critical Outcast acknowledged the film’s flaws but admired Dohler’s initiative. VideoHound’s Golden Movie Retriever awarded it one and a half out of four bones, noting the decent special effects.

Sequels 🔗

The Alien Factor 2: Alien Rampage was not a direct sequel. Fred Olen Ray, the Retromedia distributor, used the sequel-sounding title for marketing purposes. The original title was Alien Rampage, filmed in 1999 as Don Dohler’s comeback movie after an 11-year hiatus.

item.title: Center for UFO Studies
item.description:
Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS) 🔗

The Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS) is a privately funded UFO research group. It is a nonprofit organization founded in 1973 by J. Allen Hynek, who was the chair of the Department of Astronomy at Northwestern University in Illinois at the time. The organization’s headquarters are located in Chicago, Illinois, United States. CUFOS’s website is www.cufos.org.

History 🔗

J. Allen Hynek, the founder of CUFOS, was a scientific consultant for Project Blue Book, the United States Air Force’s official study of the UFO phenomenon from 1948 to 1969. Initially a skeptic, Hynek gradually became convinced that some UFO cases were not hoaxes or misidentifications and might represent something extraordinary, such as alien visitation. After the Air Force shut down Project Blue Book in 1969, Hynek founded CUFOS in 1973 to continue collecting and studying UFO reports. James W. Moseley described CUFOS as the first real attempt to establish a private research group genuinely dedicated to the scientific investigation and study of UFOs.

Operation 🔗

CUFOS, which started in Evanston, Illinois, but is now based in Chicago, continues to be a small research organization emphasizing the scientific analysis of UFO cases. Its archives include files from defunct civilian research groups like the National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP). Following Hynek’s death in 1986, CUFOS was renamed the J. Allen Hynek Center for UFO Studies in his honor. Mark Rodeghier, an associate editor of the Journal of Scientific Exploration, has been the Director of CUFOS since 1986. Ufologists who have served on the CUFOS Board of Directors include Jerome Clark, Michael D. Swords, and Thomas E. Bullard.

CUFOS maintains a library and archives of UFO-related materials, open for use by researchers and investigators. It also continues to compile and analyze reports of UFO incidents from around the world.

item.title: Jimmy Carter UFO incident
item.description:
1969 incident regarding the sighting of a UFO 🔗

This article details the UFO sighting reported by Jimmy Carter in 1969, prior to his governorship and presidency. It covers the details of the sighting, the subsequent investigation, and its impact on Carter’s views on UFOs.

Sighting 🔗

This section describes the details of the UFO sighting as reported by Jimmy Carter. In 1969, while preparing to give a speech at a Lions Club meeting in Leary, Georgia, Carter and several other witnesses observed a bright, white object in the western sky. The object reportedly moved closer, stopped near a stand of pine trees, and changed colors before receding into the distance. Carter described the object as self-illuminated and not solid. The sighting lasted approximately 10-12 minutes and was witnessed by about 10-12 people. The section also includes quotes from Carter recounting the event in later interviews.

Date 🔗

This section discusses the conflicting information regarding the exact date of the sighting. While Carter initially reported the sighting occurred in October 1969, Lions Club records suggest it took place on January 6, 1969, the date of Carter’s speech to the Leary Lions Club. The section presents evidence supporting the January date, including Carter’s role as district governor of the Lions Club (a term that ended in June 1969) and the disbandment of the Leary Lions Club before October 1969.

Object and investigation 🔗

This section details the investigation into the sighting and alternative explanations for the object. It mentions that many attendees of the Lions Club meeting did not recall the event or did not consider it significant. One guest, Fred Hart, remembered a “blue light” that he thought might have been a weather balloon. The section also notes that Carter, while considering the object a UFO (unidentified flying object), did not believe it was an alien spacecraft. Ufologist Robert Sheaffer proposed that the object was Venus, which was near its maximum brightness and in the correct location on January 6, 1969. Ufologist Allan Hendry agreed with the Venus assessment. The section also mentions a 2007 interview where Carter stated he was an amateur astronomer and knew what Venus looked like, suggesting it was not Venus. It also presents an explanation from Carl G. “Jere” Justus, who worked on Air Force projects involving the release of glowing chemical clouds. Justus suggests the sighting was a barium cloud released from Eglin AFB in Florida on January 6, 1969, at 7:35 pm EST.

Personal impact 🔗

This section discusses the impact of the sighting on Carter’s views on UFOs. During his 1976 presidential campaign, Carter pledged to make all UFO-related information available to the public if elected. However, after becoming president, he distanced himself from this pledge, citing “defense implications.”

1970s media reports 🔗

This section lists various media reports from the 1970s covering Carter’s UFO sighting. It mentions articles in the Atlanta Constitution, The National Enquirer, Argosy UFO, UFO Investigator, and The Washington Post. It also notes inaccuracies in some of these reports, such as incorrect dates and locations.

See also 🔗
