item.title: Alien Agent (2007 Film)
item.description:
Alien Agent (2007 Film) 🔗

This entry details the 2007 Canadian science fiction action film Alien Agent. It includes information about the film’s director, writers, producers, cast, release date, running time, budget, and other relevant details.

Plot 🔗

Rykker, an intergalactic warrior, is stranded on Earth and battles the Syndicate, a group of aliens plotting to take over the planet. Saylon, a Syndicate leader, arrives on Earth to build a wormhole for a full-scale invasion. Isis, the Syndicate’s leader, aims to destroy Rykker. Julie, whose family was killed by the Syndicate, seeks revenge and joins Rykker. They journey across the country, pursued by Isis and her forces. The climax occurs at a nuclear reactor, where Rykker and Julie fight Isis, Saylon, and their army to destroy the portal and prevent the invasion.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Mark Dacascos as Rykker, Amelia Cooke as Isis, and Emma Lahana as Julie. Other cast members include William MacDonald as Sheriff Devlin, Kim Coates as Carl Roderick, Billy Zane as Tom Hanson/Saylon, Dominiquie Vandenberg as Sartek, and Darren Shahlavi as Kaylor.

Reception 🔗

The film received negative reviews from critics. Adam-Troy Castro of Sci Fi Weekly criticized the film’s uninteresting characters and plot. Leah Holmes of SFX magazine gave it a low rating, calling it “stupid and nonsensical.” George Tiller of PopMatters also gave it a very poor rating.

item.title: Ilkley Moor UFO incident
item.description:
Ilkley Moor UFO Incident 🔗

This article details the alleged UFO incident that occurred on Ilkley Moor in West Yorkshire, England, on December 1, 1987. A retired police officer, using the pseudonym Philip Spencer, claimed to have been abducted by aliens during a morning walk. He purportedly took a photograph of one of the aliens.

Background 🔗

Ilkley Moor, located between Ilkley and Keighley in West Yorkshire, England, is known for inspiring the song “On Ilkla Moor Baht ‘at” and for its carved rocks, including the Swastika Stone. The area has a history of UFO sightings, which some skeptics attribute to the proximity of Menwith Hill airforce base and Leeds Bradford Airport.

Philip Spencer, a retired police officer, had moved to West Yorkshire with his family. On the morning of the incident, he was walking across Ilkley Moor to visit his father-in-law, carrying a camera and compass.

Incident 🔗

Spencer reported encountering a four-foot tall, dark green creature with an oversized head and long, thin arms. He claimed the creature gestured at him, but he took a photograph before it ran away. Spencer followed the creature but lost it in the fog. He then witnessed a whitish, two-part saucer-shaped craft rising from the moor and disappearing into the sky, accompanied by a loud hum. He did not photograph the craft.

After the encounter, Spencer found himself in a different town, two hours later than expected, and his compass was pointing in the opposite direction.

Initial Aftermath 🔗

Spencer contacted UFO researchers Jenny Randles and Peter Hough, handing over the copyright of the photo to Hough. Hough initially skeptical, later came to believe Spencer’s account. Spencer remained anonymous and did not profit from the story.

Hough had the photograph examined by experts. A wildlife photographer ruled out known animals, and Kodak experts found no evidence of tampering. US Navy optics expert and ufologist Bruce Maccabee deemed the photo too grainy for proper testing.

Ufologist Nick Redfern claims that Spencer was harassed by the Ministry of Defence and visited by Men in Black who tried to intimidate him into silence.

Account Changed Under Hypnosis 🔗

Spencer experienced strange dreams after the incident. On Hough’s advice, he underwent regressive hypnotherapy with Jim Singleton on March 16, 1988. Under hypnosis, Spencer’s account changed. Singleton considered it a “genuine recall.”

Spencer now recalled being paralyzed upon seeing the creature, lifted into the craft, and told to remain calm. Green aliens performed medical experiments on him, inserting items into his nose and mouth. He was given a tour of the craft and shown two films. The first film depicted apocalyptic imagery, including nuclear explosions, famines, and floods. He has never revealed the contents of the second film, claiming the aliens do not want humanity to know.

Afterward, Spencer was returned to Ilkley Moor and took the photograph. He now claimed the alien was waving goodbye, not telling him to stay away.

Legacy 🔗

The Ilkley Moor incident became a major news story in the UK and remains a famous UFO sighting. Nick Pope, a former Ministry of Defence ‘UFO desk’ journalist, included it in his “Top 10 UFO incidents in the UK” list in 2011. It is considered by some as one of the most persuasive UFO incidents.

Skeptics dismiss the incident as a hoax. They argue the photograph is too blurry to prove alien visitation and that the “alien” could be a person or cardboard cutout. They also question why Spencer didn’t photograph the craft and point out that compasses can be easily damaged.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “UFO sightings in the United Kingdom” page.

References 🔗

This section lists the various news articles, books, and websites used as sources for the information presented in the article.

item.title: Communication with extraterrestrial intelligence
item.description:
Communication with Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CETI) 🔗

CETI is a branch of SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) that focuses on composing and deciphering interstellar messages that could theoretically be understood by another technological civilization. A well-known CETI experiment is the 1974 Arecibo message composed by Frank Drake. The abbreviations CETI and SETI are generic and do not refer to any particular organization like the SETI Institute. CETI research focuses on mathematical languages, pictorial systems (like the Arecibo message), algorithmic communication systems (ACETI), and computational approaches to detecting and deciphering “natural” language communication. Research also addresses how to overcome problems of decipherment in interplanetary communication, similar to the challenges posed by undeciphered writing systems in human communication like Linear A. In 2015, scientists including Douglas Vakoch, David Grinspoon, Seth Shostak, and David Brin discussed active SETI and the potential risks of transmitting messages to extraterrestrials. A statement signed by many in the SETI community emphasized the need for a global discussion before sending any messages.

History 🔗

In the 19th century, speculation about inhabitants of other planets was common, with many believing intelligent beings lived on the Moon, Mars, and/or Venus. Before radio, proposals for signaling extraterrestrials included Carl Friedrich Gauss’s 1820 suggestion to draw a giant Pythagorean triangle on the Siberian tundra and Joseph Johann Littrow’s 1819 idea to use the Sahara as a “blackboard” with trenches filled with water and kerosene to create signals. Astronomers like Franz von Paula Gruithuisen also looked for signs of life, claiming to see cities and agriculture on the Moon and evidence of life on Venus. By the late 1800s, Mars became the focus after Giovanni Schiaparelli reported “canali” (channels) on Mars, which were mistranslated as “canals,” sparking enthusiasm about Martian life. Inventor Charles Cros sought funding for a giant mirror to signal Martians, while Nikola Tesla believed his inventions could be used for interplanetary communication and claimed to have observed extraterrestrial radio signals. The Guzman Prize was created, offering 100,000 francs to the first person to establish interplanetary communication, excluding Mars.

Mathematical and Scientific Languages 🔗

This section covers artificial languages designed for interstellar communication.

Lincos (Lingua cosmica) 🔗

Hans Freudenthal’s Lincos: Design of a Language for Cosmic Intercourse (1960) expands upon Astraglossa to create a general-purpose language derived from basic mathematics and logic symbols. A dictionary resembling Lincos was featured in Carl Sagan’s novel Contact and its film adaptation.

Astraglossa 🔗

Lancelot Hogben’s 1963 essay “Astraglossa” describes a system for combining numbers and operators in a series of short and long pulses, where short pulses represent numbers and trains of long pulses represent symbols for addition, subtraction, etc.

Carl Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel Contact explores how a message might be constructed for communication with an alien civilization, using prime numbers as a starting point, followed by universal principles and facts of mathematics and science. Sagan also edited a nonfiction book on the subject, and an updated collection of articles was published in 2011.

A Language Based on the Fundamental Facts of Science 🔗

Carl Devito and Richard Oehrle’s 1992 paper, A language based on the fundamental facts of science, describes a language similar in syntax to Astraglossa and Lincos, but which builds its vocabulary around known physical properties.

Busch General-Purpose Binary Language Used in Lone Signal Transmissions 🔗

In 2010, Michael W. Busch created a general-purpose binary language later used in the Lone Signal project to transmit crowdsourced messages to extraterrestrial intelligence (METI). This was followed by an attempt to extend the syntax used in the Lone Signal hailing message to communicate in a way that, while neither mathematical nor strictly logical, was nonetheless understandable given the prior definition of terms and concepts in the Lone Signal hailing message. The Lone Signal project sent messages to Gliese 526 (HD 119850) in the constellation Boötes, with the message sent on July 10, 2013, and expected to arrive in 2031.

Pictorial Messages 🔗

Pictorial communication systems describe fundamental mathematical or physical concepts via simplified diagrams sent as bitmaps. These messages assume the recipient has similar visual capabilities and can understand basic mathematics and geometry. A critique is that they presume a shared understanding of shapes, which may not be the case with a species with substantially different vision.

Pioneer Probes 🔗

Two etched plaques, known as the Pioneer plaques, were included aboard the Pioneer 10 and Pioneer 11 spacecraft when they launched in 1972 and 1973. The plaques depict the location of the Solar System within the galaxy and the Earth within the Solar System, as well as the form of the human body.

Voyager Probes 🔗

Launched in 1977, the Voyager probes carried two golden records that were inscribed with diagrams similar to the Pioneer plaques, depicting the human form, the Solar System, and its location. Also included were recordings of images and sounds from Earth.

Arecibo Message 🔗

The Arecibo message, transmitted in 1974, was a 1,679-pixel bitmap that, when properly arranged into 73 rows and 23 columns, shows the numbers one through ten; the atomic numbers of hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and phosphorus; the formulas for the sugars and bases that make up the nucleotides of DNA; the number of nucleotides in the human genome; the double helix structure of DNA; a simple illustration of a human being and its height; the human population of Earth; a diagram of the Solar System; and an illustration of the Arecibo telescope with its diameter.

Cosmic Call Messages 🔗

The Cosmic Call messages consisted of digital sections – “Rosetta Stone”, a copy of the Arecibo Message, the Bilingual Image Glossary, and the Braastad message – as well as text, audio, video, and other image files submitted for transmission by people around the world. The “Rosetta Stone” was composed by Stéphane Dumas and Yvan Dutil, and represents a multi-page bitmap that builds a vocabulary of symbols representing numbers and mathematical operations. These messages were transmitted in 1999 and 2003 from Evpatoria Planetary Radar in Russia under the scientific guidance of Alexander L. Zaitsev. Richard Braastad coordinated the overall project. Star systems to which the messages were sent include 16 Cyg A, 15 Sge, HD 178428, Gl 777, Hip 4872, HD 245409, 55 Cnc, HD 10307, and 47 UMa.

Multi-Modal Messages 🔗

Teen-Age Message 🔗

The Teen-Age Message, composed by Russian scientists (Zaitsev, Gindilis, Pshenichner, Filippova) and teens, was transmitted from the 70-m dish of Evpatoria Deep Space Center in Ukraine to six star systems resembling that of the Sun on August 29 and September 3 and 4, 2001. The message consists of three parts: a coherent-sounding radio signal with slow Doppler wavelength tuning, analog information representing musical melodies performed on the theremin, and Arecibo-like binary digital information. Star systems to which the message was sent are HD 197076, 47 UMa, 37 Gem, HD 126053, HD 76151, and HD 193664.

Cosmic Call 2 (Cosmic Call 2003) Message 🔗

The Cosmic Call-2 message contained text, images, video, music, the Dutil/Dumas message, a copy of the 1974 Arecibo message, BIG = Bilingual Image Glossary, the AI program Ella, and the Braastad message.

Algorithmic Messages 🔗

Algorithmic communication systems describe a small set of mathematic and logic symbols that form the basis for a rudimentary programming language that the recipient can run on a virtual machine. Advantages include localized communication, forward error correction, and the ability to embed proxy agents within the message.

CosmicOS 🔗

CosmicOS, designed by Paul Fitzpatrick at MIT, describes a virtual machine that is derived from lambda calculus.

Logic Gate Matrices 🔗

Logic Gate Matrices (LGM), developed by Brian McConnell, describes a universal virtual machine that is constructed by connecting coordinates in an n-dimensional space via mathematics and logic operations.

Natural Language Messages 🔗

This research focuses on receiving a signal or message that is either not directed at us (eavesdropping) or one that is in its natural communicative form. Methods are being developed to detect if a signal has structure indicative of an intelligent source, categorize the type of structure detected, and then decipher its content. This structure modeling focuses on the search for generic human and inter-species language universals to devise computational methods by which language may be discriminated from non-language, and core structural syntactic elements of unknown languages may be detected. item.title: Narrative of the abduction phenomenon
item.description:
Narrative of the Abduction Phenomenon 🔗

This article explores the alleged core similarities in claims of alien abduction experiences. Proponents believe these similarities point to an objective reality, while skeptics attribute them to psychological and cultural factors. Skeptics also suggest that some reports are hoaxes. Believers argue that the independent generation of similar narratives by individuals is unlikely. Some investigators attempt to confirm abduction claims through observation or experimentation, but these efforts are often dismissed as pseudoscientific.

Overview 🔗

This section outlines the typical sequence of events in an alien abduction narrative, according to UFO researchers like folklorist Thomas E. Bullard. The sequence includes capture, examination, conference, tour, loss of time, return, theophany, and aftermath. It notes that not all abductions feature all events and that some researchers, like Budd Hopkins and David M. Jacobs, have been accused of selectively using data to fit a specific paradigm.

Nyman’s Alternate Outline 🔗

This section presents an alternative model for abduction narratives composed by abduction researcher Joe Nyman. The model includes anxious anticipation, transition of consciousness, psycho-physical imposition, reassurance, transition back to normal consciousness, rapid forgetfulness, a marker stage, and a cycle interval. David M. Jacobs is quoted, emphasizing the orchestrated nature of abduction events. The section also mentions the connection between alien abductions and UFO reports, as well as the common portrayal of abductors as “Greys.”

Capture 🔗

This section details the events leading up to the alleged abduction. It describes unusual feelings, such as a compulsive desire to be in a certain place or expectations of something unknown. Abductees report a shift in consciousness, often accompanied by lights and a strange mist. They may be levitated into an alien craft, sometimes through solid objects. The section also mentions scenarios involving automobiles, UFO sightings, mechanical failures, and amnesia. The use of a pencil-sized device by the aliens to ensure compliance is also noted.

Examination 🔗

This section focuses on the medical procedures and examinations performed by alien beings during the abduction. It highlights the differences between these procedures and typical human medicine, as noted by physician and abduction researcher John G. Miller. The section discusses the abductors’ areas of interest, such as the cranium, nervous system, skin, and reproductive system, as well as the lack of gloves and other standard medical practices.

Cranial Procedures 🔗

This section details the specific procedures allegedly performed on the abductee’s head. Yvonne Smith, a hypnotherapist and abduction researcher, notes similarities in reports of hypnotically retrieved abduction memories. Common procedures include feelings of pressure, insertion of needles into the scalp, drilling into the skull, and procedures involving the ears and nasal passages.

Reproductive, Gynecological and Urological Procedures 🔗

This section describes the gynecological aspects of the abduction experience reported by many female abductees. It notes the absence of standard gynecological practices. Reports of sex with human-alien hybrids or other abductees are mentioned. The insertion of a long needle-like contraption into a woman’s navel is also discussed.

Other Procedures 🔗

This section covers other procedures reported by abductees, such as skin scrapings. Physician and abduction researcher John Altshuler dismisses speculation that the aliens are collecting skin samples to analyze DNA.

Reported Devices and Instruments 🔗

This section describes the devices and instruments allegedly used by the aliens during the abduction. It mentions a black, cylindrical device with a bluish light used to render abductees compliant. The placement of devices on the chest and the use of diffused colored lights are also discussed.

Subsequent Abduction Procedures 🔗

This section details procedures that occur after the medical exam, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing. Imaging involves viewing screens with emotionally provocative images. Envisioning involves images projected into the abductee’s mind. Staging involves the abductee interacting with an illusionary scenario. Testing involves operating a complicated electronic device.

Child Presentation 🔗

This section describes the “child presentation” phase, where abductees are shown hybrid children. It is speculated that these children are the products of reproductive procedures. Folklorist Thomas Bullard could not identify this phase in his study of abduction reports. The section discusses the varying ages of the hybrid children, their roles in assisting the abductors, and the expectations placed on the abductees during the presentation.

Less Common Elements 🔗

This section discusses less prominent aspects of abduction claims, based on a study by folklorist Thomas E. Bullard. These elements include the conference, the tour, the journey, and theophany.

Conference 🔗

This section describes the conference phase, where the entities engage in discussions with the abductee. The discussions may involve interrogation sessions, explanatory segments, task assignments, warnings, and prophecies.

Tour 🔗

This section discusses the rare occurrence of tours of the abductors’ craft. Abduction claimants often find the “engine room” to be the most memorable aspect.

Journey 🔗

This section describes reports of further transport within the abductors’ vessel, sometimes to other planets. The abductee may be placed in a protective environment, such as a chamber filled with liquid.

Theophany 🔗

This section discusses the rare experience of “theophany,” a sense of oneness with the universe or with God. Psychologist Susan A. Clancy notes that abductees often feel “changed” by their experiences.

Return 🔗

This section describes the return of the abductees to Earth, usually to the same location and circumstances they were in prior to being taken. Explicit memories of the abduction experience are usually absent, and the abductee may realize they have experienced “missing time.” The section also mentions instances where the abductors appear to make mistakes when returning their captives.

Missing Time 🔗

This section highlights the phenomenon of “missing time” in abduction accounts. Don C. Donderi notes that there is often independent confirmation of missing time, as well as confirmation of abduction events reported under hypnosis.

Realization Event 🔗

This section discusses the “realization event,” the insight or development leading a person to see themselves as being a victim of the abduction phenomenon. Physician and abduction researcher John G. Miller identifies common triggers for the realization event, such as tangible evidence, conversations with other abductees, exposure to depictions of the abduction phenomenon in popular culture, and hypnotic retrieval of abduction memories.

Skeptical Response 🔗

This section presents the skeptical perspective on the abduction phenomenon.

Role of Hypnosis and Investigators in Shaping the Narrative 🔗

This section discusses how individual abduction researchers appear to exert influence on the characteristics of narratives retrieved during hypnotic recall. Skeptics Robert Sheaffer and Phillip J. Klass argue that this influence reinforces the preconceived biases of the researcher.

Effect of Geography and Culture on Abduction Reports 🔗

This section discusses the variation in abduction reports across cultures and geographic boundaries. Skeptics assert that this variation supports a psycho-social hypothesis as an explanation for the origin of the abduction phenomenon. The section also notes that the contents and structure of the “abduction narrative” were already established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers strip.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narrative_of_the_abduction_phenomenon

item.title: UFO religion
item.description:
UFO Religion 🔗

A UFO religion is a religion where belief in extraterrestrial entities operating unidentified flying objects (UFOs) is a core element. Adherents typically believe these ETs are interested in humanity’s welfare and that humanity will eventually join an existing ET civilization. Some UFO religions incorporate ETs into a supernatural worldview, blurring the lines between aliens and angels. These religions draw inspiration from early science fiction, ufology, UFO sightings, and alien abduction stories. The Aetherius Society, founded by George King, is considered the first UFO religion.

Summary 🔗

Adherents believe that the arrival or rediscovery of alien civilizations, technologies, and spirituality will enable humans to overcome ecological, spiritual, and social problems. Issues like hatred, war, bigotry, and poverty are believed to be resolvable through superior alien technology and spiritual abilities. These belief systems are often millenarian in their outlook.

UFO religions developed in countries like the United States, Canada, France, the United Kingdom, and Japan, where technology is advanced enough to conceive of ETs and where religion is not suppressed. The term “flying saucers” and the popular notion of the UFO originated in 1947. The study of UFO religions by sociologists, historians, theologians, scholars of religious studies, and new religious movements began in the 1950s.

Notable UFO Religions 🔗

UFO religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings through physical contact, telepathy, and astral projection. These groups often believe that humanity will be saved by aliens who will educate humans on a better way to live or take believers to a more positive location. Extraterrestrial beings are often seen pleading with humanity to improve itself and move away from greed and violence. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity. A UFO religion can form before or after an individual claims to have experienced an alien abduction.

J. Gordon Melton identifies the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion, although Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion. Partridge notes that UFO religions believe the supreme being or “evolved entity” came from another plane or planet. The 1947 Roswell incident is a key point in time within UFO spirituality. James R. Lewis notes that Ufologists see it as the date of the “emergence of UFOs into the public consciousness.” Partridge places UFO religion within the context of theosophical esotericism and asserts that it began to be associated as “UFO religion” after the Roswell incident. He notes that most UFO religions still have many of the key points associated with Theosophy, such as belief in the same Spiritual Hierarchy, and he also draws parallels to New Age thought.

Stephen Hunt describes the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as “probably the first and certainly the most enduring UFO cult.” Hunt places the Aetherius Society and Raëlism among the “most renowned” of the “flying saucer cults.” Melodie Campbell and Stephen A. Kent place the Aetherius Society and Unarius as among the “oldest and most studied” of the flying saucer cults. They describe Heaven’s Gate and Order of the Solar Temple as the “most controversial groups combining UFO belief with variations of contactee assertions.” Gregory L. Reece classes Scientology as a “UFO group,” discussing elements of the Xenu cosmogony and Space opera in Scientology doctrine. He compares Scientology to the Aetherius Society and Ashtar Command. Victoria Nelson writes that “[t]he most prominent current UFO religion is probably the science fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard’s Church of Scientology.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_religion

item.title: Alien Planet (2005 TV series)
item.description:
Alien Planet (2005 TV series) 🔗

A 2005 docufiction TV special created for the Discovery Channel, based on Wayne Barlowe’s 1990 book Expedition. It explores the imagined extraterrestrial life of the fictional planet Darwin IV in the style of a nature documentary. It features scientists and science fiction figures discussing Darwin IV as if it had actually been discovered.

Plot 🔗

The Von Braun interstellar spacecraft travels to Darwin IV, 6.5 light-years away. It deploys the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter to find landing sites for probes. The first probe, Balboa, explodes during entry. Backup probes Leonardo da Vinci (Leo) and Isaac Newton (Ike) land successfully.

The robotic probes, called Horus Probes, are equipped with inflatable balloons, solar receptors, computers, sensors, and smaller robots. They have limited AI and are programmed with different personalities. Ike is cautious, while Leo is a risk-taker. They are equipped with a holographic message for any sentient life.

The probes encounter various lifeforms, including Arrowtongues, Gyrosprinters, Trunk Suckers, Daggerwrists, and Unths. Ike studies plant life, while Leo goes after big game. A massive storm hits, and Ike launches weather balloons. Leo finds Bladderhorns and attempts to present the holographic message, but is interrupted. Ike encounters Grovebacks, Littoralopes, Skewers, Beach Quills, and Prongheads.

Leo briefly re-establishes contact with Von Braun until a mysterious creature interferes. Ike is ordered to search for Leo. Ike finds a sea that is Amoebic in nature and encounters giant Sea Striders. Ike finds Leo’s last known location, where a Skewer is killed by a spear. Ike finds Leo and the sapient Eosapiens. Ike presents the holographic message to the Eosapiens, but one of them destroys the camera disk, and the Eosapiens attack Ike. The wrecked camera disk records the Eosapiens carrying Ike away.

Commentary from Michio Kaku, Stephen Hawking, Jack Horner, James B. Garvin, and George Lucas is interspersed throughout the special.

Production 🔗

Alien Planet is based on Expedition (1990) by Wayne Barlowe. Barlowe served as one of the executive producers. Scientists and other figures were assembled to comment on the life on Darwin IV. The documentary gives the appearance of the featured scientists having designed Darwin IV and its animals, most of what is shown of the actual planet and its life follows what is described in Expedition.

Unlike Expedition, which is set in the mid-24th century, Alien Planet is set in the near future, and the planet is explored using sophisticated probes. The technology featured is more advanced than present-day technology, but is based on current trends and informed speculation.

Reception 🔗

Dwayne A. Day of The Space Review gave the special a positive review. Some criticism was leveled at the strangeness of the creatures showcased. Day stated that the animals are bizarre and frequently border on the implausible. A review in The Washington Post stated that a few too many of the creatures seem like cartoonish monsters.

See also 🔗

Lists related speculative evolution, similar documentaries, and topics related to astrobiology and xenology.

References 🔗

Citations for reviews and articles related to the production and reception of Alien Planet.

External links 🔗

Links to the IMDb page, archived Discovery Channel page, and the Internet Archive page for Alien Planet.

item.title: Roswell, Little Green Man
item.description:
Roswell, Little Green Man 🔗

This article provides information about the Roswell, Little Green Man comic book series.

Overview 🔗

Roswell, Little Green Man is a comic book series created by Bill Morrison and published by Bongo Comics. The series received four Eisner Award nominations. It began as a four-part story within Simpsons Comics #19-22 in 1996, and later continued as its own six-issue title. The initial Simpsons Comics story and the first three issues of the Roswell, Little Green Man series, which detail the origin story of Roswell, were collected in the trade paperback Roswell Walks Among Us in 1997.

Inspiration 🔗

Bill Morrison stated that the series was inspired by the Roswell UFO incident and his interest in drawing 1940s vintage cars, fashions, and architecture. He also cited Dave Stevens’ Rocketeer as a major influence.

item.title: Natural History of an Alien
item.description:
Natural History of an Alien 🔗

This is a description of the 1998 British pseudo-documentary TV program Natural History of an Alien, also known as Anatomy of an Alien in the US. The program is similar to Alien Planet and features various alien ecosystem projects, including the Epona Project and Ringworld. It includes appearances by scientists and science fiction authors.

Plot 🔗

The program follows a viewer aboard an intergalactic spaceship named the S.S. Attenborough, which is run by a small green alien. The journey takes the viewer to various locations to explore alien life.

Cambrian Earth 🔗

The S.S. Attenborough visits Earth during the Cambrian period.

Mars 🔗

The documentary explores the possibility of life on Mars.

Asteroids 🔗

The program discusses the possibility of panspermia, where asteroids could seed solar systems with life.

Europa 🔗

The documentary explores the possibility of life on Europa, a moon of Jupiter.

Featured organisms 🔗

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Europa:

  • Europa Cone Bacteria: Tower-like bacteria that grow near hydrothermal vents.
  • Europa Sea Vent Herbivore: A large, shark-like creature with a trunk-like mouth used to feed on bacteria.
  • Europa Sea Vent Carnivore: A predatory, shark-like creature that preys on the Europa Sea Vent Herbivores.

High Gravity Planet 🔗

The documentary visits a planet with 1.5 times Earth’s gravity and an atmosphere 15 times as dense. This environment is home to insect-like aliens.

Featured organisms 🔗

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on the high gravity planet:

  • Pteropede: A millipede-like creature with dragon-like wings adapted for flight in the dense atmosphere.
  • Sputnik Bug: A small creature with spines that rolls into a ball when falling.
  • Splatter Bug: A small, vulnerable creature with no defenses.

Helliconia 🔗

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Helliconia, created by Brian Aldiss. The program explores how life could adapt to a binary star system.

Featured organism 🔗

  • Helliconian Tree: A tree with a cooling tower-shaped trunk that adapts to the planet’s extreme seasons.

Sulfuria 🔗

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Sulfuria, created by Dougal Dixon. Sulfuria is a sulfur-rich world similar to Io.

Featured organisms 🔗

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Sulfuria:

  • Sulfurian Balloon Plant: A tall, balloon-like organism that lives off sunlight.
  • Parachute Worm: A worm-like creature that feeds on the gas of the Sulfurian Balloon Plant.

Epona 🔗

The documentary visits Epona, an imaginary ecosystem created by The Epona Project, which was begun by Martyn J. Fogg.

Featured organisms 🔗

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Epona:

  • Epona Pagoda Tree: A sessile photosynthetic animal that resembles a tree with disk-shaped “leaves”.
  • Spring Croc: A one-legged, predatory creature similar to a Venus flytrap.
  • Uther: A flyer resembling a cross between a Sharovipteryx and a pterosaur.

Greenworld 🔗

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Greenworld, created by Dougal Dixon. Greenworld is an Earth-like planet filled with rainforests.

Featured organisms 🔗

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Greenworld:

  • Curlywhorl: An arboreal creature evolved from aquatic ancestors.
  • Pud: A small, three-eyed creature similar to a weevil.
  • Kwank: A large creature similar to a robber crab that feeds on Puds.
  • Unidentified large, lobster-like predator: A predator that attacks and eats Kwanks.

Artificial Life 🔗

The ship encounters artificial lifeforms from a robotic cube ship that uses solar panels to gather energy and mines asteroids for resources. The artificial life even sends a probe to explore Greenworld. The narrator is revealed to be a little green man-like female alien.

References 🔗

The article references several sources, including websites and magazine articles, related to the Epona Project and the science behind creating alien life.

External links 🔗

The article provides external links to:

  • The program’s IMDb page
  • A Discovery Channel page about Alien Planet
  • The Epona Project website
  • A discussion forum about speculative visions

item.title: UFO sightings in Canada
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Canada 🔗

This article presents a compilation of reported UFO sightings in Canada, spanning from the mid-20th century to recent years. It includes details of specific incidents, locations, and any investigations or cultural responses associated with these events.

1951, Gander, Newfoundland 🔗

This section details an incident on February 10, 1951, where a U.S. Navy aircraft flying from Gander, Newfoundland, to Iceland reported a near-collision with a large, orange, circular UFO. The UFO reportedly circled the American aircraft.

1960, Clan Lake, Northwest Territories 🔗

This section recounts a report from June 18, 1960, where a prospector informed the Yellowknife RCMP detachment about a UFO sighting at Clan Lake, 30 miles north of Yellowknife. The prospector and his partner claimed to have seen a hovering object that hit the lake’s surface. The RCMP investigated but found nothing. Chris Rutkowski, a UFOlogist, is mentioned in connection with this incident.

1967, Falcon Lake, Manitoba 🔗

This section focuses on the Falcon Lake Incident, where Stefan Michalak claimed to have been burned by a flying saucer on May 19, 1967, near Falcon Lake, Manitoba. The section mentions grid-like burn marks on Michalak’s chest and T-shirt. Ufologists consider this one of the most documented UFO stories in Canada. Two books about the incident are listed. Skeptic Aaron Sakulich suggests Michalak’s burns were likely caused by an accident related to alcohol consumption, and the story was fabricated to deter other prospectors. The Royal Canadian Mint released a commemorative coin depicting the event.

1967, Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia 🔗

This section describes the Shag Harbour incident, involving the purported crash of a UFO in Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia, in October 1967. The Royal Canadian Mint also released a glow-in-the-dark coin depicting this sighting.

1969, Prince George, British Columbia 🔗

This section details a sighting in Prince George, British Columbia, on January 1, 1969, where three unrelated witnesses reported a strange, round object radiating a yellow-orange light in the sky.

1974, Langenburg, Saskatchewan 🔗

This section recounts the experience of Edwin Fuhr, a farmer from Langenburg, Saskatchewan, who claimed to have seen five saucer-shaped objects hovering near a slough on September 1, 1974. An RCMP report confirmed the presence of five circles matching Fuhr’s description. The Royal Canadian Mint commemorated the event with a silver coin in 2024.

1975–1976, Southern Manitoba 🔗

This section mentions multiple sightings of a red glowing UFO in Southern Manitoba during 1975 and 1976. The UFO was nicknamed “Charlie Redstar.”

1978, Clarenville, Newfoundland and Labrador 🔗

This section describes a UFO sighting in Clarenville, Newfoundland and Labrador, on October 26, 1978, witnessed by twelve individuals. Constable James Blackwood of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police also observed the object. The Royal Canadian Mint released a glow-in-the-dark coin depicting the sighting. A separate sighting in Clarenville in 2016 is also mentioned.

1990, Montreal, Quebec 🔗

This section details a sighting on November 7, 1990, in Montreal, Quebec, where witnesses reported a round, metallic object with lights forming a circle over the Bonaventure Hotel. The phenomenon lasted three hours. The sighting was commemorated on a Royal Canadian Mint coin.

1997, Trail, BC 🔗

This section describes an event on July 1st in Trail, BC, where two women witnessed three small lights above them that quickly took off down the Columbia River.

2010, Harbour Mille, Newfoundland and Labrador 🔗

This section recounts multiple UFO sighting reports in Harbour Mille, Newfoundland and Labrador, on January 25, 2010. Initial reports of a missile launch were retracted, and the French Government denied any military activity. Gerry Byrne, a Member of Parliament, pressed the government for more information.

2014, Kensington, Prince Edward Island 🔗

This section details a sighting by John Sheppard in Kensington, Prince Edward Island, on June 4, 2014. Sheppard captured unusual lights on his cellphone. MUFON confirmed the sighting, and CBC covered the event.

2014, North York, Ontario 🔗

This section describes multiple UFO sighting reports in North York, Ontario, on July 26, 2014. Sarah Chun recorded videos of flashing lights. Toronto Police received several calls. Various explanations were offered, including quadcopters and Chinese lanterns.

Canadian UFO Survey results 🔗

This section summarizes the 2002 Canadian UFO Survey, noting that Toronto had the most sightings, followed by Vancouver and Terrace, B.C. It also mentions that the Canadian Federal Government directs UFO sightings to Chris Rutkowski of Ufology Research of Manitoba. A 2018 study by Ufology Research reported over 1,000 UFO sightings in Canada in 2017.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related links to people and projects associated with UFOs, including Dan Aykroyd, Stanton T. Friedman, Paul Hellyer, Peter Millman, lists of ufologists and reported UFO sightings, and Projects Magnet and Second Storey.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to external websites and publications.

item.title: First Contact (novelette)
item.description:
First Contact 🔗

“First Contact” is a science fiction novelette written by Murray Leinster, published in Astounding Science Fiction in May 1945. It received a retro Hugo Award for Best Novelette in 1996. The story is notable for its early depiction of a universal translator.

Plot 🔗

The story revolves around the crew of the exploration ship Llanvabon encountering an alien vessel near the Crab Nebula. Both ships are technologically matched and represent their respective civilizations. The central conflict arises from the mutual fear that either ship could trace the other back to their home planet, leading to potential exploitation or destruction.

Communication is established, revealing that the aliens are humanoid bipeds who perceive infrared light and communicate via microwaves. Despite the differences, the crews, particularly a young human named Tommy Dort and his alien counterpart “Buck,” develop a rapport. However, the underlying tension remains due to the strategic implications of revealing their home worlds.

The story reaches a climax when Tommy proposes a solution: a mutual exchange of crews and ships. Each crew would take the other’s ship back to their respective home planets after disabling all tracking equipment. This plan is complicated by the realization that the aliens have independently conceived the same strategy.

The story concludes with the successful exchange, each crew departing in the other’s ship. They remove any identifying information that could lead back to their home worlds. Both sides anticipate technological gains from the exchange and plan to meet again in the future. Tommy expresses optimism about future relations, based on his shared sense of humor with Buck.

Radio Plays 🔗

“First Contact” was adapted into radio plays for Dimension X on September 8, 1951, and for X Minus One on October 6, 1955. The X Minus One version was a condensed adaptation with an altered ending. The story was also performed on Exploring Tomorrow on January 15, 1958.

Style 🔗

The writing style of “First Contact” is considered representative of the Golden Age of science fiction.

Legal Action Against Paramount Pictures 🔗

In 2000, Murray Leinster’s estate filed a lawsuit against Paramount Pictures, alleging trademark infringement related to the film Star Trek: First Contact. The estate claimed ownership of the term “First Contact” and argued that Paramount’s use of the phrase infringed on their trademark. The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia ruled in favor of Paramount, granting summary judgment and dismissing the suit. The court determined that the term “First Contact” had become generic, describing a common science fiction trope, and lacked the necessary secondary meaning to be protected as a trademark.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Contact_(novelette)

item.title: Alien Terminator (1988 film)
item.description:
Alien Terminator (1988 film) 🔗

This article details the 1988 Italian film Alien Terminator, also known as Top Line. It distinguishes it from the 1995 film of the same name.

Top Line 🔗

This section provides the original Italian title of the film, which is Top Line.

Film Details 🔗

This section presents key information about the film in a table format:

  • Director: Nello Rossati (also credited as Ted Archer)
  • Writers: Roberto Gianviti and Nello Rossati
  • Stars: Franco Nero and George Kennedy
  • Cinematography: Mario DiLeo
  • Editor: Adalberto Ceccarelli
  • Music: Maurizio Dami
  • Release Date: 1988
  • Country: Italy
  • Language: Italian

Plot 🔗

The plot revolves around Ted Angelo, an alcoholic writer who discovers a 16th-century Spanish ship inside a mountain cave in Cartagena, Colombia. He learns the cave is actually the inside of a crashed UFO. He is pursued by hitmen, a Nazi fugitive named Heinrich Holzmann, and CIA operatives. He teams up with art historian June and eventually involves his ex-wife Maureen. Maureen is revealed to be an alien who has been disguising herself as a human and manipulating world events. She is killed by June. Ted and June go into hiding with an indigenous tribe, where Ted continues to write about his experiences.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the main actors and their respective roles in the film:

  • Franco Nero as Ted Angelo
  • George Kennedy as Heinrich Holzmann
  • Deborah Moore (credited as Deborah Barrymore) as June
  • Mary Stavin as Maureen De Havilland
  • William Berger as Alonso Kintero
  • Shirley Hernandez as Juanita
  • Larry Dolgin
  • Robert Redcross

Release 🔗

This section details the film’s release information. It was released theatrically in Germany on September 22, 1988. It was released on Region 1 DVD on May 25, 2004. It is also available for streaming on platforms like Amazon.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes critical reception of the film. Sci-Fi 100 noted the initial lack of science fiction elements but found the last 30 minutes more engaging. Film Authority described the film as a mix of Romancing the Stone, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and The Terminator.

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon 🔗

The Dover Demon is a creature reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings 🔗

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as about 4 feet tall with glowing orange eyes and no nose or mouth, with a watermelon-shaped head. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature the following night on Springdale Avenue. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing on a stack of Bibles to the accuracy of his drawing. The locations of the sightings, when plotted on a map, formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, and a local investigator noted similarities to the creatures in the Kelly–Hopkinsville encounter. The Mutual UFO Network also investigated the sightings.

Possible explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size and plumage, which could reflect yellow headlights. The “long spindly arms” could be the partially opened wings of the owl. Police suggested the sightings were a school vacation hoax. Ben Radford suggests the sightings may have been influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture 🔗

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in an episode of the American horror television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet in 2009. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof, where it can see into the future, and in The Perhapanauts. It also made appearances in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. A Dover Demon appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. In the manga series Dandadan, an alien known as Dover Demon takes the form of a bipedal crustacean-like alien.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon

item.title: Jafr alien invasion
item.description:
2010 Jordanian Newspaper Prank: The Jafr Alien Invasion 🔗

This article details the events surrounding a prank published by the Jordanian newspaper Al-Ghad on April 1, 2010. The prank involved a fabricated story about UFOs landing near the town of Jafr, Jordan, and the panic that ensued among the town’s residents.

Summary 🔗

The article on the front page of Al-Ghad claimed that UFOs had landed in the desert near Jafr, and the “pilots” were described as 3-meter-tall creatures. The story also stated that communications were disrupted by the UFOs.

Details of the Prank and Reaction 🔗

The story elaborated on the alien landing, describing how the town was illuminated by the flying saucers at night, causing residents to flee into the streets. The hoax caused widespread fear in Jafr, leading parents to keep their children home from school. The mayor of Jafr, Mohammed Mleihan, contacted security authorities and considered ordering an evacuation of the town’s 13,000 residents. He also expressed the residents’ fear of an alien attack and considered suing the newspaper for spreading false information.

Apology and Context 🔗

The newspaper issued a formal apology for the disruption caused by the prank. The editor did not explain why Jafr was chosen as the target of the joke. However, the BBC noted that the area is known for its military bases, which have been used by American soldiers for joint exercises with the Jordanian military and had allegedly housed al-Qaida militants in the past.

Comparison and Cultural Context 🔗

The prank is compared to the 1938 radio broadcast of War of the Worlds, which caused panic in the United States. The article emphasizes that April Fool’s Day jokes are not a common practice in Jordanian newspapers.

References 🔗

The article cites two sources: a BBC article titled “‘Alien invasion’ April Fools’ story angers Jordan mayor” and a USA Today article titled “‘Alien invasion’ April Fools prank causes public panic.”

External Links 🔗

The article provides an external link to the original article in Arabic on the Al-Ghad website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jafr_alien_invasion

item.title: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting
item.description:
Nash-Fortenberry UFO Sighting 🔗

The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting occurred on July 14, 1952, when two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported seeing eight UFOs in a tight echelon formation over Chesapeake Bay in Virginia.

Description 🔗

Two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported observing eight UFOs flying in formation over Chesapeake Bay, Virginia. Ufologists highlight the pilots’ observation allowed for measurements of the objects’ motion and size relative to known landmarks. The sighting was reportedly corroborated by independent ground witnesses. Project Blue Book listed the case as an “unknown.”

Explanations 🔗

Donald Howard Menzel suggested the pilots might have seen distorted ground lights due to haze or fireflies trapped in the cockpit window. Steuart Campbell proposed the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A NICAP report by Thomas Thulien revisiting the Nash/Fortenberry sighting.
  2. Donald Howard Menzel’s book, The World of Flying Saucers, where he offers naturalistic explanations.
  3. Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved, where he suggests the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

Further Reading 🔗

This section lists additional resources for further information:

  • Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved.
  • James W. Moseley and Karl T. Pflock’s book, Shockingly Close to the Truth: Confessions of a Grave-Robbing Ufologist.

External Links 🔗

  • “The Pilots’ Tale” at Saturday Night Uforia.
  • “We Flew Above Flying Saucers” by William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, published in True magazine in 1967.

item.title: UFO sightings in Nepal
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Nepal 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Nepal.

25 March 1968 🔗

This section details a significant event that occurred around 8:15 pm in Batulechaur, Pokhara. Residents reported witnessing a “blazing object” accompanied by a loud thunderous sound, which appeared to disintegrate over the Kaski region. Following this event, a large metallic disk-shaped object was discovered in a crater in Baltichaur, approximately five miles northeast of Pokhara. Additional fragments of a similar object were found in Talakot and Turepasal. The CIA documented this event. Kevin D. Randle mentions in his book “Moon Dust” that the American embassy in Kathmandu sent a secret message to the 1127th USAF Field Activities Group and the 1006th at Fort Belvoir, requesting full cooperation from the Nepalese government, under the subject “MOON DUST”.

20 March 2020 🔗

This section describes a more recent event in Gandaki province. A bright, “burning” object was observed flying towards Earth, followed by a crashing sound. The Astronomical Society urged people to provide evidence of the sighting.

See also 🔗

References 🔗

  1. A CIA “Information Report” documenting the 1968 incident.
  2. An article from the Kathmandu Post titled “How the US kept tabs on UFO sightings and Yeti hunting in Nepal,” referencing the 1968 event.
  3. Kevin D. Randle’s book, “Project Moon Dust,” specifically Chapter 8, which discusses the history of Project Moon Dust.
  4. An article from The Himalayan Times titled “Astronomical society urges people to provide evidence on sighting,” covering the 2020 event.

item.title: Alien Encounters (TV series)
item.description:
Alien Encounters (TV series) 🔗

Alien Encounters is a science fiction mini-series that aired on the Science Channel. It explores potential human reactions to first contact with extraterrestrial life. The series blends fictional scenarios with commentary from scientists and science fiction writers, presenting itself in a documentary style. The narrative begins with the detection of an alien signal by the SETI Institute and progresses through initial contact to the creation of human-alien hybrids.

Episodes 🔗

This section lists all episodes of the Alien Encounters series, divided by season. Each episode is listed with its title and original release date. A brief summary of each episode’s plot is also provided.

Season 1 🔗

Season 1 consists of two episodes:

  • “The Message” (March 13, 2012): Focuses on the human race’s reaction to receiving a message from outer space.
  • “The Arrival” (March 20, 2012): Depicts humanity’s response to the news that an alien spaceship is traveling to Earth.

Season 2 🔗

Season 2 also contains two episodes:

  • “The Invasion” (March 5, 2013): Shows alien spacecraft releasing thousands of pods onto the Earth’s surface.
  • “The Offspring” (March 12, 2013): Explores how humans adapt to living alongside the rapidly multiplying alien pods.

Season 3 🔗

Season 3 is the longest, with six episodes:

  • “The Seventh Sense (working title: The Aura)” (May 27, 2014): A Turkish physicist discovers blueprints for a quantum computer.
  • “The Entanglement” (June 3, 2014): A quantum supercomputer named “Quincy” is built, enabling telepathic connections with hybrid human children.
  • “The Prophecies” (June 10, 2014): Quincy becomes self-aware and begins predicting future events.
  • “The Escalation” (June 17, 2014): The U.S. government plans an attack on Quincy.
  • “The War” (June 24, 2014): After the initial attack fails, the U.S. government targets the network. A mysterious box appears from alien debris orbiting Earth.
  • “The Time Machine” (July 1, 2014): Quincy distributes its cloud intelligence before being destroyed. Information about an incoming comet is released.

Recurring Commentators 🔗

This section lists the individuals who provided commentary throughout the Alien Encounters series. These commentators include scientists, authors, and futurists. Some notable commentators include:

  • Anthony D. Call (Narrator)
  • Ariel Anbar (Director, ASU Astrobiology Program)
  • Jeffrey L. Bada (Distinguished Professor of Marine Chemistry, UCSD)
  • David Brin (Astronomer, Author, NASA Consultant)

item.title: History of the extraterrestrial life debate
item.description:
Historical Views about Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article explores the historical debate surrounding the existence of extraterrestrial life, tracing its evolution from ancient philosophical speculations to modern scientific inquiry. It highlights key figures, pivotal moments, and shifting perspectives that have shaped our understanding of this enduring question.

Ancient Greece 🔗

This section delves into the earliest recorded discussions about extraterrestrial life, focusing on Ancient Greece. It contrasts the views of atomists, who believed in the possibility of multiple worlds with life, and Aristotelians, who argued for the uniqueness of Earth.

  • Key Points: The section highlights the shift from mythological explanations of celestial objects to philosophical inquiries about the nature of the universe.
  • Important People: Thales of Miletus, Anaximander, Pythagoras, Aristarchus of Samos, Plato, Aristotle, Leucippus, Democritus, Epicurus, Lucretius, Alexander the Great.
  • Locations: Ancient Greece, Alexandria, Baghdad, Roman Empire, Byzantine Empire.
  • Major Events: The development of geometry, the proposal of heliocentric and geocentric models, the spread of Greek ideas through the Macedonian Empire and the Islamic Golden Age, and the eventual return of this knowledge to Europe.

Christianity 🔗

This section examines the influence of Christianity on the debate about extraterrestrial life during the Middle Ages. It discusses how the concept of multiple worlds was largely viewed as heretical, with a few exceptions.

  • Key Points: The section focuses on the conflict between religious doctrine and the idea of extraterrestrial life, particularly concerning the uniqueness of creation and the role of Christ’s redemption.
  • Important People: Origen, Augustine of Hippo, Thomas Aquinas, William Vorilong, John.
  • Major Events: The rise of Christianity, the Condemnation of 1277, and the discussions surrounding the implications of extraterrestrial life for Christian theology.

Copernican Revolution 🔗

This section explores how the Copernican Revolution, which shifted the Earth from the center of the universe, significantly impacted the plausibility of extraterrestrial life.

  • Key Points: The section highlights the transition from a geocentric to a heliocentric worldview and the scientific advancements that supported this shift.
  • Important People: Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, Galileo Galilei, Isaac Newton, Giordano Bruno.
  • Major Events: The publication of De revolutionibus orbium coelestium, Kepler’s discovery of elliptical orbits, Galileo’s telescopic observations, and Newton’s formulation of the laws of motion and universal gravitation.

Modern Times 🔗

This section discusses the modern scientific approach to the question of extraterrestrial life, encompassing fields like biology, chemistry, biochemistry, physics, and planetary science, all under the umbrella of astrobiology.

  • Key Points: The section emphasizes the vastness and age of the universe, the abundance of elements necessary for life, and the universality of physical laws, which together suggest that life on other worlds is plausible.
  • Major Events: The development of astrobiology as a multidisciplinary field, and the ongoing search for extraterrestrial life through scientific exploration and research.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_extraterrestrial_life_debate

item.title: James Harder
item.description:
James A. Harder 🔗

James Albert Harder was a professor of civil and hydraulic engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, and later a professor emeritus. He also had a notable interest in ufology.

Engineering 🔗

Harder taught civil engineering at various levels, emphasizing practical aspects like lab experiments and model testing. While he didn’t publish extensively, his work was recognized for its quality. He made significant contributions to flow simulations before computers were widely used. A paper he co-authored, Sea Water Intrusion in California, received an award in 1957. His work was applied in Suisun Bay and the Mekong Delta, and he also studied fish protection facilities. Later in his career, he studied fluid mechanics in a medical context, working on artificial hearts, endoscopes, and colostomy equipment.

Ufology 🔗

Harder believed that unidentified flying objects were extraterrestrial beings. He testified before the House of Representatives Committee on Science and Astronautics and was involved with the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO).

Education 🔗

Harder’s education included:

  • B.S. from the California Institute of Technology in 1948.
  • M.S. in Civil Engineering from UC Berkeley in 1952.
  • Ph.D. in Fluid Mechanics from UC Berkeley in 1957.

Career 🔗

Harder’s career included:

  • U.S. Navy as an electronics technician (1944-45).
  • Design Engineer for the soil conservation service, U.S. Department of Agriculture (1948–50).
  • Resident engineer at UC Berkeley (1952–57).
  • Assistant professor of hydraulic engineering at UC Berkeley (1957–62).
  • Associate professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1962–70).
  • Professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1970–91).
  • Professor emeritus at UC Berkeley (1991).

Organizations 🔗

Harder was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). He was also a founding member of the Society for Scientific Exploration.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Harder_(ufologist)

item.title: Barlowe's Guide to Extraterrestrials
item.description:
Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials 🔗

Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials is a science fiction book published in 1979, with a second edition in 1987. The book is authored by artist Wayne Barlowe, with text contributions from Ian Summers and Beth Meacham.

Summary 🔗

This section provides a listing of the extraterrestrial species featured in the book. Each entry includes the alien’s name, the author who created it, and the specific work of science fiction in which the alien appears. Some of the notable aliens included are the Abyormenite from Hal Clement’s Cycle of Fire, the Athshean from Ursula K. Le Guin’s The Word for World Is Forest, the Black Cloud from Fred Hoyle’s The Black Cloud, and the Guild Steersman from Frank Herbert’s Dune Messiah. The list continues with numerous other aliens from a wide range of science fiction novels and stories.

Reception 🔗

This section details the critical reception of Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials. Wendy Bousfield in Library Journal offered a mixed review, praising the colorful drawings but finding them somewhat static and artificial. She also noted the omission of publication details for the novels from which the aliens were drawn. Claudia J. Morner in School Library Journal gave a positive review, highlighting the colorful drawings and the fold-out size chart. The book was nominated for an American Book Award and the Hugo Award for Best Related Work in 1980.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article. These include the book itself, reviews from Library Journal and School Library Journal, and links to the Hugo Awards website and a Kirkus Reviews article.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources related to Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials, including its listing on the Internet Speculative Fiction Database and its entry in Open Library.

item.title: Niche insurance
item.description:
Niche Insurance 🔗

Niche insurance caters to small, low-demand markets outside typical insurance offerings like auto, home, life, travel, and business. Obtaining this type of insurance can be challenging.

Examples 🔗

This section provides various examples of niche insurance policies. These include:

  • Assigned Risk Car Insurance: Insurance for drivers with convictions.
  • Home Owners Insurance: Coverage for homeowners with a history of large claims.
  • Insurance for Unusual Professions: Policies for professions like piano tuners or high-risk jobs like scaffolders.
  • Temporary Event Insurance: Coverage for events such as fêtes and live music events.
  • Body-Part Insurance: Insurance for individuals whose livelihood depends on specific body parts, such as actors insuring their legs or noses.
  • Kidnapping Insurance: Coverage for the kidnapping of key corporate executives.
  • Hole-in-One Insurance: Insurance for country clubs or venues offering large cash prizes for a hole-in-one during golf tournaments.
  • Alien Abduction Insurance: Policies covering alien abduction, initially offered by the St. Lawrence Agency in Altamonte Springs, Florida. Other companies, including one in England, have also sold such policies.
  • Supernatural Phenomena Insurance: Coverage for death or disability caused by ghosts and poltergeists.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to articles and websites that support the information presented. These sources range from news articles to insurance company websites, offering further details and verification of the claims made in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_insurance

item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (Disambiguation) 🔗

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “Unidentified flying object” and related variations. It directs users to different articles based on their intended meaning.

Definition 🔗

The primary meaning of “Unidentified flying object” refers to a perceived aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. This is the common understanding of the term, often associated with extraterrestrial speculation.

Music 🔗

This section lists musical works that use the term “Unidentified flying object” or variations in their titles.

  • UFO 1: A 1970 album by the British rock band UFO, which was reissued under the title Unidentified Flying Object.
  • The Unidentified Flying Object: A 1966 electronica song by Perrey and Kingsley.

item.title: Aliens Exist
item.description:
Aliens Exist 🔗

“Aliens Exist” is a song by the American rock band Blink-182, featured on their 1999 album Enema of the State. The song, primarily written by guitarist Tom DeLonge with additional credit to bassist Mark Hoppus, is a lighthearted take on the existence of extraterrestrial life. It references UFO phenomena, including alleged CIA involvement and the Majestic 12.

Background 🔗

Blink-182, originating from suburban San Diego, gained prominence in the late 1990s with their pop-punk sound. The band members included guitarist Tom DeLonge, bassist Mark Hoppus, and drummer Travis Barker. DeLonge’s fascination with extraterrestrials began in middle school and continued as he toured, reading books about paranormal activity. Barker recalls DeLonge constantly searching for UFOs. DeLonge used his first personal computer to research alien phenomena. He amassed a collection of UFO books and military interviews about UFO experiences. Hoppus found DeLonge’s beliefs amusing. DeLonge and Hoppus often debated the song’s subject matter, leaving each other messages on their equipment. Barker, then a touring musician, arranged the song’s tempo and structure.

Composition 🔗

The song is written in common time with a tempo of 216 beats per minute, in the key of B major. The lyrics, written by DeLonge, express youthful curiosity about the universe and attempt to convince listeners of the legitimacy of his claims. The lyrics suggest the CIA is suppressing information and reference the Majestic 12, a supposed group of scientists studying alien spacecraft in the 1940s. DeLonge explained the song’s perspective as that of someone who believes in aliens but is dismissed by others, directing his frustration towards the government.

Release and Reception 🔗

“Aliens Exist” was initially previewed as part of an online medley and officially released on Enema of the State in June 1999. It received positive reviews, with some critics praising its departure from typical pop-punk themes.

Live Performances 🔗

Although not released as a single, the band performed the song on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno in 2000. It was a regular part of their tour and live album, The Mark, Tom and Travis Show. The band retired the song in 2002 but revived it on their 2019 tour, with Matt Skiba filling in for DeLonge. DeLonge also performed the song with Angels & Airwaves in 2019. Following DeLonge’s return to Blink-182, the band continued to perform the song on their 2023 world tour, incorporating tabloid imagery of DeLonge’s interest in aliens.

Legacy 🔗

The song has been re-examined in light of DeLonge’s continued pursuit of UFO research. It is remembered as a standout track from Enema of the State and is considered part of American pop culture’s fascination with aliens. Blink-182 embraced this image, using alien imagery on merchandise and at concerts. DeLonge continued to explore alien themes in his band Angels & Airwaves. Machine Gun Kelly’s “Concert for Aliens” was seen as reminiscent of DeLonge’s earlier work. DeLonge co-founded To the Stars, a company focused on aerospace, science, and entertainment, with former government and intelligence officials. In 2017, the company released leaked military footage of unidentified aerial phenomena, later confirmed by the Pentagon, which legitimized DeLonge’s research. This led to the Pentagon formally establishing interest in studying UFOs.

Personnel 🔗

  • Locations:

    • Signature Sound, Studio West (San Diego, California)
    • Mad Hatter Studios, The Bomb Factory (Los Angeles, California)
    • Conway Recording Studios (Hollywood, California)
    • Big Fish Studios (Encinitas, California)

  • Blink-182:

    • Mark Hoppus – bass guitar, vocals
    • Tom DeLonge – guitars, vocals
    • Travis Barker – drums, percussion

  • Production:

    • Jerry Finn – production
    • Tom Lord-Alge – mixing engineer
    • Sean O’Dwyer – recording engineer
    • Darrel Harvey – assistant engineer
    • John Nelson – assistant engineer
    • Robert Read – assistant engineer
    • Mike Fasano – drum technician
    • Brian Gardner – mastering engineer

item.title: Pascagoula Abduction
item.description:
Pascagoula Abduction 🔗

The Pascagoula Abduction refers to an alleged UFO sighting and alien abduction that occurred in 1973. Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker claimed to have been abducted and examined by extraterrestrial beings while fishing near the Pascagoula River in Mississippi.

Alleged abduction 🔗

On the evening of October 11, 1973, Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker reported to the Jackson County, Mississippi, sheriff’s office that they experienced an unusual event while fishing on a pier along the Pascagoula River. They described hearing a strange whirring sound and seeing flashing blue lights, followed by the appearance of an oval-shaped object. Hickson and Parker claimed they were paralyzed and then taken aboard the object by three creatures with robotic features and crab-like pincers, where they underwent an examination.

Publicity and later activities 🔗

Following the incident, Charles Hickson engaged in interviews, lectures, and television appearances, including an episode of To Tell The Truth. He also claimed additional encounters with aliens and authored a book titled UFO Contact at Pascagoula. Calvin Parker attended UFO conventions and started a company called “UFO Investigations.”

Charles Hickson died in September 2011.

In 2018, Calvin Parker released his own book, Pascagoula: The Closest Encounter, My Story, providing his full account of the event and its impact on his life.

In June 2019, a historical marker was unveiled at the site of the alleged abduction. Calvin Parker, along with Hickson’s son and family, attended the unveiling.

Calvin Parker died in August 2023.

Skepticism 🔗

Aviation journalist and UFO skeptic Philip J. Klass found discrepancies in Hickson’s story and noted his refusal to take a polygraph exam. Klass concluded that the case was a hoax. Skeptical investigator Joe Nickell questioned Hickson’s behavior and suggested that the alien encounter may have been a hypnagogic “waking dream state.” Nickell also suggested that Parker’s corroboration was due to suggestibility, as he initially claimed to have passed out during the incident.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “List of UFO sightings” for further reading.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article, including news articles, books, and websites.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to the Pascagoula Abduction, including information about Calvin Parker’s book, a transcript of an interview with Hickson and Parker, and an article by Joe Nickell.

item.title: Close encounter of Cussac
item.description:
Close encounter incident in Cussac, Cantal, France 🔗

This article discusses the alleged close encounter that occurred in Cussac, Cantal, France in 1967.

Summary 🔗

This section introduces the topic as a claimed close encounter with alien beings by a young brother and sister in Cussac, Cantal, France. It cites a source that refers to the incident as a “close encounter of the third kind,” comparing its fame in France to the Kelly-Hopkinsville encounter in the United States.

Details of the Incident 🔗

This section details the events of August 29, 1967, when a 13-year-old boy and his 9-year-old sister reported seeing four small, black beings about 47 inches tall while watching cows in a field. The children claimed the beings rose into the air and entered a round spaceship, about 15 feet in diameter, that was hovering over the field. Police noted a sulfur odor and dried grass at the alleged takeoff site. The incident is mentioned as one of the UFO sightings investigated by the French government and made public in a mass release of documents in March 2007.

See also 🔗

This section contains a link to the “UFO sightings in France” page.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources used in the article:

  • Rossini, David; Maillot, Eric; Déguillaume, Eric (February 2009). “UFOs: an Assessment of Thirty Years of Official Studies in France”. Skeptical Inquirer.
  • Moore, Molly (March 23, 2007). “French Get a Look at Nation’s UFO Files”. The Washington Post.

Further reading 🔗

item.title: Alien implants
item.description:
Alien Implants 🔗

Alien implants are physical objects that some people believe are placed in their bodies after being abducted by aliens. These implants are purported to have various capabilities, including telepresence, mind control, and biotelemetry.

History 🔗

The concept of alien implants can be traced back to a 1957 radio show interview with ufologist John Robinson, who recounted a neighbor’s claim of being kidnapped by aliens and controlled by “small earphones.” Betty Andreasson claimed aliens implanted a device in her nose in 1967. Dorothy Wallis made a similar claim in 1983. Authors like Whitley Strieber popularized the idea of alien abductions and associated implants. John E. Mack examined an object given to him by a client who claimed it came out of her nose after an abduction. Roger Leir claimed to have removed alien implants from patients. Skeptic Joe Nickell suggests that supposed alien implants are ordinary materials that become lodged in the body and surrounded by scar tissue. Virgil Priscu stated that there is “No mystery, no implants”.

Popular Culture 🔗

Alien implants, depicted as small needles inserted into victims, first appeared in the 1953 film Invaders from Mars.

See Also 🔗

The article references “matchbox sign”, a similar phenomenon related to delusional parasitosis.

References 🔗

The article cites several sources, including:

  • Peter Rogerson’s article “Fairyland’s Hunters, Part One” in Magonia magazine.
  • Joe Nickell’s book Real-Life X-Files: Investigating the Paranormal.
  • Susan A. Clancy’s book Abducted: How People Come To Believe They Were Kidnapped By Aliens.

External Links 🔗

The article provides links to:

  • “Scientific Analysis of an ‘Alien Implant’” by Susan Blackmore.
  • “Skeptoid #519: Alien Implants” by Brian Dunning.
