item.title: CAESAR
item.description:
CAESAR 🔗

CAESAR (Comet Astrobiology Exploration Sample Return) was a proposed sample-return mission to comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko. It was a finalist in NASA’s New Frontiers program mission 4 but was not selected. If chosen, it would have launched in 2024-2025 and returned a sample to Earth in 2038.

Mission Overview 🔗

The mission aimed to collect a sample from comet 67P, which was previously explored by the European Space Agency’s Rosetta probe and its lander Philae. The existing data from Rosetta would have allowed for a more informed spacecraft design, increasing the chances of mission success. NASA ultimately selected the Dragonfly mission over CAESAR in June 2019.

Background 🔗

A comet sample-return mission was a prioritized goal in the 2003 and 2011 Planetary Science Decadal Survey. Prior comet missions by NASA include Deep Space 1, Stardust, CONTOUR, and Deep Impact, along with participation in the Rosetta mission. Comet Hopper was another mission proposal that was a Discovery Program finalist but was not selected.

Astrobiology 🔗

CAESAR’s objectives centered on understanding the formation of the Solar System and the origins of life. The mission aimed to investigate the possibility that comets delivered organic compounds, specifically tholins, to early Earth, potentially seeding the planet with the building blocks of life. The Rosetta mission detected tholins on comet 67P.

Spacecraft 🔗

Northrop Grumman Innovation Systems would have built the spacecraft, utilizing technology from the Dawn mission. Malin Space Science Systems would have provided the camera suite for navigation, sample site selection, and documentation. Honeybee Robotics would have provided the robotic arm (TAG) and the Sample Acquisition System. The Japanese space agency JAXA would have provided the sample return capsule and heatshield.

Propulsion 🔗

The spacecraft’s propulsion system would have been NASA’s Evolutionary Xenon Thruster (NEXT), a type of solar electric propulsion. The system would have used three NEXT thrusters, with one as a spare, and xenon as the propellant.

Sample Return 🔗

The spacecraft would have used a “Touch-And-Go” (TAG) robotic arm to collect regolith from the comet’s surface, similar to OSIRIS-REx. A burst of nitrogen gas would have blown regolith particles into the sampler head. CAESAR would have collected between 80 and 800 grams of regolith. The system had enough compressed nitrogen gas for three sampling attempts. The sample would have been returned to Earth in a capsule provided by JAXA, landing at the Utah Test and Training Range in 2038. The sample would then be transported to NASA’s Johnson Space Center for curation and analysis at the Astromaterials Research and Exploration Science Directorate (ARES). A portion of the sample would also be curated at Japan’s Extraterrestrial Sample Curation Center.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAESAR_(spacecraft)

item.title: Joe Alien
item.description:
Joe Alien 🔗

Joe Alien is a British comic book character who appeared in strips published by Fleetway Publications. He debuted in the preview issue of the science fiction anthology Wildcat in October 1988. The character’s strip was one of four linked serials in Wildcat and was later briefly featured in Eagle after Wildcat was canceled. Joe Alien is the last survivor of the planet Xgangbe-4 and joins the Wildcat mission to help humanity find a new home, commanding the Wildcat 2 exploration shuttle.

Creation 🔗

Barrie Tomlinson created Joe Alien as part of a new science fiction anthology, Wildcat, for Fleetway Publications. The concept involved linking all five features in the comic to form an overall narrative centered on the spaceship Wildcat. Tomlinson created four lead characters, including Joe Alien, to head exploration teams. Massimo Belardinelli was the initial artist for “Joe Alien,” with Tomlinson praising his ability to bring the story to life.

Publishing history 🔗

Wildcat began publication in October 1988, featuring “Joe Alien” as the color strip. Ron Smith took over as the artist from the third issue. Wildcat was canceled after 12 issues and merged with Eagle in March 1989. “Joe Alien” continued in Eagle for four weeks in May 1989 to complete the story arc and also featured in three episodes of “The Wildcat Complete” anthology. Rebellion Developments purchased the rights to Wildcat in 2016 and announced plans to reprint the contents in collected editions. As of 2025, only “Turbo Jones” and “Loner” have been released.

Plot summary 🔗

Joe Alien joins the Wildcat mission after Turbo Jones realizes Earth is doomed. Joe, the last survivor of Xgangbe-4, possesses vast knowledge stored in an external brain-pack. He is selected for his intelligence and physical attributes. After the Wildcat launches, Joe’s sensors locate a potential new home for the refugees.

He leads the Wildcat Two shuttle to scout Area 17, where his team encounters carnivorous vegetation and a two-headed alien. They discover that the plants are controlled by a mad human astronaut from a 2079 Mars mission, who is now worshipped as a god. Joe brokers an alliance with giant insects to escape and later participates in other expeditions.

Joe shares the story of the Xgangbe’s destruction by the Kargroz and his revenge. He is later chosen to find an alien shapeshifter on board the Wildcat. Joe, along with Jones, Loner, and Magee, is kidnapped by a Gamemaster of the Glarzon race but is released after defeating the Glarzon’s troops.

Reception 🔗

Graham Kibble-White described Joe Alien as “dopily designed.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Alien

item.title: A Verdade Sufocada
item.description:
A Verdade Sufocada 🔗

This entry details the book “A Verdade Sufocada” (“The Suffocated Truth”) written by Carlos Alberto Brilhante Ustra, a Brazilian military colonel convicted of torture during Brazil’s military dictatorship (1964-1985). The book presents Ustra’s perspective on the left-wing armed resistance during that period and his experiences as head of DOI-CODI, an agency known for political repression, torture, and murder of the dictatorship’s opponents. The book’s publication faced boycotts, requiring the author’s family to finance its print runs. It gained attention after being quoted by Jair Bolsonaro during Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment vote in 2016 and became a bestseller. However, it has been heavily criticized by historians and sociologists who question its reliability as a historical document.

The book 🔗

This section focuses on the content of “A Verdade Sufocada,” explaining that it presents the military’s version of events during the Brazilian dictatorship, emphasizing attacks by leftist groups. The author’s wife, a historian, collaborated on the book, providing context related to the Cold War.

Criticism 🔗

This section outlines the criticisms leveled against “A Verdade Sufocada.” Luciano Oliveira, a sociology professor, deems the book historically worthless but acknowledges its value as confirmation of the disgracefulness of torture. Neusah Cerveira, a historian, points out the lack of explicit bibliographic citations and describes the book as superficial despite its length and strong title.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists academic works that reference or analyze “A Verdade Sufocada.” These include studies on persuasive communication as a strategy for controlling collective memory, discursive strategies of perpetrators of the Brazilian military dictatorship, and the portrayal of the left by the right in books written by military personnel involved in repression during the dictatorship. The listed authors are Fernando Cibelli de Castro, Fabricio Fernandes, and Clarissa Grahl dos Santos.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and figures, including:

  • Torture Never Again: An organization or movement opposed to torture.
  • List of people killed by and disappeared during the Brazilian military dictatorship: A record of victims of the regime.
  • Securing Sex: A potentially related book or study.
  • Sérgio Paranhos Fleury: A controversial figure associated with repression during the dictatorship.
  • Ternuma: Possibly a military unit or operation.
  • Vladimir Herzog: A journalist whose death under torture became a symbol of resistance against the dictatorship.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article, providing specific details about each source, including authors, titles, publishers, publication dates, and URLs where available. These references support the information presented in the article and allow readers to verify the claims made.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the official website/blog associated with the book, maintained by Joseíta Brilhante Ustra, the author’s widow.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Verdade_Sufocada

item.title: Extraterrestrial sample curation
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Sample Curation 🔗

This article discusses the specialized facilities and procedures required for handling and preserving samples returned from space, with a focus on planetary protection and sample integrity.

Overview 🔗

This section emphasizes the importance of bringing extraterrestrial materials to Earth for in-depth scientific analysis due to the limitations of spacecraft instruments. It highlights the need for specialized biocontainment facilities that also function as cleanrooms to prevent contamination of the samples and protect Earth from potential biohazards. The section differentiates between non-restricted samples (e.g., from the Moon, asteroids) and restricted samples (from potentially habitable bodies like Mars), which require more stringent containment measures. It mentions the Biosafety Levels (BSL) required for each type of sample, with restricted samples needing BSL-4 facilities. A key challenge is the need to both contain the samples and allow researchers to analyze them without compromising their integrity or Earth’s safety.

Non-restricted Materials 🔗

This section focuses on the curation of samples from celestial bodies not considered to pose a biohazard risk, such as the Moon, asteroids, and comets. It mentions that as of 2019, only JAXA (Japan) and NASA (United States) operate BSL-3 laboratories dedicated to curating these samples. The Extraterrestrial Sample Curation Center at JAXA is highlighted for its ability to handle samples without atmospheric exposure. The Vernadsky Institute of Geochemistry and Analytical Chemistry at the Russian Academy of Sciences is mentioned as the location where Luna Soviet mission samples are studied and stored. The OSIRIS-REx mission’s sample return to Earth is also mentioned.

Restricted Materials 🔗

This section addresses the handling of samples from planets or moons suspected of harboring past or present life, which are classified as Category V bodies. It emphasizes that these samples require BSL-4 facilities, but existing BSL-4 labs are not adequate for both sample preservation and Earth protection. Two proposed facilities are discussed: the European Sample Curation Facility (ESCF) in Vienna and NASA’s Mars Sample-Return Receiving Facility (MSRRF). The MSRRF had multiple designs submitted in 2009, and its construction is estimated to take 7-10 years, with an additional 2 years for staff training. A mobile BSL-4 facility for preliminary biohazard analysis at the landing site is also being considered. The section outlines stringent containment requirements, including filtering particles as small as 0.01 μm to prevent the release of potential biohazards, including gene transfer agents (GTAs) and ultramicrobacteria. The section also notes that some advocate for robotic systems within BSL-4 facilities to minimize human contamination.

item.title: Bill Moore (ufologist)
item.description:
William L. Moore (Ufologist) 🔗

William Leonard Moore, born October 31, 1943, is an author and former UFO researcher who gained prominence from the late 1970s to the late 1980s. He is best known for co-authoring two books with Charles Berlitz, including The Roswell Incident.

Career 🔗

Moore’s interest in UFOs began in his teenage years. He graduated from Thiel College in Greenville, Pennsylvania, in 1965. After teaching language and humanities at various high schools, he became the Arizona state section director of the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON). He then transitioned to a career as a freelance writer.

He co-authored The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility with Charles Berlitz in 1979, which explored the alleged naval military experiment aboard the USS Eldridge in 1943. In 1980, Moore and Berlitz co-wrote The Roswell Incident, which claimed that the Roswell UFO incident involved the crash of an extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In May 1987, Moore, along with ufologists Jaime Shandera and Stanton Friedman, circulated the Majestic 12 documents, which purported the existence of a high-level policy-making group overseeing UFOs and extraterrestrials.

At a 1989 MUFON conference, Moore admitted to engaging in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Critical Reception 🔗

The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility has been largely dismissed as an unsubstantiated urban myth. The Roswell Incident has been criticized as a collection of hearsay and unwarranted speculation. Critics have also pointed fingers at Moore regarding the fraudulent nature of the Majestic 12 documents.

Books 🔗

  • The Philadelphia Experiment Project Invisibility (1979)
  • The Roswell Incident (1980)

See also 🔗

  • UFO conspiracy theory

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Moore_(ufologist)

item.title: Max Evans (Roswell)
item.description:
Max Evans (Roswell) 🔗

Maxwell “Max” Evans is a fictional character created by Melinda Metz for the Roswell High book series and adapted for the Roswell television series (1999-2002). He is portrayed by Jason Behr in the original series and by Nathan Parsons in the CW reboot. Max is a central character throughout the series, first appearing in the pilot episode.

Fictional character summary 🔗

This section focuses on the TV character, distinguishing it from the Roswell High book version. Max’s backstory reveals that in a previous life, he was Zan, the king of Antar. After Zan’s death, his DNA and human DNA were used to create alien/human hybrids or clones, including Isabel Evans (Vilandra, Zan’s sister), Michael Guerin (Rath, Vilandra’s betrothed), and Tess Harding (Ava, Zan’s bride). These clones were sent to Earth to escape their enemies, particularly Kivar. The craft carrying Max, Isabel, Michael, and Tess crashed in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. The U.S. Army initially took the alien pods, but they were rescued and hidden. The clones emerged in 1989, appearing as children. Max and Isabel were adopted by the Evans, while Michael ended up in foster care.

Characteristics 🔗

Max is presented as shy and introverted, a facade necessitated by his hybrid nature. He is a complex character, displaying both timidity and passion. Despite his initial shyness, he emerges as the leader among his friends. He is portrayed as a deep thinker, often spurred to action by his protective instincts. He takes responsibility for his actions and is known for his unique healing powers.

Powers and abilities 🔗

Max possesses molecular manipulation and telekinesis, abilities shared by the other hybrids. His unique power is healing through physical contact, famously used to save Liz Parker in the pilot episode. He also develops the ability to generate a force field. It is suggested that his healing ability can trigger the development of alien powers in those he heals, such as Liz Parker.

Relationship with Liz Parker 🔗

Max’s love for Liz Parker is a central theme. He has been in love with her since childhood but keeps his distance due to his alien identity. He reveals his secret to save her life after she is shot, initiating the main plot of the show. Their connection is portrayed as deep and mysterious, with Liz able to sense when Max is in danger. Their relationship is considered a core aspect of the show.

Recurring themes 🔗

The relationship between Max and Liz is presented as a modern example of forbidden love, with references to Romeo and Juliet. Maria De Luca refers to them as “modern Romeo and Juliet against the world.” The concept of soulmates is also a recurring theme, emphasizing their deep connection and compatibility.

Fictional biography 🔗

Season one 🔗

Max is first seen watching Liz at the Crashdown Café. After Liz is accidentally shot, Max heals her, revealing his alien nature. Liz discovers his secret and becomes his confidante. Max and Liz’s relationship develops, complicated by his secret. Liz breaks up with Kyle Valenti to be with Max. The hybrids search for answers about their origins. Max discovers a fourth alien. Tess Harding arrives, revealed to be another hybrid. Nasedo kidnaps Liz, prompting Max to save her. Max is abducted by the FBI but rescued by Nasedo and Michael. Sheriff Valenti pledges to protect Max, Isabel, and Michael. The ship reveals their past as the Royal Four of Antar, with Tess and Max being married.

Season two 🔗

Max struggles with his role as “reluctant king.” His relationship with Liz is strained. He learns about new powers and responsibilities. The “skins” arrive in Roswell. Max tries to rekindle his relationship with Liz, but she rejects him. A future version of Max warns that their love will cause the end of the world. Max and Tess become friends. Alex dies. Max has a personal crisis and loses his balance. Tess helps him remember his past. Max sleeps with Tess, who becomes pregnant. Max takes responsibility and stays with Tess. Tess mindwarps him into believing the baby is sick. Max and his friends plan to return to Antar. Liz, Maria, and Kyle discover that Tess killed Alex. Max confronts Tess and lets her go to Antar to save the baby. He reunites with Liz and declares his love for her.

Season three 🔗

Max searches for his son. He and Liz rob a convenience store to find the ship. Liz’s parents forbid her from seeing Max. Max discovers Cal Langley, an alien protector. Langley tries to interfere with Max’s search. Max forces Langley to help him find the ship. The ship doesn’t work. Max realizes he almost lost everything, especially Liz. Max encounters Samuel, an autistic child. Max realizes that Liz is his family. Liz develops alien powers. Liz decides to take a break from Roswell. Someone kills Michael’s friend, Monk. Michael discovers that Meta-Chem is tracking him. Max, Michael, and Isabel rescue Valenti. Max sacrifices his life to heal Meris’ husband. Max’s soul is inside Clayton. Clayton assumes Max’s body. Clayton tries to kill Liz. Max takes control and tells Liz to kill him. Liz kills Clayton, and Max is resurrected. Michael becomes the king. Max returns to be the king. Tess returns with Max’s son, Zan. Tess sacrifices herself. Max gives Zan up for adoption. Liz receives visions of the future. The group agrees to flee Roswell. Max proposes to Liz. Max and Liz get married. The group leaves Roswell together.

Jason Behr about his character 🔗

Jason Behr discusses his initial understanding of Max, relating to his search for truth and his place in the world. He highlights the richness of the script and its honest portrayal of relationships and emotions. Behr notes Max’s evolution throughout the show, from being the conscience of the group to learning to allow others to make their own mistakes. He also expresses his open-mindedness about extraterrestrial life.

Reception 🔗

Jason Behr was cast as Max Evans, despite the character’s original description as blond with blue eyes. David Nutter explains that Behr was chosen for his natural talent, humility, calmness, maturity, and wisdom. Melinda Metz, the original books’ writer, approved of the casting choice. Jason Behr won a Young Hollywood Award for his portrayal of Max Evans and received nominations at the Teen Choice Awards and Saturn Awards.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Evans_(Roswell)

item.title: Darwin (spacecraft)
item.description:
Darwin 🔗

Darwin was a proposed ESA Cornerstone mission involving a constellation of spacecraft designed to detect Earth-like planets orbiting nearby stars and search for evidence of life. The most recent design featured three free-flying space telescopes redirecting light to a fourth spacecraft containing beam combiners, spectrometers, and cameras. An earlier design included six 1.5-meter telescopes, a beam combiner, and a separate power and communications spacecraft. The study of this mission ended in 2007.

  • Key Points: Detection of Earth-like planets and search for extraterrestrial life.
  • Operator: ESA (European Space Agency)
  • Location: Sun-Earth L2 Lagrangian point in a Halo orbit.
  • Major Events: Study ended in 2007 with no further activities planned.

Concept 🔗

The space telescopes were designed to observe in the infrared spectrum. This region was chosen because the difference in brightness between an Earth-like planet and its star is less pronounced in the infrared compared to the visible spectrum. The spacecraft components in the optical path would need to be passively cooled to 40 kelvins for infrared observations. The planet search would have used a nulling interferometer configuration to cancel out light from the central star, allowing for the detection of orbiting planets. If a suitable planet was detected, a detailed study of its atmosphere would be conducted by analyzing its infrared spectrum for evidence of life, such as the presence of oxygen and water vapor.

  • Key Points: Infrared observation, nulling interferometer, atmospheric analysis for biosignatures.
  • Important People: Mention of a 2000 ESA bulletin.
  • Major Events: Design considerations for infrared observations and planet detection.

Candidate planets 🔗

Planet Gliese 581 d, discovered in 2007, was considered a good candidate for the Darwin project because it orbits within the habitable zone of its star, potentially supporting life.

  • Key Points: Gliese 581 d as a potential target for observation.
  • Major Events: Discovery of Gliese 581 d in 2007.

Similar initiatives 🔗

NASA’s Terrestrial Planet Finder (TPF) mission was similar in concept to Darwin. However, the TPF project was deferred indefinitely in 2006 and later cancelled in 2011. Antoine Labeyrie proposed a larger space-based astronomical interferometer called the Hypertelescope, which would be more expensive and complex than Darwin and TPF.

  • Key Points: Comparison to NASA’s Terrestrial Planet Finder and the Hypertelescope project.
  • Important People: Antoine Labeyrie.
  • Major Events: Deferral and cancellation of NASA’s Terrestrial Planet Finder.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darwin_(spacecraft)

item.title: Northern Light (spacecraft)
item.description:
Northern Light 🔗

Northern Light was a proposed Canadian Mars lander and rover mission. It was a concept mission studied by a consortium of Canadian universities, companies, and organizations, with Thoth Technology Inc. as the primary contractor. The mission was ultimately cancelled.

Mission Overview 🔗

The mission aimed to send a lander and rover to Mars. The spacecraft would have consisted of an apogee kick engine, a cruise vehicle, the Northern Light lander, and the Beaver Rover. A Hohmann transfer orbit would have been used for the journey to Mars. Atmospheric entry would have been achieved using a heat shield, parachute, and airbag system. The lander would have deployed the rover onto the Martian surface and communicated directly with Earth via the Algonquin Radio Observatory’s 46 m parabolic antenna.

Beaver Rover 🔗

The Beaver Rover was designed to have a maximum range of 1000 meters from the landing site. It would have been battery-powered and equipped with tools and sensors to investigate surface rocks for evidence of photosynthetic life.

History 🔗

The project officially began in 2001, led by Ben Quine of York University. York University has a history of participation in the Canadian Space Program and has designed space research instruments used by NASA, including the meteorological station on the Phoenix Mars lander.

The project involved partnerships with several Canadian universities, including York University, University of Alberta, University of Toronto, University of Waterloo, University of Winnipeg, University of Western Ontario, University of Saskatchewan, University of New Brunswick, McGill University, and Simon Fraser University. Mission control after landing was planned to be headquartered at York University.

The estimated cost was $20 million, potentially less with international collaboration. The Canadian Space Agency was aware of the project but not involved. In 2014, a crowdfunding campaign was launched on Indiegogo and YouTube to raise $1.1 million CAD for flight hardware development, but it only raised $10,012.

Scientific Goals 🔗

The mission had four primary scientific goals:

  1. Search for life on Mars.
  2. Search for water on Mars.
  3. Investigate the Martian electromagnetic radiation environment and atmospheric properties.
  4. Prepare for international Mars sample return and human missions.

Payload of the Beaver Rover 🔗

The Beaver Rover was designed for geological surface exploration and subsurface imaging. Weighing approximately 6 kg, it would have operated independently with a range of about 1 km. It would have carried a visible camera for navigation and surface exploration, a point spectrometer, and a microscope camera for geological surveys. A ground-penetrating radar would have explored the Martian subsurface for water, and an active vibrator and receiver would have conducted an acoustic study of the subsurface. A rock grinding tool was included for immediate subsurface exploration.

MASSur Seismic Sensor 🔗

The MASSur Seismic Sensor, developed by the University of Calgary, would have provided depth profiles of the Martian surface. A seismometer would have tested the rigidity and elasticity of the Martian topsoil and its rock properties. The seismic system would have used a vibrational source and accelerometers on both the lander and the rover. The redundancy of sensors on both platforms ensured that some primary science objectives could be met even without rover deployment.

Ground Penetrating Radar 🔗

The Ground-Penetrating Radar (GPR) would have used a 200 MHz radar to provide fine-scale subsurface imaging to a depth of 20 m in loose aggregate and up to 100 m in permafrost or ice. The design shared systems with the seismic instruments.

TC Corer 🔗

The corer would have been capable of drilling up to 10 mm into surface rocks. It would have been used with the Aurora spectrometer and microscope to examine the near-surface composition and search for biosignatures. The core was a contribution from Hong Kong. The flight model instrument had an estimated mass of 350 g.

Payload of the Northern Light Lander 🔗

Aurora Spectrometer 🔗

The proposed spectrometer would have had a wavelength coverage of 625 nm to 2500 nm and observed the whole sky. It would have measured variations in spectral irradiance to determine aerosol and atmospheric composition, including carbon dioxide concentration. It would also have measured the angular dependency of radiation influx in the atmosphere. The Aurora instrument had a mass of 450 g.

Argus Spectrometer 🔗

Similar in design to the Argus 1000 spectrometer flown on CanX-2, the radiometer would have been the primary equipment of the Northern Light lander, making measurements of spectral rock reflectance. The spectrometer had a mass of 240 g.

Camera Systems 🔗

The camera systems on the lander would have had narrow and wide field survey capabilities. The narrow field survey would have provided a high-resolution, panoramic view of the landing site. Color filters would have performed spectral mapping and mineral identification of the surrounding soil. The camera would also have performed limited atmospheric and astronomical observations. Color images of Earth would have been obtained. The wide field survey would have provided an overall color view of the lander’s surroundings to help rover deployment and route planning.

MASSur Seismic Sensors 🔗

Similar specifications as those on the Beaver Rover.

Environmental Sensors 🔗

Environmental sensors would have monitored conditions at the landing site. Instruments would have measured UV rays, oxidizing substances, air pressure, air temperature, dust impact, wind velocity, and ground vibration. These sensors would have a combined mass of 130 g. Flight models were previously developed for Britain’s Beagle 2 lander.

Tracking 🔗

The entry system would have been tracked and targeted using a combination of Doppler radar and very long baseline interferometry. This data would have been processed by a high-resolution orbital model using high-precision ephemeris to predict spacecraft location and trajectory. Tracking would have commenced at the Algonquin Radio Observatory upon launch. Continuous tracking would have commenced as the package reached the Martian thermosphere to verify mechanism deployment during descent.

Landing Site 🔗

The landing site would have been determined from one of three options by a crowd sourcing campaign. One option was a dry ‘sea’, within 5 km of a basin formation.

item.description:
Making Contact: A Serious Handbook for Locating and Communicating With Extraterrestrials 🔗

Making Contact: A Serious Handbook for Locating and Communicating With Extraterrestrials is a book published in 1998.

Contents 🔗

This section details the book’s subject matter, which encompasses various aspects of close encounters with extraterrestrials. Bill Fawcett, the editor, is quoted stating his belief that the existence of extraterrestrials is “unquestionable.” The book delves into potential signs and symptoms of alien abduction, including burns, tinnitus, a metallic taste, and double vision. Specific locations, such as Area 51 and Mexico City, are identified as places where encounters are more likely to occur.

Reception 🔗

This section is currently empty, indicating a lack of documented critical or public response to the book.

  1. A Chicago Sun-Times article by Dolores and Roger Flaherty from July 26, 1998, discussing the book.
  2. A Daily Herald article by Hilary Shenfeld from September 22, 1997, which provides details about the book’s content and the author’s perspective.

item.title: Alien (sculpture)
item.description:
Alien (sculpture) 🔗

This entry focuses on the 2012 sculpture Alien by British artist David Breuer-Weil. It details the sculpture’s physical characteristics, its installation history, the artist’s inspiration, and its reception.

Description 🔗

The sculpture Alien is a large-scale artwork created in 2012 by David Breuer-Weil. It depicts a giant humanoid figure, five times the size of a person, seemingly embedded head-first into the ground. The sculpture is made of glass reinforced plastic with a bronze powder coat. Key features include enlarged fingerprints and graffiti by the artist, and the name “Ernst” written on its surface. Its dimensions are 600 cm (240 in).

Installation History 🔗

Alien was initially installed in Grosvenor Gardens in the City of Westminster in April 2013 as part of the City of Sculpture initiative. It remained there until April 13, 2015, after an extension to its initial six-month display period was approved. On September 7, 2015, the sculpture was moved to Mottisfont, a National Trust property in Hampshire, England, where it is currently located. The coordinates for its location at Mottisfont are provided.

Inspiration and Meaning 🔗

David Breuer-Weil drew inspiration for Alien from several sources. A significant influence was his grandfather, Ernst, who fled to England from Austria after the Nazi takeover in 1938 but was subsequently labeled an “enemy alien.” The name “Ernst” on the sculpture acknowledges this connection. The sculpture also incorporates a portrait of the fictional Kaiser of Nerac, a character from Breuer-Weil’s imaginary world.

Breuer-Weil intended Alien to evoke the surprise and shock of an alien landing. He also suggests that the sculpture explores themes of belonging and the human condition, with the “alien” representing something sudden and unexpected, like a new work of art. He connects the concept of being an alien to the Jewish experience, suggesting a sense of both belonging and being an outsider.

Reception 🔗

Alien was well-received by both the public and critics. It was named one of Time Out’s “Top 10 Public Sculptures” in July 2013.

item.title: Crop Circles
item.description:
Crop Circles 🔗

Crop circles are patterns created by flattening a crop. This is the primary meaning of the term.

Crop Circles (Other Uses) 🔗

This section lists other uses of the term “Crop Circles,” primarily referring to musical works. Dean Brody has an album titled Crop Circles released in 2013. Jon Bellion has a song called “Crop Circles” released in 2019. Tash Sultana has a song called “Crop Circles” from the 2021 album Terra Firma.

Other Uses 🔗

This section lists a documentary film titled Crop Circles: Quest for Truth directed by William Gazecki in 2002.

See Also 🔗

This section directs the reader to another album with a similar title: Crop Circle by Nines, released in 2018.

This page serves as a disambiguation page, listing articles associated with the title “Crop Circles.” It instructs users who arrived via an internal link to correct the link to point to the intended article.
